DOC.HEAD: Cat Survives Ten Days Locked In Trunk
DOC.TEXT: Curiosity didn't kill a cat trapped in the trunk of a Mercedes-Benz for 10 days, but it nearly drove him to catatonia. Kitty, the 11-year-old orange cat, apparently jumped into the Mercedes when it was being serviced Jan. 17 at his owner's shop, Richie's Auto Radio. The proprietor, Richard P. D'Auteuil, placed ads in the newspaper, made daily calls to the Animal Rescue League and tried to contact customers who visited his store on that day. ``The only customer I didn't contact was the only one I didn't have a slip for,'' the owner of the Mercedes, D'Auteuil said. The Mercedes was brought back in 10 days later, and a worker opened the trunk when he heard mewing inside, D'Auteuil said. Out jumped the desperate Kitty, thin and thirsty but basically healthy. Kitty's strong constitution, and the relative warmth of the car, stored in a garage, probably saved his life, said Lawrence A. Shinnamon, a veterinarian at Anchor Animal Hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Wisconsin vs. Windy City in Duel Over Image
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Forget regional pride. Scrap neighborly cooperation. Wisconsin and Illinois have each accused the other of besmirching its reputation, and the weapon of choice has been selected: Saber-edged wit. The two Midwestern neighbors _ which for years have squabbled over pollution, traffic, tourists, sports teams and bragging rights for best chili _ are at it again, slashing at one another all over the media dueling ground. Chicago claims the Badger State made the first thrust when an advertising campaign distributed postcards that used the chalkline of a homicide victim to portray Chicago and a chalked hopscotch game to portray the ``tranquility'' of northeastern Wisconsin. The Windy City parried with one of its biggest defenders, humorist Mike Royko, Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist for the Chicago Tribune. Royko called the advertising campaign by the Fox Valley Chamber of Commerce a cheap shot that made light of his city's serious crime problem. He wrote a column that dismissed Wisconsin residents as ``cheeseheads ... content to chomp on bratwurst.'' Royko wrote that the postcard was not ``sufficient provocation for a verbal feud,'' then proceeded to paint a picture of Wisconsin residents as deer-hunting, red flannel-wearing, cow-kissing ``farm folk.'' ``From its farms to its cities, you won't find kinder, simpler folk anywhere, except in custodial care,'' he continued. Given all the barbs that have been traded between the two states over the years, Royko said he was surprised by the angry reponse from Wisconsin residents. ``They were frothing at the lips _ which is kind of goofy,'' Royko said in an interview this week. ``They struck the first blow. ``I responded to a very tasteless card,'' he said. ``There are many people in Chicago who have been victims of crimes. Homicide is not a laughing matter.'' Radio stations and marketing agencies have done their best to continue the war of words. ``The attitude is that Chicagoans think that Milwaukeeans are just a bunch of hee-haw heads,'' said Mark A. Tuschel, who added fuel to the furor with a radio spot produced by his Chicago-based company, CW Media. The commercial for Little Switzerland Ski Hill, a resort near Milwaukee, was aired on Chicago radio stations. In it, an announcer tells some people the resort is near Milwaukee, and the group responds with a raspberry. The announcer then says, ``You don't have to stay there, you just drive through,'' eliciting a relieved cheer from the group. Tuschel revised the commerical after receiving complaints from Wisconsinites, but he said the attitudes toward Milwaukee were not of his making. ``If you stand on television with a cardboard wedge of cheese on your head, you almost have it coming,'' he said, referring to the hats frequently worn by fans at sports events in Green Bay and Milwaukee. Bill Welch, president of the Fox Valley Chamber of Commerce, conceded his office offended some people with its postcard campaign, which was designed to attract people to Fond du Lac, Appleton and Oshkosh. The homicide-hopscotch postcard compared crime rates between the two areas and cited FBI statistics indicating Fox Valley is among the 10 safest regions in the United States. Welch said he enjoyed Royko's rebuttal. ``I thought it was kind of cute, and frankly, we appreciated it. To our mind, anything that draws attention to the comparisons works to our benefit.'' Mary Ladish, marketing director of the Greater Milwaukee Committee, said Royko's column and the subsequent responses were both part of the ``cultural divide'' enjoyed by humorists in Wisconsin and Illinois. Ladish said her committee, which studies the development of the Milwaukee metropolitan area, isn't concerned with the ``cheesehead'' jokes. ``Rather than just talking about image, we are working at changing Milwaukee's image through very tangible means,'' she said, citing efforts to market Milwaukee and its festivals, businesses and restaurants nationwide. Royko said he thought his column was ``pretty funny'' and he extended his sympathy to people ``afflicted with the lack of a sense of humor.'' ``They're pretty thin-skinned,'' he said. ``You read the column and it's obvious I wrote it with my tongue partly in my cheek.'' Wisconsinites take note _ Royko didn't say his tongue was entirely in his cheek.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Declines Another Hearing In Topeka Desegregation Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court has denied the Topeka school board's request to rehear its 36-year-old desegregation case, possibly ending more than a decade of litigation, the plaintiffs' attorney said. Richard Jones, attorney for parents who reopened the Brown vs. Topeka Board of Education case, said he received a copy of the order from the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver on Wednesday. The decision sided with the plaintiffs. ``It's good to have it come down,'' he said. ``I think I'm finally seeing the end of the tunnel and there's not a train coming our way.'' Joe Zima, attorney for the school board, said the board received the decision Thursday, but he declined immediate comment. The 1954 landmark case, in which the U.S. Supreme Court said the doctrine of ``separate but equal'' had no place in public education, was reopened in 1979. A group of parents charged that the Topeka district had not accomplished the racial desegregation ordered more than two decades earlier. In 1987, U. S. District Judge Richard Rogers of Topeka ruled that the district had been effectively desegregated. The parents appealed, and last year a three-member panel of the 10th Circuit overturned Rogers' ruling, 2-1. The school board asked for a rehearing, and suggested that the entire appeals court hear the case. Both the petition and suggestion were denied by the court on Monday. Zima said the school board's alternatives are to accept the denial or ask the U.S. Supreme Court to hear the case. Jones said he doesn't expect the board to ask the U.S. Supreme Court to hear the case, and that he thought the court would refuse to hear it if asked. ``What we have had in these last 10 years is kind of a garden variety desegregation case,'' Jones said. ``We didn't break any new ground or come up with any new theories on the law.'' He said that if Rogers is required to implement a desegregation plan for the district, it must be agreeable to the plaintiffs.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Plan Would Cause Big Changes in West Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Drinking beer, paying rent, buying clothes and furnishing their apartments, U.S. soldiers account for about $2 billion in annual revenues alone in one West German state. Nationwide, the more than 250,000 GIs, their family members and civilian U.S. military employees spend several times that amount each year. For the tens of thousands of West Germans whose livelihoods depend on the presence of the U.S. military, President Bush's troop reduction proposal Wednesday signaled a possible major shift in their lives. While the Yankees aren't going home just yet, the European nation that grew up with U.S. troops is beginning to contemplate an end to a large part of their sometimes controversial presence. The occupation troops-turned-allies are still a daily fact of life, whether it's a fatigue-clad GI riding the S-4 subway home from Frankfurt or the young soldier's wife in Bitburg learning German from her landlord. Cars with the familiar black-and-white, American-size license plates crowd the autobahn highways, while any simple receiver can pick up the military's AFN radio network. ``Mad King Ludwig's'' Neuschwanstein Castle _ faithfully copied in Disneyland _ is one of several meccas for soldiers and their families every year. The U.S. military has also been the target of criticism and even rage, during the anti-missile protests of the 1980s and the low-level training flights that angered civilians. Farmers and villagers complain about tanks on maneuvers tearing up fields and crunching pavement. Deadly collisions occur every year. Saturday night brawls involving GIs are common, especially in large cities such as Frankfurt. But in the smaller towns, whole economies have grown up around the U.S. military bases, meaning those municipalities will have an even harder time in the event of reduction of tens of thousands of troops. ``In Rhineland Palatinate state, the U.S. military installations have a very important economic meaning,'' says state Interior Ministry spokesman Juergen Dietzen. He said 21,000 West Germans work at U.S. bases in the southwestern state, which has nostalgic ties with the United States because of the massive emigrations decades ago. In Rhineland Palatinate alone, the number of soldiers is 67,000, while there are 79,000 family members and 9,000 U.S. civilian workers at the bases, Dietzen said. ``They go beer drinking, wine drinking, they go out to dinner, buy coats, purchase furniture, rent apartments,'' Dietzen said, recounting the impact on the economy. ``They are store customers and order handcrafts.'' Dietzen estimated total expenditures by the soldiers themselves, family members and U.S. support civilians come to more than $2 billion. The U.S. military itself kicks in another $400,000 to the economy in Rhineland Palatinate, he said. Nevertheless, state residents are happy to see any reductions to help the process of disarmament during improving East-West relations, he said. In a country with the largest density of troops and weapons in Western Europe, disarmament is a popular priority. Officials caution that Bush's proposal to bring down the troop superpower strength in Central Europe to 195,000 for each side is just that _ a plan wating to discussed and accepted by the Soviets. Any withdrawal likely would take years. Cmdr. John Woodhouse, U.S. military spokesman at the European Command in Stuttgart, cautions that the numbers have not been itemized completely. Virtually all of the Central European reductions would come from West Germany, which had nearly 255,000 U.S. troops last year, Woodhouse says, because only small units are based in Belgium and the Netherlands. That could lead to the withdrawal of nearly 60,000 U.S. servicemen from West Germany. Woodhouse says the military is starting to look at ``contingency plans'' if the reductions occur. ``But we're not at the point yet where we starting to say `OK, this unit, you're going to be starting to close down next week,''' Woodhouse said. A huge reduction could drastically cut down on the 70,000 West Germans working for the U.S. armed forces. One town already feeling the pinch is Zweibruecken, where the U.S. Air Force Base with 3,500 servicemen recently was targeted for shutdown by 1993 even before Bush's speech. ``The situation is alarming, since we have to find substitute jobs for the 340 West German civilian workers,'' said Thilo Huble, spokesman for the town located in the far southwestern part of the country just six miles from France. Like Dietzen, Huble said small businesses will be hurt. Gitta Lampersbach, a spokesman for the federal labor ministry, said big layoffs of West German civilian workers would be treated like those from private industry, triggering financial and retraining programs. ``In certain areas where the job structure isn't strong, that could be a real burden on the job market,'' she said. Although West Germany is one of the world's richest countries, it is struggling to cope with the influx of hundreds of thousands of East Germans and ethnic Germans from other parts of Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Graves of Azerbaijani Victims Have a Hero's Place in Baku
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: On this city's highest point, the grave of 12-year-old Larisa Mamedova has a hero's place, her brown school uniform, orange scarf and cheap blue schoolbag piled atop a mountain of red carnations. Nearby, a young boy's grave _ still unmarked _ is decorated with a pink plastic bear with blue overalls and a few chocolates. A black-and-white photo of a round-faced, dark-haired boy of no more than 10 is tied with a red ribbon. On Thursday, thousands of mourners trudged for hours past a line of more than 100 graves dug into a terrace in a hilltop park, the resting place for those killed when the army stormed Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan, on Jan. 20 to put down a nationalist uprising. A Moslem mullah recited prayers from a makeshift stand as the crowd passed, some crying or wailing openly and dropping carnations on the graves. The mourners are defiant, reflecting the continuing but increasingly hidden conflict between Azerbaijanis and the Soviet military. The burial place is formally named Kirov Park, after a Soviet hero, but soon will be renamed in honor of those who ``died for justice,'' said journalist Shain Hadjiev. In the pantheon of people's heroes, Azerbaijani policeman Yusif Abilgasanov, 22, is buried next to Boris Yefemich, 44, and not far from a 16-year-old Jewish girl named Vera. ``This is already a sacred place,'' said a 35-year-old musician who identified himself only as Bakhtiar. ``The Azerbaijani people won't forget this and won't forgive anyone.'' Soviet military officials, speaking to the first foreign journalists allowed into Baku since Jan. 20, said the army used force to take control of the city because there was no other way. Armed activists of Azerbaijan's People's Front, a nationalist group, blockaded 8,000 of more than 11,000 soldiers in the area with buses and trucks, they said. ``We couldn't remove the blockades any other way,'' said Soviet army spokesman Lt. Gen. Mikhail P. Kolesnikov. Many of the graves are of young men who were at the barricades. Azerbaijani activists charge the soldiers with indiscriminate shooting when they entered the city. Larisa Mamedova, they said, was killed as she sat on a city bus. Elsewhere in Baku, her father was wounded and died several days later. According to officials, 139 people have died in Azerbaijan since the soldiers moved in. Many more were killed in ethnic attacks against Armenians in Baku Jan. 13-14 and in fighting between Armenians and Azerbaijanis throughout the Caucasus. Crowds come to the burial place daily, but are especially heavy on Thursdays, a traditional time of Moslem mourning that lsts for 40 days after death. The mourners wept especially hard when they passed the graves of the children. Hadjiev and other activists said Soviet tanks entered the city from the airport, shooting at everything in their way. Other tanks crushed a half-dozen cars in a parking lot as they burst from behind a wall of the military arsenal. The soldiers were a week too late to save Armenians who died in the ethnic attacks, say People's Front activists. They blame President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for the bloodshed. Nadzhov Nadzhavov, editor of the banned People's Front newspaper, said Gorbachev gave in to reformist critics by not cracking down on separatists in the Baltic republic of Lithuania, but appeased conservative critics by allowing the military to take Baku. ``Gorbachev's hands are now bloody,'' he said. The Soviet leader, looking tired and defeated in a TV address on Jan. 20, told the nation the soldiers were sent to Baku to stop attacks on Armenians and to control well-armed fighters. ``All our attempts at dialogue (with extremists) ended like this: You don't touch us, we won't touch you,'' said Kolesnikov, a Baku resident. ``All of the windows of my apartment house were broken out. Is this dialogue?'' he asked. Red carnations are stuck in bushes next to the park, located near the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet and down the street from the Soviet military's southern command and the KGB offices. More carnations are strewn at crossroads where Azerbaijanis died. Soldiers stand guard there at night with armored personnel carriers and military trucks to enforce an 11 p.m.-5 a.m. curfew. The park also closes for curfew but lights flood the area all night, Hadjiev said. Soldiers and police don't come near. Bakhtiar, the musician, said as he left the park after his daily visit that Azerbaijan has a bright future, but without Moscow. Asked if he favored full independence for Azerbaijan, he said, ``Naturally.''

DOC.HEAD: Bolshevik Report of Royal Killings Found in Bank Vault
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The coded telegram from Bolshevik revolutionaries reporting the execution of Russian Czar Nicholas II and his family in 1918 has been found in a bank vault among papers left by the original investigator of the crime. The papers, hidden in the vault for nearly 70 years, will be auctioned in London on April 5, Sotheby's said Thursday. The auction house would not disclose the owner's identity or say where the papers were concealed. ``The owner knew that her uncle called them his `dynamite papers' but until bringing them to us, she had no idea of what they were,'' said John Stuart, Sotheby's consultant on Russian art and history. An auction estimate of $500,000 to $840,000 has been put on the papers but Stuart remarked: ``What price can you put on them? There is interest in them everywhere. It isn't clear whether the Soviet government will buy them.'' Stuart said the owner is a descendant of Prince Nikolai Orlov who went into exile in France after the revolution. He said Orlov inherited the papers in 1924 on the death of his fellow-exile Nikolai Sokolov, the investigator. Sokolov was a lawyer working for the anti-Bolshevik White Russian forces. After the killing of the czar's family in the Ural mountain town of Ekaterinburg, the White Russians overran the area and Sokolov went to work. He interrogated everyone he could find about the fate of the last members of the Romanov dynasty and gathered every scrap of paper relating to their last days. The Bolsheviks withdrew so quickly that they failed to take the originals of their telegrams at the local telegraph office. Among them was the crucial one of July 17, 1918, the day after the royal family disappeared. Its coded numbers translate as: ``Tell Sverdlov the entire family suffered the same fate as its head. Officially the family will perish in evacuation.'' The message signed by Alexander Beloborodov, chairman of the Ural Soviet, and addressed to Nikolai Gorbunov, an official, was for Yankel Sverdlov, Lenin's head of state and leader of the Cheka secret police. ``The telegram and the other papers establish beyond doubt in my view that the murder of the whole family was directed from Moscow, but the leaders did not want to admit that at the time and claimed it was done without their orders,'' said Stuart. ``The Bolsheviks were determined to wipe out every Romanov they could find and I am convinced that the theories that any of them escaped from Ekaterinburg are fantasy,'' he said. Sokolov's book about the executions was published in Paris in 1924. It contained reproductions of some of the evidence he collected, including the telegram. The discovered files include a steamship bill for the conveyance of the royal family for part of the journey to Ekaterinburg, accounts of tips to porters and their guards' signatures on pay receipts. There are also photographs of the house of the merchant Nikolai Ipatiev, which the Bolsheviks took over. In the cellar there they executed Czar Nicholas, his wife, Alexandra, their five children and four servants. A handwritten note to a chemist's shop in Ekaterinburg demands delivery of 400 pounds of sulfuric acid costing 196 rubles, 50 kopeks, equivalent to about $95 before the revolution. Sokolov believed the acid and a large quantity of gasoline were used to destroy the bodies. ``All the people involved in killing the royal family were themselves killed in fighting, murders or purges,'' Stuart said. ``Sverdlov was assassinated in 1919 and Ekaterinburg was renamed Sverdlovsk in his memory.''

DOC.HEAD: Left and Right Bicker Over Tree-Planting Ceremony
DOC.TEXT: A tree-planting ceremony for Arbor Day is at the root of the latest squabble between the left and right branches of Israeli politics. Israeli lawmakers usually mark the day, which this year falls on Feb. 7, by planting trees in a forest near Parliament. But since that forest is fully planted, Parliament Speaker Dov Shilansky of the right-wing Likud bloc chose a site near the Jewish settlement of Maale Adumim in the occupied West Bank. Leftist lawmakers announced a boycott of the ceremony, since it would be on land occupied in the 1967 Middle East War. They want to trade at least some of that territory for peace with the Arabs. Shilansky has suggested a compromise site on Mount Scopus in east Jerusalem, the Arab section of the city annexed by Israel after the 1967 war. But the leftists left everybody hanging. They say they may hold a separate ceremony in pre-1967 Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Time Doesn't Weigh Heavy for Nation's Timekeeper
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Gernot Winkler is a government bureaucrat with plenty of time on his hands. Winkler's offices at the U.S. Naval Observatory are crowded with sundials, hourglasses, bejeweled antique watches, pendulum clocks, quartz clocks and atomic clocks so incredibly accurate that Winkler has no excuse for being late to work. ``Our business is time,'' says Winkler, 67, an Austrian-born astronomer and theoretical physicist who has been America's official timekeeper for the past 24 years. A well-worn scythe, the familiar emblem of Father Time, is propped up near his desk. Winkler's master timepiece is the atomic clock, which actually consists of 24 box-like metal instruments housed in eight climate-controlled vaults scattered around the observatory's tree-shaded grounds on a northwest Washington hillside. Each of the faceless clocks contains cesium atoms which, when heated to a low boil, emit faint beams of light from electromagnetic radiation at an unchanging frequency of 9,192,631,770 cycles per second. Every hour, computers automatically compare readings from all the clocks to produce a uniform time that doesn't vary more than a nanosecond _ one-billionth of a second _ from day to day. Some of the atomic clocks are accurate to one-tenth of a nanosecond. To set all his clocks, Winkler relies on a network of radio astronomers from Hawaii to Bologna, Italy. They determine the exact position of Earth as it rotates on its axis by taking a simultaneous fix on some distant star sending signals from the depths in space, millions of light-years away. The precision of the atomic clock seems unbelievable in a world weary of wristwatches that suddenly stop and alarm clocks that don't ring. It is so accurate, says Winkler, that it's not the clock but the rest of the world that goes wrong. Every year or two, Winkler adds a ``leap second'' to the atomic clock's time to compensate for a very slow decrease in the Earth's rotation, which is thrown slightly out of kilter by winds, ocean currents, earthquakes and even melting snow. Today's master clock is 10 million times more accurate than the quaint old pendulum clocks that tick-tocked the official time until as recently as 1950, when the observatory switched to quartz clocks and then _ eight years later _ to cesium atomic beam clocks. Nonetheless, time doesn't weigh heavy for Winkler the way it does for the Maytag repairman. No matter how flawlessly his atomic clocks run, he says, he must keep trying to shave off another millisecond here or there to meet the increasingly sophisticated demands of electronic navigation and communications systems, from deep-running nuclear submarines to satellites beaming weather advisories to airports. ``We don't wait for something to happen,'' he said. ``We need to be in the forefront of technological capabilities. If we didn't, we'd be as obsolete as the pendulum clock in three to five years.'' Already, he says a possible successor to the atomic clock is a new device that employs ions or electrically charged atoms of mercury that are trapped in an electromagnetic ``bottle'' and produce a fluorescent glow with a much higher frequency than cesium beams. When he's not busy perfecting his clocks and keeping an eye on the observatory's time-of-day announcements by telephone (dial 1-900-410-TIME), Winkler says he answers an occasional piece of ``nut mail'' about the time. Like the guy who asked, ``What actually happens to the time you waste?'' Or the request for an exact definition of a moment. A woman's letter _ one of Winkler's favorites _ inquired what God did with his time before he created the world. ``I wrote back that he invented hell for people who ask stupid questions,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says AIDS Infections Declining, Heterosexuals Have Little Risk
DOC.TEXT: A new report says the number of Americans becoming infected annually with the virus that causes AIDS is declining, although the number of new AIDS cases will continue rising until 1995. The report's author, Peter Plumley, a consulting actuary in Chicago, also says the chances that a heterosexual not using drugs intravenously will become infected are remote and that AIDS prevention efforts focus too much on this group. Plumley writes in the January-February issue of Contingencies magazine that the number of new annual infections with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, peaked in 1986 and is going down. However, he says the total number of HIV-infected Americans will continue to rise until 1991, when 1.4 million will be infected. Also, the number of new AIDS cases will continue to rise until 1995 and then begin to decline, and the number of AIDS deaths will peak at around 110,000 in 1997, Plumley's projections show. Years can elapse between the time of infection with HIV and the onset of AIDS. No one is known to have recovered from AIDS. He predicted that by the year 2000 there will have been a total of 1.3 million AIDS cases and about 1.1 million AIDS deaths. His figures do not include HIV infections and AIDS cases among blood transfusion recipients, hemophiliacs and children, which account for about 5 percent of the total infections. As of Dec. 31, 1989, AIDS had been diagnosed in 117,781 Americans. Sixty percent, or 70,313, had died since June 1, 1981, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control. The CDC, which estimates that about 1 million people in the United States are HIV-infected now, is revising its projections for future spread of the disease. A draft report released earlier this month predicted that projections for the numbers of cases will be about 15 percent lower than previous CDC estimates. CDC spokeswoman Gayle Lloyd said until the agency issues new projections, ``no one here is interested in talking about anyone else's projections.'' Plumley said, ``One of the most disturbing aspects of the AIDS epidemic is the number of people who have become concerned unnecessarily about the epidemic.'' The virus is spread mainly through contact with bodily fluids, including sexual intercourse, particularly anal sex, and sharing of needles. Its chief victims have been homosexual males and intravenous drug users. A homosexual male's risk of contracting AIDS is about 1 in 500, according to Plumley. But the risk for a heterosexual engaging in vaginal sex is less than one in a million, providing their sex partners are not from a high-risk group. Prevention efforts within the homosexual, bisexual and intravenous drug user communities should continue, but ``valid reasons exist to attempt to temper warnings issued to people whose risks are as remote as one in a million or less. ``Hyperbole could divert the focus from the truly serious areas of risk, damage credibility of the prevention efforts and create paranoia among those who don't understand and jeopardize their chances of forming the kinds of relationships necessary to health and well-being,'' he wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Rep. Savage Made `Improper Advances,' Ethics Committee Says
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Gus Savage made ``improper advances'' to a Peace Corps volunteer during a trip to Zaire last March, violating a House rule on members' conduct, according to a House ethics committee report. However, the committee took no action to punish the Chicago Democrat, citing a voluntary letter of apology he wrote to the woman, according to the unreleased report obtained Thursday by The Associated Press. ``Had the congressman not taken the initiative to send such a letter, the committee would have directed that he do so,'' the report said. The report also noted the panel has not previously considered a member's conduct during an official visit to a foreign country. The panel, formally the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct, concluded ``that Rep. Savage's sexual advances ... were contrary'' to a rule requiring members' conduct to ``reflect creditably'' on the House. Savage, who is black, contended in a House speech to a nearly empty chamber Thursday that the committee was declining to pursue the case _ adding he received ``not even a slap on the wrist.'' He did not mention the letter of apology. According to an interview the unnamed woman gave the committee last September, Savage took the volunteer on a tour of night spots in Kinshasa, Zaire, placed his hand on her leg and thigh and tried to persuade her to have sex with him. ``She recalled that he stated, as he was pulling her over to him, that one should be prepared to give their all to the movement and, if one is not prepared to do so, they are not really members of the Black movement but are, rather, traitors to it,'' the report said. Savage described the allegations as a ``racist attack'' by white government officials and the white-owned news media and called the three House Democrats who filed a complaint against him ``self-appointed guardians of personal morality.'' The three, Reps. Patricia Schroeder of Colorado, Matthew McHugh of New York and Barney Frank of Massachusetts, had no comment. While the ethics panel did not recommend any punishment and will not pursue the case to the trial stage, the report said, ``The committee concluded Rep. Savage subjected a Peace Corps volunteer to improper advances'' during his visit to Kinshasa, Zaire, last March 19. The report added Savage ``has acknowledged that he may have acted inappropriately as evidenced by his letter'' to the woman. In an interview with the committee before the letter was written, however, the report said Savage denied her allegations. The committee said it was placing other House members ``on notice'' that similar conduct would be viewed ``with the clear possibility that additional action might be pursued.'' Savage's letter to the woman said in part, ``While in Zaire earlier this year, if you felt personally offended by any words or actions of mine, I apologize, because I never intended to offend and was not aware that you felt offended at that time.'' The woman was included in a party of U.S. officials that met with Savage because she was from his district, the report said. According to the report, the volunteer said Savage took her on a tour of night spots in a chauffeur-driven car with no other passengers. ``The ... volunteer stated that soon after the car began to move, Rep. Savage grabbed her around the shoulders and tried to pull her up against him,'' the committee report said. The volunteer pushed him away, the report said, and she ``indicated that the congressman pulled her up against him, grabbed her face, and forced her to kiss him. She stated that she was very frightened, was pushing Rep. Savage away, but that he was not listening and did not stop.'' After visiting a night spot, according to the report, Savage directed her to one of the cars and ``as soon as they were seated ... the congressman renewed his earlier behavior ...'' ``This time, however, he asked her to have sex with him and tried to persuade her to do so.'' The woman told the committee she resisted and began talking about her work in a shelter and in the black community. Savage, according to the account, said, ``You should know that there are rewards to people who give their all to the movement, give everything to the movement.'' While in a second night club, the woman told the committee, Savage ``placed his hand on her leg and thigh, and told her she was beautiful and he wished her to have sex with him. She was very upset and not responsive.'' She said the night ended at a hotel, where Savage made what the woman described as a ``last-ditch pitch'' and asked her to accompany him on the rest of his trip. ``She rejected his suggestion, saying that she wished to spend no more time with him and that she did not want ever to see or hear from him again,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Say Bush Fails to Back up Education Proposals With Money
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Bush arrives Raleigh, N.C., 9:20 a.m. EST; story will be led
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's claims to be charting a program of ``excellence in education'' are under swift and heavy attack as being unrealistic with only a 2 percent education budget increase to back them up. Bush was heading to universities in North Carolina and Tennessee today to promote the national education goals he announced in his State of the Union address Wednesday night. At North Carolina State University the president was visiting a semiconductor lab and holding a roundtable discussion on competitiveness. Later his itinerary was taking him to the University of Tennessee. The president came under attack from Democrats and education groups almost as soon as he announced the goals for improvement in students' math and science achievement, literacy and drug-free schools. ``There is a yawning gap between the rhetoric of President Bush's education speeches and the funding levels he offers in his budget,'' said Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers. ``The president's words about making American workers the most productive in the world by the year 2000 are right on the mark,'' said Stephen Blair, president of the National Association of Trade and Technical Schools. However, he said, ``The hard reality is, his ... 1991 budget will deprive thousands of young Americans of their chance for quality postsecondary education, particularly in urgently needed technical fields.'' He said the budget plan would dramatically reduce program funding for postsecondary education. The critics also demand to know where the money would come from to slash the dropout rate and make U.S. children tops in math and science by the year 2000, as Bush seeks. In his 1991 budget proposal on Monday, Bush sought $500 million _ 2 percent _ more for the Education Department. He also requested an extra $500 million for Head Start, which is in the Department of Health and Human Services budget. Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos, on Thursday defended Bush's plan saying, ``It's not a matter of dollars.'' ``We could keep on adding ... another billion and another billion. That is not going to solve the education deficit,'' Cavazos told reporters. The way math and science is taught must be radically changed, he said. Just putting more dollars into the current system ``is not going to make good mathematicians'' of students, said Cavazos. However, he also said the Education Department's proposed $24.6 billion budget for fiscal 1991 ``is the largest education budget that this nation has had,'' with ``a very healthy 6.2 percent increase in discretionary programs.'' But Richard Miller, executive director of the American Association of School Administrators, urged Bush ``to get beyond rhetoric. ... His budget proposal for education is at odds with the goals.'' Cavazos said American students are in last place in performance on math and science, compared with children in other industrialized nations. Bush's education goals follow on the education summit he held with the 50 governors in Charlottesville, Va., where they agreed to come up with such performance goals. The National Governors' Association is to vote on the end product at its winter meeting at the end of this month. Meanwhile, the Bush administration opened a lobbying campaign for its proposals to cut the capital gains tax and boost personal savings, with Chief of Staff John Sununu accusing Democrats of being ``the party of taxes.'' Sununu rebuked Democrats for failing to join Republicans in giving Bush a standing ovation during the State of the Union address Wednesday, when Bush said the federal budget could be balanced ``with no new taxes.'' Democrats bristled at Sununu's attack, and House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., told reporters his party agrees something needs to be done about America's plummeting savings rate, but rejects Bush's tax cut.

DOC.HEAD: 1,000 Gold Coins Declared Fakes
DOC.TEXT: All 1,000 gold coins taken by a Tokyo dealer to a bank for deposit turned out to be counterfeits of coins issued in 1985 to commemorate the 60th year of Emperor Hirohito's reign, police said. The fakes were copies of commemorative 100,000-yen coins, the equivalent of about $694 each, authorities said Thursday. A police official declined to identify the dealer or provide further details. However, Japanese newspapers said each coin weighed about 0.7 ounces, and each had a tiny flaw in the same place on the surface. Fuji Bank official Seiji Takeuchi said Wednesday the bank found that some coins, while almost identical to the real currency, were slightly lighter in color.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Super-rich investor Sid Bass found a creative way to deal with an unwanted mansion next door: buy it, cut it up into pieces and rebuild it somewhere else. Bass and his wife Mercedes plan to move their former neighbors' 6,600-square-foot house to the grounds of the Lena Pope Home, a facility for abused, neglected and emotionally disturbed children. Officials say the donated four-bedroom, French-style house will be used as a residence for eight girls and a married couple called family teachers. The house was the former residence of the Mac Churchill family, who moved after selling the property to the Basses about three months ago. ``Thank goodness the Basses are doing this,'' Churchill said. ``Nobody else could have thought of doing it.'' Bass, whose fortune is estimated in the hundreds of millions of dollars, is in the process of remodeling his own red-brick colonial house.

Janet Jackson, the baby of the musical Jackson clan, says brother Michael is a role model, but sister LaToya is not. ``Michael and I are the closest in the family, between all my brothers and sister,'' Janet tells Rolling Stone magazine in its upcoming issue. ``He said that out of everyone in the family, we're the two that think the most alike.'' Janet, whose ``Rhythm Nation 1814'' has sold almost 3 million copies, said she wants to sell as many records as her multi-platinum brother. ``When `Thriller' came out, I was so envious. I was so happy for him, but it was like, `Why can't that be me?' That's what inspired me,'' she said. She found no inspiration, only puzzlement, in sister LaToya's semi-nude appearance in Playboy magazine. ``It didn't seem like the LaToya that I knew, the LaToya that I know,'' she said. ``She said it was something she needed to do ... It's like, I understand, but why that?''

``Miami Vice'' actor Don Johnson may turn to a bank next time he needs a loan. And a friend of his may be sure his next deal is done in writing. Last year, Johnson's company DJ Racing secured an interest-free $300,000 loan from Johnson's friend, lawyer and real estate investor Martin Ergas. Ergas has sued for failure to repay the loan by November, but Johnson says the money to build a racing boat isn't due to be paid back until 1995. Donald M. Klein, attorney for Johnson and his company, said the lawsuit is ``an effort to embarrass Mr. Johnson into settling. He does not do that as a general principle, and in this case he definitely doesn't do it.'' Neil Berman, Ergas' lawyer, said his client was glad to lend a good friend $300,000 until November on a handshake, but would have been more businesslike if he knew he'd have to wait five years for his money back. ``It was a shock,'' Berman said. ``Their whole deal was predicated on trust among friends.'' The lawsuit wa filed Tuesday in Dade Circuit Court.

C. Everett Koop's actions to warn of the dangers of smoking and press for preventing the spread of AIDS through education earned him this year's Harry S. Truman Award for Public Service. The award is presented annually by the city _ hometown of the former president _ to an American possessing the qualities personified by Truman. Independence Mayor Barbara Potts announced on Thursday the choice of Koop, the former U.S. surgeon general. She said his outspoken style and exemplary service to Americans distinguished him. Koop is now chairman of the National SAFE KIDS Campaign, a board member of AIDS Care Education and Training, and chairman of the National Museum of Health and Medicine Foundation. The award will be presented May 6 at the Truman Library and Museum.

Jane Fonda, a longtime favorite target of conservative politicians, can count a Republican, Barbara Bush, among her admirers. Mrs. Bush praised the actress for her portrayal of a woman who teaches an adult illiterate in Fonda's new movie, ``Stanley & Iris.'' She felt it gives a good ``depiction of the Laubach method'' of teaching reading, says Mrs. Bush's press secretary, Anna Perez. Literacy is Mrs. Bush's favorite cause. She frequently speaks on the topic and promotes pro-literacy groups. Perez said the first lady had the movie sent to the White House several weeks ago for a private viewing with some of her staff. In the movie, Fonda teaches a brilliant inventor, played by Robert De Niro, to read. The MGM-UA film opens around the country this month.

A man who attacked Pakistan-born actor Art Malik and insulted his wife has been sentenced to three months in jail. Malik, known to American audiences for his role as Hari Kumar in the British TV series, ``The Jewel in the Crown,'' was leaving a restaurant with his English-born wife, Gina, and an actress friend March 4 when Grant Maloney shouted insulting remarks at the two women, the prosecutor said. He said Malik, 37, called out that one of the women was his wife, and Maloney replied with an offensive remark about women who would go out with a Pakistani. Maloney, 24, punched Malik in the face and kicked him while shouting that he hated Pakistanis, the court was told. Maloney was sentenced Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Insurance Would be Eliminated Under Bush Budget
DOC.TEXT: As Congress probes deeper into new farm legislation, the Federal Crop Insurance Corp. and its mission to help protect farmers against losses from drought and other natural disasters is drawing a lot of criticism. The Bush administration wants to eliminate the half-century-old FCIC coverage in favor of some kind of permanent disaster program. Farmer acceptance of the insurance program is lukewarm and costly. Moreover, every time there is a serious drought, flood or other threat to crops, Congress comes up with a relief measure, and many say that makes FCIC operations unnecessary. One of the recommendations in the budget proposals President Bush sent to Congress this week was the elimination of federal crop insurance, starting with the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. The Bush proposal would include enough money in the 1991 fiscal year to finish off 1990 insurance operations, some $430 million against outlays of $1.18 billion in 1990, but would put an end to new coverage. According to an Agriculture Department budget analysis, the FCIC ``has not been able to provide adequate risk protection for farmers at a reasonable cost to taxpayers.'' The department added: ``Further, ad hoc disaster legislation was enacted in both 1988 and 1989. The administration will work closely with Congress to fashion a permanent disaster assistance program which can provide an effective safety net for farmers and ranchers.'' In the document submitted by Bush, the Office of Management and Budget included figures showing how the FCIC has operated. The agency was created on Feb. 16, 1938, to provide ``a sound system of crop insurance'' for farmers, the document said. But for the crop years 1948 through 1988, the budget document said, the FCIC paid out indemnities totaling nearly $4.89 billion while collecting premiums of $3.13 billion, making a ``loss ratio'' of 1.56. In other words, farmers collected $1.56 in benefits for each $1 in premium payments during those 40 years. The actuarial figures are based on crop years instead of fiscal years, so the expenditures and benefits don't match exactly. Crop years vary, with wheat, barley and oats beginning on June 1; corn, sorghum and soybeans, Oct. 1; and cotton, peanuts and rice, Aug. 1. As an example of FCIC operations under current law, the White House report showed that for 1991 crop years farmers would pay premiums of about $507.9 million. The premium subsidies would add $169.3 million, making a total premium of $677.3 million. The projections show indemnities paid out for losses could be more than $1 billion in the 1991 crop years, making a loss ratio of 1.5, the same as the level expected in 1990 but below the 1.7 of 1989. Because the federal subsidy is part of the total premium, the loss ratio actually understates the real cost to taxpayers, according to USDA analysts. Although the White House document and the USDA backup analysis make it clear the FCIC should be scrapped entirely, there has been some opposition voiced already on Capitol Hill. Sen. Quentin Burdick, D-N.D., whose state has been hit severely by drought the last couple of years, said the insurance proposal ``is a case of the president throwing out the baby with the bath water.'' Burdick added, ``The present crop insurance program isn't perfect, but we need to provide some sort of federal assistance for farmers struck by weather-related disasters.'' Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., said Bush's proposal failed to include money for a permanent emergency aid program to replace crop insurance. ``Farmers will not engage in this trapeze act with the administration because they recognize that the safety net is made of promises,'' he said. ``They will not be deceived by the sleight of hand.'' Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said the Bush proposal leaves more room for negotiation with Congress than some of the critics have indicated. ``In other words, what we say in this budget is that we need to deal with this issue in whatever way seems most appropriate after we have a full debate on the subject,'' he said. ``You've all heard me say that we need to go to one program or the other. We cannot afford to go to two.'' The conclusion within the administration is that ``the crop insurance program as it presently exists is simply not defensible,'' Yeutter said. ``We are not suggesting that there be neither program in existence,'' he said. ``We are prepared to work with the Congress in finding the proper solution and fashioning it, and then trying to find the money to fund it somewhere, somehow.'' Yeutter is expected to be questioned closely next week when he appears before the Senate Agriculture Committee to present the administration's view on 1990 farm legislation. Although Yeutter has said the administration will not have a formal bill as such, he may opt to present outlines of some of the portions that will be covered. If there is a plan for crop insurance or an alternative disaster program, the session with Senate lawmakers on Feb. 7 might be a good place to unveil it.

DOC.HEAD: Policeman Robs Bank, Outwitted By Bystanders
DOC.TEXT: A policeman who worked in the burglary division held up a bank himself, but was captured when two bystanders chased him down, authorities said. The 27-year-old officer was supposed to be on duty at the time, police said. They said the officer, whom they did not identify by name, robbed the Post Office Bank in suburban Sipoo Wednesday with an accomplice, who was not a policeman. The officer tried to flee alone in an unmarked police car, but two bystanders hopped into their own car and chased him. They caught up with him several miles away and blocked his vehicle, the authorities said. The policeman fired three shots at his pursuers with his revolver, but no one was hurt. He did not resist arrest after he was cornered. The accomplice, who was left behind at the bank, was arrested there soon after the robbery, authorities said. Police declined to say how much money was stolen but said it was all recovered.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Crunch Will Jam Voice of America Broadcasts
DOC.TEXT: What Soviet jamming failed to do, U.S. budget cuts are managing. As of April 1, the Voice of America is eliminating six of its 43 language services. The move, which will affect devotees of American radio from Uzbekistan to Malawi, will cost 57 people their jobs. Eliminating the Turkish, Greek, Lao, Uzbek, Slovenian and Swahili broadcasts is expected to save the government's radio network $2.9 million. ``This is the toughest and saddest day of my professional life,'' VOA Director Richard W. Carlson told hundreds of broadcasters, editors and engineers Thursday. After announcing the cuts, Carlson read the names of each of the employees who will lose their jobs. Many of them have worked for VOA for over 20 years. Vilified for years as a tool of U.S. propaganda, jammed by Soviet frequencies throughout the world, the Voice of America has been reaching the far corners of the world with news and entertainment programs for 42 years. But for the past four years, VOA has been grappling with an eroding budget. Inflation and real cuts have forced the station to fire more than 200 people, shut down five bureaus in the United States and abroad, and eliminate hundreds of radio hours. This time, VOA and its parent, the U.S. Information Agency, decided on ``amputation'' of whole language services rather than ``dismemberment'' by across the board cuts. This way, Carlson said, VOA will have 37 healthy services and not 43 ``crippled'' ones. Debate about VOA's budget needs is scheduled in Congress later this month, as critics are questioning whether the new order in Eastern Europe have made VOA redundant. But Carlson said VOA also broadcasts to China, Cambodia, Africa, and other areas of strife. VOA also argues its mission in Europe is more important than ever in helping the formerly one-party nations learn about democracy. ``The people in this room helped shape the revolution in Europe,'' Carlson told the employees. ``This will cripple our efforts at a time of unprecedented change and opportunity.'' The selection of the services to be eliminated was made according to priorities that take into account the political importance of the targeted countries and the availability of other foreign media there. Elimination of the Slovenian service comes during unprecedented ferment in the Yugoslav republic by residents eager to reform the communist system. But most Slovenians speak Serbo-Croatian and VOA still has a service in that language, Carlson said. Slovenians also have access to the British Broadcasting Corporation's World Service. Uzbeks in the Soviet Union and in Afghanistan and China can listen to the BBC's Uzbek service. The BBC also has Turkish and Greek programs. Impoverished communist Laos is the only country that will no longer hear foreign broadcasts once the VOA's Lao service is eliminated. VOA's operating budget for 1990 is about $170 million, and the budget for next year is expected to be $174 million. Carlson said this includes a 3.5 percent wage increase and still leaves VOA $1.5 million short. The problems were compounded this week when the administration's 1991 budget proposal called for the addition of a Tibetan language service. VOA officials estimate it will cost $1.5 million to air two hours a week of Tibetan programs. ``If we don't get budget relief, I'm afraid we're looking at more cuts,'' Carlson said in an interview.

DOC.HEAD: W. Va. County Health Officials Issue Call for Help
DOC.TEXT: Psst, comrade! Spare a few rubles for a bankrupt American health clinic? Health officials in Summer County are issuing a worldwide SOS, asking Soviet, Japanese, British and French officials through a letter campaign to help eliminate a $13,712 deficit. ``We don't find it unpalatable to ask for aid. We're desperate,'' said Steve Trail, sanitarian for the Summers County Health Department, which is also seeking help from the Geneva-based World Health Organization. Trail said Wednesday that state budget cuts have left the rural three-person department unable to function properly. The health department, one of 21 in West Virginia bankrupted by declining tax revenues, was joined the others in appealing to state officials for money to stay open. ``If we have sinned, tell us we'll rectify it. If not, send us money,'' Trail said. He said the department also will appeal to 15 corporate foundations, The health department last week stopped offering free pap smears, breast exams and blood pressure checks, despite the county's high cancer, diabetes and heart disease rates, he said. State Bureau of Public Health spokeswoman Nancy Tolliver said the state isn't turning a deaf ear. ``The state is willing to work with them. We will not let their doors be closed,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Governor, Sioux Leaders Start Year of Reconciliation
LaserPhoto ABD1
DOC.TEXT: Gov. George Mickelson, recognizing the historical hurt suffered by Indians, smoked a peace pipe with tribal leaders and proclaimed a year of reconciliation in 1990, a century after the Wounded Knee massacre. The governor and representatives of eight Sioux tribes drew deeply and passed the pipe Thursday as they sat in a circle around a buffalo skull and other items in the center of the state Capitol rotunda. The members of the South Dakota Legislature and hundreds of other spectators applauded as Mickelson and the tribal leaders completed the ceremony. They then signed a proclamation designating 1990 as a time for healing wounds that have festered between Indians and non-Indians for a century. During the state's centennial celebration last year, Indians refused to take part, claiming they had nothing to celebrate. They have been at odds with state government over issues such as hunting and fishing rights, law enforcement on reservation highways and contracts for state services. The governor decided it was time to bury the tomahawk. Mickelson said he gathered the state lawmakers and the Indian leaders together to ``make this truly a year of reconciliation that marks a new beginning.'' ``I believe it places a responsibility on all of us throughout this year to make a personal commitment,'' the governor said. Indians are going through especially tough times in the state. On South Dakota's nine reservations, unemployment approaches 80 percent, and alcoholism, drugs and health care are severe problems. Four reservation counties rank among the nation's very poorest in terms of per capita income. Tim Giago, publisher of the weekly Lakota Times, had challenged Mickelson to proclaim 1990 as a year to help ease racial discord between Indian and white people in South Dakota. Mickelson thanked the Indian publisher for issuing the challenge. In the proclamation, Mickelson said that as South Dakota begins its second century of statehood, people must also remember that the creation of the state was a sad time for Indians. In December 1890, a little more than a year after South Dakota became a state, Sioux leader Sitting Bull was killed and nearly 300 Sioux men, women and children were killed by U.S. government troops in the Wounded Knee massacre. ``Strife between the cultures in South Dakota has, for 100 years, been of grave concern and continues to be of grave concern,'' the governor said in the proclamation. The 100th anniversary of the tragic events offers an opportunity for Indians and non-Indians to put aside their fears and mistrust, build friendships, cooperate, learn about each other's culture and develop a respect and understanding that will grow in the next century, Mickelson said. More than 6 percent of the state's population _ or about 45,000 people _ are Indians, according to the 1980 U.S. Census. Mickelson said he realizes state government and the tribal governments won't settle all their disputes in the next year, but many of the problems might be resolved. A council of Indians and non-Indians should put together a broad plan by March 1 for celebrating the year of reconciliation, the governor said, and each South Dakotan should think about ways to bridge the cultural gap between Indians and non-Indians in the long run. The proclamation was signed by the governor and representatives of the Flandreau-Santee Sioux, Oglala Sioux, Rosebud Sioux, Yankton Sioux, Standing Rock Sioux, Cheyenne River, the Lower Brule Tribe and the Sisseton-Wahpeton Sioux Tribe. A Crow Creek Sioux representative didn't show up for the ceremony, but officials said a tribal representative may sign it later. The ceremony opened when two Sioux men sang the ``Lakota Flag Song'' in a high-pitched, haunting, wavering harmony, and Sioux military veterans carried in the U.S. flag, a Sioux eagle staff adorned with feathers, and other flags. It ended with the Sioux men singing the ``Peace Song.''

DOC.HEAD: Bill to Slash Civil Damages Under Racketeering Bill Clears Panel
DOC.TEXT: Maximum civil fraud damages awarded under the nation's major anti-racketeering law would be cut under a bill approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee and now ready for floor action. The bill won 11-2 approval on Thursday with sponsors complaining that attorneys have used the law _ designed as a tool against organized crime _ in ordinary fraud cases, thus thwarting the will of Congress. ``It didn't intend for federal judges to be using treble damages in divorce decree cases and landlord-tenant cases,'' said Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., the chief sponsor. The committee acted despite complaints from consumer groups that the bill would weaken a tool needed to deter unscrupulous businessmen from robbing the public through white-collar fraud schemes. Fraud victims currently can sue for triple damages under the 1970 Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO). Investors who lost thousands of dollars by purchasing bonds through the now-defunct Lincoln Savings and Loan of Irvine, Calif., have filed a RICO suit against an array of civil defendants, including the accountants who gave the institution a clean bill of financial health. DeConcini's bill would enable consumers to seek punitive damages up to twice actual damages plus attorneys' fees. Attempting to collect, however, would mean facing a second court action following a trial. The bill would require those seeking such damages to show ``clear and convincing evidence'' of fraud rather than the ``preponderance of the evidence'' often used in civil cases. They also would have to prove that ``the defendant's actions were consciously malicious or so egregious and deliberate that malice may be implied.'' Consumers would be limited to actual damages without attorneys' fees in cases involving securities or commodity futures. The limit would not, however, apply to insider trading violations. Proponents say a landslide of RICO suits in recent years is enriching attorneys and thwarting the will of Congress. ``Broad language that may be appropriate against the Mafia can be abused when used in a garden-variety fraud case,'' Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., told the Judiciary Committee. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, told the panel the ``bill is wanting'' and that he would oppose the measure on the floor. The original bill would have been retroactive and thus would have wiped out pending lawsuits such as the one in the Lincoln S&L case. DeConcini dropped that feature as he pushed for wider support, but there have been hints that it might be restored on the floor. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., backed the bill but told the committee he would oppose it on the floor if the retroactive feature were restored. DeConcini said he has been ``subjected to attacks that I am doing this for reasons of a savings and loan in Arizona. There is no basis in that.'' He is one of five senators under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee concerning their contacts with federal regulators in the $2 billion Lincoln Savings collapse. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, a co-sponsor of the bill, deplored ``reprehensible'' attacks on DeConcini in the press and by members of both political parties. Biden said DeConcini had been in favor of such a measure long before the Lincoln case surfaced. Outside the committee room, William Lerach, an attorney for the suing Lincoln bondholders, said the committee's action could be a setback for those already involved in court actions under RICO.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Press For More Cuts in U.S. Forces in Europe
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Democrats are pressing the Bush administration to push for deeper cuts in U.S. and Soviet forces in Europe beyond the president's proposal to reduce significantly the superpower's combat troops. Several members of the Senate Armed Services Committee said the United States should not stand pat once a conventional arms control pact is reached and adopt Bush's level of 225,000 troops for each side as the residual total. ``It won't take long for the allies to grab all the reductions and we're going to be sitting over there with a U.S. Army and virtually no allies and a questionable threat,'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the committee, told Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Thursday. ``Now that would be a curious position,'' Nunn said. Hours after Bush's surprise announcement in his State of the Union speech Wednesday night, Cheney told the committee the Soviet Union is likely to withdraw all its troops from Europe by the middle of the decade. Cheney estimated the 225,000 U.S. troop level in Europe could be achieved ``within a year or two certainly'' after an agreement is ratified. But he said the troops would be sent elsewhere and not removed from military service. However, the defense secretary cautioned against a unilateral pullout, saying it is important to maintain the NATO alliance and ensure a peaceful withdrawal. ``The Soviet Union remains the only nation on Earth capable of destroying the United States,'' Cheney said, adding that even if all Soviet troops leave Eastern Europe, Moscow would retain its geographic advantage in the event of a European crisis. He said it was important not to drop below a certain troop level in Europe. Sen. John Warner of Virginia, the ranking Republican on the committee, sought and received an assurance from Cheney that the administration would not consider going beyond Bush's latest troop-cut proposal in the foreseeable future. ``This is the worst possible time to contemplate changes in strategy,'' Warner said. But Sen. Alan Dixon, D-Ill., pressed Cheney about why the administration would wait for an arms control pact before reducing troops in light of moves by allies to cut their forces and pressures in the Eastern bloc for the Soviets to leave. ``They're going to get out of Eastern Europe whether they like it or not without any agreement with the United States. They're going to kick them out,'' Dixon said. ``And we're waiting here to do things until we have the agreement. ``I'm not saying strip until we're naked. I'm saying do sensible things now _ here _ in our country _ even without agreements,'' he said. Cheney said the administration recognizes the need to reduce U.S. forces overseas, and has in fact begun to cut back with plans to end U.S. operations at several foreign bases. ``We are now on the verge of winning one of the greatest victories in the history of the world without a shot ever being fired,'' the defense secretary said. Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, also used their appearance before the panel to defend the administration's $292.1 billion military budget for fiscal 1991. The spending plan would increase spending for the B-2 stealth bomber, the Strategic Defense Initiative and two land-based, nuclear missiles, but cancels some 20 small weapons systems. ``The belief that I have is that it is out of balance,'' Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., said, referring to the terminations of conventional programs and the increase for nuclear weapons. The budget, said Levin, ``only partially responds'' to the lessening Soviet threat. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., wondered why it was necessary to spend money for so many strategic weapons ``at this madcap pace.'' Cheney said the decision to cancel the weapons programs was based on the high number of existing weapons and the savings from shutting down production lines. Modernization, however, must not be abandoned because the Soviets continue to upgrade their class of high-tech weapons. Sen. Trent Lott, R-Miss., said the defense secretary may have gone too far in light of the likely cuts the Congress may make in the budget. ``You might be getting too caught up in this experience,'' Lott said.

DOC.HEAD: Quiet in the Balcony! Conductors Going Batty With Audience Noise
DOC.TEXT: It's a conductor's nightmare: the orchestra is in the middle of a moving passage when suddenly, from high in the balcony, a member of the audience is convulsed by a hacking cough. It happens all too often, according to conductors at 21 orchestras surveyed about noisy disturbances during their performances. Nineteen of the 23 conductors who answered the survey said they have been distracted by audience noises while conducting. Coughers are the worst, they said. ``A lot of times these people get these hacking coughs and just let them fly, and that's when it gets annoying,'' said George Hanson, resident conductor at the Atlanta Symphony. Jesus Lopez-Cobos, musical director of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, said he has seen musicians struggling to stifle laughter during a particularly obnoxious bout of coughing. ``When I feel that it is an evening when people are coughing too much, I try in between the movements to leave a little more time so that the people have the time to cough or whatever,'' Lopez-Cobos said. The coughing is most prevalent during the current cold and flu season, Hanson said, but conductors also sniff over audience noises. Talking and yammering youngsters were problems No. 2 and 3 on the most distracting sounds list. Kenneth Jean, associate conductor of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, said Thursday that many audience noises are signals that people are getting fidgety. And, he said, that's television's mark. ``We're used to every 14 minutes having a commercial break,'' said Jean, also music director of the Florida Symphony Orchestra. Jean said that in looking through old Chicago Symphony Orchestra program books from the 1940s, he found programs up to three hours long, ``which today's audience would probably find intolerable.'' Today's concerts last about two hours, with intermission, he said. Even then, some in the audience are sound asleep _ with a snore here and there. How do conductors get quiet? Warner-Lambert Co., which sponsored the survey, is distributing free wax-wrapped Halls Cough Tablets to patrons of the 21 orchestras whose conductors were surveyed. The company finished compiling the survey this week. It's part of the second year of a promotion called ``Silent Nights at the Symphony.'' Jean said the free cough drops do more than soothe scratchy throats _ ``It's like waving a flag to say, `Look guys, we have a problem''' with noise. Some performers are more direct. ``I've known of occasions where performers, conductors or soloists, have stopped, waited, glowered at the audience, to bring things under control,'' said Albert Webster, executive vice president and managing director of the New York Philharmonic. But Hanson cautioned that orchestras must be careful not to shoo away patrons who already may consider symphony concerts a tad high-brow. ``We don't want to scare people away by making them think that if they drop their concert program on the floor they're going to be shunned for life,'' Hanson said.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Accuse Bush of Complacency on Global Warming
DOC.TEXT: More than 700 scientists, including 49 winners of the Nobel Prize, are accusing President Bush of being complacent about the threat of global warming and urging him to show greater leadership on the issue. The scientists, representing a broad range of disciplines from medicine to physics, said in a letter Thursday to Bush that while ``more research on global warming is necessary ... uncertainty is no excuse for complacency.'' ``In view of the potential consequences, actions to curb the introduction of greenhouse gases ... must be initiated immediately. Only by taking action now can we ensure that future generations will not be put at risk,'' said the scientists. The group represented more than one-third of all members of the National Academy of Sciences. Among them were 49 Nobel laureates and 64 recipients of the National Medal of Science. Next week, a new round of meetings is to be opened in Washington of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which is examining the global warming issue. The meeting, expected to be attended by representatives from more than 60 countries, is part of an effort to reach an international agreement, perhaps next year, on what to do about global warming. Environmentalists have chided Bush for failing to endorse specific reductions in so-called ``greenhouse'' gases, especially carbon dioxide. Some European countries have argued that industrial nations should commit themselves to at least a 20 percent reduction of carbon dioxide emissions by the year 2000. But the Bush administration has said such a commitment is unwise because the economic impact has yet to be fully understood. Any significant reduction in global warming gases would require a major reduction in industry's reliance on fossil fuels such as coal and oil. Carbon dioxide, primarily from the burning of fossil fuels, accounts for about half of all greenhouse gases worldwide. The United States accounts for one-fifth of all greenhouse gas emissions. The letter was circulated among the scientific community by the Union of Concerned Scientists, which has been critical of the administration's policy on global warming. Most of the scientists who signed the appeal are not members of the group, however. Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., who has been a vocal critic of the administration's global warming policy, called the scientists' letter to Bush ``an extremely powerful statement by an impressive group'' and said it ``removes any misimpression of the position of the scientific community'' on the issue. While there is widespread agreement among scientists that man-made pollution is causing a warming of the earth, there is disagreement over how severe that warming will be and what the effect it will have on the earth. Some scientists have said the earth's temperature could increase anywhere from 4 to 9 degrees by the middle of the next century. Warming along the upper range of that estimate would cause serious coastal flooding and droughts, scientists say. Also on Thursday, the International Energy Agency released a report suggesting that any measures to deal with global warming are likely to be difficult and expensive, although no specific cost estimates were provided. ``It is clear that the economic costs of meaningful countermeasures will be very heavy,'' concluded the IEA study. ``Effective economic and technical adjustments will have to be introduced gradually over years and even decades.''

DOC.HEAD: Interior Secretary Praised by Congressional Foe of Republican Policies
DOC.TEXT: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., is getting unexpected praise from one of the harshest critics of Republican environmental policies in recent years. House Interior Committee Chairman Morris Udall, who was regularly at odds with the Reagan administration, said in a letter sent Thursday to Lujan that he sees ``an encouraging policy shift in the direction of the Department of the Interior and its management of coal mining activities.'' Steve Goldstein, chief spokesman for Lujan, said the letter came as a surprise. ``We have been plugging along for 12 months trying to get people to notice that things are different at Interior and there is an environmental tilt,'' he said. Goldstein said Lujan decided to reverse several Reagan administration decisions because they did not fit into the environmental mandate the secretary and President Bush want the department to follow. ``There is a much greater focus on stewardship in this administration,'' said Goldstein. Critics, including Udall, have said the Reagan administration favored private interests over public concerns. Udall, who is in his 13th year as chairman of the Interior Committee, often fought with interior secretaries James Watt and Donald Hodel, who served under Reagan. A former congressman, Lujan served on the Interior Committee, where he was the ranking Republican for several years. ``We sat side by side for a good number of years,'' Udall commented Thursday. ``We both know we'll disagree again along the way, but when an old friend is doing a good job, I feel moved to tell him.'' Environmental groups also have praise for Lujan's leadership. ``A lot of it is that they are waking up to the political realities that the public is interested in having the environment protected,'' said Skip Deegans, spokesman for the National Wildlife Federation. ``The situation on coal issues was so antagonistic during the Reagan administration that nothing was getting done. We were constantly in litigation with the Office of Surface Mining.'' Udall, who sponsored the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act, cited five areas for praise: _Improvements in the computerized system designed to prevent violators of the act from obtaining additional mining permits. The Reagan administration was put under court order to make improvements, but never did, said Deegans. _Abolishing a Reagan proposal to reduce the royalty rate paid the government on underground coal. It would have saved the coal industry money but cost the taxpayers. _Reversal of a Reagan administration decision to eliminate certain fees from the royalty base rate paid on coal. That had cost taxpayers about $70 million, said Udall. _Disapproval a change in a Wyoming regulatory program that would have relieved coal companies of having to return surface-mined lands to their original contours. _Action to stop mining companies from abusing the law that allows coal to be taken at a cheaper rate if the company happens to mine it when looking for another mineral in the vicinity. Companies were pretending to be mining principally for cheaper minerals in order to get coal, said Udall.

DOC.HEAD: Politburo Conservative Accused of Deception, Outdated Ideas
DOC.TEXT: Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev, viewed by many Soviets as a hard-line conservative, has come under unusually harsh attack by a newspaper that accuses him of lying and clinging to outdated socialist ideals. The weekly Moscow News, which has been at the forefront of glasnost, or openness, broke a taboo on criticizing standing Soviet rulers with a long editorial saying Ligachev opposes democracy and deceives the people. A picture accompanying the editorial underscored the critical tone. It showed the 69-year-old silver-haired Ligachev giving a Nazi-like salute, with one armed stretched above his head at a 45-degree angle. The article, in editions released Thursday, also accused Ligachev of a wide range of sins, such as glorifying dictator Josef Stalin and disregarding the people's will. The article was unusual not only for its harsh criticism of a Soviet leader but also for its timing _ just five days before the Communist Party's powerful Central Committee, of which Ligachev is a member, holds what is expected to be a stormy session. Progressives hope to present an alternative platform, and rumors are rife that hard-liners might try to make a power play. The editorial on Ligachev was given great prominence _ it was splashed over two pages _ and carried a measure of authority because it was written by a deputy editor-in-chief, Vitaly Tretyakov. The article outlined the views that have earned Ligachev, an ethnic Russian, a conservative label and frequently put him on a slower, more orthodox track than the reform-minded party leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Ligachev repeatedly has denied any discord with Gorbachev and has rejected the conservative label. While many reformers are calling for a multiparty political system, Ligachev has emphasized preserving the Communist Party's exclusive hold on power, and has warned that glasnost should not obscure the achievements of seven decades of Communist rule. He has firmly ruled out ownership of private property and has defended state and collective farms, which critics say contribute to the dismal performance of Soviet agriculture. Tretyakov wrote that Gorbachev's reform program, perestroika, has turned Ligachev ``from a supporter of the country's progress to an opponent.'' He said Ligachev apparently believes the Communists, not the people at large, are the party's source of power and in doing so, ``obviously diverges from the spirit of the day.'' Portraying Ligachev as an opponent of democracy, Tretyakov said his idea of pluralism is to accept only conflicting opinions from people who support socialism. He questioned Ligachev's approach to socialism, saying he favors what is ``the most unhealthy in socialism.'' The Politburo member also holds to a ``myth of unity of the party, the country, the model of socialism.'' ``Such unity never was, even when it was violently supported by a Stalinist regime,'' Tretyakov wrote. The solutions Ligachev and other conservatives propose, he said, arise ``not from the achievements of the past but from the mistakes.'' He criticized conservatives for acknowledging that Stalin's repression was wrong but claiming that he saved the Soviet Union from defeat to the Nazis in World War II. In fact, Tretyakov said, it could be argued that Stalin made the country vulnerable to attack and that it was saved in spite of, not because of, the dictator. Conservatives, he said, believe communism will be ``built, I'm afraid, on the blood shed not only in 1937 but also in 1989 in Tbilisi.'' He referred to the height of Stalin's bloody campaign of terror in the 1930s and a Soviet army attack on pro-independence demonstrators in the Georgian capital last April.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: US Support for Gorbachev Now Unqualified
