DOC.TEXT: When Sen. Jesse Helms, the conservative Republican from North Carolina, called Mikhail Gorbachev ``a colorful and adroit public relations man'' at a Senate hearing, he found himself alone. None of Helms' Foreign Relations Committee colleagues endorsed the senator's charge Thursday that the Soviet leader's reform program excludes freedom. Secretary of State James A. Baker III sat placidly in the witness chair and let the criticism of the Soviet president pass, although he did tell Helms he would ask in Moscow next week about allegations the Soviets are sending new weapons to Nicaragua and Cuba. Baker had just finished reading a statement endorsing ``the reformers'' in Moscow, pledging U.S. technical and other support, and warning: ``If we fail to support the principles that brought us this far, we could end up living in a future that resembles the past _ the past of Cold War and the conflicts that preceded it.'' A year ago, Helms's reservations might have been echoed by the administration. President Bush held out for months against responding to Gorbachev's overtures for troop reductions in Europe. He did not reply until June, and only Wednesday night in his State of the Union speech sweetened his offer of last year to get down to 275,000 on each side. Reflecting the reality that the Red Army could be out of Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland before a treaty is concluded, Bush called for further cuts _ ceilings of 225,000 with a limit of 195,000 U.S. and Soviet soldiers in Central Europe. A year ago, on Baker's first trip to Europe, his closest aides were advising reporters that the U.S. allies shared the view that Gorbachev was adept at public relations and had converted U.S. proposals for easing tensions to his own use. All that has changed now. One of those same aides acknowledged Wednesday night that the democratic revolutions in Eastern Europe had created ``new realities.'' If there was any resistance to Bush's latest proposal to cut U.S. and Soviet forces, it would come from the Western allies _ not Moscow. Baker, who will hold talks in the Soviet capital next Thursday and Friday with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and possibly Gorbachev, was unqualified in his support for the Soviet leader. ``We seek to probe for points of mutual advantage with the Soviet Union,'' he told the Foreign Relations Committee, ``turning areas of conflict into areas of cooperation wherever possible. In this way, we will benefit ourselves as well as the reformers in Moscow.'' Some of the Democrats urged the Bush administration to move faster. Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, for instance, is keen on Gorbachev's proposal to hold a 35-nation summit meeting next year. Biden said it would be a good opportunity to discuss the elimination of all foreign forces from Europe. Baker's response was to give the idea qualified support. First he would want the troop reduction treaty completed. And he would want the Soviets to recognize free elections as a human right. But Baker was receptive, and he is expected to develop the theme during his trip next week to Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union. He also may be able to work out with Shevardnadze answers to some of the questions still in the way of a U.S.-Soviet treaty to reduce long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines. And with the Soviet foreign minister, Baker will be looking for a solution to the war in Afghanistan between the Marxist government and U.S.-backed guerrillas. On several fronts, slow to act at first, the Bush administration is finding the Gorbachev revolution irresistible.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid covers foreign affairs for The Associated Press, specializing in U.S.-Soviet relations.

DOC.HEAD: Welders Questioned in Mail-Bomb Probe
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents probing a series of mail bombs have interviewed three welders about their relationship with a salvage store owner under investigation in the case. The welders said Thursday that the FBI agents mainly wanted to know about their ties to Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, for whom all have done work. One welder said agents took nail samples from his shop. The FBI, which established an outpost in this southeast Alabama community nearly two weeks ago, has declined to comment about specifics of the case. Part-time welder James Locke of nearby New Brockton said he told two investigators that he's known O'Ferrell about four years and has occasionally done work for him, repairing such salvage store items as metal chairs, desks and shelves. Locke said the agents took some samples of materials he uses at home to reload shotgun shells, and may have removed some nails from his scrap metal pile. ``They rooted around my nail caddy,'' he said. Authorities have said the bombs, mailed to Alabama, Florida and Georgia in December, contained finishing nails. Eleventh U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert Vance and Savannah, Ga., attorney Robert Robinson died in separate bombings. Locke said he had no knowledge of the bombs, other than what he has seen in the media. He added he did not believe O'Ferrell, who has been questioned extensively in the case, could have been involved in the attacks. ``Like I told them (the investigators), I thought Wayne was like a brother to the Lord _ a Christian,'' Locke said. Agents also questioned Joe King and Roy Reeves last week at their Enterprise shops, but did not remove any items during those meetings. Meanwhile Thursday, FBI agents in Enterprise continued their now familiar daily routine of scouring the area for an old typewriter they believe was used to write letters associated with the bombs. The typewriter allegedly also was used by O'Ferrell. Agents were seen Thursday inspecting typewriters at a downtown pawn shop as well as at nearby Fort Rucker, where a search has been conducted for the better part of this week. O'Ferrell, who has not been charged, has said he had nothing to do with the bombs. He reiterated Thursday that federal agents ``are barking up the wrong tree.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing Nikkei, dollar
DOC.TEXT: The dollar edged up against the yen Friday, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rose sharply. The dollar closed at 144.95 yen, up 0.45 yen from Thursday's close of 144.50 yen. After opening at 144.93 yen, the currency ranged between 144.77 yen and 144.98 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues gained 443.73 points, or 1.19 percent, closing the week at 37,650.15. Currency dealers said yen-dollar trading was slow in comparison with cross trading. Many market players were waiting the release of U.S. employment figures for January, due out in Washington later Friday, they said. Some economists predict the U.S. civilian unemployment rate will rise to 5.4 percent, up 0.1 percent from 5.3 percent in December. European currencies, including the West German mark, the British pound and the Swiss franc, strengthened against the dollar, said a dealer with Mitsubishi Bank, who spoke on condition he not be named. He and other dealers attributed the European currencies' strength to Thursday's State of the Union address by President Bush, in which he proposed new reductions in U.S. and Soviet combat forces in Europe. On the stock exchange, the Nikkei index started higher on small buying for domestic issues including construction, machinery and shipbuilding stocks, securities dealers said. Dealers attributed the index's gains to the firmness in Japanese government bond prices.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0430 to make slug conform to PM-News Digest.
Governor, Sioux Leaders Start Year of Reconciliation
LaserPhoto ABD1
DOC.TEXT: Gov. George Mickelson, recognizing the historical hurt suffered by Indians, smoked a peace pipe with tribal leaders and proclaimed a year of reconciliation in 1990, a century after the Wounded Knee massacre. The governor and representatives of eight Sioux tribes drew deeply and passed the pipe Thursday as they sat in a circle around a buffalo skull and other items in the center of the state Capitol rotunda. The members of the South Dakota Legislature and hundreds of other spectators applauded as Mickelson and the tribal leaders completed the ceremony. They then signed a proclamation designating 1990 as a time for healing wounds that have festered between Indians and non-Indians for a century. During the state's centennial celebration last year, Indians refused to take part, claiming they had nothing to celebrate. They have been at odds with state government over issues such as hunting and fishing rights, law enforcement on reservation highways and contracts for state services. The governor decided it was time to bury the tomahawk. Mickelson said he gathered the state lawmakers and the Indian leaders together to ``make this truly a year of reconciliation that marks a new beginning.'' ``I believe it places a responsibility on all of us throughout this year to make a personal commitment,'' the governor said. Indians are going through especially tough times in the state. On South Dakota's nine reservations, unemployment approaches 80 percent, and alcoholism, drugs and health care are severe problems. Four reservation counties rank among the nation's very poorest in terms of per capita income. Tim Giago, publisher of the weekly Lakota Times, had challenged Mickelson to proclaim 1990 as a year to help ease racial discord between Indian and white people in South Dakota. Mickelson thanked the Indian publisher for issuing the challenge. In the proclamation, Mickelson said that as South Dakota begins its second century of statehood, people must also remember that the creation of the state was a sad time for Indians. In December 1890, a little more than a year after South Dakota became a state, Sioux leader Sitting Bull was killed and nearly 300 Sioux men, women and children were killed by U.S. government troops in the Wounded Knee massacre. ``Strife between the cultures in South Dakota has, for 100 years, been of grave concern and continues to be of grave concern,'' the governor said in the proclamation. The 100th anniversary of the tragic events offers an opportunity for Indians and non-Indians to put aside their fears and mistrust, build friendships, cooperate, learn about each other's culture and develop a respect and understanding that will grow in the next century, Mickelson said. More than 6 percent of the state's population _ or about 45,000 people _ are Indians, according to the 1980 U.S. Census. Mickelson said he realizes state government and the tribal governments won't settle all their disputes in the next year, but many of the problems might be resolved. A council of Indians and non-Indians should put together a broad plan by March 1 for celebrating the year of reconciliation, the governor said, and each South Dakotan should think about ways to bridge the cultural gap between Indians and non-Indians in the long run. The proclamation was signed by the governor and representatives of the Flandreau-Santee Sioux, Oglala Sioux, Rosebud Sioux, Yankton Sioux, Standing Rock Sioux, Cheyenne River, the Lower Brule Tribe and the Sisseton-Wahpeton Sioux Tribe. A Crow Creek Sioux representative didn't show up for the ceremony, but officials said a tribal representative may sign it later. The ceremony opened when two Sioux men sang the ``Lakota Flag Song'' in a high-pitched, haunting, wavering harmony, and Sioux military veterans carried in the U.S. flag, a Sioux eagle staff adorned with feathers, and other flags. It ended with the Sioux men singing the ``Peace Song.''

DOC.HEAD: HUD Suspends Major Developer; Cites Investigation
DOC.TEXT: A Jesse Jackson supporter who runs a housing company suspended from government business wrote off a $30,000 debt owed by Jackson's 1988 presidential campaign, according to a published report. A. Bruce Rozet, a prominent Democratic fund-raiser and president of Associated Financial Corp. of California, released the campaign from a debt it owed to a hotel that Rozet partly owns, according to former hotel workers quoted in today's editions of The Washington Post. The hotel transaction was not reported to the Federal Election Commission as either an outstanding debt or contribution as required under the election laws. The Department of Housing and Urban Development said Thursday that AFC, one of the nation's largest subsidized housing landlords, was suspended from future government work because of a fraud investigation. HUD, in a letter to one of the company's affiliates, said the government ``has information indicating irregularities of a serious nature'' and the company and its affiliates were being investigated. AFC leads more than 40 affiliated companies that control nearly 50,000 units of federally assisted housing. Rozet was a Jackson delegate to the Democratic National Convention. Rozet, in a statement and additional comments issued through a spokesman, called HUD's action ``pure harassment for political reasons'' that ultimately would harm the low-income families the agency is supposed to serve. He denied any wrongdoing and accused HUD of taking the action to avoid a hearing scheduled for next week on lesser sanctions against an AFC affiliate. The Post cited former workers for the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel who said the debt was written off after the hotel was able to collect just $45,000 of $75,000 the Jackson campaign owed the hotel. The newspaper said two employees saw a company memorandum saying the unpaid balance was a ``gift'' from Rozet. Jackson told the newspaper he was not aware Rozet helped out with hotel expenses. ``Absolutely not,'' Jackson said. ``First off, we didn't need that kind favor, and second, it would have been illegal.'' Such a contribution would be illegal because it comes from a corporation. Individual contributions are limited by law to $1,000 per election per candidate. On the suspension announced Thursday, HUD General Counsel Francis Keating said AFC and its affiliates were being investigated by the department's inspector general. Law enforcement sources told The Associated Press that the U.S. attorney's office in Los Angeles was also investigating the companies. Those sources, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said Charles Bazarian, a man Rozet used as a property scout who later was convicted of skimming money a from HUD-assisted project, was cooperating with investigators. But the sources declined to discuss the substance of the probe, and the Los Angeles prosecutor handling it, Lee Weidman, declined comment. Rozet and AFC have had a number of run-ins with HUD in the past decade, including several in the last year, and Rozet has said first-year HUD Secretary Jack Kemp has allowed bureaucrats with old grudges against the company to dictate HUD policy toward AFC. Kemp visited one AFC property shortly after taking office last year and termed conditions there ``scandalous.'' Kemp's top deputy also has called Rozet and his companies ``slumlords.'' But community leaders in several areas with AFC properties have defended the company, and Rozet often is called on by Congress as an expert on housing policy. One of Rozet's biggest defenders in Congress is Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., for whom Rozet has been a major fund-raiser. HUD announced the suspension in a letter to an AFC affiliate, Housing Resources Management Inc., which is controlled by Rozet partner Deane E. Ross. Also affected by the suspension are AFC and more that 40 related development and investment companies involved in the purchase and management of government-assisted housing and the syndication of tax credits developers of such projects receive from the government. AFC, speaking on behalf of its affiliate, denied Housing Resources Management was involved in any improper activities. Even if those allegations were true, AFC said a suspension was unwarranted because the allegations involved about $35,000.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Experts Say Seat Belt Dispute May Lead to Road Injuries
DOC.TEXT: Safety experted their efforts to convince drivers and passengers to buckle uged by a claim that rear-seat lap belts can cause devastating injuries, especially to children. The Institute for Injury Reduction on Thursday launched a campaign to fit older cars wit shoulder straps, contending lap belts used alo than 1,000 serious injuries a year. Benjamin Kelley, the institute's president, said many victims of serious lap belt injuries are children because they are more likely to sit in the rear seats of automobiles than adults. The institute was founded two years ago by a group of lawyers who specialize in representing accident victims. Children strapped into the rear seats of cars often are killed or injured in slow-speed crashes by the sudden pressure of the belt on the stomach and spine, he said. But he said others in the car often emerge uninjured, sometimes when they are wearing no belt at all. But safety experts said many lives haved by seat belts, an advance that could be reversed if people stop using them out of needless fear. ``We don't want someone to think that it's safer to sit in that back seat with no belt at all,'' said Jerry Ralph Curry, administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. ``Our concern is that by scaring the public, parents will take a child out of the seat belt and that a child will t killed.''he said. In Fort Worth, Texas, officials attending a meeting of the National Highway Transportation Safety Association were just as blunt. ``The claims made at the Washington press conference can causey needless deaths and serious injuries,'' said Beverlee Anderson, spokeswoman for the safety association meeting and director of the Tennessee Traffic Safety Coalition. The association said the ``largeevidence shows more lives are saved by properlyap belts than by no restraining device at all. ``We estimate that lap belts in passenger cars saved about lives and prevented over 1,400 serious injuries in 1988,'' the statement said. Kelley did not advocate not using seat belts, acknowledging they do save lives. But he said that quickly fitting the nation's automobiles with shoulder straps would help eliminate seat belt injuries. He said such injuries can cause permanent paralysis through spinal damage or result in serious damage to abdominal muscles. ``Neither government nor the car industry are vigorously acting to see that existing cars are rapidly equipped with safe, effective rear-seat lap-shoulder belts,'' Kelley said. Kelley urged the government to urge auto manufacturers and dealers to make shoulder-strap retrofit kits quickly available to the public at affordable prices and to launch a publicity and advertising campaign to convince drivers to install them. Under a rule adopted last year by the traffic safety administration, new cars must be equipped with rear-seat shoulder belts. But Kelley said the rule does not apply to 140 million older cars already on the road.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Bush
DOC.TEXT: Here are President Bush's six education goals for America:

1. By the year 2000, every child must start school ready to learn. 2. The United States must increase the high school graduation rate to no less than 90 percent. 3. In critical subjects _ at the fourth, eighth and 12th grades _ we must assess our students' performance. 4. By the year 2000, U.S. students must be first in the world in math and science achievement. 5. Every American adult must be a literate worker and citizen. 6. Every school must offer the kind of disciplined environment that makes it possible for our kids to learn _ and every school in America must be drug-free.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev, East Bloc Reformers Among Nobel Peace Nominees
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and activists who toppled Czechoslovakia's hard-line Communist leadership are among the nominees for the 1990 Nobel Peace Prize, according to newspaper reports. The nominations closed Thursday and remain secret. The Oslo-based Norwegian Nobel Institute, as usual, refused to discuss candidates for the 71st prize. However, the Norwegian news media said the Soviet president was nominated for the third year in a row. Also among the reported nominees are Chinese students and their leader Chai Ling, whose pro-democracy demonstrations were crushed in June; jailed South African black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela; and former President Ronald Reagan. News reports said there were three Czech nominees: the students who demonstrated for reforms; former dissident and now President Vaclav Havel; and former Foreign Minister Jiri Hajek. Havel and Hajek, both nominated last year, were signers of the human rights manifesto Charter 77. The Norwegian Nobel Institute said 80 valid nominations were received for 56 individuals and 24 organizations. The number may increase as other nominations postmarked by Feb. 1 arrive, said an institute official. The prize, first awarded in 1901, is presented on Dec. 10, the anniversary of the 1896 death of the Swedish inventor of dynamite, Alfred Nobel. He founded the prize to honor those working toward disarmament and arranging peace conferences. In recent years, the peace prize also has been used to encourage human rights. The selection is kept secret until the official announcement, usually in October. Candidates for the $428,000 prize may be nominated by previous laureates, members of parliaments, or political science faculty members of selected universities. The 1989 award to Tibet's religious and political leader, the Dalai Lama, was broadly praised outside China, committee chairman Egil Aarvik said. The Buddhist monk advocates non-violence in Tibet's 40-year struggle against Chinese occupation.

DOC.HEAD: Consumers Get Conflicting Advice on Several Foods
With PM-Olive Oil, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The study published today in the Journal of the American Medical Association linking olive oil consumption with lower blood cholesterol, blood sugar and blood pressure is the latest volley in what often seems like a contradictory barrage of news about what constitutes healthful eating. Bonnie Liebman, director of nutrition for the Washington-based consumer group Center for Science in the Public Interest, advises patience. ``Scientists are used to having studies with opposite results and they know that, over time, the truth emerges,'' Ms. Liebman said. ``Consumers have only recently accepted science and health as news, and they aren't used to that.'' With that in mind, here is a list of some recent reports linking various foods to health problems or benefits:

OAT BRAN: One could find oat bran everywhere, even in beer, after reports emerged indicating that eating it helped reduce blood-cholesterol levels and the risk of heart attack. A recent study, however, said the apparent benefits of oat bran resulted from its replacement of fatty foods in people's diets, not from a special property of the grain itself, and that other cereals work just as well to reduce artery-clogging excess cholesterol in the bloodstream. RICE BRAN: Although some earlier studies indicated that rice bran had cholesterol-lowering properties, a researcher financed by the rice industry searching for such benefits has said he didn't find any, and advised people trying to lower cholesterol levels to reduce fat intake, get to a normal weight and exercise. MILK: Public concern about the safety of milk was sparked after two independent surveys found supplies in several areas contaminated with antibiotics and sulfa drugs used to treat sick cattle. The government says it sees no public health threat but researchers are concerned about the continuing possibility of contamination from detectable and undetectable veterinary drugs. COFFEE: Often subject to scrutiny, coffee made news recently after a study revealed that older couples who drink coffee appear to be more sexually active than elderly non-coffee drinkers. One researcher suggested that coffee stimulates the central nervous system and relaxes certain muscles, but also said it was possible that coffee drinkers were ``more liberal in their sexual behavior.'' Some studies have linked coffee to heart disease, high cholesterol levels and pancreatic cancer, while others have found no such relationship. FISH OIL: A recent study found that large doses of fish oil can return mild high blood pressure to normal levels. However, the subjects had to take three tablespoons each day of liquid herring oil, which caused belching and a lingering fishy aftertaste. The amount of fish oil used, equivalent to 50 fish oil gel capsules, was much higher than that recommended by capsule manufacturers. In fact, when taken at the dose usually suggested, the oil did not help. Despite their encouraging findings, the researchers said people should not exchange blood pressure pills for fish oil until doctors know more. They also advised people not to substitute cod liver oil, which contains too much vitamin A and D and not enough omega-3 fatty acids. Oily ocean fish, such as herring and mackerel, are rich in omega-3 fatty acids, the particular variety of fish oil that appears to be good for the heart.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Labs Double Bills for Medicare
DOC.TEXT: Medicare testing laboratories are billing the government program nearly twice what they charge physicians for the same services, according to a report by the inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services. Medicare could reduce significantly the more than $3.9 billion it pays annually for lab services if the program were to pay rates comparable to what physicians pay, said the report by Inspector General Richard Kusserow. ``Because Medicare is such a large volume payer of tests, we believe a strong case could be made for Medicare paying less than physicians. Certainly, the program should not be asked to pay more,'' said the report released Thursday. The review of 4,120 lab billings found Medicare payment rates were overall about 90 percent higher than the amounts paid by physicians, mostly because of the way Medicare pays for packages of tests ordered as a group. Physicians are offered deep discounts for these groups of tests, called profiles, but Medicare pays separately for each test according to its schedule of fees. Of 1,525 profiles reviewed, Medicare paid 176 percent more than physicians for the same tests, the report said. Nineteen of the 26 independent clinical laboratories surveyed had separate price lists for physicians and third-party payers, including Medicare. Of the seven labs studied in detail, all billed Medicare at least twice as much as physicians for the same tests and one charged Medicare five times more. Labs most often said they charged Medicare higher prices because they said it costs more to bill and get reimbursement from Medicare, the report said. Representatives at one lab complained that after they billed for about 500 Medicare patients on a single computer tape, they received 500 separate checks from Medicare, rather than one, as its physician customers would have issued. But the inspector general suggested some of the industry's complaints were unfounded, pointing out that to simplify billing, Medicare eliminated co-insurance and deductibles for lab services in 1984. Medicare serves about 33 million elderly and disabled Americans, and accounts for an estimated 10 percent to 20 percent of all lab tests. The program paid $3.9 billion for lab services in 1987, the latest year for which figures were available. This was a 22 percent increase over 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Parkinson's Disease Patient Treated With Transplanted Fetal Brain Tissue
DOC.TEXT: A man with severe Parkinson's disease showed marked improvement after receiving a transplant of brain tissue from an aborted fetus into his own brain, European researchers report. The transplanted fetal brain tissue apparently thrived and is producing dopamine, a brain chemical that is essential for normal controlled muscle movements, the researchers reported in a study published in Science magazine today. Olle Lindvall of the University Hospital in Lund, Sweden, chief author of the report, told The Washington Post that the study, involving a single patient, ``is very exciting and promising news.'' But he cautioned that the study ``does not prove that we can get this effect in other patients or sustain it in this one.'' Parkinson's disease occurs when areas of the brain degenerate and stop producing dopamine, a neurotransmitter essential for carrying signals from one part of the brain to another. By transplanting fetal brain tissue into the affected area, researchers hope to restore the production of dopamine. Clinical trials using transplanted fetal tissue have been conducted for the last two years and some improvement has been reported earlier in a few patients. But Lindvall said in Science that the earlier cases did not determine if the transplanted tissue survived in the host brain or if dopamine production was restored. Some of the improvement, he said, could have been the result of the surgery itself. The Swedish study involved a 49-year-old man described as ``severely affected'' with the muscular rigidity and tremors typical of Parkinson's disease. His right arm was most affected. Brain scans showed that the left side of his brain was deficient in dopamine production, and that the right side of the brain was less affected. The man, who first developed the disease in 1977, was helped for a time by a drug called L-dopa, which is chemically changed into dopamine in the body. But starting in 1984, the effect of the drug began to diminish, a characteristic of that drug. To perform the transplant, doctors removed brain tissue from four fetuses within four hours of routine suction abortions. The tissue was treated chemically and then injected by needle into three sites in the affected part of the brain of the Parkinsonian patient. ``From two to three months after surgery, the patient exhibited a marked improvement of movement speed ... in the right arm and a similar change (although of lesser magnitude) in the left arm,'' the Science study reports. The improvement, the study said, ``is consistent with the slow development of a growing graft.'' The researchers said that the patient also now responds better and for a longer period of time to treatment by the drug L-dopa. A brain scan, which can detect a chemical used as a tracer, showed five months after surgery that there was a dramatic increase in the amount of dopamine present in the patient's brain. Eight months after the transplant, the patient continues to improve. Future assessment, the study said, ``will show whether these neurons (the transplanted tissue) can survive permanently, or if they will be destroyed either by the underlying disease process or by immunological rejection.'' Eugene Redmond Jr., a Yale School of Medicine professor of psychiatry, said clinical improvement found in the study ``is very clear and well documented.'' ``The therapy could become the best hope for many people,'' he told The Washington Post, although he cautioned that only a single patient was used and final conclusions cannot yet be drawn. Redmond and some colleagues expect to complete a study of fetal cell transplants in 20 patients within two years. Fetal tissue experimentation slowed in the United States last year after the Bush administration banned the use of federal funds for research into transplantation of any fetal tissue into humans. Another researcher, Dr. Curt Freed of the University of Colorado Medical Center in Denver, said he got similar results with a 52-year-old man with Parkinson's disease. Those results will be published in April. Ten researchers, including four from England and one from Switzerland, co-authored the Science study with Lindvall. Science is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Paula Sims Sentenced to Life Imprisonment
DOC.TEXT: A woman convicted of murdering her infant baby, the second daughter she had reported abducted by a masked gunman in three years, was sentenced to life in prison despite her request for the death penalty. Jurors said Thursday they spared Paula Marie Sims her life because they did not believe she was soley responsible for the April 29 death of 6-week-old Heather Lee and that she might implicate other people in the slaying. Jury foreman Harold William Ryan Jr. said jurors didn't believe her story that a masked gunman stole Heather, just three years after Mrs. Sims' firstborn daughter, 13-day-old Loralei, disappeared under nearly identical circumstances. ``Mrs. Sims was well-rehearsed,'' Ryan said. ``But I guess we just didn't believe her.'' Mrs. Sims, 30, was convicted Tuesday of first-degree murder, obstruction of justice and concealing a homicide in Heather Lee's death. Her sentence includes no chance of parole. Mrs. Sims told her attorney Thursday she no longer cared to live, and urged him to let the jury issue a death sentence. ``She still maintains her innocence, but says, `I don't have any reason to go on, I don't have any reason to live,''' defense attorney Donald Groshong told the courtroom before sentencing. ``Whether I'm innocent doesn't matter _ they can go ahead and execute me,'' Groshong quoted his client as saying. But juror John Joplin said the jury was not moved by Groshong's plea for mercy and warnings to ``ignore the angry mob outside crying for blood.'' Instead, it was the unanswered questions surrounding the two deaths that spared Mrs. Sims, Joplin said. ``She killed her children and she has to live with it the rest of her life,'' Joplin said. ``By not sentencing her to death, maybe she'll help lead police to the others involved in the killings.'' The sentencing did not end legal problems facing Mrs. Sims and her husband, 37-year-old Robert Sims, who may be charged in the April slaying, said Madison County State's Attorney William Haine. Sims has not been charged in either infants' death and he retains custody of the couple's 2-year-son, Randy. Charges of obstruction of justice and concealment of a homicide await Mrs. Sims in Loralei's death. No murder charges have been filed in that case. Mrs. Sims, of Alton, near St. Louis, testified both her daughters were abducted by a masked gunman while her husband was at work. Mrs. Sims reported Heather was abducted April 29 from the Simses' home in Alton. Her body was found May 3 in a trash barrel across the Mississippi River in nearby West Alton, Mo. An autopsy indicated she had been suffocated and her body subsequently frozen. Loralei was reported abducted June 17, 1986, from the Simses' former home in Brighton, a few miles from Alton. A badly decomposed body identified as Loralei was found a week later in a wooded ravine near the house.

DOC.HEAD: Castro Says Bush Must Have OK'd Freighter Attack
DOC.TEXT: President Fidel Castro said President Bush must have approved a U.S. Coast Guard attack on a Cuban freighter suspected of drug-running, the official Cuban news agency reported. Castro welcomed the freighter's crew as heroes who had won a ``skirmish against imperialism'' when they returned to Havana Thursday from the Mexican port of Tampico, where they left their bullet-scarred boat. A U.S. Coast Guard cutter opened fire on the freighter Hermann with a machine gun and cannon after it refused demands to halt in the Gulf of Mexico. The Coast Guard let the boat go when it entered Mexican waters Wednesday. On Thursday, the Mexican Foreign Ministry issued a statement saying the Navy had ``meticulously'' searched the freighter twice and it showed no sign of drugs. Mexican officials seached the boat at the request of U.S. officials. Castro met the crew at the airport Thursday and accompanied them to a downtown rally, according to the Cuban news agency Prensa Latina. The Communist leader said the decision to fire on the Hermann must have come from the very highest level in Washington. ``President Bush must have been consulted,'' he said, according to Prensa Latina dispatches monitored in Mexico City. The official Mexican news agency Notimex said 60,000 people were at the welcoming rally near the U.S. interest section in Havana, which handles U.S. diplomatic affairs in Cuba. Prensa Latina said the crowd numbered in the ``hundreds of thousands.'' Castro praised the crew for their courage, Prensa Latina said. He said their refusal to stop and allow the Coast Guard to board and search ``was a demonstration of the courage of our people. It's what I would have expected in the face of a Yankee attack,'' Prensa Latina reported. Castro also called the incident a ``grave provocation.'' Cuba has filed a protest. Secretary of State James A. Baker III has said the incident ``was not an attack and a provocation.'' ``We were engaged in a legal law enforcement activity,'' he said. U.S. officials say the 250-foot freighter, which is registered in Panama, ``fit the profile'' of a drug-smuggling ship. Cuban officials said the boat carried 10 tons of chromium, a metallic element used in electroplating and alloys. In July, Cuban authorities executed four military officers on drug-running charges. Capt. Aristides Palma Palma, head of port operations in Tampico, said the Hermann will undergo repairs in Tampico. He said it was hit by at least 50 bullets. The freighter's captain, Diego Sanchez Serrano, filed a damage claim with Tampico harbor authorities saying the Hermann, owned by the Cuban Guamar Shipping Co., and its crew had been the victims of a terrorist act, the Excelsior news service in Mexico said.

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats Honor Rosa Parks
DOC.TEXT: House Democratic leaders honoring Rosa Parks say her refusal to move to the back of the bus 35 years ago, a key moment in the civil rights struggle, changed the nation. ``Rosa, let me thank you personally for sitting down so long ago so I could stand here today,'' said Rep. Bill Gray, D-Pa., the House Democratic whip, in honoring Mrs. Parks on Thursday. Gray credited her with triggering changes that have allowed blacks such as himself to attain high office. Mrs. Parks' 77th birthday on Sunday will be marked by a black-tie national tribute at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley and other House Democrats appeared with Mrs. Parks at a news conference in anticipation of that event. ``There are few people that can say they changed the nation. Rosa Parks changed the nation,'' Foley said. Mrs. Parks' refusal to surrender her seat to a white passenger on a Montgomery, Ala., city bus on Dec. 1, 1955, led to a city-wide bus boycott that last 381 days. The boycott triggered other protests and propelled Martin Luther King Jr. to national attention and to the leadership of the civil rights movement. Since 1965, Mrs. Parks has lived in Detroit and worked in the office of Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich. For the last three years she has run the Rosa and Raymond Parks Institute for Self Development, whose aim is to help young people.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Withdraws Silverman Nomination After Critics Hit No-Job
DOC.TEXT: Portfolio

President Bush has withdrawn the nomination of GOP fund-raiser Joy Silverman as ambassador to Barbados after receiving complaints from Capitol Hill that she lacked qualifications. Bush instead named Mrs. Silverman to the board of trustees of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. Mrs. Silverman, a New Yorker who had no job history, was one of several Bush ambassadorial appointees who critics said were being rewarded for her contribution to Bush's political campaign. Sen. Paul Sarbanes, D-Md., last year produced a list of $300,000 worth of political contributions to Republican campaigns by Mrs. Silverman, her husband, Jeffery Silverman, and her husband's wood products company, Playgem. Federal Election Commission records show she gave $100,000 to the Republican National Committee in 1988. Ambassadorial appointments require Senate confirmation. The Kennedy Center post does not.
DOC.HEAD: Air Force Announces Civilian Drug Testing
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force expects to begin tests by the end of the month on some 24,000 civilian workers holding sensitive jobs who have been deemed eligible for random drug testing, the Pentagon says. ``We're looking at testing approximately 6,000 employees per year,'' an Air Force spokesman, Maj. Lou Figueroa, said Thursday. Employees who test positive will be removed from their jobs and referred to a substance-abuse counseling program. They also will be subject to ``appropriate disciplinary action,'' which could include a written reprimand, suspension or firing, a Pentagon statement said. The program is designed ``to ensure employees refrain from using illegal drugs on or off duty,'' and also will include applicants for the posts deemed to be sensitive, the statement said. All of the tests will screen for marijuana or cocaine use. Tests for amphetamines, opiates and PCP can be ordered, the spokesman said. The Air Force has some 566,000 military personnel and 260,000 civilian employees. All active-duty military personnel have been subject to random drug tests since 1981. The Air Force has begun bargaining with the affected labor unions on the matter, the statement said. The program is designed to affect those civilians occupying or applying for positions that directly relate to ``the public health and safety, the protection of life and property, law enforcement and national security,'' the statement said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd item of lites to CORRECT attribution in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Dirty sheep? Wash 'em in Woolite, says a man who knows his livestock grooming. ``It's designed for wool, and they're wool,'' Marshall Eaton said as he used a blow-dryer on a lamb at the 94th Southwestern Exposition and Livestock Show and Rodeo recently. ``We used to use Mrs. Stewart's Bluing, what your grandmother used,'' said Eaton, an agriculture teacher at Tuscola in West Texas. ``I guess people switched over at least 10 years ago.'' Woolite was one of a number of products used to help Junior Lamb Show entrants look their best at the exposition, where empty bottles of Ivory, Palmolive and Dawn dishwashing liquids also were found lying about. Why is it important to have lambs' coats looking their brightest when they are led before the judges? Said Eaton: ``It's a little bit of a beauty contest.''

DOC.HEAD: Armenian Patriarch Of Jerusalem Dies
DOC.TEXT:
The Armenian patriarch of Jerusalem, Yeghishe Derderian, spiritual leader of thousands of Armenians in Israel, the occupied lands and Jordan, has died of a heart attack. He was 80. Derderian died Thursday in his home in the St. James Convent in Jerusalem's walled Old City, church secretary Father George Hintlian said. Derderian had been ill with the flu for two days, he said. Bells of mourning pealed in the Old City's Armenian Quarter to announce the death, and dozens of congregation members rushed to the convent. Derderian was the spiritual leader of 8,000 Armenians in Israel, the Israeli-occupied West Bank, and Jordan. He was also one of three custodians of Jerusalem's holy places, along with the Greek Orthodox and Latin patriarchs. Derderian was born in the eastern Turkish city of Van and lost all his relatives at the hands of the Turks in 1915 during what Armenians view as a massacre. Armenians claim the Turks killed 1.5 million ethnic Armenians between 1915 and 1923 during the days of the Ottoman Empire. Turks counter that the number of dead is at most 600,000 and that most died from disease and hunger during deportation from eastern Turkey to Syria and Lebanon during World War 1.
During January celebrations of the Armenian Christmas, Derderian accused Soviet authorities of not doing enough to stop the violence in Azerbaijan, where Azerbaijani Moslems were attacking Christian Armenians. Derderian came to Jerusalem in 1922 to study at the St. James Theological Seminary. He served as dean of the seminary before being named deputy patriarch in 1949. In 1960, he became patriarch of Jerusalem. Derderian also wrote 22 books, including biographies of religious figures and poetry, Hintlian said. The Armenian Church is one of the Eastern rite churches which are organized along ethnic lines. They accept the authority of the pope but have considerable autonomy in ritual and other matters. Derderian was not married. Hintlian said the funeral was tentatively scheduled for the middle of next week, adding that hundreds of clergymen from abroad would attend.

DOC.HEAD: Crackdown on Cocaine Moms Raises Questions Over Effects
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors are bringing charges against more and more pregnant women who take drugs, but a lawyer for one woman accused of delivering cocaine through the womb says the war on drugs is ``going from hysteria to ... absurdity.'' Authorities in areas where expectant mothers have been arrested say they're turning to criminal law as a last resort because nothing else worked in stopping the growing number of cocaine-addicted babies. ``When you have seen these children shake, it gets to you,'' said Lt. Stephan Banakas, narcotics chief for the Pensacola Police Department. ``If it's through arrest or the threat of arrests ..., whatever it's taken to get people to take care of their children, it's working.'' The controversy has emerged from the growing use of crack cocaine around the nation, but mothers addicted to other drugs also have been charged. In Wyoming on Thursday, a judge dismissed a child abuse charge against a pregnant woman who drank excessively. The judge said the prosecutor did not establish that the woman's drinking habits injured her unborn baby. More than 30 women have been arrested nationwide since the first mother was convicted of delivering cocaine to her newborn in central Florida last August, said Alison Marshall, a Washington, D.C., lawyer. Some police and prosecutors said the arrests are a way of forcing mothers of cocaine babies to get drug treatment. They contend that some pregnant addicts are going straight because they fear prosecution. But crackdown critics _ they include the American Public Health Association, National Women's Health Network and National Organization for Women _ say the arrests are doing more harm than good. The threat of jail is scaring pregnant addicts away from prenatal care and hospitals, increasing the risks to their babies, said Robyn Blumner, Florida director of the American Civil Liberties Union in Miami. Some even say the arrests could encourage women to have abortions or result in ``trash can babies.'' ``This is the war on drugs going from hysteria to illogical absurdity,'' said attorney Alan Rapoport of the American Civil Liberties Union. He is representing Kimberly Hardy, the first woman in Michigan charged with delivering cocaine to her newborn through the umbilical cord. A District Court judge on Thursday ordered Ms. Hardy to stand trial after a pediatrician testified that the baby's exposure to cocaine likely was responsible for his low birthweight, inability to hold food down and gastrointestinal dysfunction. Two days after birth, a drug test showed signs of cocaine in the baby's urine. Critics also contend a nationwide shortage of treatment facilities for pregnant addicts means women who seek rehabilitation as a result of the crackdown won't get it. In Florida, officials estimate more than 10,000 babies are born to addicted women each year. Authorities in South Carolina and the Florida Panhandle have been the most aggressive in bringing charges, said Marshall, who represents the Chicago-based National Association for Perinatal Addiction Research and Education. Police in this Panhandle city have arrested five mothers on charges of delivering cocaine to their newborn babies. Assistant State Attorney Jeff Deen of Sanford contends cocaine is delivered through the umbilical cord; the violation occurs during the minute to 90 seconds the baby is outside the womb before the umbilical cord is cut. Deen said his intention is to use prosecution to force women into drug rehabilitation. One Pensacola woman received 18 months in prison after pleading no contest to cocaine delivery, but that sentence was part of a plea bargain and runs concurrently with terms of equal length in two cases unrelated to drugs or children. Three other cases in Pensacola are pending; in the fifth case, the woman was placed on 15 years' probation. At least nine alleged cocaine mothers have been arrested in Greenville, S.C., said Solicitor Joe Watson who pioneered the prosecutions in that state. One woman has entered a guilty plea and was placed on probation. The other cases are pending. The South Carolina defendants are charged with child neglect by passing narcotics to their babies before birth. Pensacola has been able to help addicted mothers-to-be because it has the facilities to treat them, said Elizabeth Myer, client manager for the Community Drug and Alcohol Commission. She estimated that before the arrests only about 40 percent of the pregnant cocaine addicts who came to her office asked for treatment. Now, she said, they all want treatment. ``A lot of them will tell you, `I don't want to go to prison,''' she said.

DOC.HEAD: No Sign of Harm to Wild Panthers from AIDS-Like Virus
DOC.TEXT: The discovery of an AIDS-like virus in Florida panthers has scientists worried about its impact on the endangered animals, but they say there is no indication the disease is fatal to the beasts. Scientists have expressed surprise at finding the antibodies in panthers living in the wilds of South Florida, whose numbers are said to range from about 30 to 50. ``It's just another problem that we need to be aware of,'' Dr. Melody Roelke, state panther recovery project veterinarian, said Thursday. ``These panthers are having to deal with so many facets that are potentially dangerous to them ... and yet somehow they're surviving,'' Roelke said in a telephone interview from Gainesville. Feline immunodeficiency virus was first detected in domesticated panthers two years ago. A Cornell University researcher testing panther blood samples last year detected FIV antibodies in six of 20 tests. Technological advances in the identification of acquired immune deficiency syndrome may partially explain an increase in positive test results. A review of old blood samples using the new technology shows the virus was present in panthers long before it was discovered in humans in the early 1980s. ``I believe from the research they have been able to go back to bank serum samples to 1960, ad they have found positive samples,'' said Roelke. ``It may have been there a lot longer than that.'' The time span the virus has been present gives researchers some relief that it does not spell doom for the panthers. ``I don't think we need to look at this as another impending disaster. If it was going to be that way, it would've happened already,'' said David Maehr, state wildlife biologist in charge of panther research in South Florida. But the positive tests adds a concern to the captive breeding program to be launched in March or April. Wild panthers will be sent to four Florida zoos with the idea of boosting their population under controlled conditions. Roelke said it will be important to test the panthers and make sure none that test positive are placed in zoos with cat populations free of FIV.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Iranians To Be Deported From Britain
DOC.TEXT: Britain announced it was deporting nine Iranians for reasons of national security, but would give no details about their identities or what they had done. Iranian television said one of the nine was the chief of its London bureau. The Home Office said Thursday that the nine have until Feb. 9 to be out of the country. ``They are being asked to leave on the grounds that it would be conducive to the public good and for reasons of national security,'' said a spokesman, who was not identified in keeping with British custom. A spokesman for Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting (IRIB) said Ara, who has been bureau chief for nearly two years, was notified Thursday by letter that he had to leave the country. In a statement, Ara said, ``I was surprised to receive the notice. I think the decision has been made on the basis of anti-cultural discrimination.'' Ara and the TV spokesman said they did not know who the other eight Iranians were, but an Iranian TV broadcast monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp. said two were students. Britain deported two Iranians students in December. Their attorney said Britain suspected the men of being a hit squad to kill writer Salman Rushdie. The late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini issued a religious edict Feb. 14, 1989, calling on Moslems to kill Rushdie, the author of ``The Satanic Verses.'' Many Moslem leaders consider the book blasphemous to Islam. The Home Office refused to comment on any possible connection between the Rushdie affair and the nine Iranians.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Positive Test for AIDS Virus Doesn't Increase Suicidal Ideas
DOC.TEXT: Doctors need not be overly concerned about doing AIDS-virus testing for fear that patients might commit suicide if they learn they are infected, according to a study published today. With proper counseling, people who learn they are infected with the AIDS virus are no more likely to think about killing themselves than those who learn they are virus-free, the study in the Journal of the American Medical Association reported. ``Given the improved early treatments for HIV-related illnesses, neither physicians nor patients should avoid seeking the test for fear they won't be able to deal with the results,'' said Dr. Samuel Perry, professor of clinical psychiatry at Cornell University Medical College in New York. ``It is not an imminent death sentence, as many people believe.'' The study reported on 244 men and 57 women who completed written tests to gauge depression at intervals two weeks before, and one week and two months after notification of results of their AIDS-virus tests, researchers said. ``The reassuring part is that if people at risk for infection are given adequate pre- and post-test counseling, notifying them of infection doesn't increase their risk of suicidal (ideas),'' Perry said in a telephone interview Thursday. ``At least not if they are asymptomatic and over a short time.'' ``The less reassuring part is that people at risk seem to have a high rate of depressive illness independent of whether they're infected with the virus,'' he said. Previous studies have shown high rates of suicide among men who have developed the disease. A study found the rate of suicide in 1985 among men ages 20 to 59 who had AIDS _ not just the infection, which may take years to cause symptoms, but the actual disease _ was 36 times the rate of men without AIDS. Another study, of 1986 California death certificates, found the relative suicide rate of men ages 20 to 39 who had AIDS was 21 times that of men without AIDS, the researchers said. In the new study, among the 49 subjects who were found to be infected, rates of thinking about suicide were 28.6 percent at entry and 27.1 percent and 16.3 percent at the followups, the researchers reported. Among the 252 subjects informed they were virus-free, suicidal ideas decreased from 30.6 percent at entry to 17.1 percent and 15.9 percent at one week and two months after notification, the study found.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
De Klerk Lifts Ban On African National Congress
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk announced today that the African National Congress will be legalized after 30 years of guerrilla war against white rule, but he said ANC leader Nelson Mandela would not be freed from jail immediately. MORE

DOC.HEAD: CAPE TOWN: jail immediately.
DOC.TEXT: De Klerk also said he would lift bans on more than 30 other opposition groups, free all prisoners jailed for belonging to these groups, declare a moritorium on executions, and scrap most of the restrictions imposed during more than three years of a state of emergency. These were among the steps demanded by Mandela and the ANC as preconditions for negotiations on a new constitution that would end the black majority's exclusion from national politics. De Klerk's announcements, reversing decades of his governing National Party's policy, appeared to set the the stage for such talks to begin, probably with the government accepting Mandela's offer to serve as mediator. The alternative to negotiation, de Klerk said, ``is growing violence, tension and conflicts.''

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Man Named to Committee on Homeless in Reno
DOC.TEXT: City Hall is becoming as familiar a place for Walter Rhodes as the Salvation Army, missions and churches he frequents by day and the shelters or bridges where he sleeps at night. But Rhodes isn't camping out on government steps or sifting through the trash outside the downtown building. After seeing him regularly at City Council meetings, Reno leaders decided in January to appoint Rhodes to a city committee, hoping he can help them resolve Reno's homeless problem. ``I guess, right now, I'm going to be the token homeless person on the committee,'' said Rhodes, 54, who's been homeless three times in his life. ``But I'm glad they're giving me the chance to be heard. Even if they don't listen, I can say I tried.'' The Greenbelt Preservation Committee was proposed by the Reno Police Department, which showed council members photographs depicting filthy homeless camps along the nearby Truckee River, which officers want cleaned up. Rhodes initially saw the panel as another attempt to roust the homeless, who number from 600 to 5,000 in Reno depending on who's counting and who qualifies: some agencies count people temporarily living in the city's cheap motels as homeless; others tally only those living on the streets. ``As soon as I saw the police were proposing this committee then I knew it was just something they cooked up to get us off the river and out of sight,'' Rhodes says. ``I hope I'm proved wrong.'' Rhodes, who claims an IQ of 167, is scheduled to be officially appointed at the Feb. 13 council meeting, but already he's finding political life difficult. ``As soon as it got around that I was going to be on the committee, I got two death threats from two guys camped out by me on the river,'' said Rhodes. Rhodes moved from his living quarters under a busy bridge outside of Reno to a room above the Gospel Mission with the help of a church friend who picked up the $30-a-week tab for two weeks after the mid-January death threats. He escaped the darkness, litter and human excrement polluting the riverbank. ``This is where we live,'' he said, crouching near a makeshift campfire grill. ``It's cleaner than most, but even the best camps are bad.'' Born in Lisbon, a small Ohio town near Youngstown, Rhodes said he graduated from high school, attended one year of business school and took a correspondence course in religion. He was placed in a mental hospital twice in the late 1950s and found himself homeless shortly after his release. He later found work for a telephone directory sales company for nine years, traveling through 37 states in the 1960s and early 1970s. He became homeless again from 1975 until 1977 after a long spell of unemployment, and returned to the streets again last September after he lost a telephone sales job. Unlike many of Reno's transients, he said he doesn't drink alcohol or gamble. It's Rhodes' theory that about half of the homeless people in America don't want to get off the streets and a third of those who do want a home and job aren't capable of succeeding. ``The homeless problem will never go away because only about one-third of all the people on the street will ever get off,'' he says. ``I think it's up to the churches to help them, but when that doesn't happen it's up to government.'' Reno's City Council has agreed to spend as much as $2 million to find a location for a new homeless center that would centralize many services now spread throughout the city. Plans are in the initial stages. Rhodes said the biggest mistake Reno and other cities make is treating each street person the same instead of providing individualized help. ``If someone wants to stay on the street, all he needs is limited services like food, clothing, some shelter,'' Rhodes said. ``But the rest, they need help to find jobs. ``It's hard to get a job when you've been on the streets and smell like 16 miles of road,'' added Rhodes, who wears a green corduroy coat he doesn't remove, even indoors, during the winter. ``The worst thing to happen to homeless people is to be treated like we aren't there or we're less than human.''

DOC.HEAD: Teacher, Librarian Suspended Over Showing of `Catch-22'
DOC.TEXT: A teacher who showed the film ``Catch-22'' to college-bound juniors has been suspended along with a school librarian because the movie is rated R, officials said. La Cueva High School teacher Joyce Briscoe didn't know about the movie's rating when she showed it, teachers union spokeswoman Mary Lombardo said Thursday. Ms. Briscoe also had drawn the wrath of some parents in October for screening ``The Last Temptation of Christ'' for students who had parental permission. School board member Leonard DeLayo Jr. said he was disgusted by the suspension and by two groups' use of the ``Last Temptation'' issue in an effort to defeat a mill-levy for schools in next Tuesday's election. ``I think the suspension was wrong, and I think it's wrong for one group to hold an entire school district hostage because of their beliefs,'' DeLayo said. Ron Frost, spokesman for one of the organizations, Albuquerque American Family Coalition, said the group had nothing to do with the suspensions but was pleased by the action. He called for Ms. Briscoe to be fired. Parents upset by the ``Last Temptation'' screening launched a campaign last month against the levy and any other proposed tax increases for schools. ``Last Temptation'' is considered offensive by some religious groups. The furor over the screening forced the Albuquerque Public Schools to revise its movie policy. New guidelines released last month require a school committee to review films rated PG-13 or R before they are shown. The principal would make a final decision. Ms. Lombardo said ``Catch-22'' was not stored with other R-rated films in the library. School spokeswoman Crystal McClernon said librarian Pauline Jones has been suspended with pay for checking the movie out for Ms. Briscoe. Superintendent Jack Bobroff said he decided to suspend the two with pay ``until the matter is investigated and resolved.'' A R-rated film at a movie theater requires children under age 17 to be accompanied by a parent or adult guardian. Ms. Lombardo said the union plans to file a grievance for Ms. Briscoe, asking that she be immediately reinstated. ``Catch-22,'' based on Joseph Heller's novel of the same name, portrays life in a U.S. bomber squadron during World War II. The 1970 film was directed by Mike Nichols and starred Alan Arkin, Jon Voight, Orson Welles, Richard Benjamin, Art Garfunkel, Anthony Perkins and Bob Newhart.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
De Klerk Lifts Ban on ANC, Mandela Not To Be Freed Immediately
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with president saying ANC will be legalized, Mandela will be freed but not immediately, no date set. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk announced Friday that the African National Congress will be legalized after 30 years of guerrilla war against white rule, but that its leader Nelson Mandela will not be freed from jail immediately. In a speech opening Parliament, De Klerk also said he would lift bans on more than 30 other opposition groups, free all prisoners jailed for belonging to these groups, declare a moratorium on executions, and scrap most of the restrictions imposed during more than three years of a state of emergency. These were among the steps demanded by Mandela and the ANC as preconditions for negotiations on a new constitution that would end the black majority's exclusion from national politics. De Klerk's announcements, reversing decades of his governing National Party's policy, appeared to set the stage for such talks to begin _ probably with the government accepting Mandela's offer to serve as mediator. The alternative to negotiation, de Klerk said, ``is growing violence, tension and conflicts.'' Although he decined to set an exact date for Mandela's release, the president said: ``I want to put it plainly that the government has decided to release Nelson Mandela unconditionally.'' ``The government will take a decision soon on the date of his release,'' he said, speaking in Afrikaans. ``Unfortunately, a further short passage of time is unavoidable.'' He did not elaborate. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater has said President Bush will invite Mandela to Washington as soon as he is released. South, an anti-apartheid newspaper in Cape Town, reported Mandela recently gave a letter to the government saying that ``conflict and violence in South Africa would never be settled unless the government and the African National Congress reached agreement.'' ``The climate (for negotiations) would be created if apartheid legislation was scrapped, the state of emergency lifted, banned organizations unbanned, political prisoners released, exiles allowed to return and all executions and political trials halted,'' South quoted Mandela as saying. The magazaine said Mandela personally handed the document to Justice Minister Kobie Coetsee. De Klerk and Mandela first met Dec. 13. Since then, both the government and the ANC have given increasingly serious consideration to the possibility of negotiations. De Klerk, who took office in August, had eased restrictions on anti-government protests and offered to negotiate a new constitution that would include a political role for blacks. But he says he is not prepared to accept the ANC's demand for a one-person, one-vote system that would lead to black majority rule. Mandela, 71, has spent more than 27 years in prison for his role in planning the start of the ANC's guerrilla campaign. His release is seen as necessary before black leaders will enter negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Workers Accept Three-Year Amoco Contract
DOC.TEXT: The oil workers union reached a tentative agreement with Amoco Corp. that is expected to pave the way for negotiations with the oil industry nationwide. The offer was presented to union representatives Thursday at various Amoco refineries. The Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union represents about 40,000 workers, including about 4,500 employed by Amoco. Strikes at individual oil companies had been a possibility since midnight Wednesday, with the expiration of some 300 contracts between oil companies and the union. Union leaders never planned a nationwide walkout, but said they might strike individual companies. Amoco spokesman Mike Thompson confirmed from Chicago that a tentative agreement for a new three-year labor contract has been reached at at least two Amoco refineries in Casper, Wyoming, and Yorktown, Virginia. Union Vice President Robert Wages said he expects the Amoco offer providing a general wage increase of $2.36 per hour over three years to set a pattern for the current round of negotiations with the oil industry. The contract calls for an immediate 80-cent-per-hour wage increase, a 5.3 percent hike based on the refinery worker's current average pay of $15.18 per hour. Amoco agreed to increase its contribution to health care premiums by $55 per month for family coverage in the first year. The company will add an additional $45 a month in the second year of the agreement and another $50 in the third year. A $250,000 death benefit for workers killed in work-related accidents also was negotiated into the contract. Amoco agreed to provide up to 26 weeks at full pay for workers absent due to occupational illness or injury, and an additional 26 weeks at half pay. But Wages said in a news release that Amoco failed to address environmental issues brought up by union representatives. ``We are extremely disappointed at the industry's failure to address our proposal on environmental monitoring,'' Wages said. ``It would have been in their own best interest to take that step. It would have benefited them tremendously.''

DOC.HEAD: Mexico: No Charges Against Latest Suspects In Murder Of U.S. Drug Agent
DOC.TEXT: The government says it will not charge two former ranking officials and three other Mexicans who were indicted in Los Angeles this week in the torture-slaying of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena Salazar. ``We are not going to file any complaints at this time,'' a spokeswoman for the Attorney General's office said in an interview Thursday. ``They were members of the past administration.'' Manuel Ibarra Herrera, former chief of Federal Judicial Police, and Miguel Aldana Ibarra, who headed the Mexican branch of the international policy agency Interpol, live in Mexico City and served in the administration of former President Miguel de la Madrid, who left office 13 months ago. They were indicted Wednesday by a federal grand jury in Los Angeles that is continuing a five-year investigation into the deaths of Camarena, a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent, and his Mexican pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar. Camarena and Zavala were killed after Camarena led raids on marijuana plantations allegedly run by Guadalajara drug kingpin Rafael Caro Quintero. Camarena's body was found March 5, 1985, on a ranch 65 miles southeast of Guadalajara. The DEA pledged it will prosecute all connected to the case. A Mexican judge in December sentenced Caro Quintero to 40 years in prison for his role in the Camarena slaying. He is one of a dozen people convicted in the case in Mexico. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said authorities have no information about any U.S. plans to request extradition of the five. The Los Angeles indictment also named reputed drug lord Miguel Angel Felix Gallardo, who has been in jail in Mexico on narcotics charges since April. The whereabouts of the two others, Humberto Alvarez Machain and Antonio Vasquez Ochoa, are unknown. Vasquez is charged with violent crime in aid of racketeering in the Guadalajara slayings of U.S. citizens John Walker and Alberto Radelat in January 1985. The indictment also named a Honduran, Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, who was extradited from his homeland in 1988 and sentenced to a life term in prison by a Los Angeles federal judge after being convicted of masterminding a California drug ring linked to Colombian traffickers. Neither Aldana or Ibarra could be reached at their Mexico City telephone numbers on Thursday. But Aldana, 44, was quoted by the independent Excelsior news service in Mexico as saying he is considering ``a countersuit through Foreign Ministry channels.'' Aldana resigned from his Interpol post on Jan. 2, 1986, after 28 years as a law enforcement officer. He said he wanted to write books and do criminology research. He resigned after the weekly newsmagazine Proceso said a drug defendant had testified that a shipment of Colombian cocaine seized at the Mexico City airport was for Aldana. The defendant later recanted, claiming his testimony was made under duress. Aldana alleged in recent interviews that Camarena was corrupt. He told Excelsior his only involvement with the Camarena murder were ``investigations ordered by the Attorney General's office in 1985.'' The former Interpol chief in Mexico now is a top member of a lawyers associations in Mexico City and runs a private consulting business. Ibarra, 58, dropped out of public life in 1988 when he retired from the judicial police, Mexico's equivalent of the FBI. Newsweek said in a 1985 report that when Ibarra led the force, the DEA gave him a tip that Matta Ballesteros was in a Mexico City hotel. But the magazine said that it took Ibarra's men 36 hours to reach the hotel and by the time they arrived, Matta Ballesteros had fled, . The Attorney General's Office told Excelsior that both Aldana and Ibarra have been called before federal magistrates since retiring, but only to testify as investigators.

DOC.HEAD: CDC: Better Education Needed to Prevent Sexually Transmitted Diseases
DOC.TEXT: Syphilis has soared to its highest rate in 40 years and young people's education about sexually transmitted diseases is lacking, federal health researchers say. The national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday that just two of five major 1990 goals for the prevention of sexually transmitted diseases are on track. The federal government's goals, set in 1979, were aimed at reducing gonorrhea and syphilis while raising awareness among doctors and young people. Gonorrhea rates dropped as hoped during the 1980s, the CDC said, but syphilis is soaring and education efforts are falling behind. ``There's good news and bad news,'' said Dr. Ward Cates, the CDC's director of sexually transmitted disease prevention. ``We've made major inroads in controlling gonorrhea, but we've seen much less success on syphilis and other sexually transmitted infections.'' The major sexually transmitted diseases, for the most part, are preventable or curable, Cates said. ``We have seen over the last half century that if adequate resources are targeted to each of these conditions, it can lead to sustained efforts and controlling them,'' he said. The five goals for 1990 and the progress, or lack of it: _Reduce the syphilis rate to seven cases per 100,000 Americans per year, and congenital syphilis _ syphilis at birth _ to 1.5 cases per 100,000 infants under 1. Status: Not likely. Syphilis in 1988 was at its highest rate in 40 years, 16.2 cases per 100,000, with about 39,000 cases reported. Congenital syphilis also has soared, to a rate of 17.7 in '88 (672 cases). _Reduce the gonorrhea rate to 280 per 100,000 Americans. Status: Likely. The rate had fallen by 1988 to 303, down from more than 450 in 1975. _Reduce the rate of pelvic inflammatory disease to 560 cases per 100,000 women. Status: Likely. The rate dropped from nearly 900 in '81 to 610 by '88. _Ninety-five percent of health-care providers treating sexually transmitted diseases should be able to diagnose and appropriately treat all recognized forms of such ailments. Status: Not likely. A 1985 survey found that nearly two-thirds of physicians wouldn't implement traditional spouse notification in a typical gonorrhea case, and 90 percent didn't assess their patients' sexual practices. _Give every junior and senior high school student accurate, timely education about sexually transmitted diseases. Status: Not likely. Just three out of four teen-agers surveyed in '88 reported education on the illnesses before age 18. The Atlanta-based CDC said the war on sexually transmitted diseases was made more difficult in the 1980s by increases in ailments such as chancroid and herpes, by the practice of trading sex for crack cocaine, and by the advent of AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: Crews Picking Up Wreckage of Flight 52
DOC.TEXT: Workers began removing the wreckage of a crashed Colombian jetliner and federal investigators prepared a trip to Bogota to study records that might cast light on the crash. The records National Transportation Safety Board investigators will view include maintenance logs and information about the crew's employment records and personal habits before the Jan. 25 plane crash that killed 73 people. As workers with chainsaws Thursday sliced through the wings of the Boeing 707 that was Avianca Flight 52, resident Samuel Tissenbaum said the wreckage had been a horrible reminder of the tragedy. ``This has been a terrible experience. We're anxious for them to get rid of this plane,'' said Tissenbaum, whose house barely was missed by the crashing aircraft. Its nose remains stuck in the deck of his home. Avianca hired Charlotte Aircraft Corp. of Charlotte, N.C., to remove the wreckage, and a half-dozen workers worked Thursday on its wings. NTSB officials wrapped up their on-site investigation Wednesday. In addition to the deaths, 85 were injured when the plane, heading to John F. Kennedy International Airport from Colombia, slammed into a hillside after apparently running out of gas above this secluded Long Island town. Before workers began cutting the plane's wings into 5-foot-square pieces for removal, the scene appeared frozen in time since the night of the crash with hunks of twisted metal, seats and other debris scattered on the hillside next to Tissenbaum's house. Once the pieces of wing were cut, they were loaded onto a truck and hauled away. The cleanup could take up to three weeks because the site can only be reached by a single winding road, said police Sgt. John Woodworth. Nassau County police were also at the scene collecting luggage, property and other personal effects that were not initially picked up. Workers from New York Telephone and the Long Island Lighting Co. were there, too, moving wires and cutting down trees.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I want to put it plainly that the government has decided to release Nelson Mandela unconditionally. The government will take a decision soon on the date of his release.'' _ South African President F.W. de Klerk, announcing that the African National Congress will be legalized after 30 years of guerrilla war against white rule, and that its leader Nelson Mandela, 71, who has been jailed for more than 27 years, would be freed.

``I definitely do watch to see what he does. I didn't say I believe it. I say I watch it.'' _ Albert Peterlin, of the National Weather Service in Harrisburg, Pa., on the Groundhog Day tradition of checking to see if Punxsutawney Phil sees his shadow.

``At the end of the summer, when I was finished the job he said, `Well, how did you enjoy Wall Street?' and I said, `I'll tell you one thing, I don't know what I'm going to do in life but I'm certainly not going to work on Wall Street.''' _ John J. Phelan Jr., chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, in announcing his retirement at year's end, 42 years after he worked as a teen-ager for his father as a ``runner'' on the stock exchange floor _ and hated it.

DOC.HEAD: Whooping Cough Up Somewhat; Most Patients Still Under 1
DOC.TEXT: Whooping cough strikes as many as 60,000 Americans a year, federal researchers say, adding that most victims are preschoolers and too many are unvaccinated. The national Centers for Disease Control said Thursday that 3,450 cases of whooping cough, or pertussis, were reported in 1988, 2,823 in 1987 and 4,195 in 1986. CDC's unofficial 1989 count is 3,745 cases. But the CDC said the reported cases are perhaps only 5 percent or 10 percent of the nation's total pertussis cases. Of 10,468 reported cases from 1986-88, 4,394, or 42 percent, occurred in children under 1. Another 2,602, or 25 percent, occurred in children between 1 and 4. Twenty-six of 8,682 patients studied between 1986 and 1988 died, and 14 of them were younger than 6 months old, the CDC said. The CDC's Immunization Practices Advisory Committee recommends pertussis vaccinations _ usually given in diptheria-pertussis-tetanus shots _ at or before 3 months, 5 months, 7 months and 19 months. Out of a group of 3,793 pertussis patients between 3 months and 4 years old, the CDC said, a survey found that 63 percent had not had the appropriate number of shots, and 34 percent had never received a shot at all. Pertussis, which causes its characteristic cough among other symptoms, is treatable with drugs in most cases, most often erythromycin.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Military Officers Plead Guilty in Spy Case
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs lead to replace dropped word `officer.'
