DOC.TEXT: A former Marine and Air Force communications officer will face a substantially reduced sentence in exchange for pleading guilty to passing secret information to the Soviet Union. Frank Nesbitt changed his verdict to guilty Thursday, five days before his trial on espionage charges was due to begin in federal court. If convicted on the original charges, he could have faced life imprisonment. The plea bargain arrangement means he could get a maximum jail term of 10 years. ``Did you do it?'' U.S. District Judge T.S. Ellis asked Nesbitt, 45. ``Yes, sir,'' Nesbitt said calmly. According to earlier testimony by the government, Nesbitt came to the FBI last October to tell them of an odyssey that led him through Central and South America and on to the Soviet Union and back. His attorney claimed Nesbitt simply wanted ``some excitement in his life.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Mark Hulkower said Nesbitt passed information to the Soviets later determined by the National Security Agency to be classified, but the nature of the material was not disclosed publicly. Nesbitt was indicted in November on espionage charges. Nesbitt testified Thursday he did not realize that the material was classified. ``It was my true and honest effort not to do that,'' he told the judge. The judge set sentencing for March 16. The agreement does not entitle Nesbitt to parole. He also could be fined up to $250,000. FBI Special Agent Lizzie Cassell testified in October that Nesbitt left his wife and two children in Millington, Tenn., last June, leaving a note saying: ``Don't look for me. I'm gone.'' Nesbitt said Thursday he decided to go to the Soviet Union after contacting Soviet officials while traveling in Bolivia last year. He said he was later kept in a safe house for a few days until he failed a lie detector test and the Soviets then broke off the contacts. He said he had agreed to cooperate with the Soviets after they showed him a picture of his two children taken outside his Tennessee home. Nesbitt said two Soviet agents followed him when he returned to the United States and he went to the FBI. Ms. Cassell said that a few days after telling the FBI his story, Nesbitt was arrested at a Virginia hotel when ``agents were forced to break the door down.'' Nesbitt served from 1963 to 1966 in the Air Force's Electronic Security Command in West Germany and from 1969 to 1979 in the Marine Corps, where he dealt with classified communication gathering. He also worked in the Los Alamos National Laboratories from 1983 to 1984. He had a top secret code word clearance in all his jobs. His attorney, David Hopkins, said Nesbitt pleaded guilty because of ``a recognition of the strength of the government's case. This is 10 years, the other is life. It's enough to give anyone pause.''

DOC.HEAD: California Officials Consider Changing Time of Executions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with date set for judge to schedule execution, details on Harris' status; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: San Quentin Prison officials are considering changing the time for executions to midnight from the traditional 10 a.m. to avoid traffic problems on the highway outside the prison. A San Diego court will set a date Monday for the execution of Robert Alton Harris, convicted of killing two teen-agers, who would be the first person to die in the California gas chamber since 1967. ``A lot has happened out there in the last 23 years,'' said Vernell Crittenden, administrative assistant to the warden. ``It's not just one motorist coming down the road anymore. ``You're going to have people rubbernecking when this happens. There will be hundreds of people around the prison. People driving by. The media. Illegally parked cars.'' Considerations of a time-change developed after the Oct. 17 earthquake, when freeway gridlock and damage to the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge routed hundreds of thousands of motorists north to the Richmond-San Rafael Bridge, and right past San Quentin. Prison spokesman Cal White said that since no one at the prison has any experience with an execution, a team is being trained. The U.S. Supreme Court on Jan. 16 rejected Harris' latest appeal. Superior Court Judge Jesus Rodriguez in San Diego said Thursday he had denied a defense request to postpone Monday's scheduled issuance of a death warrant. The execution could occur from 30 to 60 days after the warrant is signed. Defense attorneys Michael McCabe and Charles Sevilla contended in their motion that setting an execution date while Harris' final appeal is pending before the California Supreme Court would be ``a waste of judicial resources, attorney time and public money.'' The state Supreme Court has requested written arguments to be submitted by March 16 on 10 issues raised by the defense. Harris' case procedurally is further along the legal appeals process than that of any of the 271 other inmates on San Quentin's Death Row.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Send Pregnant Woman to Trial
With PM-Cocaine Moms, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A judge dismissed a child-abuse complaint brought against a pregnant woman because she drank alcohol, saying the state did not produce probable cause that her fetus had been injured. ``The key as I see it is that the child already has to have suffered,'' Judge Robert Denhardt said. Diane Pfannenstiel, 29, was about four months pregnant when she was arrested Jan. 4, two months after another judge ordered her to remain alcohol-free. A blood test revealed she had a blood alcohol level of 0.1 percent, the level at which a person is considered intoxicated under state law. Pfannenstiel quickly left the court after Denhardt's decision without commenting. Her lawyer, Mary Elizabeth Galvan, said the judge's decision Thursday adhered to the letter of the law, which states an injury must exist for abuse to occur. ``If you want the child abuse statutes to cover fetuses, then you go to the Legislature and you ask them to enact that statute,'' Galvan said. Dr. Gary Lang, a pediatrician, testified that studies have shown pregnant women who drink excessively are prone to give birth to children suffering from fetal alcohol syndrome, which is exhibited by physical and mental developmental defects. But Lang could not say definitely that the defendant's fetus had been injured by its mother's drinking. He said it could take years to determine if the drinking had injured the fetus. Denhardt declined at the beginning of a preliminary hearing to dismiss the case. He made his ruling after hearing testimony. The defense never presented witnesses, winning the dismissal after the state closed its case.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Defends Governing Party in Televised Debate
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu today defended his conservative party's 34 years in power against attacks from four opposition leaders in Japan's first televised campaign debate since 1960. The governing Liberal Democrats face the first serious challenge in decades to their majority in the 512-seat lower house. Elections are set for Feb. 18. Party leaders agreed to the debate after opposition parties and the news media criticized Kaifu for dissolving the lower house of parliament on Jan. 24 in preparation for elections without giving a traditional pre-election policy speech. ``Four versus one _ it's not fair,'' Kaifu said, drawing laughs after he tried to comment out of order during the three-hour debate. The debate dealt at length with the question of whether leftist opposition parties would preserve democratic liberties if they win a majority. ``This election is a choice between liberalism and socialism, and we've already seen on a global scale that liberalism has won,'' said Kaifu, voicing the key campaign strategy of his party. Takako Doi of the Japan Socialist Party and Japan Communist Party Chairman Tetsuzo Fuwa sharply rebutted that theme. Ms. Doi accused Kaifu of ``spreading ink like an escaping squid'' to obscure the real issues of the election. ``Under the current constitution, liberty and democracy is already guaranteed,'' she said. Sitting side by side, Kaifu, 59, and Ms. Doi, 61, dominated the debate at the Japan National Press Club. It was the first televised confrontation between a Liberal Democratic prime minister and top leaders of the opposition since Nov. 12, 1960, when Liberal Democratic Prime Minister Hayato Ikeda took on the leaders of the Socialist and Democratic Socialist parties. Ms. Doi drew indignant looks from Kaifu when she accused the Liberal Democrats of deceiving the public. ``People feel they can't trust the government because of repeated incidents and the lies they have heard,'' the Socialist leader said, alluding to a series of scandals and an unpopular sales tax enacted after the Liberal Democrats had promised to avoid such a levy. ``It's the way it was done that's the problem,'' Ms. Doi said. ``We want to return the country to a true `people's government.''' Polls show the Liberal Democrats could lose their majority in the powerful lower house, partly because of dislike of the 3-percent sales tax and partly due to the party's rocky record in the past year. Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita resigned in April amid a stock-profiteering scandal. His successor, Sousuke Uno, lasted only two months after allegations surfaced that he kept paid mistresses. The Liberal Democrats lost their majority in the upper house of Parliament in July. After opening statements, Kaifu, Ms. Doi, Fuwa and the leaders of the centrist Komeito (Clean Government Party) and Democratic Socialist Party responded to pre-arranged questions on foreign policy, political reform, the sales tax and other issues. The highly formalized debate drew a lukewarm reaction from political analysts. ``Neither side ... was able to present a clear vision'' on how to handle pressure from foreign governments to open Japanese markets, said Josen Takahashi, at Mitsubishi Research Institute, a private think tank.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Admits Sobriety Tests as Evidence
DOC.TEXT: The judge in the trial of former Exxon Valdez captain Joseph Hazelwood rejected defense efforts to exclude as evidence the results of two sobriety tests. Thursday was the third day of jury selection in the trial of Hazelwood, skipper of the super tanker when it wrecked and spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound in March. Jury selection was scheduled to continue today for the trial, which could last six weeks. Anchorage Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone rejected a defense argument that blood-alcohol results should be banned as evidence because they were obtained more than four hours after the accident. He also denied an effort to have the results blocked on grounds they were not presented to a grand jury as evidence of recklessness. Hazelwood faces a felony charge of criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. The maximum penalty for conviction on all counts is seven years, three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. Johnstone said he would study defense attorneys' requests for information they say the Coast Guard is unwilling to turn over. The defense requested blood and urine tests administered to Hazelwood and members of the Exxon Valdez crew after the tanker struck a reef. The attorneys said the state should be restricted in the information it can use against Hazelwood if they do not have access to such material. Johnstone instructed attorneys for the Coast Guard and the state to compile a list of information that the Coast Guard provided to state prosecutors. He intends to consider that list in weighing what the defense claims is material the Coast Guard denied it but gave the state. Federal attorney R. Michael Underhill said the Coast Guard has been fair in its release of information, but said the government is unwilling to concede its right of federal sovereignty and privilege in handling requests for material in the state court.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Saw Two Sides of Africa During Trip
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II saw two starkly different sides of Africa during his sixth trip to the continent, from a thatched hut in Guinea-Bissau to a palace in Chad. Although he delivered 35 speeches in five countries of the Sahel region, two off-the-cuff remarks summed up the pope's look at today's Africa. ``Even here freedom is compromised'' by poverty, John Paul lamented after stopping along a dirt road in Cumura, Guinea-Bissau, and wandering unannounced into a tiny hut with no furniture, water or electricity. Days later, in Chad, the pope found himself in another world, greeted by President Hissene Habre in his brand new palace, complete with fountains. ``Good night, Mr. President,'' the pontiff said as he left. ``You have a magnificent palace.'' The average annual per capita income in Chad is about $150. The pope returned to Rome Thursday night after an eight-day, 8,600-mile journey through Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, Mali, Burkina Faso and Chad. Throughout the voyage, John Paul coupled his expressions of distress at the grinding poverty with warnings against materialism and unchecked wealth. He avoided a potentially embarrassing situation by deciding, for now at least, not to travel to the Ivory Coast to consecrate a huge basilica in Yamoussoukro that resembles St. Peter's in Rome. Some foreign prelates protested such a grandiose display in poor Africa, but President Felix Houphouet-Boigny says the church was built with his own funds. ``The pope has been invited by the president and the local church hierarchy (to consecrate the basilica) and now it's up to him whether to go on another trip,'' Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro said. ``Many different elements have to be taken into account.'' To offset any negative image, the Vatican hopes that a special institute for social development will be opened on the basilica grounds, he said. While the pope's trip was intended to give hope to millions of impoverished Africans, his message was just as often directed to leaders in Europe and North America: Don't forget Africa and the Third World. ``The great changes under way in Eastern Europe should not divert attention from the South, especially the African continent,'' he said in a speech to diplomats in Chad on Thursday. With the thaw in East-West relations, the Polish-born pope is especially determined to draw the world's attention to the persistent hardships in developing nations and the need for North-South cooperation, Navarro said. John Paul pleaded for solidarity with Africa during a ceremony in Ougadougou, Burkina Faso, marking the 10th anniversary of his first appeal on behalf of the Sahel. ``God has allowed me to renew the appeal,'' Navarro quoted him as telling local bishops later. ``If I hadn't done so, I wouldn't be able to die in peace.'' As the pope left Africa, planning was already under way for his seventh tour of the continent in September. He is scheduled to travel to Tanzania, Rwanda and Burundi. Until then, he offered the African faithful a simple prayer: ``I ask God,'' the pope said before departing Chad, ``to give all the people of Africa the strength of hope.''

DOC.HEAD: ANC's Future: Political Battles
With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: After 30 years of exile and mostly futile guerrilla warfare, the African National Congress will return to South Africa for political battles in which it is the overwhelming favorite. The ANC, which has exile headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia, was legalized today by President F.W. de Klerk in a move that instantly changed the country's political scene. The most powerful black group opposing the white-led government and its apartheid policies, the ANC has an estimated 15,000 members in exile and millions of black supporters in South Africa. Most observers believe it would win elections if the 28-million black majority were allowed to vote. Virtually all leading anti-apartheid groups in South Africa support the ANC. Its leadership is made up mostly of older, well-educated men such as the imprisoned Nelson Mandela, 71, and Oliver Tambo, the ANC's 71-year-old president, who is recovering in Sweden from a stroke. De Klerk said today that Mandela, the country's best-known black leader, will be freed shortly after more than 27 years in prison. He is serving a life sentence for launching the ANC's guerrilla campaign. Despite its aging leadership, the ANC's support is strongest among South Africa's black youths, many of whom who received their political education in repeated street clashes with the security forces. Most of the ANC's young backers are ardent supporters of the armed struggle. Until today, the organization had said its guerrilla campaign remained an important part of struggle to obtain black political rights, but de Klerk's announcements may prompt it to suspend violence. The armed struggle has slackened considerably in the past two years and poses no serious threat to the South African government. ``Looking at our situation realistically, we must admit that we do not have the capacity within our country to intensify the (armed) struggle in any meaningful way,'' ANC secretary-general Alfred Nzo said last month. Even prior to de Klerk's speech today at the opening of Parliament, the ANC appeared to be thrown off balance by the president's reforms. Its emphasis on the armed struggle and building support for sanctions against South Africa were generating little enthusiasm. Now, such policies are even less likely to win support. The ANC says it wants a one-person, one-vote democracy in South Africa, a system de Klerk opposes, saying it will lead to black domination of the 5 million whites. The ANC also says it envisions a mixed economy in South Africa, though it has a strong ideological preference for socialism. The ANC, founded in 1912, peacefully opposed the South African government until it was banned in 1960. A year later, Mandela launched its guerrilla campaign and most of the leadership was either arrested or went into exile. Seven senior leaders, including 77-year-old Walter Sisulu, were released last October and have been campaigning openly on behalf of the ANC. They continue to support the ANC's alliance with the South African Communist Party, another banned group that de Klerk legalized today. The membership of the two organizations overlap, and about half of the ANC's top 35 leaders are believed to be members of the Communist Party. De Klerk also legalized the Pan Africanist Congress, a smaller black group that wages a sporadic guerrilla campaign. The Pan Africanist Congress split from the ANC in 1959 over the question of white participation in the black political struggle. The ANC has some white members and believes in a multiracial quest for black political rights, while the Pan Africanist Congress believes blacks should be completely self-reliant.

DOC.HEAD: South Africa's Recent Political History
With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT:
Here is a brief chronology of South Africa's recent political history.
1912 _ The South African Native National Congress, forerunner of the African National Congress, is formed to fight for black political rights. 1948 _ The National Party government is elected and begins codifying apartheid legislation. 1955 _ A national People's Congress is broken up and 156 black leaders, including Nelson Mandela, are charged with treason. All are acquitted after a trial that lasts until 1961. March 21, 1960 _ The ANC and the Pan Africanist Congress call for peaceful protests against laws requiring blacks to have passses to enter white areas. Police shoot and kill 69 blacks at a rally in the Sharpeville township south of Johannesburg. April 1960 _ Parliament outlaws the ANC and the PAC. Both organizations launch guerrilla campaigns a year later. Aug. 5, 1962 _ Nelson Mandela is arrested and two years later is sentenced to life in prison for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. June 16, 1976 _ Thousands of black students demonstrate in the Soweto township outside Johannesburg, protesting a requirement that lessons be taught in the Afrikaans language. Police fatally shoot several students, touching off nationwide riots and boycotts that last more than a year and claim at least 575 black lives. Sept. 12, 1977 _ Steve Biko, founder of the Black Consciousness movement, dies in police detention. Oct. 19, 1977 _ The government bans 18 organizations and the two largest black newspapers. It also detains 47 black leaders. Aug. 20, 1983 _ The United Democratic Front is launched to organize opposition to a planned three-house Parliament that still excludes blacks. The Front quickly becomes the largest legal anti-apartheid group. September 1983 _ Riots break out in Sharpeville, touching off three years of widespread violence claiming at least 2,500 black lives. June 12, 1986 _ President P.W. Botha declares a nationwide state of emergency, giving authorities broad powers to crack down on opposition groups. More than 1,000 activists are detained predawn raids. More than 30,000 people, almost all black, have been held for varying lengths of time during the emergency. Feb. 24, 1988 _ The government effectively bans 17 opposition groups, including the United Democratic Front. July 5, 1989 _ Botha invites jailed ANC leader Nelson Mandela to the president's office for a conversation. Aug. 14, 1989 _ Botha resigns and is replaced by F.W. de Klerk. September 1989 _ De Klerk says he will allow peaceful anti-government protest. Demonstrations in all major cities are held without serious incident. Oct. 15, 1989 _ De Klerk frees six of Mandela's ANC colleagues imprisoned for more than 25 years, including Walter Sisulu. Dec. 13, 1989 _ De Klerk meets Mandela at the president's office. Feb. 2, 1990 _ De Klerk legalizes the ANC and dozens of other banned opposition groups and says Nelson Mandela soon will be freed unconditionally.

DOC.HEAD: Union Leader: Workers Unhappy with New Wage Rate
DOC.TEXT: A labor leader says workers at assembly plants in this border city are unhappy with a new one-year contract and wage agreement that ended a strike threat. Union and management officials at the mostly American-owned plants said Thursday the new accord brought average wage and benefits to roughly $2.30 an hour, a raise of about 15 percent. Union leaders demanding a 25 percent pay raise had threatened several times to strike after the contracts ran out at 53 of the city's approximately 80 maquiladora plants, in which mostly foreign-made components are assembled for export to their country of origin. A walkout could have idled as many as 60,000 workers at the plants and in related industries in this town across the border from Brownsville, Texas. Agapito Gonzalez Cavazos, who has led the Confederation of Mexican Workers in Matamoros for the past 40 years, said rank-and-file were disappointed in the compromise, which was reached in Mexico City without his participation. But he said the union would accept the accord. ``There is a restlessness among the workers, a malaise among the workers,'' Gonzalez said Thursday after learning of the accord. ``A worker who is not in agreement will become less productive. ``Fifteen percent to us means nothing because the cost of living in Matamoros is high, the most expensive place to live in Mexico,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Science Academy to Open Office in Beijing
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli scientific academy will open an office in Beijing next month, establishing the Jewish state's first presence in the Chinese capital, an Israeli diplomatic source said today. The liaison office of the Israeli Academy of Science and Humanities will be non-official, saod the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We think ... academic cooperation is a good start,'' the diplomat said. ``It is a nice way for two ancient civilizations to meet after 4,000 years.'' China and Israel do not have formal relations. Beijing has said it will not normalize ties until Israel returns land seized from Arab countries in 1967. China has good relations with Arab nations and the Palestine Liberation Organization. However, foreign ministers of China and Israel have met on several occasions, and China recently opened a travel office in Israel. There also have been published reports of Israeli arms sales to China. The source said the new office will concentrate on agricultural research.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Charge 3 in Conspiracy to Sell Military Planes to Iran
DOC.TEXT: Two Americans and an Israeli have been charged in a federal indictment with conspiring to arrange the sale to Iran of three Israeli-owned U.S.-made military cargo planes. The indictment filed Thursday in U.S. District Court stemmed from an undercover investigation by the U.S. Customs Service. The sale, in which Iran was to buy the aircraft for $12 million each, never went through. The men, allegedly middlemen in the deal, were charged with conspiring to cover up the true destination of the C-130E transports by submitting to the State Department false papers that said a Brazilian company would buy them. Prosecutors said the proposed sale violated the Arms Export Control Act in which the State Department must approve all transfers abroad of American-made military goods. It prohibits the sale of such goods to countries such as Iran that have supported acts of international terrorism. Assistant U.S. Attorney Baruch Weiss said he could not say whether Israel knew the planes were to be sold to Iran. The Brazilian company, which was not identified, allegedly was to receive $500,000 for providing the false information to the State Department, the indictment said. The defendants named in the indictment were Joseph O'Toole, 58, of Claremont, Calif.; Richard St. Francis, 40, of Fairfield, Conn.; and Ari Ben Menashe, an Israeli. All three were first arrested in April when the terms of the deal were finalized with an undercover Customs agent. The case was then presented to a grand jury, which returned the indictment, charging each with one count of conspiracy. Menashe has been jailed without bail since his arrest. The others are free on bond. Weiss said he could not give more information about the defendants. St. Francis, however, was identified in court papers as a vice president of the Connecticut office of Vienna, Va.-based TransCapital Corp. If convicted of conspiracy, the men face up to five years in jail and a $250,000 fine.

DOC.HEAD: Independent Counsel Sought to Investigate Pierce, HUD
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 3rd graf to replace dropped word `breaks'
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh wants an independent counsel to determine if former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. and his aides broke the law by steering federal rent subsidies to politically connected developers. Thornburgh, stressing that the special prosecutor law left him no other choice, said an independent counsel is needed to determine if Pierce and other former housing officials ``may have violated federal criminal law'' in the way they chose developers to participate in the moderate rehabilitation program between 1984 and 1988. The Department of Housing and Urban Development program provides rent subsidies and lucrative tax breaks to developers who perform a moderate amount of rehabilitation on low-income housing units. Thornburgh's formal application to a special court cited reports of a ``widespread perception among developers'' and local officials that ``funds were being disbursed in disproportionate amounts to projects backed by prominent Republicans acting as consultants or by former HUD officials.'' But the attorney general said he ``found no reasonable grounds to believe that further investigation is warranted'' of allegations that Pierce lied during congressional testimony when questioned last May about political favoritism in the awarding of HUD grants. Jack Kemp, who succeeded Pierce at HUD at the start of the Bush administration, promised to cooperate with the investigation. ``This is a tragic situation for all involved,'' Kemp said in a statement. ``However, the department will provide whatever cooperation and assistance is required for full and fair disposition of this matter.'' Robert Plotkin, one of Pierce's lawyers, said, ``We continue to believe that Mr. Pierce has not violated any federal laws and we are confident that, at the conclusion of an independent counsel investigation, that will be determined.'' The attorney general, an outspoken critic of the special prosecutor law, made it plain that his decision to seek court appointment of an independent counsel was forced upon him by the statute. Thornburgh said the Justice Department's preliminary inquiry into the allegations, which began Dec. 4, was hindered by the department's inability under the law to conduct grand jury proceedings or grant immunity to witnesses. Despite a review of ``voluminous information'' compiled by the HUD inspector general and the House subcommittee and interviews with department officials, ``a determination that no further investigation is warranted is virtually foreclosed,'' Thornburgh said. Any decision to drop the matter ``is made especially difficult by the breadth of the allegations and the fact that a number of figures central to the alleged conspiracy, including Secretary Pierce and his former executive assistant, Deborah Dean, have declined to be interviewed,'' Thornburgh said. Thornburgh disclosed that Pierce provided written answers to questions submitted to him by the Justice Department's public integrity section. The special prosecutor law virtually assures that an independent counsel will be appointed by a special three-judge panel of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The court's Special Division customarily acts within weeks of receiving requests by the attorney general. The independent counsel law was triggered Nov. 2 when 19 Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee formally asked Thornburgh to consider appointing an independent counsel to investigate allegations of political favoritism at HUD uncovered in congressional hearings last year. The attorney general said the questions asked by the lawmakers and Pierce's answers were too ambiguous to sustain any charge of perjury. Pierce's statement to a House Government Operations subcommittee that he did not have a ``hands on'' involvement in running the moderate rehabilitation program is ``readily susceptible to countless interpretations,'' Thornburgh said. Thornburgh said there was also no basis to investigate the other allegation of perjury put forth by House Democrats. Pierce's statement that he ``did not give Miss Dean permission to say that I wanted certain programs'' is subject to several interpretations not unfavorable to the former secretary, Thornburgh said. Ms. Dean's attorney, Joseph diGenova, declined to comment on the development. She was one of three former aides to Pierce who invoked the Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination and refused to testify before the House subcommittee hearings. Pierce, after testifying last spring, declined to answer further questions when called back last fall. He, too, invoked the Fifth Amendment. Thornburgh's decision was hailed by Democrats who spearheaded the original request for a Justice Department review of the case. Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., who chaired the subcommittee hearings, said he welcomed the decision, saying ``an independent counsel, is in the best position to fully investigate and resolve questions of possible criminal wrongdoing.''

DOC.HEAD: Military Talks With People's Front in Baku
DOC.TEXT: Soviet military commanders and Azerbaijani People's Front leaders met for their first direct peace talks, bypassing local government and Communist Party officials, People's Front leaders said today. In Riga, Latvia, other representatives of the Azerbaijani People's Front planned to start face-to-face negotiations with leaders of the Armenian People's Front, with Baltic officials serving as mediators. In Baku, Tofik Gosymov, one of 14 directors of the Azerbaijani People's Front, told reporters he had demanded the immediate withdrawal of the soldiers who entered Baku on Jan. 20 after days of violent ethnic unrest in which scores of Armenians were chased from their homes and beaten by Azerbaijani mobs. At least 214 died and more than 500 were injured in clashes between citizens and Soviet soldiers, according to the latest figures reported today. The two neighboring southern republics have been engaged in a decades-old territorial dispute, largely focusing on the Armenian enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh, which is located inside Azerbaijani territory. Armenians are mostly Christian; the Azerbaijanis are predominantly Shiite Moslem. The peace talks indicate the growing prominence of people's fronts, the unofficial, grass-roots organizations that have sprung up in the Soviet Union, especially in republics seeking greater autonomy from Moscow. Thursday's one-hour talks, at the Azerbaijani Interior Ministry, entirely bypassed the Azerbaijan Communist Party and the Caucasus republic's government, which has been sharply criticized for failing to control the violence. The negotiations were organized by Lev Ponamarev, of the Russian People's Front. There will be no further talks unless the Kremlin agrees to withdraw its 17,000 soldiers from Baku, Gosymov said. ``If the question of the removal of the soldiers is not solved, we won't negotiate with them and we won't cooperate,'' he said. Gosymov said Lt. Gen. Vladimir S. Dubinyak, the military commandant, promised to transmit the demand to Moscow. The People's Front also demanded release of members arrested by the military and an explanation of what they said were military assaults on the People's Front headquarters. Dubinyak, accompanied by his assistant for political affairs, Maj. Gen. Anatoly I. Kirilyuk, and an official of the national Interior Ministry, said those issues could only be decided in Moscow, Gosymov reported. He also said the military expressed interest in leaving Baku for its own reasons. Gosymov said the People's Front needed at least a schedule for withdrawal of the soldiers to bring the situation in Baku back to normal. With such a schedule, ``We can appeal to the people to go back to work and they will, 100 percent,'' he said. Soviet officials say more than 80 percent of Baku's workforce is back on the job, but the People's Front claims the figure is much lower. The talks in Riga were organized by the people's fronts of the three Baltic republics. Armenian and Azerbaijani delegations appeared willing to try to iron out their problems at the negotiating table. But Baltic mediators cautioned that it could take two to three months to achieve concrete results. ``We believe the exchange of views which will take place here will serve to create better understanding of the positions of both sides, and to help normalize the situation and find a way to resolve our problems,'' Armenian delegate Ashot Manucharian told The Associated Press. Dainis Ivans, chairman of the Latvian People's Front, said the Baltic people's fronts want to share their strategies for achieving independence and democracy, which have won greater freedom from Moscow in a peaceful way, while the Caucasus has been engulfed in violence. Khikmet Khazhidzade said he and his fellow Azerbaijani negotiator, Sabit Bagirov, had found a meeting with the Baltic leaders very constructive. The Armenians and the Azerbaijanis agreed to discuss the presence of Soviet troops, the refugee problem and other humanitarian issues related to their conflict. But Khazhidzade stressed that final resolution of the dispute without a decision on the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh is impossible. Nagorno-Karabakh is not on the agenda, but the Baltic mediators say they expect the thorny territorial issue to come up early in the talks.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Dies From Heart Attack While Trying to Revive Wife
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `He said, to CORRECT spelling of resuscitation.
DOC.TEXT: A doctor apparently trying to revive his wife who was suffering a fatal asthma attack collapsed and died of a heart attack. Paramedics found Betty Wrenn, 66, dead and her husband, Frank Wrenn, 67, slumped over her in cardiac arrest on the floor of their home Thursday, said Parks Evans, deputy coroner of Greenville County. Wrenn was pronounced dead at Greenville Memorial Hospital a half-hour later, Evans said. He said Wrenn was apparently trying to administer cardiopulmonary resuscitation to his wife when he collapsed. The two were childhood sweethearts. ``It was a wonderful way to go for them,'' said Mrs. Wrenn's sister, Mary S. McConnell. ``But it's just terrible on the rest of us.'' An expert in emergency medicine, Wrenn had served on the staff of the Greenville Hospital System since 1955 until his retirement in July, and was an examiner for the American Board of Neurological Surgeons. A past president of the American Association of Neurosurgeons, Wrenn was internationally known in his field.

DOC.HEAD: Tornadoes, High Wind Cause Damage As Storm System Crosses State
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to UPDATE with death of utility worker. Picks up 2nd graf, `One tornado...'. DELETES redundant last graf.
DOC.TEXT: At least four tornadoes were reported in southeastern Texas and severe storms moved across a large area of the state, triggering flash floods and tumbling mobile homes with winds up to 85 mph. No injuries were reported in the storms, but a utility lineman working to restore power in Austin died early today after grabbing a power line as he slipped while on a pole, authorities said. One tornado ripped through the Meadowbrook Trailer Park in Humble, outside Houston, Thursday night. It overturned eight trailer but caused no injuries, said Nancy Bivens, a police dispatcher. ``All at once the trailer started shaking and she said, `C'mon, the car port's going,''' said Floyd Miller, who was inside his trailer with his wife, Karen. ``And I thought, `How could it? It's anchored.''' ``Then, I looked and the patio was gone,'' Mrs. Miller said. Weather watchers reported tornadoes in three other counties north of Houston. About 18,000 homes were without power in north Houston late Thursday, and strong winds and heavy rain delayed flights at Houston Hobby Airport. The storm activity was triggered by the combination of an upper-level storm system and the northward flow of moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, the weather service said. Flash flooding and power failures were reported in Dallas as heavy rainfall snarled rush hour traffic and closed numerous streets. An estimated 6,300 utility customers lost power in Fort Worth. Full power was expected to be restored today, said TU Electric spokesman George Hedrick. In Austin, the storm tore into the University of Texas' communications building and knocked out power to some areas. At Cotulla, about 70 miles southwest of San Antonio, winds of at least 85 mph ripped away roofs and business awnings, said City Secretary Glenda Janek.

DOC.HEAD: President: Moynihan Proposal on Social Security Dead
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he believes a Democratic proposal to cut Social Security taxes is dead, and he rules out any major tax revision despite charges that middle-income families pay a greater share than do their rich neighbors. ``Well, in a world where you were starting over maybe we could design a better tax system, but I don't want to open up the entire tax system at this point,'' Bush said Thursday, in an interview published in today's Wall Street Journal. Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan had proposed rolling back Social Security taxes, charging that the surplus in the Social Security trust fund was being used to mask the size of the federal budget deficit. Asked about the proposal's chances, Bush said, ``I hope it's dead, and I think it is. ... After talking to the guys that are wrestling with the problem on the administration's behalf, none of us has a feeling there's a great thrust behind it anymore.'' Bush said there is no need to take extraordinary measures to reduce the budget deficit, because ``it isn't that long before the budget is in balance'' thanks to Gramm-Rudman reductions. On other matters, Bush reiterated his support of Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. ``I do feel that after (the summit at) Malta I had a better feel for him as an individual and what he's trying to do. ... I think that he has done more in a short period of time for glasnost and reform than anybody in this room would have ever predicted.'' Still, he said, progress on arms control does not depend on Gorbachev's continuing to hold power. ``I don't think it depends on one man. I think we've got a policy, a program, and I think that's established,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Hakim Says Iran Arms Figures Threaten Him Over Remaining Payments
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf, He pleaded, to CORRECT date of guilty plea to Nov. 21
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Iran-Contra middleman Albert Hakim, placed on two years' probation and fined $5,000, says he is being threatened by intermediaries who never received payments in the uproar following public exposure of the secret arms sales to Iran. The Iranian-born businessman said in court papers released Thursday that he has been impoverished by the Iran-Contra affair. He had to defend himself in civil suits stemming from the scandal and hire criminal defense lawyers. He pleaded guilty Nov. 21 to helping supplement former White House aide Oliver North's income by allowing business partner Richard Secord to pay for a security system at North's home. Hakim told Congress in 1987 that he promised to pay ``baksheesh'' to Iranian intermediaries who helped open a new channel of communication in 1986 in the Reagan administration's efforts to free hostages held in Lebanon. ``These intermediaries include individuals both inside and outside of Iran, a number of whom can only be described as dangerous,'' Hakim's lawyers said in the court papers. ``Mr. Hakim ... has been threatened on a number of occasions if these obligations are not met.'' officials who understood that money for the payments would come from theU.S. proceeds of earlier arms sales to Iran. The Iranians had been charged exorbitant prices in those sales. He set up a $2 million reserve fund for the payments at the Enterprise, the maze of offshore companies Hakim created to handle money in the Iran-Contra affair. The Iran initiative was exposed before the payments could be made and Hakim has been left ``holding the bag,'' his lawyers said in the court filing. The $2 million reserve was part of $7.8 million frozen by the Swiss, at the request of the United States, when the Iran-Contra affair erupted. Interest on the money has raised the total to $9 million. Hakim has forsworn any claim to $7.3 million of the money and he says he is unlikely to see any of the remainder. ``It is to him personally that the Iranian intermediaries even today are pressing Mr. Hakim for payment,'' Hakim's lawyers said. Hakim will be able to file a claim for the $1.7 million, but two Swiss-based lawyers who work with him, Willard Zucker and Philippe Neyroud, also are claiming part of the money. Hakim says whatever he recovers won't be enough to satisfy ``enormous debts'' arising from the affair, which he says he participated in only after he was assured every aspect had been authorized by then-President Reagan. North, Secord and former national security adviser John Poindexter have ``been fortunate to belong to a community of military officers and others who have been able to offer them considerable assistance,'' Hakim's lawyers said in court papers. But Hakim and his family ``have shouldered the burdens of this affair essentially alone.''

DOC.HEAD: Bulgaria's Communists Choose a New Reformist Leader
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party today appointed a new leader who has criticized hard-liners and indicated he would speed the pace of democratic reforms sought by the nation's emerging opposition movement. Alexander Lilov, taking power following a secret party session that ousted top Old Guard leaders, has promised to overhaul his party before multiparty elections, scheduled for May. Outgoing party boss Petar Mladenov will remain as state president. Bowing to demands for reform, he had proposed that the head of the Communist Party and the head of state be separated. The changes, announced by the party, were the latest since Mladenov replaced Todor Zhivkov, the hard-line Communist leader whose 35-year rule ended on Nov. 10, and promised elections and other democratic reforms. During the secret party session, which ended early today, the party also cut the size of its Politburo and Central Committee. Those ousted included Premier Georgi Atanassov, a holdover from the Zhivkov era. The Central Committee was renamed as the party's Supreme Council. Atanassov and his 22-member Cabinet resigned Thursday following sharp criticism during the emergency party congress for failing to solve mounting labor unrest in Bulgaria. The Cabinet will serve until Saturday, when Parliament will meet to accept the resignation, the state news agency BTA said. The resignation was necessary ``to form a Cabinet on a broad national basis,'' BTA said. The Communists have made a vague proposal for an interim government that would includ figures from the nation's emerging pro-democracy opposition. But the opposition has so far been reluctant to accept the offer until the Communists say how much power opposition leaders will get. Compared with Communists in neighboring countries, who have ceded power to opposition groups after a wave of democratic reforms last year, Bulgarian Communists have given up relatively little power and faced a relatively weak though growing opposition. After his unanimous election by the Supreme Council, Lilov told the delegates that the party, increasingly divided between hard-liners and reformers, will have to make changes before the election. Lilov, the party ideologist through the 1970s who was shunted aside by Zhivkov about six years ago, directly criticized Atanassov on Wednesday and told the party congress that ``we are lagging behind.'' ``If the programs are not competent and realistic, we will lose,'' he said. The Supreme Council also elected Mladenov, Lilov and two other top party figures _ Andrei Lukanov, a possible candidate to be the new premier, and Defense Minister Dobri Dzhurov _ to a Presidium that will essentially replace the Politburo under the new party structure. There will likely be other members, but the panel will be smaller than the former Politburo. The new 153-member Supreme Council is less than half the size of the Central Committee it replaces. The new council includes some Communists who have called for radical internal changes, including at least three members of the Alternative Socialist Alliance. A leader of that reform faction had said Thursday it intended to split with the party and form its own socialist party. Not elected to the council were Politburo member Mincho Yovchev, Prosecutor Vassil Mruchkov, alternate Politburo member Pantelei Pachov and six of the nine regional party secretaries. The interior minister and one of his deputies were the only representatives of the security forces on the council, and there were five members of the armed forces. Most members are technocrats, managers and other economic leaders. The delegates also created a 51-member commission on party ethics and a 31-member Central Finance Commission. Zhivkov, 78, has been arrested on charges of abuse of office and inciting ethnic hostility during his rule.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Politburo Member Expelled from Communist Party for Ethics Violation
With PM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party has expelled former candidate Politburo member Yuri F. Solovyov for violating party ethics by purchasing a Mercedes-Benz for non-convertible rubles, Tass and a party official said today. The harsh action against a die-hard Communist comes just three days before a critical meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee, where discussion of a new party platform is expected to bring a heated debate between progressives and hard-lieners. Solovyov is still a member of the powerful Central Committee, so his expulsion must be confirmed when it meets on Monday and Tuesday, said Vladimir Kiryanov of the Leningrad party's press office. He confirmed that Solovyov was accused of violating rules on car purchases. If his ouster is upheld, Solovyov will lose his pension and numerous other privileges, Kiryanov said. The expulsion was another humiliation for Solovyov, the former hard-line Leningrad party chief who was defeated during the spring in the vote for parliament despite having no opposition. More than 50 percent of the voters crossed his lone name off the ballot. Solovyov also was a candidate, or non-voting, member of the party's ruling Politburo in the Kremlin until being demoted last summer. He had been criticized for resisting the reforms of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The Tass report implied that Solovyov abused his position to obtain the vehicle, but Kiryanov refused to elaborate. Top Communists have enjoyed special privileges like foreign cars and luxury food allotments for decades. Former Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev, now blamed for economic stagnation and corruption during his tenure, was known for his love of fancy Western cars. The Tass article implied that others in the generally conservative Leningrad party leadership might be threatened. It said the local prosecutor had been asked to investigate whether other Communist leaders bought their cars in violation of the law. Neither Tass nor Kiryanov explained the precise violation. Solovyov is one of many hard-liners based in Leningrad. His replacement as Leningrad party chief, Boris Gidaspov, is considered one of the leading hard-liners in the Soviet Union. Solovyov was expelled at an emergency meeting of the Leningrad party committee on Thursday, the day after the sensational Leningrad TV program 600 Seconds broadcast a report showing his name on an auto registration list. Journalist Alexander Nevzorov told viewers it had become easy to buy a Mercedes-Benz 280-S automobile for 9,780 rubles. Rubles are worthless on the international market, so such a statement implies that the Soviet government took rubles from the buyers and paid for the cars from its scarce store of foreign currency. Nevzorov noted in the broadcast that 9,780 rubles is lower even than the state price for a Soviet-made Volga, editor Alexander Borisoglebsky confirmed today. Shortages require normal would-be buyers to wait years or pay a vastly higher black-market price. Privileged people in the Soviet Union, however, can skip to the head of the line.

DOC.HEAD: Cult Members Describe Shootings in Videotapes
DOC.TEXT: Before a family of five was shot to death last April, cult leader Jeffrey Don Lundgren invited them to his farm for their last meal, according to a report published today. Citing videotaped statements two cult members gave federal authorities, today's editions of The Plain Dealer said Dennis Avery, his wife, Cheryl, and their three daughters were led one by one inside a barn, where they were gagged, tied and shot. Several cult members carefully covered the bodies with lime and stone and then heaped tons of trash on a common grave while Lundgren, his wife and son retrieved Averys' belongings from a nearby motel, the newspaper said. The descriptions of what authorities have called a religious sacrifice were among videotaped statements that federal authorities in Missouri and California took from six cult members indicted in the killings of the Avery family. Lundgren, a defrocked lay minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Chirst Latter Day Saints, reportedly told his followers that the family had to be sacrificed so the cult could be cleansed spiritually and leave for the wilderness to prepare for the second coming of Christ. The bodies of the Avery family were found early last month on the farm in Kirtland, 30 miles east of Cleveland. In the taped statements, Lundgren's wife, Alice E. Lundgren, 38, and cult members Susan Luff, 31, Tonya J. Patrick, 33, and her husband, Dennis S. Patrick, 35, said they feared for their lives and dared not defy Lundgren, the newspaper said. They said they lied to family and friends about their lives with Lundgren, a leader they called ``prophet'' and ``father.'' The four said they did not take part in the killings and found out about them later. But two other cult members, Ronald B. Luff and Richard E. Brand, described the killings in statements to officers of the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms in Kansas City, the newspaper said. Thirteen people have been arrested in the case. Charges filed against them range from aggravated murder to kidnapping. The day after the April 17 shootings, 20 FBI agents and Kirtland policemen who had been monitoring the cult's activities came to the farm, questioning each of the cult members, who said they were not being held against their will. That night, the cult members packed and left for West Virginia and later went to Missouri before the cult split up. The bodies were not found until months later. Lawyers for 13 defendants in the case were entitled to see the statements given to the federal agents. The tapes were shown Wednesday to defense lawyers.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Leader Warns Pakistan on Kashmir
DOC.NOTE: Eds: One name for Jagmohan is cq
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh was quoted today as warning Pakistan that India is ready to fight if necessary over Kashmir, where two weeks of secessionist violence have left at least 73 people dead. Moslem militants today shot and killed a Hindu businessman in Indian-controlled Kashmir. It was the first reported attack on a Hindu civilian since Islamic militants took to the streets in the northern area bordering Pakistan. In his remarks today, Singh said if Pakistan wants a confrontation over Kashmir, the ``Indian people and army are ready to give a befitting reply,'' the United News of India news agency reported. Singh's statements, made at a state government function in the eastern city of Calcutta, were the prime minister's first public remarks on possible hostilities between the countries. India and Pakistan have gone to war three times since they were partitioned in 1947 upon gaining independence from Britain. Two wars have been over Kashmir, a region also claimed by Moslem-dominated Pakistan. India, where Hindus predominated, accuses Pakistan of arming the separatists. Pakistan denies the charge and accuses India of trying to suppress the independence movement. Police today set up road blocks at major intersections in the northern city of Srinagar on the Moslem sabbath, fearing more of the separatist violence, witnesses said. Police said militants and paramilitary federal troops exchanged gunfire, but no one was injured. A police official, Gov. Jagmohan, said the Hindu businessman, Satish Tikku, was shot in the head by two unidentified gunmen at his home in Srinagar. Police sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Tikku probably was killed because the militants suspected him of being a police informer _ not because he was a Hindu. But Jagmohan ordered increased security in the predominantly Hindu Jammu region of Jammu-Kashmir state to prevent retaliatory attacks on Moslems, a government source said, also speaking on condition of anonymity. The rest of the state is mainly Moslem. An around-the-clock curfew was lifted for only six hours today, compared with 12 hours earlier in the week. The daily curfew was imposed Jan. 20 when Moslem militants took to streets and clashed with police. The militants want to free this part of Kashmir from Indian rule and create an independent state or become part of Moslem-dominated Pakistan. Between Jan. 20 and Jan. 25, at least 72 people, mostly demonstrators, were killed in battles with security forces. Before today's attack, the government had said there was little violence since then. Paramilitary troops and state policemen today partially blocked roads with steel drums and checked passing vehicles, the witnesses said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Each barrier was backed by sandbagged bunkers manned by 11 policemen, they said. Mass prayers are held at mosques on the Moslem sabbath, and they have ignited protests in the past. Reporters for The Associated Press and Agence France-Presse, the French news agency, received expulsion orders Thursday night, but it was not clear when or how those orders would be enforced.

DOC.HEAD: Factory Orders Rose 1.9 Percent in December
DOC.TEXT: Orders to U.S. factories for manufactured goods rose 1.9 percent in December and closed out the year up 6.4 percent, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and non-durable manufactured goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $244.2 billion in the final month of 1989 after rising 2.4 percent in November. The increase put orders for the year at $2.83 trillion after a 9.7 percent increase in 1988, the largest since 1983. Durable goods were up 5.9 percent for the year, following gains of 11 percent in 1988 and 7.6 percent in 1987. For much of the year, Federal Reserve interest rate policies held back orders for durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years _ because many of those goods are financed through loans. But durable goods orders started to perk up late this fall and jumped 4.8 percent in November and 3.2 percent in December. After the December report, analysts said it appeared the manufacturing sector of the economy was stabilizing. But the manufacturing sluggishness through much of 1989 was reflected in the report's figures for the entire year: While durable goods orders were up 5.9 percent to $1.52 trillion, they advanced at their slowest pace since a 0.4 percent gain in 1986. In addition to new orders, the Commerce Department said shipments of manufactured goods fell 0.5 percent in December to $231.8 billion, while inventories dropped 0.4 percent to $371.5 billion. If inventories increase without a corresonding gain in new orders, it could signal produciton cutbacks in the future as factories attempt to get rid of goods on shelves and back lots. Orders for durable goods rose 3.2 percent in December to $134.4 billion, paced by transportation equipment which was up 11.2 percent to $40.9 billion. Large increases in aircraft, shipbuilding and tanks more than offset a decline in motor vehicles, the department said. Without the transportation category, orders would have edged up 0.2 percent. Electrical machinery orders increased 5 percent to $22.7 billion, offsetting a decline of 4.7 percent in non-electical machinery to $21.6 billion. Primary metals orders were down 3.8 percent to $10.8 billion. The often-volatile defense orders were off 11.6 percent to $9.96 billion. Excluding defense, orders would have been up 2.5 percent. Non-durable orders were up 0.3 percent to $109.9 billion, led by a large increase in petroleum products. In the key category of non-defense capital goods, a barometer of business investment plants, orders rose 18 percent in December to $45.9 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Wet Weekend Ahead for Much of Nation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with traffic problems in Midwest, Utah ice and fatalities, picking up at the 7th graf pvs, `The area...'.
DOC.TEXT: Freezing rain and snow fell in parts of the Plains, Mississippi Valley, Great Lakes region and Midwest today as an arctic air mass moved south with plummeting temperatures. Heavy snow was expected today in Colorado, Kansas and Missouri, and showers extended across the upper Ohio Valley and the lower Great Lakes. Freezing rain and snow slowed commuters this morning across much of Michigan and parts of northern Indiana and northern Illinois. Up to 13 cars were involved in fender-bender accidents on Chicago's Lake Shore Drive before dawn, forcing police to close southbound lanes briefly. In Texas on Thursday, at least four tornadoes touched down outside Houston. Severe storms moved across a large area of the state, triggering flash floods and tumbling mobile homes with wind up to 85 mph at Cotulla, about 70 miles southwest of San Antonio. The Dallas-Fort Worth area received nearly 3 inches of rain during the 24 hours ending at noon Thursday. Some Dallas streets were closed by flooding. The Pacific Northwest looked for coastal rain and inland snow today. On Thursday, Idaho's Grand Targhee ski resort received 10 inches of snow. Farther south, snow fell in the mountains of Nevada, Utah and northern Arizona. Light snow that fell Thursday in Utah formed sheets of ice after dusk, causing accidents along the Wasatch Front in the Salt Lake City area. The weather was considered a possible factor in two traffic deaths. The area around the nation's capital was due for increasing cloudiness and rain by day's end and colder temperatures for the weekend. North Dakota chattered through wind chills as cold as 40 below zero on Thursday. Strong winds also lashed Montana, where Glasgow weathered a wind chill reading of minus 57. Record highs Thursday were reported in Bluefiled, W.Va., with 71 degrees; Cape Hatteras, N.C., 73; St. Peterburg, Fla., 84; and Tampa, Fla., 85. January was the wettest on record for Eugene, Ore., with 15.09 inches of precipitation. Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., which endured a record 46.8 inches of snow in November and a record cold December, enjoyed a January that averaged more than 10 degrees above normal and was free of subzero cold. At 5 a.m. EST today, however, the mercury was at zero under cloudy skies. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 35 below zero at Plentywood Mont. The high was 86 degress in Fort Myers and Naples, Fla.
