DOC.HEAD: Punxsutawney Phil Doesn't Spot Shadow, Means Early Spring
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts one graf after 6th, `I've always...'. to ADD other forecasting groundhogs. Picks up 7th graf, `Legend has...'. INSERTS one graf after 16th graf, `The 14...'. to ADD groundhog hat worn by handler. Picks up 17th graf, `Every other...'. ADDS three grafs with details on other groundhogs.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PUNX1
DOC.TEXT: Punxsutawney Phil, America's premier groundhog, emerged from his burrow today and indicated in ``unmistakable groundhogese'' that he had failed to spot his shadow, a sure sign spring is just around the corner, according to Phil's followers. ``He stood proud, tall and confident, surveyed the throng of loyal followers, peered skyward toward the east and then fixed his eyes groundward,'' said county judge Edwin Snyder. He is a member of the Punxsutawney Groundhog Club's exclusive Inner Circle, which each year decides in advance whether Phil will ``see'' his shadow. Snyder said Phil ``turned to Groundhog President Jim Means and signaled to him in unmistakable groundhogese, `There is no shadow today.''' The squirming, 10-pound woodchuck was pulled from his man-made burrow atop Gobbler's Knob at sunrise, 7:27 a.m. Means held the groundhog up to his ear to hear the once-a-year prediction, then lifted him toward Snyder. The approximately 1,500 people who had gathered under cloudy skies and in light rain cheered as Phil's forecast was announced. ``I've always wanted to come to this event ever since I was a kid,'' said Peter Teicher, 49, of Los Angeles. ``I'm really excited. I couldn't sleep last night. It's a real thrill.'' Other prognasticating groundhogs around the country followed Phil's lead and also failed to see their shadows. Legend has it that if the famous groundhog sees his shadow when he emerges from his bungalow at sunrise on Feb. 2, there will be six more weeks of winter. If he doesn't, spring is supposedly just around the corner. ``You know and I know that Feb. 2 is too darn early to expect spring to come,'' said Tim Clark, executive editor of The Old Farmer's Almanac. But the two-legged variety of weather forecasters are still curious about what Phil has to say on Groundhog Day. ``I definitely do watch to see what he does. I didn't say I believe it. I say I watch it,'' said Albert Peterlin, a hydrologist for the National Weather Service in Harrisburg. ``This has a little bit of history and fact,'' he said. ``Animals respond to temperature and environment as it occurs.'' Before today, Phil had predicted an early spring only nine times since 1887, when German-born farmers initiated the yearly event in this small western Pennsylvania town. The farmers borrowed from the legend of Candlemas, a Christian holiday celebrating the first time the infant Jesus was taken to the temple. An old Scottish couplet claims, ``If Candlemas be fair, there'll be two winters in the year.'' Groundhogs, part of the rodent family, usually hibernate by December and stay underground until April or so, but sometimes venture out early if the weather is mild. ``Phil's never been wrong,'' boasted Means, 66. The 14 local businessmen who comprise the Inner Circle decide well in advance what Phil's forecast will be. Group members stages several rehearsals before Groundhog Day, when they don top hats and tails for the event. Phil's handler, Bud Dunkel, sported a fake fur hat resembling a groundhog. Every other day of the year, Phil lives at his heated, air-conditioned hutch at the local library with two other groundhogs, Philomena and Barney. As far as The Old Farmer's Almanac is concerned, February _ at least around Punxsutawney _ will be extremely cold and snowy followed by similar weather in early March. The National Weather Service is calling for a warmer than usual February, but a colder than usual March and April. ``If I were to give you the scientific point of view, I think it would be cold for the rest of this winter,'' said meteorologist Victor Nouhan. ``Of course, that's worth a grain of salt.'' Groundhog Octorara Orphie also saw no shadow in central Pennsylvania's Quarryville. And neither did West Virginia's Concord Charlie as he was ``wandering around campus to see if any flowers are up,'' said Tom Bone, public information director for Concord College in Athens. Ditto for French Creek Freddie at the French Creek Wildlife Preserve in Upshur County in West Virginia and General Lee at the Yellow River Game Ranch in Lilburn, Ga. The newest addition to the groundhog lineup, Little Hog, made his debut at the Indianapolis Zoo with fans joining in a rousing chorus of ``You Are My Sunshine'' on kazoos. But there was no sunshine and no shadow there.

DOC.HEAD: Olive Oil Linked to Lower Blood Pressure, Blood Sugar
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 5th graf pvs, `But olive...', to raise reference to researchers' call for more study, add additional comment by Grundy. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Saturated fats...'. DELETES 16-18th grafs pvs, bgng `I don't..., now redundant, picking up at last graf.
DOC.TEXT: Olive oil, a food already anointed with cholesterol-lowering charisma in a health-conscious age, appears to also lower blood pressure and blood sugar, say doctors who studied almost 5,000 Italians. By contrast, consumption of butter and other saturated fats was found to be associated with higher blood cholesterol, blood pressure and blood sugar, the doctors reported in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. ``The message is not new, in a sense,'' said the lead researcher, Dr. Marizio Trevisan, associate professor in medicine at the State University of New York at Buffalo. Doctors have been telling people that a diet low in saturated fats will help lower the risk of developing heart disease, he noted. But olive oil, a form of unsaturated fat with proven cholesterol-lowering ability, may have ``an overall impact on coronary risk that is much stronger than we expected,'' Trevisan said in a telephone interview Thursday. ``I don't want to come out as a salesman for olive oil,'' Trevisan cautioned. ``I think the results are exciting and interesting, but ... a number of studies need to be done.'' Dr. Scott M. Grundy, director of the Center for Human Nutrition at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical School in Dallas, agreed in calling for further research to confirm the findings. ``I'm very loath to draw conclusions from epidemiology (population studies), especially when there's not a broad base of epidemiological data,'' Grundy said in a telephone interview. Grundy added: ``The study provides a consistency with what's already known in terms of lipids (fatty substances in the blood), and that's reassuring. It is of interest that other risk factors seem to be affected.'' Saturated fats, derived largely from meat, dairy products, and coconut and palm oils, are usually solid at room temperature. Polyunsaturated fats, made from vegetable products, usually are liquid at room temperature. The polyunsaturates _ like the monounsaturates, including olive oil _ are blood-cholesterol reducers and help protect the body against heart disease. Researchers analyzed data on 4,903 healthy Italian men and women ages 20 to 59 in a study exploring traits linked to atherosclerosis, a thickening of the arteries due to a buildup of fatty deposits, which causes more deaths in the United States than any other condition. The study was conducted at nine medical centers throughout Italy. People were questioned about their eating habits and were tested for levels of blood cholesterol, blood pressure and blood sugar. Levels of saturated fat consumption were found to differ up to 40 percent, with the lowest levels in the south, where people eat a diet high in olive oil, vegetables and starches traditional to the Mediterranean. In northern Italy, people consume more butter and other animal fats. In both sexes, higher consumption of butter and margarine was associated with significantly higher levels of blood sugar, increased blood pressure and increased blood-cholesterol levels, the study said, though the link was statistically significant only in men. Whether elevated blood sugar levels play a role in heart disease is unclear and is under intensive study, Trevisan said. Diabetes, in which the body fails to process blood sugar properly, is known to be linked with heart disease, but subjects in the Italian study all had blood-sugar levels in the normal range, rather than in the diabetic range. Italians who consumed more olive oil had significantly lower levels of systolic blood pressure (pressure during the heart's contraction), and of blood sugar and blood cholesterol, researchers said. The Italian study found that diets high in other polyunsaturated oils _ corn oil, soybean oil, sunflower oil and mixed vegetable oil _ were linked significantly to lower cholesterol and blood-sugar levels in both sexes.

DOC.HEAD: Text of ANC Statement on South Africa, ^With South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following is the text of an African National Congress statement reacting to measures announced by South Africa's president, F.W. de Klerk, on Friday:

Today, Pretoria's President F.W. de Klerk made important announcements that go a long way toward creating a climate conducive to negotiations. We welcome the lifting of the ban on the ANC and other organizations. We also welcome other positive measures announced by F.W. de Klerk, such as the suspension of the death sentence, the release of some political prisoners, the ending of media restrictions and the lifting of restrictions on ex-detainees. We are, however, greatly concerned that the Pretoria regime has taken the decision that some political prisoners will not be released, that the state of emergency is not lifted in its entirety and that the practice of detention without trial will continue. These decisions subtract rather than add to the process of creating the proper political climate. They must be reviewed and changed without delay. We urge the Pretoria regime to release Nelson Mandela without further delay. Questions concerning his personal security cannot be and are not the exclusive concern of the South African regime. They must be decided together with his organization, the ANC. The ANC will take urgent measures to review the new situation that has emerged, to determine the steps we have to take to move our country further forward toward finally ending the apartheid system. This will include a process of consultation with the mass democratic movement of our country and all other anti-apartheid forces. The normalization of relations between South Africa and the rest of the world must continue to depend on ending the apartheid system. We therefore expect that no country committed to ending white-minority domination in South Africa will do anything to lessen the isolation of the apartheid regime. The ANC remains committed to doing everything in its power to end the apartheid system as quickly as possible and by all means possible, including negotiations. The review of the new situation will therefore include an assessment of the prospects of genuine negotiations to end the apartheid system. This situation also calls for the greatest unity of all forces within our country that are committed to the perspective of a united, democratic and non-racial South Africa. We therefore call on all our people to work for this unity, with even greater vigor.

DOC.HEAD: Documents Reported Missing in British Disinformation Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th pvs, `Paisley, who...' with 1 graf to ADD possible reason for Paisley to be targeted in smear campaign. Pickup 6th, `In an ...'
DOC.TEXT: A member of the governing Conservative Party said today that files have disappeared on a 1970s disinformation campaign to discredit the IRA that critics say grew into a smear campaign against some British politicians. On Thursday, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher rejected calls for a full inquiry into the case. She said there was no evidence that the security services' operation was extended to undermine politicians. Lawmakers who claim they were targets of such an operation continued to press for a full investigation. ``The time has come for a full, open and honest uncovering of these things so that people in Northern Ireland can know that this has come to an end, the dirty tricks that were carried on,'' the Rev. Ian Paisley, the province's militant Protestant leader, told the House of Commons Thursday. Paisley allegedly was targeted because of fears that his political party might prop up a minority Labor Party government. In an interview today with British Broadcasting Corp. radio, Conservative lawmaker Michael Marshall said, ``When documents I know ... have gone missing and there are other documents internally which seem to have gone missing, one does begin to wonder whether there is a systematic problem here rather than a series of isolated incidents.'' Marshall said seven such files had disappeared, but he gave no details. Mrs. Thatcher has for years denied allegations by former army press officer Colin Wallace of a dirty tricks campaign against the Irish Republican Army and some politicians. The mainly Roman Catholic IRA opposes British rule in Northern Ireland and wants to unite it with the Irish Republic. On Wednesday, Mrs. Thatcher acknowledged in a letter to a lawmaker in her Conservative Party that her denials had been based on false information from civil servants. She said, however, that none of the allegations involve activities since 1979 when she became prime minister. Her letter was released a day after the government confirmed the existence of a covert operation codenamed ``Clockwork Orange'' to feed lies to journalists reporting from Northern Ireland. ``A Clockwork Orange'' is the title of a novel by Anthony Burgess, published in 1962, about mind control in a totalitarian state. Mrs. Thatcher said she stood by her May 1987 statement that there was ``no evidence of misuse of information by any member of the security services'' and rejected a full investigation of the case. In particular, she said, there was no evidence of any plot to destabilize Harold Wilson's 1974-76 Labor Party government. Such a plot was described in ``Spycatcher,'' the memoirs of Peter Wright, a retired senior officer in the MI5 counterintelligence agency. Wallace maintains he was dismissed in 1975, four years before Mrs. Thatcher became prime minister, for threatening to expose the campaign. He says that in addition to his regular army duties, he led a secret psychological warfare unit in Northern Ireland in the 1970s. Wallace says ``Clockwork Orange'' began as an attempt to discredit the IRA through false stories, such as the claim the guerrillas had Soviet rockets armed with unstable explosives. He says it was later expanded to smear politicians such as Wilson and Edward Heath, who was Conservative prime minister from 1970 to 1974. Tony Benn, a former Labor Cabinet minister, said another target was former Labor prime minister James Callaghan, who was in power from 1976 to 1979. Journalist Paul Foot said in his book ``Who Framed Colin Wallace?'' that Wallace received detailed information on homosexuality, bogus bank accounts, corrupt earnings and Communist sympathies. Foot said the campaign aimed at stopping Labor from being elected in 1974 and also at deposing Heath and former Northern Ireland Minister William Whitelaw from top positions in the Conservative Party.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Take to Streets After de Klerk Announcement
With PM-South Africa, Bjt
By SAHM VENTER
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of blacks sang, danced and chanted today in impromptu street celebrations following President F.W. de Klerk's announcement of sweeping changes, including legalization of the African National Congress. ``We had expected that Mr. de Klerk might deliver something, but what he said has certianly taken my breath away,'' said Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, who could not stop laughing and smiling throughout a news conference at St. George's Cathedral. ``We are probably seeing history in the making in South Africa.'' A predominately black crowd of 5,000 broke into cheers and whistles in the parade ground outside Cape Town City Hall when anti-apartheid activist Popo Molefe gave them the news over a bullhorn from the back of an open truck. The crowd marched peacefully through the streets, in and out of the nearby train station, announcing over a bullhorn to startled train passengers: ``This is an ANC station.'' Scores of white policemen and white shopkeepers watched silently from the sidewalks, some shaking their heads. But police riot squads kept out of view on side streets. In Johannesburg, whites came out of their shops to take pictures with instamatic cameras and many smiled as hundreds of blacks danced and marched through downtown, waving banners and newspaper vendors placards which declared: ``ANC Unbanned.'' At the offices of the anti-apartheid Congress of South African Trade Unions a huge black, green-and-gold ANC banner was hung from the windows. Drivers stopped their cars in the street, honking their horns and punching their fists into their air, as black workers stuck their heads out office windows, whistling and shouting. Police halted the march with a line of yellow patrol vehicles, chased some as they tried to march back to the union headquarters and sprayed tear gas on demonstrators singing on the sidewalk after they were ordered to disperse. No injuries or arrests were reported. In Durban, the sound of cheers intensified as a group of black railway union members broke out of their strike settlement meeting to dance and march through the city center. Leaders of anti-apartheid groups gathered around radios and televisions, listening intently to the speech. When de Klerk announced that restrictions had been lifted on 374 activists, many of those who were under the orders broke into smiles. Blacks in the townships were out in the dirt streets between their shanty homes, chatting, laughing and listening to the radio. In Cape Town, blacks and whites stood in groups with one person reading aloud the stories under the headline of the afternoon newspaper, which said, ``ANC Legalized.'' ``The staying power for me would be the ability of Mr. de Klerk to move very quickly now to do those things and to make them concrete.'' said the Rev. Allan Boesak, a leading activist and president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches. ``I have a lot more faith in his ability now than I did a week ago,'' At the downtown rally, Molefe said, ``We would be unreasonable if we failed to acknowledge that of all the presidents, of all the leaders of the Nationalist government, that in fact de Klerk has taken the most bold step and has emerged as the most courageous.'' However, Molefe noted the changes still had limitations. He said that if ANC President Oliver Tambo, recovering from a stroke in Sweden, were to return to South Africa from his 30-year exile tomorrow, he could still be arrested under the existing Internal Security Act or the remaining emergency regulations. Winnie Mandela, wife of imprisoned ANC leader Nelson Mandela was disappointed her husband was not released immediately from prison. ``We want to warn Mr. de Klerk we are not going to accept a bone without any meat. ... The unbanning of the ANC, the South African Communist Party and the Pan-Africanist Congress in the prevailing South African climate is simply a recipe for further problems.''

DOC.HEAD: Officials Explode Box Containing Fake Bomb
With PM-Mail Bombs
DOC.TEXT: Authorities exploded what appeared to be a mail bomb sent to the NAACP branch in Washington County last month before discovering it was a fake, authorities said today. An office worker collecting the group's mail from a post office box in this western Pennsylvania town decided not to open a suspicious-looking package after it arrived Jan. 19, said Louis Waller, a former NAACP branch president. Postal officials X-rayed the box, which contained wires and two batteries, but couldn't determine if it was a bomb until after it was exploded by Pittsburgh police, said Dick Balya, a postal inspector in Pittsburgh, 25 miles northeast of Washington. ``We think it might have been sent locally by some less than rocket scientist type people,'' said Balya. The package contained an unsigned letter with racist remarks aimed at both the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and Jews, Waller said. ``Someone went to a lot of trouble to make us think it was a real bomb,'' Waller said. The national NAACP sent warning to its 1,800 branches last August after a tear-gas bomb was mailed to its Atlanta southeastern regional office and again when its Jacksonville, Fla., branch received a mail bomb on Dec. 19. About the same time as the December bomb was received, a federal appeals judge in Alabama and a civil rights attorney in Savannah, Ga., were killed when they opened mail bombs. The bomb sent to Jacksonville and another sent to a federal courthouse in Atlanta were defused. Authorities believe the incidents were racially motivated. Washington County last year was the site of racial tensions when former Pittsburgh Steelers football player Mel Blount announced plans to build a home for trouble boys near Taylorstown. Members of the Ku Klux Klan distributed fliers protesting the home in May, but Buffalo Township officials eventually granted Blount a zoning change necessary to begin construction. Balya said investigators have found no evidence the package was sent by the Klan. Even though the package was not a bomb, the sender could be charged under federal postal regulations dealing with mailing dangerous items, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Will Review Sanctions Against South Africa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 13, The sanctions, with sanctions.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush announced today he will review U.S. sanctions against South Africa with congressional leaders, calling Pretoria's decision to free imprisoned black leader Nelson Mandela ``quite positive.'' ``I think when people move in the right direction, it is certainly time to review all policy,'' Bush said, speaking with reporters aboard Air Force One before his arrival in Raleigh, N.C., for an appearance at North Carolina State University. However, Bush indicated any easing of sanctions would depend on South African President F.W. de Klerk making good on his promise to free Mandela. ``We want to see the policy initiatives go forward, the release of Mandela,'' he said. Bush previously had indicated he would invite Mandela to the United States once he is freed, and would also invite de Klerk. De Klerk announced earlier today that Mandela will be freed, but not immediately. De Klerk also legalized Mandela's outlawed African National Congress after 30 years of guerrilla war against white rule. He said he would lift bans on more than 30 other opposition groups, free all prisoners jailed for belonging to these groups, declare a moratorium on executions, and scrap most of the restrictions imposed during more than three years of a state of emergency. Bush called de Klerk's announcement ``very interesting and I would say quite positive.'' ``I view it positively and most people around the world will,'' he added. Referring to de Klerk, the president said, ``He recognizes the status quo is not acceptable to him or the people of South Africa and to a lot of people in the world who want to see a more just society.'' Asked if the announcement could lead to an easing of U.S. sanctions imposed in 1986, Bush said: ``I want to talk to the (congressional) leaders about that.'' However, he indicated there was bound to be ``a lot of debate and discussion inside the administration about what the next move by the United States ought to be.'' He said, ``I'm one who has not proposed additional sanctions. ... I don't want any additional sanctions, but I do want a review.'' The sanctions include a ban on importing South African steel, textiles, uranium, coal and agricultural produce. They also bar new U.S. investment in South Africa, forbid new bank loans and end U.S. landing rights for South African Airways. Earlier, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater welcomed de Klerk's action as ``positive steps'' and said ``we remain hopeful the release will occur as soon as possible.'' Rep. William Gray, D-Pa., the House majority whip and author of legislation imposing the sanctions, said Bush should hold off bringing de Klerk to the White House. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., chairman of a Senate subcommittee on Africa, also suggested that inviting de Klerk to the United States would be premature. ``I urge caution before that step is taken,'' Simon said. ``State visits involving South Africa have been ruled out by past administrations as long as we continue to have fundamental differences with the South African government.'' The Bush administration raised the possibility of inviting de Klerk to the United States last year, but never followed through after dozens of lawmakers objected to the visit. On Thursday, Fitzwater said Bush would invite Mandela and de Klerk for separate visits if Mandela is released. Bush's purpose would be to ``determine how the U.S. can best help South Africa move forward toward a non-racial government and society,'' Fitzwater said. Releasing Mandela would be a ``significant step,'' Gray said, adding, ``I applaud the president'' for wanting to meet with Mandela. But before Bush sees de Klerk, the American president should hold talks with a cross-section of black South Africans to garner their views, Gray said. Gray also said South Africa would have to free all political prisoners _ not just Mandela _ lift the ban on political groups opposed to apartheid and end all residential restrictions before Congress would consider loosening economic sanctions.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT ^Ceausescu Aides Convicted, Sentenced To Life In Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Four top officials in the government of Nicolae Ceausescu were convicted today of supporting his orders to shoot scores of demonstrators and were sentenced to life in prison by a military tribunal. The four men were convicted of being accomplices to a genocide during the December revolution that toppled the Communist dictator after 24 years, Radio Bucharest reported. Western diplomats have said as many as 10,000 people died in the fighting between Ceausescu's Securitate forces and citizens who joined with the army. The tribunal, the first to try leading figures in the Ceausescu government, rejected a prosecution demand that the four be convicted of the more serious crime of ``co-authorship to genocide.'' The five-judge panel ordered the seizure of all property belonging to the four men _ including gold, jewels and large sums of money _ and stripped them of their civil rights. The four, who had already pleaded guilty to the charge of ``complicity to genocide,'' stood solemnly as the tribunal president, Col. Andrei Nitoiu, announced the majority verdict after two hours of deliberation. Three of the four defendants _ Emil Bobu, 62, former secretary of the Communist Party Central Committee and the third-ranking member of the Ceausescu leadership, former state council Vice President Manea Manescu, 74, and former Politburo member Ion Dinca, 62 _ stared at the judges, showing no emotion as the verdict was read. Former Interior Minister Tudor Postelnicu, 59, bowed his head, as he had through much of the five-day trial. Bobu, Postelnicu and Manescu said they would appeal, but Dinca told the judge he would not. Manescu, while saying he was guilty, had asked for a lesser sentence than the others, contending he had no part in the repression of the demonstrators. The four Politburo members admitted they backed Ceausescu's orders to shoot the demonstrators and did nothing to end his dictatorship. But they all denied they gave direct orders to put down the protests. The military prosecutor, Col. Aurel Cosma, urged the judges to imprison all four for life ``on behalf of the thousands of victims, of orphans, children, men, women and brave military men who were killed'' in the revolution. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, fled Bucharest by helicopter on Dec. 22 as demonstrators neared the Communist Party Central Committee headquarters. They were arrested, convicted of genocide and ruining the nation's economy in a secret, summary trial, and executed on Dec. 25. The Ceausescus were accused during their trial of killing 60,000 Romanians during their 24 years in power. The National Salvation Front, which took power during the revolution, later abolished the death penalty, make life in prison the maximum penalty. The convictions of the four former officials came after a tense standoff between the National Salvation Front and a growing opposition movement. The front, made up of former Communist officials, intellectuals and reformers, came under fire after announcing that it would field candidates in the May 20 elections. Critics said candidates fielded by theprovisional governmentwould have an unfair advantage. The opposition argued that the unelected National Salvation Front couldn't be a referee and player in Romania's first free election since World War II. The crisis was defused for the time being on Thursday, when the front formed a new governing coalition that includes opposition members.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Leaders Say South African Government Needs to Make More Concessions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS one graf with quotes from ANC official in Zimbabwe.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leaders today cautiously welcomed the South African government's decision to legalize their guerrilla group, but said the measures do not go far enough to end apartheid. The ANC said in a statement that South Africa's white-led government should remain isolated in the world community until it agrees to take further steps. They said sanctions against South Africa should be maintained and strengthened. ``Victory is in sight,'' said veteran ANC leader Walter Sisulu, who described as ``progressive'' the steps announced by President F.W. de Klerk at the opening of South Africa's Parliament in Cape Town. De Klerk said he was legalizing ANC, lifting bans or restrictions on more than 60 other organizations and freeing most people who had been jailed for joining them when they were banned. He told Parliament he was relaxing state of emergency restrictions and would soon free jailed ANC leader Nelson Mandela. De Klerk did not say when Mandela would be freed, saying more time was needed to settle issues related to his safety. The ANC statement said South Africa's main black nationalist movement was ``greatly concerned'' that some political prisoners will not be released, that the state of emergency will not be wholly removed and that detentions without trial may continue. The ANC said Mandela should be freed ``without further delay,'' and that the ANC would share with the South African government responsibility for his safety after his release. Mandela, 71, was jailed 27 years ago for plotting against white-minority rule. Sisulu and other veteran ANC leaders were in Sweden on their first visit outside Africa since being released from prison in October, where they had served 25 years of a life sentence. Sisulu, asked whether negotiations with the government could start now, replied, ``No. This is merely a preliminary.'' ``He has done a great deal,'' Sisulu said of de Klerk. Asked whether de Klerk had gone far enough, however, Sisulu said: ``No, not yet. ... This is only the beginning. We want the end of apartheid in South Africa.'' Before negotiations can start, Sisulu said, the government will have to remove soldiers and police from black townships and clarify its attitude toward political exiles, including ANC President Oliver Tambo, recovering in a Stockholm clinic from a stroke. Sisulu said it was unclear whether Tambo could safely return from exile. Sisulu said he was not confident that the South African government was committed to ending apartheid. ``I don't know yet,'' he said. ``They have made a progressive beginning and, on the basis of that, I hope they will go further.'' In Harare, Zimbabwe, ANC spokesman Pallo Jordan said the government still has laws it canuse to move against opposition groups. ``Repressive measures can still be deployed (against us) because the capacity is there in term of statutes,'' Jordan said.

DOC.HEAD: President Visits Troubled Kosovo Province; No New Violence Reported
DOC.TEXT: President Janez Drnovsek today said he brought ``new ideas'' to the troubled province of Kosovo in a personal effort to halt mounting ethnic unrest that has already claimed at least 21 lives. No new demonstrations by ethnic Albanians were reported today after 10 days of unrest, but a virtual general strike appeared to be in force in the southern province, Yugoslavia's poorest region. ``Production has almost completely stopped,'' the state Tanjug news agency said, adding that even those who showed up at their jobs were refusing to work. At least 30,000 people throughout Kosovo have been on strike since the unrest started on Jan. 24 at Pristina University, official statistics show. The deaths resulted from clashes between the province's majority ethnic Albanians and police. On Thursday, trainloads of minority Serbs fled the province and tanks sent from neighboring Serbia patrolled Pristina. ``I have come with some new ideas for solving the Kosovo problem,'' Drnovsek told journalists after arriving in the Kosovo capital. But he declined to elaborate, saying he would first discuss them with provincial authorities. In the Yugoslav capital, Belgrade, Premier Ante Markovic and six other Cabinet members, including the defense and interior ministers, formed a special unit to ``monitor and control'' the situation in Kosovo, Tanjug reported today. Ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of Kosovo's 1.9 million people, have been demanding greater autonomy for their province since the enactment a year ago of constitutional amendments that gave Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest state, more control over the province. Three people, including a young girl, lost their lives in protests Thursday, Pristina radio said. That brought the death toll in the recent unrest to 21, by official count. Serbian authorities maintain the changes were necessary to protect the Serbian minority against alleged harassment by the ethnic Albanians. Yugoslavia's liberal northern regions of Slovenia and Croatia have backed ethnic Albanian calls for greater self-government to the province. About 10,000 Serbs rallied in a downtown Pristina sports center today demanding the federal government ensure order in the region or they would arm themselves to do so. Ethnic Albanian ``nationalists have clearly demonstrated they intend to secede from Yugoslavia in order to join Albania,'' Deputy Defense Minister Adm. Stane Brovet told Parliament in Belgrade today, Tanjug reported. ``Their intentions must be thwarted by all means, including force.'' But the Slovenian newspaper Delo today said there was no civil war in Kosovo, ``only powerless demonstrators ... whose every act is immediately misinterpreted in the province's politicized atmosphere.''

DOC.HEAD: Bank Bombing Suspect Has Double Life
DOC.TEXT: A furniture salesman who the FBI said was leading a double life has been arrested in connection with an attempted bank robbery and is a suspect in up to 20 more crimes, authorities say. Edward L. Jones, 50, of Lakewood, once ordained a minister and actively involved in his community and his children's schools, was being held without bond pending a court appearance Monday. Jones has been charged in connection with a botched attempt to blow open a safe at American Industrial Bank of Cherry Creek on Jan. 10. Jones also is a suspect in as many as 20 bank robberies and burglaries in the past year in Colorado, based on items recovered in searches and other information, FBI Agent Bob Pence said Thursday. Jones' wife, Shirley, said her husband didn't need money and the family had seen no evidence of any extravagant spending. The couple have two teen-age children. ``We were devastated; we're still devastated,'' she said. Jones, who once was a minister in an independent church, came to the attention of authorities Jan. 23, when Lakewood police were summoned to his home because his wife was concerned he might be suicidal, said John Hunt, spokesman for Lakewood police. ``He had gone through some recent behavioral changes,'' Hunt said. Jones was taken to a hospital for a psychiatric evaluation. About an hour later, Hunt said, Mrs. Jones called again, saying: ``Come on back out here. I found some things that might be of interest to you and also might show that he's having some problems with coping.'' She showed officers a trunk containing wigs, fake mustaches, masks, a handgun, tools, nylons, a trench coat, assorted keys and a stolen federal government license plate, police said. In the botched attempt to rob the Cherry Creek bank, a crude homemade bomb was used to try to blow open a small safe. The explosion merely singed the carpet, nicked a desk, blew a few holes in the ceiling and loosened marble counter panels.

DOC.HEAD: Commercial Jet Lands Safely After Flames Seen From Engine
DOC.TEXT: Flames shooting from an engine forced a Northwest Airlines DC-10 with 110 people aboard to double back to Los Angeles International Airport shortly after takeoff early today, officials said. No injuries were reported following the safe landing of Flight 84, bound for Minneapolis, airline and Federal Aviation Administration officials said. Air traffic controllers noticed flames coming from the jet's left engine shortly after it took off at 1:45 a.m., said Rich Tornquist, FAA regional duty officer. He said the pilot shut down the engine, dumped the fuel in the ocean and landed at 2:19 a.m. A DC-10 has three engines, but can safely land on two, said Tornquist. Northwest spokesman Kevin Whalen in Minneapolis said the problem was caused by a stall of air flow in plane's left engine. ``There was no fire in the engine per se. Any flames seen would have been residual fuel that hadn't burned off because of the stall in the engine,'' he said. The engine was repaired and the flight would be rescheduled for later today after the crew has had a chance to rest, the airline said.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Endorses Gorbachev Plan for 35-Nation Summit _ With Qualifications
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS reference to ``next year'' in lead and INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf pvs, But he ... to show Baker gave qualified endorsement to approval of summit this year; picks up 4th graf pvs, A treaty ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal for a 35-nation summit meeting now has the qualified approval of the Bush administration _ provided a treaty is completed to reduce troops and tanks in Europe. Secretary of State James A. Baker III told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Thursday the summit could be the forum for signing the treaty and also provide a framework to deal with the question of German reunification. But he said the Soviets first must agree to the principle that free elections are a human right. Gorbachev proposed the summit be held this year and the 12 members of the European Community have endorsed the idea of a far-ranging meeting. Baker said ``we would be willing to attend such a summit'' to sign the treaty provided U.S. conditions are met. It is not clear, however, if the treaty can be concluded this year. Taking Baker's qualifications into account, the summit meeting presumably could be held next year as well, with U.S. approval. A treaty to reduce NATO and Warsaw Pact troops and non-nuclear weapons in Europe is nearing completion in Vienna. However, Baker said there is disagreement on how to deal with combat aircraft and helicopters. The Soviets insist that some of the planes the West wants to restrict are defensive in mission and should be excluded from limits. President Bush's proposal on Wednesday night for deeper cuts also could complicate completion of the pact. The 35-nation conference would bring together the United States, Canada, the Soviet Union, the Vatican and all the countries of Europe except Albania. The same 35 signed the Helsinki agreement of 1975 that promoted human rights and, in effect, recognized the post-World War II borders of Europe. Sen. Joseph D. Biden Jr., D-Del., had urged the Bush administration to accept Gorbachev's proposal. ``If we don't provide a framework that accommodates East and West German concerns to resolve the unification issue, events could seize the day,'' Biden said. The senator earlier had urged the Bush administration to accept Gorbachev's offer and to use the 35-nation conference to discuss further cuts in troops and weapons, the German question and a timetable for the removal of all foreign forces from Europe. Baker will hold talks next Thursday and Friday in Moscow with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and possibly Gorbachev. His endorsement of the summit proposal _ although qualified _ represented another attempt by the Bush administration to back the Soviet leader. Also, U.S. officials are trying to develop a strategy for dealing with the German issue. On Tuesday, Gorbachev appeared to soften the Soviets' longstanding opposition to reunification. ``It is essential to act responsibly and not seek the solution to this important issue on the streets,'' the Soviet leader said during a visit to Moscow by Hans Modrow, the East German premier. Baker said the prospect of a 35-nation summit could serve as ``a carrot'' to encourage completion by NATO and the Warsaw Pact of a treaty this year to reduce troops and weapons in Europe. The treaty would set a ceiling of 275,000 for U.S. and Soviet soldiers on foreign soil. President Bush, on Wednesday night, proposed reducing the level to 225,000 and setting a sub-ceiling of 195,000 for Central Europe, which includes East and West Germany. It was not clear if the deeper cuts would be part of the treaty now being negotiated in Vienna or become the basis of a second treaty. Baker stressed the U.S. priority is to complete a treaty by the time Bush and Gorbachev hold a summit meeting in Washington in the second half of June. Referring to the treaty, which is known as CFE for conventional forces in Europe, Baker told Biden: ``We would be willing to attend such a summit provided we can get a CFE agreement completed and signed at such an event.'' Also, Baker said, a scheduled review in 1992 of compliance with the Helsinki agreement should be held, as well.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Factions Battle in East Beirut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to UPDATE with appeals to halt fighting, more than 100 killed; Pickup up 16th pvs, `The renewed...'
DOC.TEXT: Renegade Gen. Michel Aoun's troops attacked a rival Christian militia's command post today in the heaviest fighting in a 4-day-old confrontation that has reportedly killed at least 100 people. President Elias Hrawi urged France and other countries to demand that Aoun halt the fighting. Lebanon's Maronite Catholic prelate called on both sides to end ``this mass suicide.'' Police said at least 450 people have been wounded during the conflict, and two people were killed and 23 wounded from stray mortar shells and gunfire that hit Moslem west Beirut, which has not been involved in the Christian fighting. Police said they could not say how many people had been killed today because of the intensity of the clashes in east Beirut's Ashrafiyeh and Karantina districts. They said the tank-led forces of Aoun, moving behind a howitzer barrage of 20 shells a minute, were trying to penetrate defenses of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces, the main Christian militia. The Lebanese Forces said in a communique its forces were ``shaking off one tank assault after another.'' In another communique, the Lebanese Forces said commanders of Aoun's air base at Adma, north of Beirut, were ``negotiating surrender terms with our forces.'' Adma, the communique said, has been surrounded by Geagea's militiamen since Thursday. A police spokesman said Geagea's fighters were locked in ``close-range clashes'' with Aoun's troops on the southern edge of Ashrafiyeh that also commands a street leading to Beirut's northern entrance. The police spokesman, who requested anonymity, said Lebanese Forces engineer units had planted mines along the southern slopes of Ashrafiyeh and part of the street to hamper any attempt to advance. The thuds of artillery explosions and the whooshing sound of outgoing rockets echoed across the Lebanese capital. Archbishop Nasrallah Sfeir, patriarch of the Maronite Catholic community, called on Aoun and Geagea to ``stop shooting immediately.'' ``Have mercy on people. Their lives and property are not yours. You must stop this mass massacre now. You must stop this mass suicide,'' he said. In an interview with France-Info radio, Hrawi said, ``I call on the Lebanese of France and overseas to press the country in which they are living to intervene to prevent Gen. Aoun from crucifying Lebanon and the Lebanese.'' The president, also a Maronite, fled his residence in Moslem west Beirut as as repeated salvos crashed in the district, aides said. The renewed fighting violated a truce struck late Thursday between Aoun and Geagea and shattered a relative overnight lull in east Beirut and the rest of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. Aoun, who has been dismissed as army commander but clings to his command of about 20,000 soldiers, attacked on Tuesday to try to gain full control of the enclave north and east of Beirut where 1 million Christians live. Geagea has 6,000 militiamen bolstered by several thousand reservists. Aoun was fired by Hrawi, who was elected in November under the terms of an Arab League-brokered peace plan aimed at shifting political power to the Moslem majority and ending a 15-year-old civil war. The war has left 150,000 people dead. Aoun says the plan, approved by Parliament in October, provides no fixed withdrawal timetable for Syria's estimated 45,000 troops. Geagea has neither accepted or rejected the peace accord, but has recognized Hrawi as president.

DOC.HEAD: World Leaders Hail de Klerk Speech; Some Encourage Further Pressure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 16th pvs, ``It is...'' to UPDATE with Canadian comment. Pickup 17th pvs, `Scandinavian countries...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: World leaders today hailed South Africa's decision to free black leader Nelson Mandela and legalize the African National Congress, but some urged continued sanctions to encourage the dismantling of apartheid. President Bush praised the announcements as ``quite positive'' and said he will review U.S. sanctions against South Africa with congressional leaders. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher immediately invited South African President F.W. de Klerk to visit her and said she wants Mandela to come as soon as he is free. Bush also has indicated he will extend invitations. Mandela, 71, has been imprisoned since 1962 for helping to plan the start of the ANC's bombing and sabotage campaign against the white-led government. In his speech to South Africa's Parliament, de Klerk said Mandela would be freed without conditions, but he didn't say when. He said concerns about Mandela's safety were among the factors affecting his release date. De Klerk's decision to free Mandela soon was a ``historic landmark on the road to a new South Africa,'' Mrs. Thatcher said in a statement. ``President de Klerk is to be congratulated on his decision,'' she said. ``Mr. Mandela will have a major role to play in shaping his country's future.'' Mrs. Thatcher, who has been instrumental in blocking harsh economic sanctions against the white-led government, also said Britain will in the future ``not discourage artists, scientists and academics from going to South Africa.'' The London-based Anti-Apartheid movement, the biggest in the Western world, said its delight at the legalizing of the ANC was ``tinged with concern.'' ``Simply reducing the level of apartheid repression does not mean he (de Klerk) is committed to ending it,'' Anti-Apartheid Movement secretary Mike Terry said. He said international pressures and black dissent in South Africa have forced de Klerk to move, adding these pressures should not be relaxed. ``He (de Klerk) has gone a long way towards creating a climate for negotiations,'' he added. ``But obviously we are bitterly disappointed that he has not announced the release of Nelson Mandela.'' In contrast, the British government statement said the ``changes now taking place in South Africa vindicate a policy of contact rather than isolation.'' In Nigeria, Professor Gabriel Olusanya, director-general of the Nigerian Institute of International Affairs, called de Klerk's move a ``a bold and courageous step deserving of encouragement.'' Although de Klerk did not announce the abolition of apartheid, his refoms pointed toward the eventual end of the hated system, Olusanya said. ``It is obvious that with all these measures, apartheid will not remain what it used to be,'' he said. Canada applauded the speech but cautiouned that much work remained before apartheid is dismantled. ``It's a historic step in the right direction,'' said Mark Entwistle, a spokesman for the Department of External Affairs. Scandinavian countries, which were among the first to impose sanctions against the white-led South African government, praised the decisions. Denmark indicated it may consider upgrading its level of diplomatic relations, but joined Sweden and Norway in urging continued pressure on South Africa to dismantle apartheid, its system of legalized racial discrimination. Swedish Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson hailed the moves as ``a great victory in the fight against apartheid,'' but said more steps were needed for South Africa to achieve the full measure of democracy and freedom. ``Until then, the struggle against apartheid must continue and the pressure on the South Africa regime must be kept up,'' Carlsson said. ``The South African liberation movements can count on Sweden's support in this struggle.'' Norwegian Foreign Minister Kjell Magne Bondevik also said Oslo won't change its policy toward South Africa. ``Many of the opposition's demands have been met, but still important things remain to be solved, first of all elimination of the basic foundations of the system of apartheid and the actual release from prison of Nelson Mandela,'' Bondevik said. The Finnish Foreign Ministry in Helsinki said that when de Klerk's promises are carried out ``it will mean a great step in the dismantling of apartheid.'' Portuguese President Mario Soares, who last October became the first foreign head of state to visit South Africa in nearly 15 years, congratulated de Klerk on his announcements. Soares said he heard the news of the decisions ``with great pleasure and a sentiment of profound hope.''

DOC.HEAD: Ferry Accident Kills 70
DOC.TEXT: A ferry sank after being struck by an oil tanker on the Yangtze River in central China, killing 70 people and leaving 43 others missing, a newspaper said. Thursday's edition of the Shanghai newspaper Liberation Daily, seen in Beijing on Friday, said the accident occurred near Anqing in Anhui province, about 230 miles southwest of Shanghai. The report gave no details on the collision. It said a preliminary investigation determined that the ferry was carrying 151 people, of whom 38 were known to have survived. Officials quickly formed a team to handle what it called the ``Jan. 24 sea loss incident,'' indicating the accident took place on that date.

DOC.HEAD: Fatal Explosion at Brothel Frequented by Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: An explosion at a brothel frequented by soldiers killed one person and injured five others Friday, and police believe the blast was caused by a military device, a news agency reported. The explosion, which occurred around dawn in the two-story building, killed a 15-year-old girl and injured four other women and a man, according to the Zimbabwe Inter-African News Agency. Janitor Jezati Sandran said Zimbabwean soldiers regularly visited about 100 prostitutes living at the 64-room former hotel. The news agency said police believed the explosion was caused by a military-style device. Several previous bombings have occurred at facilities occupied by South African exiles and have been blamed on South African government agents, but police told the news agency they do not believe Friday's explosion was politically motivated.

DOC.HEAD: Day-Care Owner Charged with Having Child Porn; Children ID'd in Nude Photos
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5-9th grafs, bgng `Three other...', with 6 grafs to UPDATE with children undergoing counseling, examinations; move up description of pictures, add other detail. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `While Shaver...'. Ott is cq in 9th graf
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen children have been identified by their parents in nude photographs seized from the home of a day-care center owner charged with possession of child pornography, police said. John Shaver, 56, was charged with five counts of possessing child pornography after the photographs and magazines were found at his home last Sunday. Police say they are considering additional charges. Broward County officials on Thursday shut down Shaver's Rainbow Learning Center, contending Shaver ``lacked good moral character.'' Fourteen children who attended the day-care center were identified by some of the 140 parents who went to the police department Thursday night and sorted through 200 to 300 pictures taken from Shaver's home. Only the faces of the children were shown to the parents, police Sgt. David Geyer said. The children were pictured naked finger-painting and playing in swimming pools, he said. No sexual situations were depicted, police said. Three other children were tentatively identified by their parents from among the photographs, police said. Those parents planned to take another look at the photos today, as did many of the other 60 parents who have yet to view the pictures, police said. A weeping Marla Echevarria, whose daughter was not among those in the pictures, expressed relief but concern for other parents who saw their children in the photographs. ``The pictures were horrifying,'' she said. ``I saw parents hysterical in there.'' The children identified in the photographs Thursday night were undergoing medical examinations and counseling today at the county's sexual assault treatment center, said police spokesman Ott Cefkin. The interviews will be videotaped, he added. No new charges are expected immediately against Shaver, because police must carefully examine the evidence and interview the families first, he said. While Shaver admits owning the pictures police confiscated, he does not consider simple possession as pornography. ``The way I understand child pornography is to tell kids to take off their clothes and photograph them in the nude. I didn't do it,'' he said. ``It's probably done ... but I am not that way.'' ``It didn't cause harm to anyone,'' he said. ``A lot of people have secret vices.'' Shaver opened the day-care center in 1985. Thirty preschool children attended the center and about 200 have attended since it opened. ``I just feel dejected. I don't want to do anything,'' Shaver said after he was notified Thursday that the Broward County Social Services Division revoked his day-care license. Shaver has 15 days to appeal but said he did not want to fight it. ``I never did anything improper (to the children),'' he said repeatedly. When he applied for his license, Shaver said he wasn't asked whether he ever operated a day-care center and did not volunteer such information. In 1984 in Hawaii, Shaver pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge of operating a day-care center without a license. The plea came a year after the state of Hawaii revoked his license amid allegations that he fondled several young girls at his center. He was never criminally charged and Shaver denies any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEAD: Violence Flares in India's Kashmir Valley
DOC.TEXT: Violence flared in the Kashmir Valley on Friday after an eight-day lull, and officials said at least four people were killed in attacks by Moslem separatists and by police firing on curfew violators. Prime Minister V.P. Singh made his first comments on an increasingly belligerent exchange of charges between India and Pakistan on the Kashmir issue, saying: ``The Indian people and army are prepared to give a befitting reply'' if Islamabad wanted a confrontation. Singh's comments, made in Calcutta, were reported by United News of India. New Delhi has accused neighboring Pakistan, an Islamic state, of fomenting the trouble in Kashmir. Islamabad has denied the charges but said the people of Kashmir had a right to self-determination. India and Pakistan have gone to war three times since they were partitioned in 1947 on gaining independence from Britain. Two of the wars have been over Kashmir, a region claimed by both Pakistan and India, and there have been recent reports of increased military activity along the border. The latest deaths in Kashmir raise to 76 the number of people killed since the government ordered a crackdown Jan. 20 on the Moslem movement for secession of Kashmir from predominantly Hindu India. In Srinagar, the largest town in Kashmir, Hindu businessman Satish Kumar Tikku was shot and killed by the militants during a six-hour relaxation of curfew, Jammu-Kashmir state Gov. Jagmohan told reporters. Tikku was the first Hindu civilian known to have been killed in the violence _ other victims have been Moslem protesters or government troops. Police sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Tikku was killed because militants suspected him of being a police informer and not because he was a Hindu. In the neighboring town of Sopore, three people were killed when paramilitary police opened fire on a mob gathered in defiance of curfew restrictions early Friday, said police officials in Jammu, also speaking on condition of anonymity. Jammu is the winter capital of the Moslem-majority state, which includes the Kashmir Valley and the plains of Jammu to the south. The last reported deaths in the Kashmir Valley occurred Jan. 25, when at least 15 people were killed. Two days later, the government began relaxing the around-the-clock curfew for varying periods extending up to 12 hours a day. On Friday, the relaxation was limited to six hours beginning at 5 a.m., apparently in fear of trouble on the Friday Moslem sabbath, frequently a weekly flashpoint for violence by the militants. A government statement said militants and paramilitary federal troops exchanged gunfire in the old district of Srinagar and two people were wounded. It also said two people who hurled a gasoline bomb at a paramilitary police bunker were arrested. The Moslem movement for an independent Kashmir dates to the 1947 partition of the subcontinent along religious lines. The Hindu ruler of the state opted to join India, but Pakistan opposed the decision, saying as a Moslem-majority area it should have gone to Pakistan. A war over the issue in 1948 left parts of the valley under Pakistani control. Kashmiri militants at first demanded union with Pakistan but recently they have demanded a separate neutral nation which if formed would be sandwiched next to India, Pakistan and China. Meanwhile, the government declined to enforce an order expelling reporters for The Associated Press and Agence France-Presse from Srinagar. They had been ordered expelled on the grounds their presence was ``prejudicial to the security of the state.''

DOC.HEAD: Veterinarians Treating More Pets for Drug Overdose
DOC.TEXT: If the nation needs another sign that the drug problem is getting worse, veterinarians have one. Animal doctors in the Atlanta area say they are treating an increasing number of patients who are disoriented, having seizures, in a coma or undergoing cardiac arrest because they ate their owner's drugs. ``Oh, we see it all the time,'' said Darryl Mickle, who practices in a clinic in southeastern Atlanta. He told of a dachshund _ Muffin _ who was brought in disoriented and salivating heavily. ``Is it possible that Muffin got hold of some type of plant or, uh, medication?'' Mickle asked, diplomatically. The owner said no. But Mickle traced the problem to an overdose. ``You know, I thought it was my roommate who had stolen my marijuana, but it was Muffin,'' the man later admitted. Mickle estimated his clinic sees two pets a month that have eaten illegal drugs, plus another two a month that swallowed a prescription drug, alcohol or an over-the-counter remedy. The Illinois Animal Poison Information Center, which has the only national 24-hour hot line for pets, handled 85 calls in 1988 for animals that had consumed marijuana, said operations director Harold Trammel. Cocaine and alcohol ingestion were second with 35 calls each, and other calls came in for prescription drug consumption, amphetamines, hallucinogens such as LSD, and even one for heroin. Last month, Rob Lafferty of the Veterinary Medical Center in Alpharetta treated a sheepdog that had eaten its owner's marijuana. He said he gave the animal a drug that induces vomiting and ``about the equivalent of a nickel bag came up.'' Jason Trotman, a veterinarian with the 24-hour Animal Emergency Care Center in Smyrna, said a man last month brought in a miniature schnauzer that was in cardiac arrest from cocaine. The man said the dog belonged to a friend. The dog died, and when Trotman tried to contact the man, the name, address and telephone number he had left all turned out to be phony. Both Trotman and Mickle said they do not report drug cases to police. ``My main concern is saving the animal's life, not getting into the owner's personal affairs,'' Trotman said. But for every animal taken to a veterinarian, more probably are never treated because owners are afraid of being prosecuted for possession, veterinarians say. Trotman said he often gets anonymous calls from people seeking advice on how to help a pet that consumed cocaine or marijuana. When the owners are told they have to bring the dog in for proper treatment, they usually hang up, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Women Shaped Like Apples at Higher Breast Cancer Risk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 12th & 13th grafs, ``Schapiro said,'' to CORRECT Schapiro to Schapira.
DOC.TEXT: A new study indicates that weight distribution plays a role in the risk of breast cancer, with ``apple'' shapes having a greater risk than women with ``pear''-shaped bodies. Women can gauge their risk of breast cancer by dividing their waist measurements by their hip measurements, researchers from the University of South Florida said in a study published Thursday in the Philadelphia-based Annals of Internal Medicine. In a separate study, Texas researchers said they have identified an enzyme that may help predict which breast-cancer patients are most likely to suffer a relapse. Breast cancer is expected to strike an estimated 150,000 women and cause 44,000 deaths this year. The Florida study, led by David Schapira of the H. Lee Moffitt Cancer Center & Research Institute at the University of South Florida, found that women who carry their weight around the middle are more at risk for developing breast cancer than those who bulge at the hips and thighs. ``When we looked at women, obesity was not a factor. It's where you have the fat,'' Schapira said. ``An overweight pear is still at lower risk than someone leaner and apple shaped.'' ``This refines our information,'' said oncologist Dr. Paul F. Engstrom of the Fox Chase Cancer Center. ``Not all obesity is the same.'' Previous studies had established a link between obesity and breast cancer, but Schapira said this may be because women tend to gain weight in their abdomen. Fat cells in the upper part of the body, he said, are larger and have a different metabolic and hormonal structure than those in the lower part of the body. The Florida team studied 216 breast-cancer patients diagnosed from August 1987 to June 1988 and 432 healthy women. The subjects ranged in age from 25 to 83. Breast-cancer patients had significantly greater deposits of upper body fat, plus greater waist-to-hip and abdomen-to-thigh ratios, researchers found. Schapira said women whose waist-to-hip ratio is 0.77 to 0.80 are classified as ``mildly apple shaped'' and are three times as likely to develop breast cancer, a risk equal to having either a sister or mother who had breast cancer. Women whose ratio is higher than 0.80 are ``very apple shaped,'' Schapira said, and are six times as likely to develop breast cancer, a risk equal to having both a mother and sister who had breast cancer. Ratios of 0.73 to 0.76 define a woman as ``mildly pear shaped,'' while women with ratios of less than 0.73 are ``very pear shaped'' and at low risk of getting breast cancer, he said. Last week, researchers in St. Louis reported that cholesterol levels are closely linked with the way people carry their fat, reporting it is healthier for people to be shaped like a pear than an apple. The second study, published Thursday in the New England Journal of Medicine, said the presence of an enzyme called cathepsin D could help doctors determine which women should receive chemotherapy or radiation treatment after breast-cancer surgery. The enzyme appears to play a part in the rapid production of cancer cells, according to the study. Doctors at the University of Texas Health Science Center in San Antonio found that breast cancer patients with higher levels of the enzyme had 2.6 times the chance of a relapse and 3.9 times the possibility of dying in five years compared with those who had low levels. Measurement of the detection of the enzyme may help doctors shape treatment for breast-cancer victims who don't show signs of further cancer. About 30 percent of the patients experience a recurrence, and, until now, doctors have been unable to predict which women are at risk. The National Cancer Institute recommends chemotherapy for all women not showing signs of further disease.

DOC.HEAD: Father in Baby Swap Contracts for TV Movie
DOC.TEXT: Television movie rights have been sold to the baby swap story of an 11-year-old who attorneys say was switched in a hospital nursery with another newborn. Attorneys say genetic tests showed that for 10 years Kimberly Mays and Arlene Twigg were raised by the wrong parents. Bob Mays, who reared Kimberly since birth, sold the rights to their custody battle Thursday to Hollywood television producers for an undisclosed sum that includes a college education fund for Kimberly. Mays, who will be a script consultant, said he made the deal to publicize his fight to keep his daughter and to pay legal bills he estimates will top $100,000. Ernest and Regina Twigg, who were living in Langhorne, Pa., at the time, sued to get genetic testing of Kimberly after they discovered the girl they raised was not their biological daughter. Arlena died of heart disease in 1988. Afterward, the Twiggs set out to find their biological daughter. Mrs. Twigg had given birth in central Florida's Hardee Memorial Hospital in 1978 days apart from Mays' wife, Barbara. The girls were the only two white girls in the nursery at the time. Mrs. Mays died in 1981 from cancer. Mays consented last year to genetic testing of Kimberly on condition that whatever the findings, the Twiggs would not seek custody. The Twiggs agreed to settle for visitation, but a plan has not been worked out. Mays, a roofing contractor, said his daughter is excited about the deal. ``It's quite a thing to realize that all of a sudden a movie is going to be made about you,'' he said. Los Angeles producer Michael O'Hara, co-owner of O'Hara-Horowitz Productions Inc., said NBC has given him the go-ahead for the project, but a script must still receive final network approval before he is certain the project will be broadcast.

DOC.HEAD: 400,000 Pairs of Latex Gloves Donated to New Orleans
DOC.TEXT: The New Orleans Health Department won't need to buy surgical gloves until 1995 or so, thanks to a 400,000-pair gift from an importer. Suzy Shay of Direct China Trade Ltd. said $48,000 worth of latex gloves arrived from China too late for the customer for whom she had ordered them. ``That's the nature of the business,'' she said. Shay decided to donate the gloves to the city rather than find another buyer. Dr. Brobson Lutz, the department's director, said they will be distributed to ambulance workers and health clinics. ``With the advent of the AIDS virus, this item has been essential,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecution Rests in Gotti Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with victim testifying as defense witness. Picks up 4th graf pvs, ``Gotti, 49...'' Note language in 12th graf.
DOC.TEXT: A union official who was allegedly shot on orders from reputed mob boss John Gotti testified today he did not know the men who shot him. John F. O'Connor, subpoenaed as a defense witness, detailed what happened when he was shot in the buttocks on May 7, 1986. O'Connor, 56, of Brewster said he noticed four or five men hanging around the offices of Carpenters Union Local 608, where he was then business manager. While waiting for the elevator, O'Connor said he heard ``a thunderous clap'' and felt something in his buttocks, although he did not realize he had been shot. He said someone shouted his name and he turned and saw a man pointing a gun at him, and that when he got on the elevator the gunman fired more bullets into his buttocks. The prosecution rested its case Thursday after the jury heard members of the Westies, an Irish-American gang, say on secretly recorded tape that they shot O'Connor to appease Gotti. Gotti, 49, and Anthony Guerrieri, 60, are on charged with assault and conspiracy in the retaliation shooting of O'Connor. The tapes were recorded at Rikers Island jail. Westies member Kevin Kelly and his friend, Larry Palermo, had gone to visit Francis ``Mickey'' Featherstone, a former Westies leader who was an informer. Prosecutors said Gotti, reputed boss of the Gambino crime family, sent the Westies to shoot O'Connor because he led the trashing of a mob-affiliated restaurant that was being constructed with non-union labor. Transcripts of the tape, the accuracy of which is in dispute, show that Featherstone was the first to mention O'Connor's shooting. Kelly and Palermo had no idea that a microphone was hidden behind a picture on the wall near them when they visited Featherstone in jail. At one point on the tape, Kelly said one gang member ``popped him.'' When Featherstone asked who requested the shooting, Kelly replied it was done ``for the greaseballs.'' He said the Westies volunteered their services to Gotti at the funeral of Gambino family underboss Frank DeCicco. Defense attorneys have challenged the quality of the tapes and the veracity of the transcripts. Acting Justice Edward McLaughlin told the jurors that what they hear on the tapes and how they interpret it is what counts. He said he was not sure he would allow them to take the transcripts into the jury room during deliberations. McLaughlin told the jurors they will hear closing arguments Monday and begin deliberations Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: U. of Wisconsin Regents Reject Proposal to Expel ROTC Because of Ban on Gays
DOC.TEXT: University of Wisconsin regents today rejected a faculty-backed proposal to kick the Reserve Officers' Training Corps from campus to protest the military's ban on homosexuals. The board voted 13-3 instead to accept the recommendation of UW System President Kenneth Shaw that the university strengthen its effort to lobby Congress to change the military's policy. In December, the Faculty Senate at UW-Madison, the system's largest campus, approved a resolution asking the university to expel ROTC from campus in 1993 if the military continued to prohibit gays and lesbians. Several other campus groups followed with similar resolutions. But Shaw responded this week by saying he did not believe severing the university's ties to the military would effectively encourage the military to change its policy. Furthermore, elimination of the military programs would hurt those students who benefit from them, he said. There are about 440 students in Army, Navy and Air Force ROTC programs at UW-Madison, which has an enrollment of 42,000, and a total of about 1,300 ROTC students in the entire UW System, which has 135,000 students at 13 major campuses and several smaller centers. The regents listened to testimony from 15 people before voting in favor of Shaw's resolution, which called on the university to step up efforts it began in 1987 to lobby Congress and the military. ``I think it was the appropriate resolution to pass,'' said Regent Erroll Davis Jr. of Madison. ``I think we have to work a little harder than in the past. This resolution keeps the issue in the front line and will force us to deal with it.'' The resolution passed today differs from one approved by the regents in 1987 because it requires UW administrators to report annually to the board on the progress of its lobbying efforts to change the military's policy. The 1987 resolution, which stated the university would seek to lobby the military, was criticized recently for being too broad and ineffective. The majority of regents said they agreed with Shaw that kicking the military off campus would not effect the change sought in a national policy. ``By opting out we will have nothing to say about this issue,'' Shaw told the regents. ``It's an issue that must be changed legislatively.'' An official at the Army's ROTC office at UW-Madison, who declined to give his name, said ROTC officials would decline to comment until seeing a copy of the regents' decision. Jordan Marsh, of the Wisconsin Student Association, said he was dissapointed by the regents' vote but was encouraged by some of the members' comments. Some regents said they would want ROTC banned if the lobbying to change military policy fails. ``It shows they are serious about this and want the discrimination stopped,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Brady Distances Administration From Calls for Lower Interest Rates
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady tried to distance the Bush administration today from its earlier calls for lower interest rates, saying those remarks were aimed at a homebuilders' convention. Brady's comments were an indication the White House may be trying to ease the pressure it has been placing in recent weeks on the Federal Reserve Board to take actions to lower interest rates. Testifying before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, Brady said a statement made two weeks ago by White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater urging lower rates ``was not meant to be a contest with the Fed.'' Brady said he understood Fitzwater was aiming his remark at a visit President Bush was scheduled to make the next day to a homebuilders' convention. The housing industry has been in a slump for the past year due to high mortgage rates. ``Presidents generally talk about lower interest rates at housing conferences,'' Brady said. The White House generally refrains from commenting publicly on Federal Reserve policy Asked by committee Chairman Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., whether Fitzwater's comments were inappropriate, Brady said, ``Not in light of what I understand was the reason for the statement being given.'' Brady said he holds ``vigorous discussions'' weekly with Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan in which disagreements are expressed, but he declined to reveal the specifics of their talks. ``The administration probably has a bias toward growth that's greater than that of the Fed,'' Brady said. ``At the same time, we keep a weather eye on inflation.'' Brady's remarks today came only four days before Federal Reserve policymakers were scheduled to hold a closed-door session in Washington where they will set monetary targets for the rest of the year. On Jan. 18, Fitzwater told White House reporters that a recent prime rate reduction by banks had not been passed through to the general economy. He said, ``It's important occasionally to point out that lower interest rates are normally good for the economy.'' Fitzwater went on to cite Commerce Department statistics showing a drop in housing starts as evidence that lower interest rates are needed. The next day in Atlanta, Bush told the National Association of Homebuilders that he wants interest rates to drop further. ``The truth is, there's one housing policy and one sales strategy that's better than all others combined _ a healthy growing economy with low, long-term interest rates,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: China Protests U.S. Sanctions Bill
DOC.TEXT: China on Friday strongly protested U.S. legislation imposing trade sanctions on China, saying Congress had ``wilfully trampled on the basic norms governing international relations.'' The protest was lodged by Vice Foreign Minister Liu Huaqiu in a meeting with U.S. Ambassador James Lilley, the official Xinhua News Agency reported. Liu said he had been instructed to ``express our utmost indignation and lodge a strong protest'' against the ``hegemonist act of the U.S. Congress, which, basing its legislation on rumors, has wilfully trampled on the basic norms governing international relations and wantonly interfered in China's internal affairs.'' The sanctions bill, passed Wednesday by a 98-0 vote in the Senate after earlier approval by the House, was expected to be signed into law by President Bush. The legislation, however, is largely symbolic, reflecting actions Bush took earlier following the bloody military crackdown of the student-led pro-democracy movement in China last spring. The bill gives the president the power to waive the measures if he deems it in the national interest or if he can show Congress there have been human rights improvements in China. The sanctions measures were originally part of a State Department spending authoritization bill that Bush vetoed in November because of a separate dispute concerning the Iran-Contra affair. The sanctions suspend financial underwriting for U.S. companies investing in China and aid under the Trade and Development Program. Sales of military and crime control equipment are stopped and controls are put on export of U.S.-built satellites and nuclear cooperation. The legislation also calls for a review of China's most favored nation trading status if repression against political dissidents continues. Bush has already eased some sanctions, including the ban on export of U.S. satellites, citing improved conditions in China. Bush also won a victory for his policy of keeping the door open to better U.S.-China relations when the Senate last week sustained his veto of a bill protecting Chinese students from deportation. The president said the bill was unnecessary because he had already taken administrative measures to protect students worried about persecution upon their return to China. China's strong response to the sanctions bill, however, reflected the government's intense dislike of foreign criticism and its past acknowledgments that sanctions have hurt the Chinese economy. ``Certain U.S. congressmen, addicted to bias and disregarding the realities, have readopted the amendment on sanctions against China,'' Liu said. ``This can only reveal their stubborn anti-China position and their true nature of pushing power politics.''
