He said China's road to socialist modernization will not be deterred by economic sanctions and the U.S. actions ``are just like lifting a rock only to drop it on their own feet. In the end, it is the interests of the United States itself that will be harmed.'' Liu said the U.S. government ``has an unshirkable responsibility for the unbridled anti-China wave stirred up by the U.S. Congress.'' He said China welcomes U.S. statements that it hopes to see relations returned to a positive course, but the lifting of the sanctions ``is a necessary condition for the return to normal of the bilateral relations.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Claims Capture of Airstrip; Rebels Deny It
DOC.TEXT: A ranking military source said Friday the army had captured a strategic airstrip in southeastern Angola after a fierce battle, but a rebel spokesman in Lisbon denied it. The military source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Mavinga airstrip fell Thursday after air force bombardment and fighting that caused heavy casualties on both sides. He said two columns of soldiers had consolidated positions in ``all the area of Mavinga,'' including the airstrip and ``all other important points.'' Mavinga is considered a key to military control of the region and vital to any government plans to attack the rebel stronghold at Jamba, 120 miles farther south. Norberto de Castro, rebel spokesman in Lisbon, Portugal, said a dispatch from Jonas Savimbi, chief of the UNITA rebels, reported continued heavy fighting more than 15 miles from Mavinga. There has been no government comment on the operation. Savimbi, whose group's full name is the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, cut short a five-nation European tour Tuesday to return to Angola. He ordered the rebels on general alert Friday for full-scale operations against government forces. According to the rebel radio, monitored in Luanda, Savimbi said his call for an ``all-out attack'' was in response to heavy shelling of Mavinga by government troops. He said the assault would include urban guerrilla attacks intended to make Angolan cities ``uncontrollable'' over the next two months, the radio reported. In Lisbon, de Castro confirmed government troops crossed the Lomba River, a rebel defense line that passes as near as 12 miles to Mavinga's north. A Western diplomat who follows the 15-year old conflict from Lisbon said government forces were within about half a mile of Mavinga on Thursday afternoon, but were short on supplies and might not attack Jamba immediately. An estimated 10,000 soldiers began a drive on Mavinga late in December from the government base at Cuito Cuanavale, about 100 miles to the northwest. Other government units were said to be advancing from the west. Western diplomats in Luanda said the government could use the capture of Mavinga to strengthen their position in new cease-fire talks. Diplomats from the United States, Soviet Union, Portugal and several African nations have been trying to revive negotiations for an end to the civil war, which has continued since independence from Portugal in 1975. A cease-fire agreement sealed between Savimbi and President Jose Eduardo dos Santos last June broke down within days. Savimbi demands free elections as a condition for peace. Dos Santos offers the rebels an amnesty and integration in a one-party Marxist state run by his Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, which has controlled the government since 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Oasis of Democracy Ready For 10th Straight Peaceful Vote
DOC.TEXT: Costa Rica, an oasis of democracy in Central America, celebrates its 10th straight peaceful presidential election Sunday with a youthful two-time loser as the narrow favorite. The election pits Rafael Angel Calderon, 40, who founded the Social Christian Unity Party in 1984, against Carlos Manuel Castillo, 61, of the National Liberation Party that has dominated the presidency since 1948. ``We'll win because the country doesn't want to keep the same party in power all the time, and because our organization has more energy than theirs,'' said Calderon in an interview after a campaign-closing rally Thursday night. The National Liberation Party has won seven of nine presidential races since 1948. Incumbent Oscar Arias, who could not succeed himself, beat Calderon in 1986. Calderon is considered the narrow favorite, although by agreement between the parties and the Supreme Electoral Council no polls have been conducted since Dec. 10, when Calderon had a 5 percent lead with 20 percent undecided. More than 80 percent of the 1.6 million-member electorate is expected to vote, with the winner taking office on May 8. Voters will also elect 525 mayors and 57 deputies to the unicameral National Assembly. The campaign has been relatively bland, with issues such as corruption and drug trafficking backpedaled by both major parties. Castillo was hurt when his mentor, former President Daniel Oduber, admitted accepting a party contribution of more than $100,000 in 1986 from a man charged with drug trafficking in the United States. Calderon denies accusations that he received even more money from Manuel Antonio Noriega, and both say pervasive administrative corruption is one of their top concerns. Both have also said they will continue to support the Central American peace process, but neither has the moral authority of an Arias, who won a Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts. The Costa Rican economy has been damaged by instability in El Salvador, Nicaragua and Panama, which made investors reluctant to put money into any country in the region. Confidence has been partially restored by an agreement that helped reduce the impact of the nation's $5.5 billion foreign debt _ one of the world's highest per capita _ along with the downfall of Noriega and elections in Nicaragua. Costa Rica is considered a staunch U.S. ally, and U.S. aid runs about $90 million a year. In contrast to the rest of Central America, this country of about 2.9 million has experienced peaceful elections every four years since 1948, when Calderon's father was exiled for trying to upset that year's result. After a 40-day revolution, the Calderon family was packed off to exile and the army was eliminated. Rafael Calderon himself was born in Nicaragua and didn't live in Costa Rica until he was 15. Castillo's literature refers to Calderon's background glancingly by saying Castillo represents ``the ideal of what it means to be Costa Rican'' _ which in his case includes graduate study in economics at the universities of Wisconsin and Tennessee. Calderon got 33 percent of the vote in 1982 while running for his father's party, the Calderon Republicans, before he founded his own party. He said he would view victory partially as vindication of his father and partially as the result of a growing party with a ``strong mystique.'' There are five minor candidates who are not expected to affect the outcome, although one attracted some attention last week when he was arrested on charges of child molesting, charges he denied. The minor parties complain that the major candidates are offering similar platforms and that Costa Rica suffers from a ``two-party dictatorship,'' to the detriment of Costa Rican pluralism.

DOC.HEAD: Rehnquist Urges More Stamps Honoring Supreme Court Members
DOC.TEXT: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist made a pitch Friday for more U.S. stamps depicting past Supreme Court members as he helped dedicate a stamp commemorating the court's 200th anniversary. The new stamp depicts John Marshall, the fourth chief justice, whose likeness has appeared on postage stamps three times previously. ``When it comes to members of the court who were not John Marshall, the pickings are slim,'' Rehnquist said during a ceremony at a larger-than-life statue of Marshall in the Supreme Court building. Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank responded ``I get lobbied for stamps all the time but I have never been lobbied more graciously.'' Noting that some 700,000 lawyers are doing business across the nation, Frank quipped, ``If they would use stamps instead of faxes, we could accommodate some of your wishes.'' Of Rehnquist's 15 predecessors in the chief justice's post, four besides Marshall have been depicted on stamps: John Jay, William Howard Taft, Harlan Fisk Stone and Charles Evans Hughes. Two associate justices have been honored: Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. and Hugo Black. ``For those who are associate justices, there's some hope but not a great deal,'' Rehnquist said as Justice William J. Brennan and retired Justice Lewis F. Powell chuckled in the audience. ``There may be some who will feel that John Marshall has already had more than his share of stamps depicting him as compared with other distinguished members of this court and other distinguished Americans,'' Rehnquist said. ``But this issue is designed to represent the judicial branch of the United States government,'' he said, and no one person embodies that branch more than Marshall, who served as chief justice from 1801 to 1835. ``He came to a court that was weak and insignificant,'' Rehnquist said. ``When Marshall left the court ... it was a vigorous and co-equal branch of the government, with its power of judicial review firmly established.'' The Marshall depiction apparently was not the Postal Service's first design choice for the court bicentennial stamp. Frank said that when an initial design was shown to Rehnquist, ``He opined that he hated it.'' When Rehnquist suggested depicting Marshall, Frank mentioned that Marshall had been on three previous stamps. ``The chief justice said, `A fourth will not be amiss,''' Frank said.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Literary Critic Dead at 78
DOC.TEXT: Gianfranco Contini, a renowned linguist and literary critic, has died at the age of 78. Contini has suffered from partial paralysis since last year, but the cause of his death Thursday night was not given. Contini was a professor of philology who gained worldwide recognition for his analysis of the literary techniques used by such Italian masters as Dante and Petrarch and for his critiques of his contemporaries. Contini began his career as a professor in West Germany at the University of Freiburg. He later taught at the universities of Pisa and Florence, where he had his home. Among his publications are Critical editions of Dante's ``Rime'' (``Rhymes'') and of the Italian poets of the 13th century, his ``Esercizi di Lettura'' (``Exercises in Reading''), written at 25, and his ``Letteratura dell'Italia Unita'' (``Literature of Unified Italy''). Survivors include his wife, Margareth, and two sons.

DOC.HEAD: Official Seeking Allied Support for Unification; Soviets Seeking Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Shevardnadze proposal. Pickup 3rd pvs, `Genscher said...'
DOC.TEXT: West Germany's foreign minister today said he is seeking support from the four World War II Allies for German unification, and the Soviet Union proposed Europeans, Americans and Canadians vote on the issue. In an interview published today in Moscow, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said the outside groups should vote or hold ``wide parliamentary discussions'' because they suffered so much from a unified Germany in World War II. The Soviet envoy gave the Kremlin's strongest endorsement yet to unification, but repeated conditions that this must not destabilize Europe. The interview was carried by the official Soviet news agency Tass. The West German official, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, made his comments in a radio interview before flying to Washington to discuss the prospect of unification with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Genscher said he also was consulting with British and French officials and would meet with Shevardnadze next week. East Germany's premier, Hans Modrow, on Thursday outlined a plan for a ``united fatherland'' that would be governed from Berlin but would remain militarily neutral. Genscher joined Chancellor Helmut Kohl in rejecting neutrality for the future German state. But he also said that East Germany, a member of the Warsaw Pact, should not be drawn into NATO. Uniting the two Germanys has become likely since a pro-democracy revolution ousted hard-line East German leader Erich Honecker on Oct. 18, opened the Berlin Wall, formed a coaltion government and scheduled elections in March. Earlier in the week, Genscher had said a reunited Germany should remain a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization but the territory of East Germany should not be part of the Western alliance's military structure. In an interview with Deutschlandfunk radio, Genscher also called for the European Security Conference, which includes the United States, to convene this year to give ``the dramatic developments in East and Central Europe a stable framework.'' The conference, he said, should also discuss German unification. Kohl said in a statement issued by his office in Bonn on Thursday that he would agree to talks with East German leaders as soon as a new government is elected on March 18. But he added: ``I strongly reject the concept of German neutrality.'' West Germany is home to much of the West's military might. Officials in both Germanys welcomed President Bush's proposal to cut superpower troops in Central Europe to 195,000 on each side to correspond to a recent diminishing of tensions between NATO and its rival Warsaw Pact. Modrow's government predicted the White House initiative would speed a conventional armed forces reduction being negotiated in Vienna. Modrow called for ``a reasonable time horizon'' for reunification to be determined by an inter-German dialogue. The premier's reunification plan marked a turnaround in the Communist-dominated government's position on the German question. The East Berlin leadership had previously resisted reunification efforts as premature and destabilizing. But mounting economic woes and an accelerating exodus of skilled workers to the West are forcing the nation's interim leaders to address public pressure for a merger with prosperous West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Singh Wears Another Hat: No More Fur
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh's trademark fur hats are no longer the real thing. Following protests from animal lovers and ecologists, including the minister of state for environment, the prime minister has been sporting a new line of headgear made from synthetic fur. ``Some things are done without the awareness of the background,'' Singh said in a letter addressed to Diana Ratnagar, who heads the Indian branch of Beauty Without Cruelty, an international animal rights trust founded in Britain in 1959. ``I have always stood for those who are voiceless. Therefore, my decision to switch to an artificial fur cap as soon as I was informed of the cruelty involved,'' Singh's letter said. The prime minister, who took office two months ago, frequently was photographed wearing a curly dark Karakul lamb hat, prompting protest letters and gossip-column notes in the Indian press. In the past week, he has been seen wearing fake fur. Ms. Ratnagar and several of the letter writers said Karakul lambs were slaughtered within 48 hours of their birth _ or deliberately aborted before birth _ in order for the hatmakers to obtain their hides before the curls straightened out. Ms. Ratnagar said Friday her group had given Singh one synthetic Karakul hat and two other fake fur hats. ``We felt it was wrong for the prime minister to be wearing Karakul caps,'' she said. ``Wearing fur today is a moral issue, and we feel that people shouldn't be imitating him by wearing these caps.''

DOC.HEAD: Tibetan Spiritual Leader in Prague
DOC.TEXT: The Dalai Lama arrived Friday for a five-day visit at the invitation of President Vaclav Havel. Chinese diplomats criticized the invitation as an indication of political support for Tibetan separatism. ``I have explained to the Chinese ambassador that the Dalai Lama's visit to Czechoslovakia is of a private nature. I wanted to invite him a long time ago when I was not yet a president,'' Havel said Monday. ``I want to meditate with him. ``If the Chinese republic is not satisified with this explanation, I am sorry. The Dalai Lama is coming,'' Havel added. The Tibetan spiritual leader scheduled meetings with Czechoslovakia's Roman Catholic primate, Cardinal Frantisek Tomasek, and with other religious representatives, the official CTK news agency reported. The new government installed after the November democratic revolution has sought to remove the sanctions against religious observance placed by the former Communist regime. Havel and the Dalai Lama are to spend all day Sunday in ``spiritual consultations and meditations'' in the presidential country residence at Lany, west of Prague. The visit also includes meetings with journalists and a speech on peace and spirituality to artists, scientists and the public in a Prague theater, CTK said.

DOC.HEAD: INS to Allow Some Immigrants' Families to Stay
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of illegal aliens who are spouses or children of legalized immigrants will be allowed to stay in this country under a new policy unveiled today by Immigration Commissioner Gene McNary. The new policy announced by McNary reverses a three-year-old practice of admitting only those family members for ``compelling humanitarian reasons.'' McNary said the previous policy was not being administered evenhandedly by INS district offices and as a result split families. ``We can enforce the law humanely,'' McNary told reporters at a briefing. ``To split families simply encourages further violation of the law as they (illegal aliens) attempt to reunite,'' McNary said. Under the new policy, spouses and unmarried children of a legalized immigrant will be allowed to remain in this country if they resided here on Nov. 6, 1986 _ the day the Immigration Reform and Control Act took effect. The law granted blanket amnesty to illegal aliens who could prove they were residing in the country before Jan. 1, 1982. It also provided immigrant status to undocumented farm workers who could prove they worked 90 days picking crops in this country during any of three years. More than 3 million illegal aliens have been granted amnesty under the 1986 law. The new policy effects the spouses and children of aliens who received legal resident status under the 1986 law. These people typically followed their relatives to this country but did not arrive in time to qualify for amnesty and are still illegal aliens. Under the Reagan administration policy reversed by McNary, INS deported only a small number of people following case-by-case reviews of some 10,000 applicants. But McNary said that policy ``has not been evenly and uniformly enforced throughout the country'' as ``some district directors were very lenient and other ones were very strict.'' The new policy should encourage more people to apply for the extended voluntary departure status, which allows qualified aliens to remain in this country while awaiting permission to immigrate. The only difference is they will wait in this country instead of their homeland, he said. These aliens will be given work permits and will be eligible to collect social welfare benefits. But yearly reviews of each alien will be conducted to ensure they are productive citizens. Those who commit crimes or become ``public charges'' by depending on welfare would be subject to deportation. McNary said the new order is in line with legislation that has passed the Senate and is awaiting action in the House. The new policy was criticized by the Federation for American Immigration Reform as ``just plain illegal.'' ``It ignores congressional intent, and undermines the delicate compromise crafted over a decade of national debate. It's over-broad, arbitrary, capricious and illegal,'' said Dan Stein, the group's executive director. ``At issue here,'' said Stein, ``is who defines the basic immigration law, Congress and the American people or the bureaucrats and pressure groups that surround them. It's an open invitation for future illegal immigration.''

DOC.HEAD: Whites React to Reforms with Uncertainty, Apprehension
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A thin line of white police on Friday silently watched the pulsating throng of singing and chanting blacks celebrating the legalization of the African National Congress. Small groups of glum-looking white civilians stood behind the police, staring at the jubilant blacks waving the organization's black, green and gold flag as they chanted, ``ANC! ANC!'' Other whites, eyes cast down, walked quickly past the exuberant blacks. The police, who broke up a peaceful demonstration in central Cape Town on Wednesday, made no move to block the crowd Friday. White reaction to President F.W. de Klerk's announcement of sweeping reforms appeared subdued and uncertain. De Klerk legalized the ANC and other outlawed anti-apartheid groups and called for talks with blacks on ending South Africa's racial divisions. Andries Treurnicht, leader of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party, called for a referendum on de Klerk's proposals. ``It was the most revolutionary speech to which I have listened in this Parliament,'' said Treurnicht. ``He gave no indication whatsoever in the (September) general election that he intends making such sweeping announcements today. And we say he has no mandate for doing the drastic things he intends doing and we challenge him to call a general election.'' De Klerk is unlikely to heed the call. He said after the September voting that 70 percent of the white electorate supported his plans to end apartheid and negotiate a new constitution with blacks. De Klerk included the anti-apartheid Democratic Party voters in his calculations. Democratic Party co-leader Zach de Beer said de Klerk's speech was ``a great event. ... Of course the road ahead will be steep and rough and there's a possibility of setbacks and problems. But taken all in all I have more hope for South Africa at this moment than I've had for 40 years.'' Although de Klerk did not commit himself to ending white rule, some whites expressed concern about their future in South Africa after centuries of white domination. Some said they were afraid of being swamped by blacks in a mass democracy or of being under black rule. ``As a South African I have reservations,'' said Michael Loor, a white businessman. ``Whites are feeling a bit insecure. There is reservation in the hearts of whites.'' There was little talk about de Klerk's speech in several fashionable restaurants, where the solidly white clientele, dressed in business suits and chic dresses, chatted over long lunches. Some people said they did not want to spoil lunch with talk about politics. Shoppers and businessmen hurrying along the smart streets of the city center appeared mostly unaware of the black crowds celebrating on the nearby harbor front. A white police officer watching the black celebrations said he was glad the state of emergency was being partly lifted. But he expressed doubt about any future plans to share power with blacks. ``To my mind, blacks are good people, but there is a certain element that doesn't want everything to flow freely,'' said the officer, who declined to give his name. A businessman, who also did not want to be identified, said he believed de Klerk was seeking a peaceful solution to ensure the rights of all South Africans, and would guarantee the safety of whites. ``De Klerk is a good man. He won't do the wrong thing for us,'' the man said. A few whites, mostly young students, mingled with the black marchers, waving ANC banners and dancing and clapping. They expressed hope that de Klerk and the white minority were serious about radical change that would usher in democracy and end white rule. But some expressed reservations, saying de Klerk had not spelled out a commitment to ending white rule and had declined to reveal the government's position on the future of South African government and society. ``It's quite guarded (the speech) when you read it,'' said one young man with a long blond pony tail before he was swept away in the crowd.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Politburo Member Expelled from Party for Ethics Violation
DOC.TEXT: A former Politburo member and hard-liner was expelled from the Communist Party for using his influence to buy a Mercedes-Benz at a great discount, official media said Friday. The harsh action against a conservative member of the party's Central Committee comes just three days before the committee holds a critical meeting that is expected to bring heated debate between progressives and conservatives. The expulsion of Yuri Solovyov, who was a non-voting member of the Politburo until his demotion last summer, must be confirmed by the Central Committee when it meets Monday and Tuesday, said Vladimir Kiryanov of the Leningrad party's press office. If his ouster is upheld, Solovyov will lose his pension and numerous other privileges, Kiryanov said. It was the second attack this week on a prominent hard-line Communist. The weekly Moscow News on Thursday attacked Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev and accused him of lying and clinging to outdated socialist ideals. Solovyov, former Leningrad party chief, was retired last summer during a meeting of the Leningrad party organization attended by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Solovyov had been criticized for resisting Gorbachev's reforms. Last spring, Solovyov suffered a humiliating defeat in the vote for parliament, despite having no opposition, when more than 50 percent of the voters crossed his lone name off the ballot. Solovyov bought a ``luxurious Mercedes'' in December for ``a practically symbolic price, even less than the cost of a new (Soviet-made) Zhiguli,'' the government newspaper Izvestia reported. He was expelled for violating party ethics because he did not follow the rules on car purchases, Kiryanov said. Another reason he was kicked out was ``immodesty,'' Izvestia said. The official news agency Tass implied that Solovyov abused his position to obtain the vehicle, but Kiryanov refused to elaborate. Top Communists have enjoyed special privileges such as foreign cars and luxury food allotments for decades, but Gorbachev has pushed for ``social fairness'' that has eliminated some privileges. Former Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev, who has been discredited and blamed for economic stagnation and corruption, had a great love of Western automobiles. Tass implied that others in the generally conservative Leningrad party leadership might be threatened by the scandal. It said the local prosecutor had been asked to investigate whether other Communist leaders bought their cars illegally. Neither Tass nor Kiryanov explained the precise violation. Izvestia specifically named former Leningrad Vice-Mayor G. Bukin as another involved in the scandal, for acquiring an almost-new Audi. Solovyov was expelled at an emergency meeting of the Leningrad party committee on Thursday, the day after the sensational Leningrad TV program ``600 Seconds'' broadcast a report showing Solovyov's name on an auto registration list. Journalist Alexander Nevzorov told viewers it had become easy to buy a Mercedes-Benz for 9,780 rubles. Rubles are worthless on the international market, so such a statement implies the Soviet government took rubles from the buyers and paid for the cars from its scarce store of foreign currency. Nevzorov noted in the broadcast that 9,780 rubles is lower even than the state price for a Soviet-made Volga, editor Alexander Borisoglebsky confirmed Friday. Shortages require normal would-be buyers to wait years or pay a vastly higher black-market price. Privileged people in the Soviet Union, however, can skip to the head of the line. The 9,780 rubles are worth about $16,000 at the commercial exchange rate and about one-tenth of that at the rate for tourists and other individuals. Solovyov acquired a Mercedes 280-S, Borisoglebsky said. That model was last produced in 1985 and cost about $23,000 without taxes in West Germany. Solovyov, 64, is former construction engineer on the Leningrad subway. He began full-time party work in 1974 as a secretary in the Leningrad regional party committee. He became Leningrad party chief in 1985 and a candidate member of the Politburo in 1986 _ during Gorbachev's tenure as party chief.

DOC.HEAD: Inmate Arraigned on Renewed Murder Charge in Car-Bombing of Reporter
DOC.TEXT: An inmate pleaded innocent Friday to a renewed murder charge in the 1976 car-bomb slaying of an investigative reporter for the Arizona Republic. James Robison, 67, of Chandler, was convicted of killing Don Bolles in 1977, but the conviction was reversed on appeal. Robison remained in prison on an unrelated conviction and was still there when Attorney General Bob Corbin filed the new murder charge last fall. Maricopa County Superior Court Judge Thomas O'Toole set trial April 19. In addition to the murder charge, Corbin's office has been working with a state grand jury investigating a possible conspiracy to obstruct earlier investigations of the Bolles probe. The grand jury's work is secret, but there are indications that Phoenix attorney Neal Roberts is a potential target. Roberts was granted limited immunity early in the police investigation, but he told The Phoenix Gazette this week he had brought his lawyer with him to the latest grand jury probe. Under Arizona law, the only grand jury witnesses who can be accompanied by lawyers are those the state designates as potential targets of the grand jury. Roberts told police in 1976 that he had arranged a charter flight and motel room for John Harvey Adamson, a greyhound breeder and tow-truck operator who has acknowledged planting the fatal bomb and has claimed that Robison triggered it by remote control. Roberts has said he had nothing to do with Bolles' death. Adamson testified at Robison's initial trial in return for leniency. Robison and another man were convicted, but an appeals court threw out the convictions because the defense wasn't allowed to question a witness adequately. Adamson then demanded a better deal before he would agree to testify at the new trial. Arguing that Adamson's refusal to testify again broke the plea bargain, Corbin brought Adamson to trial and won a first-degree murder conviction and a death sentence he hoped would persuade Adamson to talk. Adamson's death sentence was thrown out by a federal appeals court earlier this year. Corbin now says he has enough evidence to proceed against Robison without Adamson's help. Bolles died June 13, 1976, 11 days after his car was blown up in a hotel parking lot. A motive for the slaying has never been established.

DOC.HEAD: Baby Shamu to Leave Mom, Move to Ohio Sea World
DOC.TEXT: The original Baby Shamu, the first killer whale born and raised successfully in captivity, will be taken away from her mother this month to become the star of her own Sea World show in Ohio. Florida's Department of Natural Resources has authorized the separation and transfer from the Sea World marine park in Orlando _ the first time a captive killer whale has been intentionally separated from its mother, state officials say. Federal wildlife officials also agreed to the move. The company doesn't expect the move to affect either the mother or her 5-year-old offspring, a Sea World spokesman said Thursday. ``We really anticipate no problems at all,'' said Nick Gollatscheck. Researchers who study the marine mammals in the wild say they live in pods or groups related on the mother's side. Many believe killer whale offspring remain with their mothers throughout their lifetime, but some biologists dispute this theory. Ed Asper, zoological director for the Orlando Sea World, said the bonds between Baby Shamu and her mother, Katina, have weakened because the mother has since had another offspring. In addition to Baby Shamu, now known by the stage name of Shamu, the Florida park has five other killer whales. The Aurora, Ohio, Sea World now has two killer whales. One of those animals will be moved to another of the Sea World parks, but company officials would not say which one. Sea World applied for a state permit to move the whale last month, and the agency conducted an investigation before granting a transport permit. ``The primary concern was the condition of the facilities at Sea World (in Ohio),'' said Charles Futch, an assistant director of marine resources for DNR in Tallahassee. An inspection certificate signed Thursday by the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, a branch of the U.S. Agriculture Department, concluded that killer whale tanks in Ohio met federal standards. The DNR then approved the move to take place by Feb. 28. Shamu and two Pacific white-sided dolphins will be placed in special stretchers and flown to the Aurora park, which will open for the season around Memorial Day, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Pleased, But Will Keep Up Pressure to End Apartheid
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leaders praised South Africa's decision Friday to legalize the guerrilla group but said the government would remain a global outcast until it ends apartheid. ``Victory is in sight,'' said ANC leader Walter Sisulu, although he declined to describe the white-run government as committed to ending racial segregation. ``They have made a progressive beginning and, on the basis of that, I am hopeful that they will go farther.'' President F.W. de Klerk said that he was legalizing the ANC, lifting bans or restrictions on more than 60 other organizations and freeing most people who had been jailed for joining them when they were banned. De Klerk told Parliament in Cape Town that he was relaxing state of emergency restrictions and would soon free jailed ANC leader Nelson Mandela. He did not say when Mandela would be freed, saying more time was needed to settle issues related to his safety. Sisulu praised the changes but said they were only preliminary. Talks to end South Africa's decades of racial conflict could not yet begin, he said, and sanctions against the government should remain. An ANC statement said South Africa's main black nationalist movement remained ``greatly concerned'' that some political prisoners would not be freed, detentions without trial could continue and some emergency regulations would remain. ``These decisions ... must be reviewed and changed without delay,'' the ANC said. The statement said Mandela, who has served 27 years in jail for plotting against white rule, should be freed immediately. It rejected de Klerk's expressed concern for Mandela's personal security outside of prison and said the ANC should share responsibility for the 71-year-old leader's safety. Sisulu and other top ANC leaders were in Stockholm on a Scandinavian tour, the first visit outside Africa for six elderly ANC figures since their recent release from life sentences in South Africa. The group visited ANC President Oliver Tambo, who is recovering from a stroke in a Stockholm clinic, and sought to resume personal contacts with Scandinavian governments, which have long been among the ANC's strongest backers. An ANC spokesman said Secretary-General Alfred Nzo and Joe Slovo, head of the South African Communist Party and former head of the ANC's armed wing, were also expected in Sweden late Friday. Their presence raised the possibility that an urgent review of the South African situation, promised by the ANC as a result of de Klerk's announcements, would begin over the weekend. In its statement, the ANC leadership said it would consult with the Mass Democratic Movement, the main alliance of anti-apartheid groups within South Africa, as well as other allies in the country. ``The review of the new situation will include an assessment of the prospects of genuine negotiations to end the apartheid system,'' the ANC said. It urged the world community, meanwhile, to do nothing ``to lessen the isolation of the apartheid regime.'' Although the ANC has conceded that its guerrilla operations inside South Africa have had little effect, it has in the past refused to abandon the armed struggle. Sisulu said that the continuation of violence by the ANC ``will have to be discussed'' as part of its policy review. Asked whether negotiations with the government could begin, Sisulu said, ``No. ... This is only the beginning.'' He said the government should remove soldiers from black townships in South Africa and should clarify the question of whether political exiles, such as Tambo, were now free to return home. Sisulu said he doubted de Klerk had placed himself at political risk, despite opposition by the white Conservative Party to any concessions to blacks. He said he believed that the conservative movement has already ``reached the zenith of its power'' in South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Siegfried & Roy Launch $20 Million Extravaganza
LaserPhoto VG1
DOC.TEXT: Illusionists Siegfried and Roy, who came here 20 years ago as bit players and remained to become one of the city's top draws, have launched their long-awaited $20 million entertainment spectacle. Some of the top names in the American theater share the credits for the flashy show, which opened to a sellout audience Thursday night at the new Mirage Hotel. ``This is a total feast for the senses,'' said producer Kenneth Feld after the show. ``This elevates the level of entertainment in Las Vegas to new heights.'' The famed illusionists were one of the city's top entertainment attractions before closing 19 months ago for a tour that included performances in Japan and a stint at Radio City Music Hall in New York City. They were signed by Mirage Hotel owner Steve Wynn to a five-year, $57.5 million contract, and were scheduled to open Dec. 26. The show was delayed because of technical problems associated with the complex production. ``It's like producing `Star Wars' and `Indiana Jones' live on stage twice nightly,'' Feld said of production glitches that delayed the opening. The show left even jaded Las Vegas show veterans somewhat agog. One television reporter called the production ``the show of the century.'' The show's designer and co-director is John Napier, whose credits include ``Cats,'' ``Les Miserables'' and ``Starlight Express.'' Singer Michael Jackson wrote some of the music for the production. John Caird is writer and co-director for the show. Caird won Tony awards for his role as co-director of ``Les Miserables'' and ``Nicholas Nickleby.'' Andrew Bridge, who won a Tony for his work in ``Phantom of the Opera,'' is the show's lighting director. Feld is producer of the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus and five Walt Disney ice spectaculars currently touring the world. Wynn spent more than $25 million on the showroom, including a giant stage and lighting facilities capable of showcasing Broadway productions. Tickets run $55 in the 1,500-seat showroom, with two shows a night, six nights a week, three weeks a month. ``We're bringing back to Las Vegas the magic that Las Vegas deserves,'' Roy said after the show. ``We've combined the magic of the theater with the technology of tomorrow,'' added Siegfried. The one hour, 45 minute show features spectacular staging, laser technology, a 30-foot tall mechanical dragon, 54 dancers and a dozen of the rare white tigers raised by Siegfried and Roy at their Las Vegas home. The illusionists, natives of West Germany, are known around the world for their efforts to breed the white tigers, which have become extinct in the wild. The show opens with a flashy ``Star Wars'' scenario and Siegfried and Roy arriving in their own mini space capsules. Another segment has Roy sitting atop a 30-foot pyramid that is destroyed by an explosion and fire, leaving him levitated high above the stage. One of the most popular portions of the show is a simple film of the duo's white tigers, shot when some of the 500-pound tigers featured in the show were 25-pound cubs, romping about the entertainers' desert compound. The show ends with the mother of several of the tigers, Sitarra, and eight of her grown offspring on the set, as the song ``Bless the Beasts and the Children'' plays.

DOC.HEAD: January's Unemployment Rate Holds Steady at 5.3 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The nation's unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent for an eighth straight month in January but the economy still produced 275,000 new jobs, the government said Friday in a report that analysts took as a refreshing sign of an economic rebound. ``This shows the economy is strengthening. It's about as clear an indication as we're going to get that the economy is not going down,'' said Michael K. Evans, head of a private Washington forecasting firm. ``It has to relieve some of the fears that we're headed for recession,'' added economist David Wyss of DRI-McGraw Hill. Since last June, monthly unemployment rates as originally reported by the Labor Department have fluctuated within a percentage point of 5.3 percent. Those monthly figures later were revised with updated seasonal adjustment factors, and each month showed a 5.3 percent level, the agency said. Analysts said the steady jobless rate and better-than-expected job growth was especially encouraging in light of the economy's 0.5 percent growth at the end of 1989, the poorest showing in more than three years. They said Friday's report, the first comprehensive look at economic activity in 1990, indicates the pace of economic expansion, as measured by the gross national product, should improve in the first three months of the year. In other good economic news, the Commerce Department said Friday that orders to U.S. factories for manufactured goods shot up 1.9 percent in December to a seasonally adjusted $244.2 billion. Analysts said the sluggish manufacturing sector of the economy might be perking up after durable goods orders jumped 4.8 percent in November and 3.2 percent in December. The Labor Department said January's strong job growth figures might be overstated because the warm weather last month, which followed a bitter cold December, made it tough to seasonally adjust job totals for construction and other industries affected by weather. Delays in the reporting of post-Christmas layoffs in retail trade also may have skewed the numbers. The manufacturing slump added to the overall slowdown in the nation's economy last year, and that sector's lackluster performance continued in January. Factory jobs dropped 112,000 last month, with 90,000 of the losses suffered by the struggling auto industry. However, many of those laid-off auto workers have been recalled since last month when the Labor Department conducted its survey to gauge job growth, the agency said. Still, it was the 10th straight month manufacturing jobs declined. Yet analysts were impressed at the economy's ability to absorb those losses without a hike in the jobless rate. ``The auto industry has taken a really big hit, but the rest of the economy is marching along, and has virtually swallowed up the manufacturing losses,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. ``It certainly indicates that the economy is weathering the storm. It has favorable implications for later on,'' Dederick said. Michigan has been particularly hard hit by the manufacturing decline; the jobless rate there jumped to 8.4 percent in January, up from 7.2 percent in December. That was the largest unemployment increase in the 11 large industrial states surveyed by the government. Construction employers reported a gain of 104,000 jobs during last month's mild weather, following the 50,000-job loss during December's harsh conditions. Meanwhile, the service-producing industries, which helped carry the economy last year, continued to demonstrate healthy gains this year. Those industries reported 284,000 new jobs, with 48,000 of them created in health services. Other industries of the service sector posting large gains were transportation, with 27,000 new jobs; wholesale trade, 24,00 new jobs; and retail trade, 127,000. The last figure, though, is likely overstated because of problems factoring in seasonal adjustments after Christmas. Average hourly earnings, sometimes an advance warning of inflationary pressures on the economy, were up just 0.1 percent in January to $9.84. The government said that the civilian labor force, or the number of people with jobs or those actively seeking employment, declined by 149,000 last month to 124 million. The number of Americans with jobs fell by 25,000 to 117.8 million. There were few major shifts in the jobless rate among major demographic groups last month. The biggest change was among Hispanics, where unemployment fell from 8.5 percent in December to 7.1 percent in January. In a separate calculation of unemployment that counts members of the armed services stationed in the United States, the January jobless rate was 5.2 percent, down from 5.3 percent in December.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Privately, Paul McCartney says he's really just an ordinary Joe. The former Beatle, who reportedly has amassed $600 million, says he grows his own wheat and vegetables, jogs and paints a bit, goes to school plays, and tries to ``get on with'' his daughter's boyfriends. McCartney, 47, and his wife of 20 years, Linda, described their offstage life in an interview in the Feb. 19 issue of US magazine. Mrs. McCartney says she revels in being an ``ordinary housewife.'' ``I like getting up and getting the kids to school. I make their lunches. I love it.'' They have four children: Heather, 26, from Linda's previous marriage; Mary, 20; Stella, 18; and James, 12.

Sammy Cahn, who wrote Frank Sinatra's hits ``Three Coins in the Fountain,'' ``Call Me Irresponsible,'' ``Fly Me to the Moon'' and ``Love and Marriage,'' got a star Friday on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. And it's right next to the star for Ol' Blue Eyes. ``His wife requested that,'' Ana Holler, a spokeswoman for the Hollywood Walk of Fame, explained before Cahn was honored Friday. ``She wanted him to be near Frank or Dean Martin _ but there was nothing near Dean Martin.'' Among the four-time Oscar winner's friends who paid $3,500 to the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce to sponsor the star were David Niven Jr., Sidney Poitier, Tony Danza, Dudley Moore, Jackie Collins and Sinatra offsprings Nancy and Tina.

Country music star Randy Travis says that at heart he's still a kid who wants to be a cowboy. ``You know, raised on a farm and you think you are a cowboy, I just got into guns,'' he said. ``I don't hunt anymore because I'm not going to dress it and eat it, so I'm not gonna go shoot it. Now I just shoot targets.'' Travis, who performs Saturday in Dallas, said he frequently practices his quick-draw technique. ``I like twirling the gun and doing fancy ways of putting it back in the holster, throw it over my shoulder and all sorts of stuff,'' he said. ``I'm more or less a kid. I doubt I ever will grow up.'' Travis, 30, has sold more than 10 million albums and his current release, ``No Holdin' Back,'' is No. 1 on the country charts.

Former Sen. Howard Baker has been elected to the United Technologies Corp. board of directors following his private work for the company in developing a corporate code of ethics. ``The mutual respect that grew out of those meetings, in addition to Howard's insights into the corporation, have prompted us to continue the relationship,'' said Robert Daniell, United Technologies chairman and chief executive officer. United Technologies, based in Hartford, Conn., produces high-tech products and provides support services to the aerospace, building systems and automotive industries. Baker, who returned to private law practice in Washington and Knoxville after 19 years in the Senate and two years as President Reagan's chief of staff, also is a director of Federal Express, Waste Management, Memorex, Telex and MCA, and is a trustee of the Mayo Clinic.

Veteran country music star Conway Twitty is offering his tourist complex for sale for $6 million, his real estate agent says. The 9.5-acre Twitty City, which opened in May 1982, has a museum, pavilion and offices. ``Basically, he is trying to simplify his lifestyle,'' said real estate agent Jerre Wheelhouse. ``There is no financial pressure to sell the property.'' Twitty, a former rock 'n' roll star, is known for such hit records as ``It's Only Make Believe'' and ``Linda on My Mind.''

Fans queued up by the thousands outside the Civic Center, and some spent the night waiting, for a chance to get tickets to the climactic fight scene in Sylvester Stallone's ``Rocky V.'' Within about an hour Thursday, people had grabbed up 16,000 of the 20,000 tickets for two days of filming in Stallone's latest installment of the Rocky Balboa saga. Ten thousand people are needed for a boxing match audience each day of filming, Feb. 8 and Feb. 9. Tickets went to people who had vouchers that were given out in stores, restaurants and other places. ``We want to be in the movies,'' said Doug Eagar, 18, of suburban Upper Darby, who stood in line with his brother and three friends. Dave Fulton, the film's publicist, has refused to say who would fight in the scene. Rocky Balboa retires from the ring in ``Rocky V.''

Vanna White won't be part of a campaign to attract a National Football League franchise after all. City officials had said they were negotiating with Disney-MGM Studios to hold a mock ``Wheel of Fortune'' game and wanted to hire Miss White to turn the letters on the show's set at Disney-MGM. But Arthur ``Chick'' Sherrer, president of Touchdown Jacksonville Inc., says the game-show project planned for a NFL owners reception March 11 in Orlando has been scrapped. ``That was a very preliminary concept, one of several being considered,'' he said Thursday.

Thomas DeBarge, a member of the singing DeBarge family, faces up to 20 years in prison after pleading guilty to possessing cocaine with intent to deliver. DeBarge, 32, entered his plea Wednesday in Kent County Circuit Court. Sentencing has not been scheduled. The charge stems from DeBarge's sale of the drug to an undercover officer last fall. DeBarge, who has been free on $2,500 bond, is in a drug treatment program in Muskegon.

DOC.HEAD: Baker To Make First Apperance Before Committee of Soviet Legislature
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of States James A. Baker III will make an unprecedented appearance and answer questions before a committee of the Supreme Soviet during a visit to the Soviet Union next week, the State Department announced Friday. Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Baker will leave Washington on Monday, stop in Prague en route to Moscow and hold meetings in the Soviet capital on Wednesday through Saturday. The spokeswoman also said Baker will meet with French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas during a refueling stop at Shannon Airport in Ireland early Tuesday on the way to Prague. In Prague he will meet with Czechoslovakian President Vaclav Havel and hold other meetings. On the way home, Baker will stop in Ottawa, Canada, to attend a meeting Feb. 12-13 of NATO and Warsaw Pact officials to discuss an ``open skies'' proposal that would open U.S. and Soviet territory to overflights. Ms. Tutwiler said Baker had no other stops planned, but said she could not rule them out. There have been reports he might meet with Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abel-Meguid, and his Israeli counterpart, Moshe Arens. ``Anything is possible,'' she said. ``We have nothing to announce.'' On arrival in Moscow on Wednesday, Baker will meet with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. He will meet with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev on Friday. She said the secretary of state will make a brief opening statement and then answer questions for 90 minutes in his appearance before the 44-member International Affairs Committee of the Supreme Soviet, the nation's chief legislative body, on Feb. 10. ``The Soviet legislature is ... likely to play an increasingly important role in shaping Soviet foreign policy,'' the spokeswoman said. ``Secretary Baker's meetings involve an excellent opportunity to deepen our own undertanding of Soviet legislators most concerned with foreign affairs, as well as answer their questions about U.S. foreign policy.'' Mrs. Tutwiler said it was the first time a U.S. official would appear and answer questions in the Sovoiet equivalent of a congressional hearing. ``This kind of meeting has not been done in the past,'' she said. ``We are living in a time when a lot of things that haven't been done before are being done, and this is one of them.'' Ms. Tutwiler said current plans were to remain in the Soviet Union on Saturday and fly to Ottawa on Sunday and return to Washington on Tuesday or Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Surge Into Streets to Celebrate de Klerk's Announcement
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Black taxi-drivers honked horns and stopped traffic, and workers whistled to celebrate President F.W. de Klerk's announcement Friday of watershed political changes. Blacks surged into in the streets in Cape Town, Durban and Johannesburg at the news that the African National Congress and all other organizations had been legalized and many national emergency restrictions lifted. They streamed into the dusty roads of townships to cheer, and marched through a Cape Town train station chanting, ``ANC! ANC!'' while police watched passively. ``We are probably seeing history in the making in South Africa,'' said Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, who could not stop smiling during a news conference. ``We had expected that Mr. de Klerk might deliver something, but what he said has certainly taken my breath away,'' Tutu said. Johannesburg whites stepped out of their shops to take photographs and smiled as hundreds of blacks danced and marched through downtown, waving banners and newspaper headlines that declared: ``ANC Unbanned.'' Drivers stopped their cars in the street, honking their horns and punching their fists into their air, as black workers leaned out of office windows, whistling and shouting. Police halted the march with a line of yellow patrol vehicles, chased some protesters and fired tear gas to disperse others. No injuries or arrests were reported, and many protesters laughed as they ran from the police. In Cape Town, thousands of blacks banged placards against the fence around Parliament, chanting ``ANC! ANC!'' before de Klerk arrived to deliver his speech, which granted many of their demands. The announcement of the legalization of the ANC was picked up on a car radio. The predominantly black crowd of 5,000 broke into cheers, whistles and more chants as recently freed anti-apartheid activist Popo Molefe relayed the news over a bullhorn from the back of a truck. ``We would be unreasonable if we failed to acknowledge that of all the presidents, of all the leaders of the Nationalist government, that in fact de Klerk has taken the most bold step and has emerged as the most courageous,'' Molefe said. ``Mr. de Klerk, in his speech, has moved rather swiftly to meet most of the demands of the people,'' said the Rev. Allan Boesak, the president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches. ``These are clear, decisive steps that will undoubtedly, help to create a better atmosphere here.'' A black youth climbed atop a statue near Parliament of Jan Smuts, a former South African prime minister, waving an ANC flag and brandishing a wooden model of an AK-47 automatic rifle, the symbol of the ANC's military wing. But police riot squads remained out of view and there were no confrontations as the crowd marched joyfully through Cape Town's streets. Scores of white policemen and white shopkeepers watched silently from the sidewalks, some shaking their heads. Blacks and whites stood in groups with people reading the afternoon newspaper, whose headline said, ``ANC Legalized.'' After dark, thousands of blacks paraded through the townships outside Cape Town, waving banners and singing hoarsely, while black men, women and children came to the doors of their tents or tin-roofed shanties to cheer. Street dancing broke out in downtown Durban as a group of black railway union members marched through the city center to a crescendo of cheers.

DOC.HEAD: President Appeals for Peace in Kosovo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs, Drnovsek quotes and small protest; picks up 7th `Tanjug said'
DOC.TEXT: Federal President Janez Drnovsek visited Kosovo province Friday and appealed for an end to violence that has cost the lives of at least 21 ethnic Albanians in 10 days. He said the ethnic unrest threatens political and economic reform in Yugoslavia, which is trying to transform itself from a Communist nation to a Western-style democracy with a market economy. Riot police used tear gas to disperse about 200 demonstrators in Pristina, capital of Kosovo, while Drnovsek met with provincial officials. No other protests were reported Friday, but a virtual general strike seemed to be in force. Kosovo, a southern province next to Albania, is the nation's poorest region and 90 percent of its 1.9 million people are ethnic Albanians. ``Production has almost completely stopped,'' and even some people who went to their jobs were refusing to work, the official news agency Tanjug reported. At least 30,000 people in Kosovo have been on almost constant strike since protests and riots began Jan. 24, according to official statistics. Ethnic Albanians have demanded greater autonomy since Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, made constitutional changs a year ago that gave it almost total control of the province. Kosovo is part of Serbia, but had functioned as an autonomous region. Tanjug quoted Drnovsek as saying: ``I appeal to all peoples in Kosovo, regardless of their nationalities, to stop violent activities.'' He said the situation was ``exceptionally grave and complex,'' and ``blocks the country's fundamental reforms.'' The federal government has sent a sweeping political and economic reform package to Parliament. When Drnovsek arrived in Pristina, he said: ``I have come with some new ideas for solving the Kosovo problem.'' He would not give details, and said he would discuss the proposals with provincial authorities. Tanjug said a federal government commission consisting of Premier Ante Markovic, the defense and interior ministers and four other Cabinet ministers had been formed to ``monitor and control'' the Kosovo situation. ``Defense Minister Veljko Kadijevic is at his command post with a group of generals,'' it said, without elaborating. Serbian authorities claim the constitutional changes were necessary to protect minority Slavs in Kosovo. The republic's conservative leaders have denounced proposals from two liberal northern provinces, Slovenia and Croatia, that Kosovo be allowed greater Freedom. About 10,000 Serbs held a rally Friday in a Pristina sports arena to demand that the federal government ensure order. If it does not, the demonstrators said, they should be issued weapons to defend themselves from ``attacks by separatists and terrorists,'' terms used by Serbian officials to describe ethnic Albanians who seek greater autonomy. Demonstrators carried portraits of Slobodan Milosevic, president of Serbia, and chanted his name. Speakers claimed Slovenia and Croatia were inciting unrest by claiming the rights of ethnic Albanians were being violated. Three people were killed Thursday, including a young girl, Pristina radio said. That brought the number killed since Jan. 24 to 21, by official count. More army tanks and armored personnal carriers arrived Friday from the neighboring republic of Macedonia. Adm. Stane Brovet, deputy defense minister, told the federal parliament Friday that ethnic Albanian ``nationalists have clearly demonstrated they intend to secede from Yugoslavia in order to join Albania,'' Tanjug reported. ``Their intentions must be thwarted by all means, including force,'' and the armed forces are ``prepared at all times to defend the country's integrity and its constitutional order,'' Brovet declared. In contrast, an editorial in the Slovenian daily Delo said: ``There is no war in Kosovo. There are no mad terrorists, but only powerless demonstrators ... whose every act is immediately misinterpreted in the province's politicized atmosphere.'' It said the demonstrators were victims of ``a planned policy of repression, which wants to subjugate them by any means possible. . .. Serbian policy in the province should be allowed to fail completely.''

DOC.HEAD: Liquor Consumption Drops Again
DOC.TEXT: Americans drank less liquor last year, continuing a decade-long trend, and wine consumption dropped for the third straight year, an industry group reported Friday. Changing lifestyles, concerns about health and publicity about drunken driving and alcohol abuse contributed to the declines, according to the Jobson Beverage Alcohol Group, which publishes an annual survey. Consumption of distilled spirits dropped more than 2 percent in 1989, to 141 million cases. Liquor drinking peaked at 166 million cases in 1979 and has dropped 15 percent in 10 years. Wine consumption fell 7 percent in 1989, largely because of the decreasing popularity of wine coolers and a drop in table wine consumption, the organization said. Wine coolers were down 19 percent, to about 40 million cases, while table wine was down 4.3 percent, to 141.4 million cases. Sparkling wine was off 5.4 percent in 1989 and dessert wine was off 1.2 percent, but vermouth was up 5 percent, possibly reflecting an increase in the consumption of martinis, Jobson reported. The nation's liquor consumption worked out to 0.8 cases per adult, down from 1.1 cases per adult in 1979. Per capita consumption was at 0.6 cases, the lowest level since 1965. An average case of liquor contains 12 bottles and holds 2.7 gallons. Despite the overall drop, tequila was up 1.2 percent and Irish whiskey was up 2.2 percent. The statistics are printed in Jobson's Handbook Advance, a 138-page report.

DOC.HEAD: Criminals Have Discovered Computers
DOC.TEXT: Criminals have discovered the value of computers and are using them ``in crimes of unprecedented economic cost,'' the National Instiute of Justice said Friday. The institute cited a recent accounting firm study that estimated $3 billion to $5 billion in thefts each year by high-tech criminals. ``Increasingly, computers are being found in the illegal activities of drug networks,'' said Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. ``Drug traffickers use them to communicate with each other, record their transactions and transfer and launder money.'' The crimes include electronic funds transfer fraud and theft of commercial inventories. The report mentioned a former insurance firm employee in Fort Worth, Texas, who used a program to delete more than 160,000 records from the company's computer and also a prostitution ring that had a data base of more than 80,000 clients, their credit card numbers and sexual preferences.

DOC.HEAD: Punxsutawney Phil Forecasts Early Spring
LaserPhoto PUNX1
DOC.TEXT: Punxsutawney Phil, the country's No. 1 four-footed forecaster, squinted hard but failed to see his shadow Friday, thus predicting an early spring for only the 10th time in more than a century. The squirming, 10-pound groundhog was pulled from his manmade burrow atop Gobbler's Knob at 7:27 a.m. The crowd of about 1,500 screamed wildly after Phil's forecast was announced. ``He stood proud, tall and confident, surveyed the throng of loyal followers, peered skyward toward the east and then fixed his eyes groundward,'' said Edwin Snyder, 64, a county judge and a member of the Punxsutawney Groundhog Club's exclusive Inner Circle. ``He turned to Groundhog Club President Jim Means and signaled to him in unmistakable groundhogese, `There is no shadow today,''' Snyder said. Virtually everyone in the crowd of mostly students, some of whom had waited in the light rain and mud for hours, seemed stunned by the woodchuck's prediction. Even the tuxedo-clad members of the Inner Circle, who decide well in advance what Phil predicts every Groundhog Day, professed astonishment. ``I think he made a good pick,'' said Means, 66, who held Phil to his ear then informed Snyder of the forecast so the judge could announce it. John Groninger, 24, a college student from Fairbanks, Alaska, who's traveling around the country, was thrilled with Phil's prediction even though he doubts it will apply back home. ``It will be six more weeks of winter no matter what Phil says,'' Groninger said, grinning. Tradition has it that if a groundhog sees his shadow at sunrise on Feb. 2, there will be six more weeks of winter. If he doesn't, spring is just around the corner. Phil has predicted an early spring just nine other times since 1887, when German-born farmers initiated the yearly event in this small western Pennsylvania town. The favorable forecasts were in 1890, 1902, 1934, 1950, 1970, 1975, 1983, 1986 and 1988. The farmers borrowed from the legend of Candlemas, a Christian feast celebrating the first time the infant Jesus was taken to the temple. An old Scottish couplet claims, ``If Candlemas be fair, there'll be two winters in the year.'' As soon as his forecast was announced, Phil was whisked away from the burrow and returned to his rest-of-the-year home at the local library, a heated and air-conditioned hutch that he shares with two other groundhogs, Philomena and Barney. Other prognosticating groundhogs around the country followed Phil's lead. Octorara Orphie also saw no shadow in central Pennsylvania's Quarryville. Neither did West Virginia's Concord Charlie as he was ``wandering around campus to see if any flowers are up,'' said Tom Bone, public information director for Concord College in Athens. Ditto for French Creek Freddie at the French Creek Wildlife Preserve in Upshur County in West Virginia and General Lee at the Yellow River Game Ranch in Lilburn, Ga. Buckeye Chuck, Ohio's official groundhog, also failed to see his shadow when he emerged from his burrow in a wooded lot next to the studios of radio station WMRN in Marion. The newest addition to the groundhog lineup, Little Hog, made his debut at the Indianapolis Zoo with fans joining in a rousing chorus of ``You Are My Sunshine'' on kazoos. But there was no sunshine and no shadow there. Phil's forecast isn't too far off the National Weather Service's prediction for the next few months. Meteorologists expect February to be warmer than usual in western Pennsylvania but colder than usual in March and April. The Old Farmer's Almanac, on the other hand, is predicting an extremely cold and snowy February around Punxsutawney.

DOC.HEAD: Boston Station to Begin Broadcasting Soviet News Show
DOC.TEXT: A group of public television stations will begin broadcasting ``Vremya,'' a Soviet news show, with an English translation, one of the stations announced Friday. WGBH and 20 other public television stations nationwide will broadcast ``Vremya'' for a two-week test period starting Feb. 12 while they try to line up underwriters for the show, which could cost $1 million a year, WGBH news director Alan Foster said. He described the show as ``remarkably like what we're used to seeing here'' and said the U.S. broadcast would give viewers an opportunity to judge Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's policy of ``glasnost'' or openness. ``We can judge for ourselves just how free it is,'' he said. WGBH will broadcast the program at 1 a.m., 10 to 12 hours after it is broadcast in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Garcia Says He Will Attend Colombia Drug Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD that other Latin American leaders also protested the invasion, Noriega brought to Florida to face drug charges. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Alan Garcia said today he will attend a drug summit in Colombia on Feb. 15 now that President Bush has promised to reduce the number of U.S. troops in Panama to their pre-invasion levels. Soon after the United States invaded Panama on Dec. 20 and toppled the regime of Manuel Antonio Noriega, Garcia and other Latin American leaders protested to Washington. Garcia said at the time that he would boycott the summit, probably sending a government minister in his place. Garcia, Bush and the presidents of Colombia and Bolivia had planned to coordinate their fight against drug trafficking at the meeting in Cartagena. Earlier this week, President Bush said he would reduce the U.S. military presence in Panama to its pre-invasion level of about 13,000 troops ``well before the end of February.'' He did not give a specific date. At the peak of the U.S. intervention in Panama last month, 27,000 U.S. troops were there. Washington already has brought 11,000 home. Twenty-three American servicemen were killed in Panama and more than 300 wounded. The civilian death toll is unclear, but more than 200 are believed to have died. Before the invasion, about 13,000 U.S. troops were stationed in Panama, where the U.S. Southern Command is located. A major objective of the invasion was to bring Noriega to Florida to face federal drug trafficking charges. Garcia said Bush's announcement caused him to reconsider his decision to boycott the summit in Colombia. In a statement, he said will not only attend the meeting, but he also will present a ``decisive and positive proposal'' to combat drug trafficking. Presidents Virgilio Barco of Colombia and Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia have already agreed to attend the summit, which will discuss strategies to fight drug trafficking in the United States and the three Andean nations. The Andean nations are the source of most of the world supply of cocaine, the bulk of which is sold and consumed in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Met Presents New Production of `Faust'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: Gounod's ``Faust,'' once one of the world's most popular operas but nowadays rarely heard, has been given a new production at the Metropolitan Opera under the hand of Broadway veteran Harold Prince. At Thursday night's premiere, the singing was beautiful, but emotion was lacking. In fact, the most moving parts of the opera were the overture conducted by Charles Dutoit and the final trio for Carol Vaness as Marguerite, Neil Shicoff as Faust and James Morris as Mephistopheles. All three were in splendid voice throughout the long evening. Since the entire cast was singing in ``Faust'' for the first time at the Met and the scenery and production were new, it is understandable that digging into character and delivering emotion is yet to come. ``Faust,'' presented on the Metropolitan Opera's opening night in 1883, hadn't been heard there since the 1976-77 season. The scenery by Rolf Langenfass, who also did costumes, was on the Met's turntable. Buildings looked as if made by a potter creating a suggestion of buildings, then greatly enlarged. Marguerite's house had a small doorway, a window and a few sloping tiles indicating a roof. Depending on what was facing the audience, the scenery could look like a ruin or beautifully other-worldly. The devil is often present in ``Faust.'' However, in this production, the church and heaven are always represented. The backdrop usually looked like stained-glass windows blurred because seen from a distance. Sometimes the shape of a gothic church was superimposed on this. In village square scenes, arches indicate the entrance to a church. When this turned, the church's interior, with candles banked before an altar, was seen. The decision not to include the Walpurgis Night ballet was wise. Recent previous attempts have been long and silly. Prince, in his Met debut, has made some directorial decisions so that this ``Faust'' is neither run-of-the-mill nor outrageous. Sometimes Mephistopheles comes and goes in a flash of fire. His first appearance, which often occurs that way, is more startling in this production because the devil simply turns around in the chair Faust had recently swiveled for his own entrance. Mephistopheles and Marthe (sung by Loretta Di Franco) do too much horseplay during Faust's courtship of Marguerite, so that it's too often interrupted by laughter. Other small details, such as Marguerite's odd movements when Faust is early shown a vision of her, could be praised or debated. Mezzo-soprano Delores Ziegler of Decatur, Ga., made her Met debut. Her rich voice made a good impression as Siebel but and made a listener look forward to hearing her in other roles. Brian Schexnayder, as Marguerite's brother Valentin, was showing roughness and strain, especially on top notes, early in the opera. Before the final act it was announced that a sinus infection which he had thought cured had returned. He finished the opera.

DOC.HEAD: Pilots Had Alcohol in Systems, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: The pilot and co-pilot of a Federal Aviation Administration plane that crashed in 1988, killing all three crew members, were seen drinking the night before the accident, according to a federal report. The National Transportation Safety Board report, released this week in Washington, also said the co-pilot previously had lost his driver's license for driving under the influence of alcohol. The board ruled the pilot's failure to reduce ice buildup caused the twin-engine jet to crash in November 1988, 11{ miles from the Westmoreland County Airport near Latrobe. The NTSB report said the pilot, James E. Burger, 64, of Linwood, N.J., had a blood-alcohol level of 0.057 percent and the co-pilot, Richard M. Wadsworth, 46, of Ocean City, N.J., had traces of alcohol in his urine. Also killed was an FAA technician. Federal aviation rules bar pilots from flying civil aircraft within eight hours after consumption of any alcoholic beverage, while under the influence of alcohol or while having 0.04 percent blood-alcohol content. The legal limit for driving in Pennsylvania is 0.10 percent. The board concluded Burger's blood-alcohol content was due partly to decomposition and fermenting of body fluids. Dr. Charles Winek, director of the Pittsburgh laboratory that prepared a toxicology report on the bodies for the Westmoreland County Coroner's Office, agreed Thursday that body fluids can ferment during putrification, which can result in the production of ethyl alcohol. ``However, this occurs in a hot, humid climate ... over a matter of weeks,'' he told the Tribune-Review of Greensburg. ``This was November. In wintertime it would take a lot longer than a matter of a couple of hours to occur.'' The men, based at the FAA Center in Pomona, N.J., were on a routine inspection flight to test the radar landing-guidance system at the Westmoreland County Airport. The NTSB said the aircraft's ice-detection system had been operating only intermittently. Despite forecasts of icing conditions in the area, the crew decided to complete their testing, the NTBS said. ``Evidence indicated crew noticed ice accretion, activated surface de-ice system, ice broke loose and entered engine intakes. Both engines flames out,'' the report said. The agency said ice that entered the engine intakes damaged the compressor assembly and blades. ``Both pilots had personal stresses which may have influenced performance,'' the report said. The report said Burger had decided to retire that day and Wadsworth recently had lost his driver's license.

DOC.HEAD: Assets Turn Up in Abbie Hoffman's Estate
DOC.TEXT: Abbie Hoffman, a 1960s activist who gave away most of his earnings, had more assets when he committed suicide last spring than previously believed, his attorney says. His estate is worth more than $37,000, according to tax papers filed in Bucks County Courthouse in Doylestown, instead of the $2,000 reported last fall. A large portion of that amount came from Hoffman's share of a property in Massachusetts, which ``he never mentioned, never used,'' Gerald Lefcourt of New York, Hoffman's attorney and friend for 20 years, said Friday. Hoffman held 15 percent of the property, worth about $100,000, which his father left to him, his brother, sister and mother, Lefcourt said, and thus he could not give it away as he did most of his wealth. ``He never owned a house, never took the proceeds from his books and never bought anything for himself,'' Lefcourt said. Hoffman gave away hundreds of thousands of dollars to causes he supported, according to Lefcourt, who said he watched in the early 1970s as Hoffman signed over to the Black Panther bail fund the movie rights to his book ``Revolution For The Hell Of It.'' The movie never was made. Lefcourt said about $5,000 in speaking fees that Hoffman never collected also turned up in his estate. The rest of the money came from a motorboat, a 1988 Hyundai Excel, a New York checking account and a Bucks County checking account. Hoffman left his entire estate to Johanna Lawrenson, his companion for 15 years. On April 12, at age 52, he committed suicide in his Solebury Township apartment by taking an overdose of barbiturates mixed with alcohol.

DOC.HEAD: Brightest Comet in 15 Years Expected to Fly By in Mid-April
DOC.TEXT: Skywatchers disappointed by Comets Halley and Kahoutek are getting another chance _ newly discovered Comet Austin, the brightest such object to approach Earth in 15 years. By mid-April, Coment Austin should be visible before dawn in most parts of the planet, University of Florida astronomer Billy Cooke said Friday. ``It won't be spectacular, but it will put on a better show than Halley,'' he said. ``Austin looks pretty strong.'' He estimated Austin will be twice as bright as Halley, making it the brightest since Comet West in 1975. There are already indications Austin could be a little brighter than now projected. ``Austin appears to be a very dirty and gassy comet, which gives us cause for optimism because dirty and gassy comets tend to be bright,'' Cooke said. Although it will be closest to Earth at a distance of 30 million miles May 19, it will give its best view around April 14 just after it swings around the sun. ``Floridians will get one of the clearest views because it will be smack dab over our heads just before sunrise,'' Cooke said. Austin will appear to the unaided eye as a dim, fuzzy ball. The tail, pointed away from the sun, will be visible through binoculars or low-powered telescopes. Now visible only from the Southern Hemisphere, the comet will come into view in the Northern Hemisphere in late March just after sunset. Austin will disappear behind the sun during the first week of April and reappear a week later, he said. Astronomers from University of Florida and other schools will be heading to observatories around the world to study Austin. ``Comets are leftover material from the beginning of the universe,'' Cooke said. ``We can get a view of how the early solar system was formed.'' The new comet was discovered Dec. 6 inside Jupiter's orbit by Rodney R.D. Austin, an amateur astronomer. Like most comets, Austin probably originated in the Oort Cloud, far beyond the outermost planet of Pluto, Cooke said. ``For some reason it's been flung into our part of the solar system,'' the astronomer said. ``It'll probably keep coming back every hundred thousand years or so now.''

DOC.HEAD: Brady Tries Easing Administration Pressure on Fed for Lower Rates
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady on Friday tried to ease the Bush administration away from its recent calls for lower interest rates, saying such comments were really aimed at the slumping home-building industry. Brady told Congress' Joint Economic Committee that a statement made two weeks ago by White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater urging lower interest rates was not meant to pressure the Federal Reserve Board.
