He said Fitzwater's remarks were meant merely as a prelude to a visit President Bush paid the next day to a homebuilders' convention in Atlanta. ``Presidents generally talk about lower interest rates at housing conferences,'' Brady said. Brady's remarks came just four days before Fed policymakers were scheduled to hold a closed-door session in Washington to set monetary targets for the rest of the year. Fed officials are sensitive about appearing to respond to prodding from the White House for fear that the financial markets will lose confidence in the central bank's independence. Talking with reporters on Jan. 18, Fitzwater said a recent prime rate reduction by banks had not been passed through to the general economy. ``It's important occasionally to point out that lower interest rates are normally good for the economy,'' Fitzwater said at the time. The White House spokesman went on to cite Commerce Department statistics showing a drop in housing starts as evidence that lower interest rates were needed. The next day, Bush told the National Association of Homebuilders that he wanted interest rates to drop further. ``The 1990s must be another decade of lower taxes and lower interest rates,'' Bush said. The White House usually does not comment publicly on Federal Reserve policy. Asked by committee Chairman Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., whether Fitzwater's comments were inappropriate, Brady said, ``Not in light of what I understand was the reason for the statement being given.'' Brady conceded that at his weekly meetings with Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan, the two men have ``vigorous discussions'' in which they frequently disagree. ``The administration probably has a bias toward growth that's greater than that of the Fed,'' Brady said. ``At the same time, we keep a weather eye on inflation.'' The Treasury secretary also indicated that although he was not satisfied with the current annual inflation rate of 4.6 percent, he looked favorably on the lack of dramatic fluctuation in the cost of living. ``Stability is something to be sought after,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Creating Panel of Science Advisers
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs pvs graf 11 with new grafs 11-13 including new quotes. Editing to shorten.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, citing ``tremendous problems'' from overseas competition, today announced he is creating a panel of science advisers to search for ways to make the United States more competitive in science and technology. Bush vowed to engage in tough negotiations to try to knock down foreign trade barriers. ``I think we can compete, I believe that. But we can't do it if we're up against closed markets and if we're up against trade restrictions,'' the president said. Speaking at a roundtable discussion on high-tech issues at North Carolina State University, the president said, ``We've just got to find ways to free up as much as possible our commerce.'' ``I am optimistic about the country. I know we've got tremendous problems with competition, but we're getting our focus on it now,'' Bush said. ``We're moving into a whole new decade with a whole new focus,'' he said. The business leaders told Bush that to keep abreast of foreign competition in their industry they wouild like to see more emphasis on education, particularly math and science at all levels. Bush summoned the newly-formed panel, to be headed by White House science adviser Allan Bromley, to the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., for a kickoff meeting on Saturday. The panel, which will have between 10 and 14 members, will be called the president's Council of Advisers on Science and Technology. The president traveled to Raleigh and to Knoxville, Tenn., to promote educational goals he outlined in his State of the Union address earlier this week _ goals already under attack from critics who contend Bush doesn't back up his promises with enough money. ``Look, I came here to learn and listen,'' Bush said. He called himself ``fired up'' on the subject of improving U.S. competitiveness. Bush was focusing today on enhancing research and development activities for which he has proposed $71 billion in his fiscal-year 1991 budget. The sum represents an increase of $4.5 billion over the money enacted for 1990, according to White House figures. At the University of Tennessee in Knoxville, Bush called on Congress to implement his proposals quickly. ``Building America's competitive strength today...means that we need quick congressional action on our other proposals for investing new capital _ intellectual capital. That includes everything from reforming product liability laws to doubling the budget of the National Science Foundation,'' Bush said. ``Some wonder if America has lost its competitive edge and ask if we must now look overseas for the answer,'' he said. ``The United States is the defending world champion. But we have to defend our title day by day, week by week, year in and year out.'' Bush told reporters flying with him this morning that his goal is ``to make the United States more competitive around the world ... We must not lose our prominence in science and technology.'' Bush toured the Surface Science Laboratory at North Carolina State University, where students and professors explained their work in studying semiconductor surfaces. After they showed him an elaborate system of equipment and electronic gadgetry, Bush commented, ``All this brain work out here. It's a little awesome.'' Laboratory supervisor Dr. Robert Nemanich said the program receives $250,000 in federal funds and that within his field many scientists ``would like to see an increase in support in these areas. We see in our leadership in technology eroding'' in comparison with foreign competition, he told reporters. The new 15-member advisory panel will advise Bush ``on matters involving all areas of science and technology.'' Its members, the White House said, will be the director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy and 14 members from the private sector. The president's action came a day after more than 700 scientists, including 49 winners of the Nobel Prize, accused Bush of being complacent about the threat of global warming and urging him to show greater leadership on the issue. The scientists, representing more than one-third of all members of the National Academy of Sciences, said in a letter to Bush, that action ``must be initiated immediately. Only by taking action now can we ensure that future generations will not be put at risk.'' Critics on Thursday also attacked the president's education budget for being insufficient to achieve his goal of ``excellence in education.'' The president came under attack from Democrats and education groups almost as soon as he announced the goals for improvement in students' math and science achievement, literacy and drug-free schools. ``There is a yawning gap between the rhetoric of President Bush's education speeches and the funding levels he offers in his budget,'' said Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers.

DOC.HEAD: Reaction to de Klerk Speech
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Reaction to the speech Friday by South African President F.W. de Klerk:

``We had expected that Mr. de Klerk might deliver something, but what he said has certainly taken my breath away. ... We are probably seeing history in the making in South Africa.'' _ Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu.
``This is only the beginning. We want the end of apartheid in South Africa.'' _ African National Congress leader Walter Sisulu.

``It was the most revolutionary speech to which I have listened in this Parliament. ... We say he has no mandate for doing the drastic things he intends doing and we challenge him to call a general election.'' _ Andries Treurnicht, leader of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party.

``Of course the road ahead will be steep and rough and there's a possibility of setbacks and problems. But taken all in all I have more hope for South Africa at this moment than I've had for 40 years.'' _ Zach de Beer, co-leader of the anti-apartheid Democratic Party.

``In a matter of just over half an hour, Mr. de Klerk has set in motion a process of peaceful revolution that will undo four decades of doctrinaire National Party policies that have spelt misery for millions.'' _ Rev. Stanley Mogoba, head of South Africa's Methodist Church.
``As a South African I have reservations. Whites are feeling a bit insecure. There is reservation in the hearts of whites.'' _ Michael Loor, white South African businessman.

``We want to warn Mr. de Klerk we are not going to accept a bone without any meat. ... The unbanning of the ANC, the South African Communist Party and the Pan-Africanist Congress in the prevailing South African climate is simply a recipe for further problems.'' _ Winnie Mandela, wife of imprisoned ANC leader Nelson Mandela.

``If there were any who doubted his sincerity, they can now be assured they were wrong. What Mr. de Klerk did today ... creates a situation in which it should be patently clear to all that there can now be no going back.'' _ Zulu leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi, the country's most powerful black moderate.
``Simply reducing the level of apartheid repression does not mean he (de Klerk) is committed to ending it.'' _ Mike Terry, secretary of the London-based Anti-Apartheid Movement.
``It is obvious that with all these measures, apartheid will not remain what it used to be.'' _ Professor Gabriel Olusanya, director-general of the Nigerian Institute of International Affairs.

``The struggle against apartheid must continue and the pressure on the South Africa regime must be kept up. The South African liberation movements can count on Sweden's support in this struggle.'' _ Swedish Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson.
``I think when people move in the right direction, it is certainly time to review all policy. ... I view it positively and most people around the world will.'' _ President Bush.

``We would be unreasonable if we failed to acknowledge that of all the presidents, of all the leaders of the Nationalist government, that in fact de Klerk has taken the most bold step and has emerged as the most courageous.'' _ Anti-apartheid leader Popo Molefe.

``The staying power for me would be the ability of Mr. de Klerk to move very quickly now to do those things and to make them concrete.'' _ Rev. Allan Boesak, activist and president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches.

DOC.HEAD: Bad Omen: `Number of the Beast' Dropped From License Plates
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have dropped the number 666 from car license plates after some motorists complained that the Biblical number of the beast had bedeviled their lives, causing everything from fender benders to bad water. ``It's not that we as an organization give any credence to this, but we don't want to be inadvertently causing real distress to people,'' Jeff Mumford, senior executive officer of the policy branch of the government Driving, Vehicle and Licensing Center, said Friday. The belief that 666 represents Satan comes from chapter 13, verse 18 of the New Testament Book of Revelation, which refers to ``the number of the beast; for it is the number of a man; and his number is six hundred threescore and six.'' Among those who shun the number is Ronald Reagan, who changed his California address from 666 to 668 St. Cloud Drive after leaving the White House. Complaints also arose in Tennessee in 1988 over the number when the state began using new three-digit tags. The Davidson County clerk withdrew all 366 license plates from the county stockpile bearing the number 666 when motorists refused to accept the plates and said they bore the mark of the devil. A man from North Wales claimed that within one week his house was burglarized, a garbage truck backed into his car and he was told his water supply was poisoned, Mumford said. The man blamed his troubles on the 666 in his number plate. ``Then there was a lady who claimed the car actually took hold of her and she couldn't control it. It reversed, mounted the doorstep and squashed her son's scooter. She said she stopped it only in time to prevent it crashing into the kitchen.'' He also cited the case of a mother of a convicted murderer who said her son had been ``a quiet, home-loving boy'' until his job required him to drive a van with 666 in the license plate. A recent television report featured a man who said he lost his family, home and business after buying a car with 666 in its license plate. The traffic center decided to stop issuing new plates containing 666 four months ago, but is not withdrawing the thousands already in circulation, Mumford said in a telephone interview from the center's headquarters in Swansea, Wales. ``If you were to convince us that the presence of the number is causing you distress we would consider it sympathetically,'' he added. Mumford said that because of the practicalities and the implications for law enforcement, ``We are very reluctant to change number plates on vehicles.'' Also, he said, one would assume that ``if you are so religious and superstitious you wouldn't have bought the vehicle in the first place.'' British license plates have a sequence of three letters, three digits and an additional letter. These signify the year the car was produced and the region where it was sold. Some combinations are already excluded, including MAD, GOD and SEX.

DOC.HEAD: Savage Has Criticism of Colleagues Deleted from Record
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Gus Savage on Friday deleted from the Congressional Record personal criticism of three House members whose complaint led to his investigation by the chamber's ethics committee. On Thursday, Savage took the floor to announce that the committee had ended its investigation of him and to call the allegations against him a ``racist attack'' by the news media and government officials. Savage, an Illinois Democrat, did not mention in the speech that the committee had concluded that his ``sexual advances'' to a Peace Corps volunteer during a trip to Zaire last March ``were contrary'' to a House rule requiring members' conduct to ``reflect creditably'' on the chamber. The report, obtained Thursday by the AP, said the committee would have directed Savage to apologize to the women had he not already done so. In Thursday's speech, Savage, who is black, attacked the movitations of the three white lawmakers who had complained to the ethics panel _ Reps. Patricia Schroeder of Colorado, Matthew McHugh of New York and Barney Frank of Massachusetts. All are Democrats. Savage noted in the speech that the three lawmakers had filed their complaint ``despite admitting that they knew absolutely nothing about the case other than allegations in a Washington Post newspaper story'' last year that detailed the woman's account of the incident. A tape of his speech shows that Savage then said, in remarks deleted from the record: ``And believe it or not, among these self-appointed guardians of personal morality was one who since has admitted keeping and prostituting a homosexual. As for the other two so-called liberals, I urge them to review their sensitivity to racism and respect for fairness.'' The ethics committee is investigating Frank, who has acknowledged paying a male prostitute for sex but has denied other allegations of improper conduct made by the prostitute. Savage's spokesman, Donnovan Dunkley, was not immediately available for comment. None of the three representatives Savage criticized would comment after his speech. Only a member can revise his remarks in the official record. A House staff source, speaking only on the condition of anonymity, said, ``A member of the House floor staff suggested that he (Savage) remove those remarks from the record and he agreed to that.'' The proceedings of a House or Senate session are printed the next day in the Congressional Record, which is the official transcript of proceedings but is not always an accurate reflection of what was said on the floor. The discrepancy occurs whenever a member exercises his right to ``revise and extend'' his remarks in the printed record.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official Cool to Modrow Plan for Neutral Germany
With AM-East Germany
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. ambassador to NATO said Friday the East German premier's proposal that a reunited Germany be neutral was both premature and unrealistic. ``The right thing to do is to wait until (East Germany) has had elections and has a democratically elected government in place, and take up the subject at that time,'' William H. Taft IV said in an interview in his office at alliance headquarters. He said Premier Hans Modrow's proposal ``is certainly a novel one, coming from a leader of what is still a non-democratically elected government.'' Taft, a former deputy defense secretary, said a unified Germany within NATO ``is a much better idea in terms of contributing to the stability and security of Europe and of Germany for that matter.'' East Germany belongs to the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany has suggested a reunified Germany remain part of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, but with only the territory of West Germany be tied to its military structure. Taft said Genscher's proposal ``answers the basic requirement for stability in Europe, which is that (West Germany) should be aligned with the West.'' The Genscher plan recognizes that West Germany's links to NATO and the European Community have been ``crucial for Germany's security and prosperity over the years, and it would continue that,'' he said. It would be ``a very big mistake'' for Germany to leave the Western military alliance, Taft said, and ``I don't understand that this is at all contemplated by the government'' in Bonn. ``Germany's security, Germany's prosperity, Germany's freedom have been won and protected and grown ... within NATO (and) the EC,'' the U.S. ambassador said. ``I really don't sense any desire to give that up.'' Taft said he believed President Bush's proposal for further deep cuts in Soviet and American troops strengths in Europe would help advance the negotiations on conventional arms being conducted in Vienna. In his State of the Union message Wednesday night, Bush suggested a ceiling of 195,000 soldiers each for the United States and Soviet Union in Central Europe. The United States would have 30,000 more in Britain and southern Europe. Last May, Bush proposed an overall limit of 275,000 each. The Soviet Union has an estimated 565,000 troops stationed in Europe outside its national territory, and the United States has 305,000 in Western Europe. Taft said political changes in Eastern Europe ``suggested that the levels we had arrived at in May could be reduced,'' and that proposal ``was becoming one that needed some change'' at the Vienna talks. Czechoslovakia and Hungary have asked the Kremlin for quick withdrawal of the estimated 120,000 Red Army soldiers still on their soil. ``We anticipate that the difficulties that the Soviets have had in finding the welcome mat for their troops in Eastern Europe will certainly result in substantial reductions,'' Taft said. ``It may well result in reductions below 195,000.'' He said the American plan would be submitted to a special NATO panel Monday for approval, then be proposed soon in Vienna. Bargainers for the 16 NATO nations and the seven in the Warsaw Pact hope for agreement this year on reducing the number of battle tanks, artillery, armored troop carriers, combat aircraft, helicopters and soldiers in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Lost Sermon by Cotton Mather Rediscovered
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, bgng `Worthylake, keeper, ...' to CORRECT island name to Little Brewster sted Beacon; pick up 6th graf, `Tho they...'
DOC.TEXT: The long-lost text of a sermon delivered 271 years ago by Puritan leader Cotton Mather has been rediscovered, offering a more complex portrait of the man best known for his role in the Salem witch trials. ``Because of Mather's standing as one of the most learned and most influential of the Puritan people, a find of this nature is very significant,'' said Richard Fyffe, who identified the document. He is chief librarian of the Essex Institute, which collects, preserves and studies the history of Essex County. Although historians and bibliographers knew Mather gave a stirring funeral sermon from newspaper accounts, letters and other sources, they had searched in vain for decades for a full text of Mather's remarks. Mather read the sermon on Nov. 9, 1718, at the funeral of George Worthylake, his wife Ann, and their daughter, Ruth. Worthylake, keeper of Boston's first lighthouse on Little Brewster Island, was drowned with his wife and daughter when their boat capsized in a fierce storm. Worthylake's two other children witnessed the accident from the shore. ``Tho they were now so very near the shoar, yet the winds and the seas, were so high they could not fetch it, before they were all of them unhappily drowned,'' Mather wrote. ``There were two or three children with a kinswoman, who with inexpressible horror and anguish, beheld the deadly distress of their parents and sister, and others thus perishing in the waters; unable to give the least help unto them.'' ``Imagine if thou canst, the agony,'' he urged in the sermon. ``The dead bodies of their parents and sister and others being thrown upon the land, were the only company which these poor children had upon the desolate island; for two whole days and nights together.'' Mather's eulogy pointed to the Puritan ethic that tragedies are a part of God's will, but Fyffe noted that Mather's sympathy for the children and the horror expressed at the accident were characteristics not normally associated with Puritan expression. ``It is not surprising that we have caricatured the Puritans as a hard, unemotional people, but they were not as unfeeling and unsympathetic as we seem to believe they were,'' said Fyffe. ``Mather's sermon is an example of this.'' Fyffe found the sermon, ``Providence Asserted and Adored,'' last year as he was cataloguing the Essex Institute's collection for a nationwide computer database of all early American printed material made before 1801. In the course of the work, Fyffe came across the pamphlet, which had never been properly identified because it was missing a cover. A former librarian had placed a note with the document suggesting it might be written by Mather, but apparently never followed up on it. Fyffe did. The pamphlet is now at the institute in Salem, a seaside city about 20 miles north of downtown Boston. Mather, who lived from 1663 to 1728, was considered a leading theological and scientific expert of his time. He published nearly 400 documents, ranging from fiery sermons to scientific examinations. However, he is probably best known for his role in support of the Salem witch trials of 1692, during which 20 people were executed. Fyffe said the finding is important because Mather has long been considered both an intellectual and spiritual genius, and the pamphlet could change an image tainted by the witch trials. ``If this contributes to the public's developing a more complex sense of who Cotton Mather was, then it is important,'' Fyffe said. ``Cotton was not the ideal man in any means but he was a more sympathetic man than we tend to give him credit for being.''

DOC.HEAD: Incumbent Expected To Win Second Term
DOC.TEXT: Sidney Barthelemy, New Orleans' second black mayor, is expected to add another election to his unbroken string Saturday against a white challenger who has accused him of race-baiting. ``I do expect the voting returns to fall along racial lines,'' said Silas Lee, Barthelemy's pollster. About 54.4 percent of New Orleans' 237,342 registered voters are black and 44.4 percent white, with Asians making up the rest. Barthelemy, 47, and Donald Mintz, 46, a lawyer who formerly headed the city's dock board, spent Friday shaking hands and making personal appearances. Early polls put Mintz ahead of Barthelemy. But in recent polls, Barthelemy, who was a state senator and city councilman before becoming mayor and has never lost an election, has drawn ahead by 10 to 12 percentage points. The four-month campaign created little interest, upstaged by parties for the year-end holidays, the Sugar Bowl and the Super Bowl. Even the issue of race, which sparked the candidates' two televised debates, did little to enliven the campaign. Mintz, who wears a lapel button showing white and black hands interlinked, claimed Barthelemy's ads on a black radio station appealed to anti-white racism. Barthelemy said it was Mintz who interjected the issue of race. ``Mintz didn't want Sidney to highlight what he did for black business and the black community on black radio,'' Lee said. ``No other candidate has said that was race-baiting. ``And in the past, other candidates haven't said `By highlighting what you've done for one group or constituency, that is race baiting or sex baiting or any other type of baiting.''' Another racial issue arose when anonymous fliers depicted Barthelemy as an opportunistic Uncle Tom. Barthelemy accused Mintz of distributing the fliers, but Mintz vehemently denied it. The campaign's other issues have been high crime, low employment, and the candidates' political experience and competence. But until his death on Dec. 23, most of the interest was focused on former Mayor Ernest Dutch Morial, the city's first black mayor. ``The whole campaign for the past year, literally, was dominated by Dutch Morial,'' said Ed Renwick, director of Loyola University's Institute of Politics and pollster for Mintz. Until Morial announced Dec. 14 that he wouldn't run, ``the basic question was would he run or wouldn't he run,'' said Renwick. ``And from then until his death, it was why didn't he run and would he endorse Mintz?'' ``I would say you still have a lot of voters showing little or no interest,'' said Lee. ``... Usually you have a passionate electorate when you have a candidate who is disliked by a substantial number of voters. You don't have that here. People get passionate when there's somebody they want out of office.'' But Registrar Louis Keller said 55 to 60 percent of the voters are expected to turn out for the election, which also includes races for five City Council seats and nine other city offices. Herman J. ``Buster'' Bustamente and black businessman Rudy E. Mills Sr. are also in the race for mayor but expected to draw few votes. If no candidate gets more than half the vote, a runoff will be held March 3.

DOC.HEAD: Former Oglala Sioux Tribal Chairman Dead at 55
DOC.TEXT: Richard Wilson, who was chairman of the Oglala Sioux Tribe during the 1973 American Indian Movement occupation of Wounded Knee, has died. He was 55. Wilson, who had been hospitalized in Rapid City, died Thursday of complications from an enlarged heart and kidney failure, according to his brother, Jim Wilson. He was the only Oglala Sioux tribal chairman to serve two consecutive terms, holding office from 1972 to 1976. It was ironic that Wilson died the same day Gov. George Mickelson and tribal leaders from across the state signed a document naming 1990 a year of reconciliation between Indians and whites, long-time friend Tim Giago of Rapid City said Friday. That's something Wilson strived for all his life, said Giago, publisher of the Lakota Times, an Indian newspaper. Wilson, who disagreed publicly with the militant tactics of AIM, was labeled a ``goon'' by the AIM activists who occupied Wounded Knee. Controversy erupted because it was Wilson's sworn duty to uphold reservation laws, ``and the laws were being broken,'' Giago said. Wilson was treated unfairly because the national media told the Wounded Knee story from AIM's viewpoint, he said. ``They (AIM) had the ear and the eye of the press, of the national media that flocked out here. Unfortunately, Dick was never very good at working and dealing with the press,'' according to Giago. ``After AIM left ... and after all their leaders went off to other places in the world, Dick Wilson stayed on that reservation and helped clean up the mess that was left there.'' Wilson urged Indians to get involved in tribal and state government. He helped set up the first Indian housing authority on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation. Giago said he went to the hospital Thursday and talked to Wilson before he died. ``He told me that he just couldn't continue anymore, that his heart was broken,'' Giago said His eldest son, Billy B. Wilson, 35, was killed a week ago in a vehicle-pedestrian accident in Dallas, ``and I guess the stress of that just broke him up completely,'' Giago said. Wilson, a contractor and plumber, served as a tribal council member for six years before being elected chairman of the tribe. He lived on a ranch north of Pine Ridge. He had been attempting a political comeback and was a candidate for tribal chairman again in the primary Feb. 13. In addition to his brother, Wilson is survived by his wife, Mary, and several children.

DOC.HEAD: Bakker's Top Deputy Arrives at Prison
DOC.TEXT: Richard Dortch, once Jim Bakker's top deputy at the PTL ministry, arrived Friday at the federal prison camp on this base to begin serving an eight-year sentence for fraud and conspiracy. Dortch, 58, pleaded guilty in August, days before he and Bakker were to go on trial in Charlotte, N.C. Under a plea bargain, Dortch testified against Bakker at his former boss' trial. He also appeared in December before a grand jury that later indicted the Rev. Sam Johnson, a former PTL executive, for perjury. Bakker is serving a 45-year sentence in a federal prison in Minnesota. Dortch will be eligible for parole after serving about 2{ years. He also was fined $200,000. U.S. District Judge Robert Potter has yet to hear a motion from Dortch's lawyers for a reduction in his sentence. Dortch will be in an admission and orientation program for about two weeks before he is assigned a job at the camp or elsewhere on the base about 40 miles east of Pensacola, said warden Willie Scott. Dortch is the lastest on a long list of celeberity inmates who have served time at the unfenced, minimum-security camp. Others have included Watergate figure E. Howard Hunt, fashion magnates Aldo Gucci and Albert Nipon and former baseball pitcher LaMarr Hoyt. Politicians and judges also have been Eglin inmates, including former U.S. Rep. Richard Kelly, R-Fla., who was convicted in the Abscam scandal, and former Maryland Gov. Marvin Mandel. Most of the 800 or so inmates on the 28-acre compound are white-collar criminals and low-level drug dealers. The camp has been derided by critics as a ``country club'' prison and nicknamed ``Club Fed.'' Two Air Force sergeants recently pleaded guilty to accepting or agreeing to accept bribes to take an inmate to nearby motel for a rendezvous with his wife. Prison officials dispute the country club image. ``These are non-violent people from a variety of backgrounds; not all of them are big shots by any means,'' Scott told The Associated Press last year. ``Most of them are serving short sentences. And, since they aren't dangerous and we are located on a military base, we don't even need to have a fence around the place.'' In addition to housekeeping jobs at the camp, prisoners work throughout the base, primarily doing landscaping, Scott said. Eglin is the nation's largest air base, covering 720 square miles.

DOC.HEAD: Sources: Iran-Contra Prosecutors Probing Former CIA Agent Clines
DOC.TEXT: Iran-Contra prosecutors are pursuing allegations that former CIA operative Thomas G. Clines failed to report income on his tax returns from arms transactions involving the Contras, according to sources familiar with the probe. A key witness in the investigation of Clines, according to the sources, is Albert Hakim, who was placed on two years' probation and fined $5,000 Thursday for his role in the Iran-Contra affair. Hakim and business partner Richard Secord set up ``the Enterprise,'' the network of offshore companies used to handle money in the secret supply operation to the Contras and the Reagan administration's sales of arms to Iran. At the request of his friend Secord, Clines helped procure arms for the Contra rebels starting in 1985. In addition to locating a European arms dealer as a source of weapons, Clines helped arrange for shipping and lined up crews to transport the supplies to the rebels. Some $972,728 in commissions were set aside for Clines in the account of an entity code-named C. Tea, according to the congressional Iran-Contra report issued in November 1987. In testimony to Congress in 1987 _ given under immunity from prosecution based on his words _ Hakim identified C. Tea as the code name for Clines. Hakim didn't begin supplying Iran-Contra prosecutors with information on the matter until he entered a plea agreement with the government Nov. 21. In court papers, the government said Hakim has ``indicated his willingness'' to give testimony ``in an anticipated future case'' and is cooperating in a grand jury investigation outside Washington. The papers did not elaborate, but the sources, commenting only on condition they not be named, said the subject of the investigation is Clines. A longtime attorney for Clines, John Ellsworth Stein, declined comment Friday. But other sources familiar with the situation say that Clines did in fact report money from the transactions on his tax returns. Clines takes the position that he has reported all his income, the sources added. Mary Belcher, a spokeswoman for the Iran-Contra prosecutor's office, declined to comment. The office of independent counsel Lawrence Walsh, which began operating in December 1986, focused on Clines early in its investigation but was unable to assemble a case, the sources said. Clines worked for the CIA for 30 years. He was an agent in Southeast Asia, was involved in the Bay of Pigs invasion in Cuba and became director of training in the directorate of operations, also known as the clandestine services. He also became a close associate of Edwin Wilson, the former CIA agent who is serving 52 years in federal prison for illegally selling guns and explosives to Libya. Clines pleaded guilty in 1984 on behalf of his wholly owned company to inflating bills submitted to the Defense Department for shipping U.S. military equipment to Egypt. He was fined the maximum $10,000 and paid the government $100,000 on behalf of his firm, Systems Services International.

DOC.HEAD: US Asks Angola To Stop Attack on Rebels, Seeks Soviet Cooperation
DOC.TEXT: The United States on Friday urged the Angolan government to stop its offensive against the U.S.-armed UNITA rebels, and said it had sought Soviet cooperation to end the fighting. Gains by Soviet-armed government forces have brought them to the edge of UNITA-controlled territory in southeastern Angola. A military source in Lisbon said Friday the Angolan army had captured the strategic UNITA airstrip of Mavinga after a fierce battle that included air strikes, but a UNITA spokesman in Lisbon denied it. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said she could not confirm the fall of Mavinga to the government, but that a large force of troops had crossed the Lombo River and were within 10 miles of Mavinga. That information was based on independent confirmation, officials said. Mavinga is considered a key to military control of the region and vital to any government plans to attack the rebel stronghold at Jamba, 120 miles farther south. The offensive by the Soviet-backed government began in late December, apparently in an attempt to capture more territory as a bargaining chip in peace talks with UNITA, the Union for the Total Independence of Angola. Efforts by the United States, the Soviet Union and Portugal to revive the peace talks that began last June have stalled. The offensive ``will make it increasingly difficult to reach the negotiated settlement necessary to conclude this tragic conflict,'' Tutwiler said. ``We urge Luanda to halt its military offensive, and to devote its efforts to finding a negotiated solution. ``The United States stands willing to assist the parties and the mediator in the search for peace,'' she said. Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen discussed this at meetngs in the Angolan capital of Luanda 10 days ago. The United States has spoken to Soviet officials about the latest offensive several times, Mrs. Tutwiler said. ``The Soviets have restated their commitment to a negotiated settlement of the Angolan conflict and their belief that there are no military solutions.'' But Soviet military aid to Angola's government ``continues at high levels, and Soviet military advisers remain in Angola,'' she said. The United States gives UNITA, headed by Jonas Savimbi, at least $40 million in weapons every year. It has vowed to continue arming the group until peace is achieved. However, Soviet military advisers have pulled back from the forward fighting area in southeastern Angola since mid-January, Mrs. Tutwiler added. There also were no signs of Cubans involved in the offensive. Cuban troops, estimated to number 50,000 at the peak of their presence in Angola, have been ahead of a scheduled 1991 pullout agreed to last year as part of a complex peace package that also brought independence to the former South African colony of Namibia.

DOC.HEAD: INS to Allow Some Immigrants' Families to Stay
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of illegal aliens who are children or spouses of legal immigrants will be allowed to stay in this country under a policy announced Friday by Immigration Commissioner Gene McNary. Under McNary's order, those aliens will be given permission to stay if they were in this country on Nov. 1, 1986, the day the Immigration Reform and Control Act took effect. Officials estimated that more than 100,000 people might be affected by the new policy. The policy previously enforced by the Immigration and Naturalization Service allowed family members who are illegal aliens to stay only if there was a ``compelling humanitarian reason'' against deportation. McNary said that standard was too ``nebulous'' and resulted in a policy that ``has not been evenly and uniformly enforced throughout the country.'' Some INS district directors were too strict and others too lenient in applying the standard, he told reporters. Only a handful of people were deported under the old policy, he said. But McNary said a more consistent policy may encourage more people to apply for the new status, which would allow them to obtain work permits. While the INS will strictly enforce immigration laws to deter illegal border crossings,``we can enforce the law humanely,'' McNary said. ``To split families simply encourages further violation of the law as they (illegal aliens) attempt to reunite,'' McNary said. The law granted blanket amnesty to illegal aliens who could prove they were residing in the country before Jan. 1, 1982. It also provided immigrant status to undocumented farm workers who could prove they had worked 90 days picking crops in this country in any one of three years. More than 3 million illegal aliens have been given legal status under the amnesty program in the 1986 law. Of those, more than 1 million have applied for permanent residency. The spouses and children covered by the order typically followed their relatives to this country but did not arrive in time to qualify for amnesty. These people technically remain illegal aliens. The decision was lauded by representatives of immigrant-rights groups but was also termed belated because it was made long after the legalization program ended. Illegal aliens had until May 1988, to apply for permanent residency status under the amnesty program. ``It's just a shame that it has taken such a long time to ameliorate some of the harsh and restrictive elements that had been used in the legalization program,'' said Arthur C. Helton, head of the asylum project of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights. Many eligible aliens didn't apply for permanent residency because they feared relatives who entered illegally would be caught and deported, Helton said. Arnoldo Torres, national political director of the League of United Latin American Citizens who has been harshly critical of the agency, called the order ``probably one of the most reasonable positions that INS has taken.'' The cases of those given permission to stay will be reviewed annually to determine if the aliens had committed crimes or had become dependent on welfare assistance. Aliens could be deported if they committed crimes or if the INS found they had become ``public charges,'' McNary said. The new policy was criticized by the Federation for American Immigration Reform as ``just plain illegal.''

DOC.HEAD: Tumbling Team Helps Youths Hurdle Past Gangs
LaserPhoto CX5
DOC.TEXT: State Rep. Jesse White has spent more than 30 years helping inner-city youths who live in some of the toughest neighborhoods somersault their way past gangs and into a better way of life. Since its creation in 1959, the Jesse White Tumbling Team has been featured at professional sports games, in a book and a movie. White, 55, said he designed the team to combat juvenile delinquency _ a frequent hazard for his tumblers, most of whom live in the crime-ridden Cabrini-Green housing project. ``My kids know that as long as they're part of the tumbling team, they're safe in the community,'' White said Thursday of his 75 varsity tumblers, who range in age from 6 to 26. ``We're looked upon as baseball heroes or movie stars ...,'' said White, a legislator for 14 years. Eighteen-year-old James Hogg, a team member for the last eight years, said joining the squad kept him out of trouble. ``The team taught me not to settle for less in life,'' said Hogg. The tumblers perform a dizzying array of stunts. Members flip over obstacles, do double twists and double backward flips. For the finale, members bounce off a mini-trampoline over as many as 25 other teammates. The team, which depends largely on corporate sponsors for financial support, has visited Japan and performed at professional sporting events in Chicago and across the country. This year they plan to visit China and Korea. The tumblers were featured in the movie ``Ferris Bueller's Day Off'' and a book, ``I Am a Jesse White Tumbler,'' which tells the story of a boy who joined the team when he was 5. White said tumblers are prohibited from joining gangs. ``It's simple,'' said White. ``If you're with them, we don't need you. I have a waiting list of 3,600 kids for this program. If you want to be part of the gangbangers, go.'' White said tumblers have often told him that they'd rather be in trouble with the police than with him. He described an incident four years ago with a tumbler who for the third, and final, time had violated team rules. ``He slapped another member of the team ... and I said that I have to dismiss you. He said, `Please Mr. White don't take this away from me. This is all that I have ... you can take off my arms, take off my legs, pluck out my eyes, but please don't put me off the team,''' said White. In addition to the 75 varsity tumblers, there are 10 girls in his dance troupe and 550 would-be varsity members are tutored each week. White said his schedule is busy, but that he doesn't mind because he remembers what people did for him as a youngster. ``Often when we reach great heights in life, we forget who brought us there. Well, I have not,'' he said. For some, being a team member is a dream come true. ``The team is like a family to me,'' said 16-year-old Cornell Wallace, who joined the team 5{ years ago. ``It shows people that we're trying to get something going for ourselves in the future,'' said Wallace, whose 18-year-old brother was killed by gang members last year. ``I really enjoy the respect that I get from the team and the respect that others give me _ on the streets in particular,'' Hoff said. ``It makes me feel proud ... like I'm achieving something.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Budget Calls for More Money for European Weapons
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is seeking more than $18 billion in fiscal 1991 defense spending for major weapons targeting Warsaw Pact forces despite the political upheaval in Eastern Europe, a congressional agency reported Friday. Congress' bipartisan Arms Control and Foreign Policy Caucus said President Bush's new budget calls for an increase of more than $1 billion from the fiscal 1990 budget for the weapons. The chairman of the caucus, Rep. Howard L. Berman, D-Calif., said that while he applauded Bush's call for reduced troop levels in Europe, ``the budget for weapons should reflect the new era too. We shouldn't pour billions into new weapons systems designed to counter Warsaw Pact forces that no longer exist.'' In his State of the Union address, Bush proposed a reduction of U.S. and Soviet combat troops in Europe to 225,000 on each side in response to the tumultuous changes in the Eastern bloc where democracies have emerged from the rubble of communist regimes. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, in testimony before the Senate Armed Services Committee on Thursday, said the Soviet Union is likely to withdraw all it troops from Eastern Europe by the middle of the decade. The caucus lists 25 major nuclear and conventional weapons systems which in the past the Pentagon has justified as primarily for use in Europe. According to the report, if the administration continues these programs, the cost will total about $70 billion over a three-year period beginning in fiscal 1992. Bush is seeking $292.1 billion in defense spending in fiscal 1991. Among the budget requests are an increase of $64 million for the SRAM-T, or tactical short-range attack missile; a jump of $80 million in spending for the short-range missile, or follow-on to the Lance; and $235 million more for the Tomahawk land-attach nuclear cruise missile. The proposed spending plan also includes slightly more than $1 billion for the Advanced Tactical Fighter, $2.7 billion for the C-17 transport aircraft and $3 billion for the F-16 fighter plane. ``Our weapons policy should match our threat assessment,'' Berman said in releasing the caucus report. ``Obviously not every weapon on this list should be canceled. But given the last six months, both Congress and the executive branch have a duty to re-evaluate the assumptions behind these weapons before we write the check for them.'' The caucus is composed of 140 members of Congress. The organization's staff and the Congressional Research Service of the Library of Congress compiled the list of weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Chairman Says Sanctions Should Stay, For Now
With AM-US-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Party chairman Ronald H. Brown said Friday that while he sees ``hopeful signs'' of progress in South Africa, it is too early to consider lifting U.S. economic sanctions. ``I think we ought to keep the pressure on South Africa as long as it takes,'' said Brown. The Democratic Party leader commented shortly after President Bush said he would review U.S. sanctions in the light of the announcement by South African President F.W. de Klerk that he was legalizing the opposition African National Congress and would soon free its imprisoned leader, Nelson Mandela. ``I think when people move in the right direction, it is certainly time to review all policy,'' Bush said. ``Let's see what happens,'' Brown said when asked about the possibility of lifting U.S. sanctions against the apartheid government. ``Let's see what happens with Mandela. ``There are certainly some hopeful signs and we all ought to be pleased with those signs. I don't know that we ought to be recommending any abrupt changes.'' The U.S. sanctions include a ban on importing South African steel, textiles, uranium, coal and agricultural produce. They also bar new U.S. investment in South Africa, forbid new bank loans and end U.S. landing rights for South African Airways. Brown also said that when he was in Israel last week, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir assured him that Israel would disclose within the next several weeks a timetable for terminating its military contracts with South Africa. South Africa is Israel's largest military trading partner.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Purge Ranks, Replace Party Leadership
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party purged its ranks of the old guard Friday and handed leadership to a moderate reformer who promised to pursue democratic reforms. Alexander Lilov, a veteran Communist who fell from favor in the old Stalinist regime, said he would overhaul the party before it competes in Bulgaria's free elections set for May. Lilov replaces Petar Mladenov, who will remain as state president. Bowing to demands of reformers, Mladenov had proposed separating the posts of Communist Party chief and head of state. The changes in the party were the latest since Mladenov replaced Todor Zhivkov, the hard-line Communist leader whose 35-year rule was ended on Nov. 10. Lilov said it is not possible for the party to avoid reform ``because the situation in the country and the party has changed.'' Lilov was elected during a 24-hour secret session that closed a four-day emergency party congress. The Central Committee was replaced by a 153-member Supreme Council that is less than half the size of its predecessor but contains a much broader political spectrum, including radical pro-reform factions. Ninety percent of the Central Committee members failed to win election to the council that replaces it, party sources said. The delegates also created a 51-member commission on party ethics and a 31-member Central Finance Commission. Zhivkov, 78, has been arrested on charges of abuse of office and inciting ethnic hostility during his rule. Bulgarian state radio reported Friday that Zhivkov's health was so bad he could not remain in prison and was moved to a hospital. The radio did not describe Zhivkov's illness nor say when he was hospitalized. Among those not on the new Supreme Council is Premier Georgi Atanassov, who resigned Thursday with his 22-member cabinet after coming under sharp criticism during the congress for failing to solve Bulgaria's economic woes. The resignation was necessary ``to form a Cabinet on a broad national basis,'' said the state news agency BTA. The communists have made a vague proposal for a government of ``national concord'' to rule until the May elections. Lilov announced that talks on the new government would begin Saturday with opposition groups. But Lyubomir Pavlov, a senior official from the opposition Union of Democratic Forces, said the opposition is unlikely to take part in a provisional government. He said the opposition would have little clout since Communists control 67 percent of Parliament. Compared with their East bloc neighbors, Bulgarian communists have given up relatively little power, bolstered by a century of roots in the nation's politics and a relatively weak, though growing, opposition. But after his unanimous election by the Supreme Council, Lilov, 56, told the delegates the party is at a critical juncture. ``We really had to try to elect a leadership ... which will work not only in difficult conditions but will lead the party to victory in elections,'' he said. A philologist by training who was the Politburo ideologist through the 1970s but absent from the leadership from 1983 to 1989, Lilov told the congress Wednesday ``we are lagging behind.'' He acknowledged the party suffers from a ``a lack of confidence,'' and said, ``while the party and the country are in a crisis, we have not reached the climax yet.'' The Supreme Council also elected Mladenov, Lilov and two other top party figures _ Andrei Lukanov and popular Defense Minister Dobri Dzhurov _ to a presidium that will essentially replace the Politburo under the new party structure. By far the most urgent task of the new leadership will be restructuring the economy, which many congress delegates said is in disarray. The economic problems felled Atanassov, a holdover from the Zhivkov era, who had come under fire for failing to curb unprecedented labor unrest and making concessions to striking miners. A Bulgarian official said French experts had been called in to work out a program of unspecified economic reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Orders Up 6.4 Percent in 1989
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Hagans to Hagens in 3rd graf pvs, John Hagans. ^By JOHN D. McCLAIN
DOC.TEXT: Orders to factories for manufactured goods slowed to a 6.4 percent increase in 1989, the government said Friday, but analysts said manufacturing should revive slowly this year. ``If you take the figures at face value, except for some industries like autos, the worst is over,'' said Gordon Richards, director of economic policy at the National Association of Manufacturers. John Hagens, an economist with the WEFA group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., had a similar assessment, saying that while much of the economy continues to grow slowly, it's ``not on the verge of a recession.'' The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and non-durable manufactured goods gained 1.9 percent to a seasonally adjusted $244.2 billion in December after rising 2.4 percent in November. The increase put orders for the year at $2.83 trillion after a 9.7 percent increase in 1988, which was the largest advance since 1983. Orders had declined 1 percent in 1986. Durable goods orders, held back during much of the year by the Federal Reserve's high-interest policies, slowed to a 5.9 percent gain in 1989, following advances of 11 percent in 1988 and 7.6 percent in 1987. But in the key category of non-defense capital goods, a barometer of business investment plans, orders rose 18 percent in December to $45.9 billion after an 8.1 percent hike in November. Evelina Tainer, senior domestic economist at First National Bank of Chicago, said non-defense capital goods orders fell about 16 percent during the third quarter, pointing to the weakness in the manufacturing sector. But they rose 7 percent at an annual rate in the October-December period, which she said ``shows the manufacturing sector was bottoming out in the fourth quarter and there's a little revival there.'' Michael K. Evans, head of Evans Economics Inc., a Washington forecasting firm, noted that in another report Friday the Labor Department said 116,000 factory jobs were lost in January, 90,000 of them in the automobile industry. But, Evans added, many of the autoworkers have returned to work. ``It's the end of the manufacturing slump,'' he said. For December, durable goods orders were up 3.2 percent to a seasonally adjusted $134.4 billion after rising 4.8 percent in November. Most of the increase was in transportation, which increased 11.2 percent to $40.9 billion. Excluding transportation, orders would have risen only 0.2 percent. Electrical machinery increased 5 percent to $22.7 billion, offsetting a 4.7 percent decline in non-electrical machinery to $21.6 billion. Primary metals orders were down 3.8 percent to $10.8 billion. Non-durable goods orders increased 0.3 percent in December to $109.9 billion, with most of the increase in petroleum products. Non-durable orders had fallen 0.2 percent in November after a 0.6 percent gain in October. The often-volatile defense orders were down 11.6 percent to $9.96 billion after rising 17.7 percent a month earlier. Excluding defense, orders would have advanced 2.5 percent. The Commerce Department also said shipments of manufactured goods fell 0.5 percent in December to $231.8 billion, while inventories dropped 0.4 percent to $371.5 billion. It was the first decline in inventories since last September and the largest since they dropped 0.4 percent in September 1986. If inventories increase without a corresonding gain in new orders, it could signal production cutbacks as factories attempt to get rid of goods on shelves and in back lots.

DOC.HEAD: President to Attend Drug Summit After U.S. Assurances on Panama
DOC.TEXT: President Alan Garcia said Friday he will attend the Feb. 15 drug summit with President Bush in Colombia, reversing his earlier decision to boycott the meeting if U.S. troops were still in Panama. Garcia said he decided to go to the meeting after Bush announced his intention to withdraw by the end of the month troops sent to Panama to remove Gen. Antonio Manuel Noriega from power. Presidents Virgilio Barco of Colombia and Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia are also set to attend the summit, which is to take place in Cartagena, Colombia. They are to discuss strategies to fight drug trafficking in their respective countries. The three Andean nations are the source of most of the world supply of cocaine, most of which is sold in the United States. Garcia cited the ``gravity of the drug problem'' and said he will go with a ``decisive and positive proposal'' to combat trafficking. Bolivia and Peru produce 90 percent of the world's coca leaf. Most of Peru's coca harvest is transformed into paste and shipped to Colombia, where it is refined into cocaine. Bolivian traffickers formerly did the the same but increasingly are producing refined cocaine and smuggling it directly to the United States and Europe, according to U.S. drug officials. The drug trade brings billions of dollars in clandestine revenues into the three countries each year. Bush last year proposed spending $2.2 billion over the next five years to fight the drug trade in the three Andean nations. Among the topics the four presidents are expected to discuss are military and police aid to fight smugglers and leftist guerrillas tied to drug trafficking, crop eradication and substitution programs, cooperation in stopping the laundering of drug money, and the extradition of drug suspects. Garcia had pulled out of the meeting after U.S. troops landed in Panama Dec. 20 to topple Noriega, saying, ``I cannot meet with the leader of an invading nation.'' Peru had planned to send a high-level delegation to the summit even if Garcia did not go. On Jan. 7, Garcia said he would attend the summit if U.S. troops were first withdrawn. In announcing his decision to go, Garcia said Friday he trusted Bush's promise to withdraw the troops by the end of February. ``This removes one of the obstacles in the way of my attendance,'' Garcia told reporters at the Government Palace. ``I have no reason to doubt the announcement he made before Congress.'' Bush said Wednesday in his State of the Union address that all ``additional troops'' sent to Panama would be withdrawn by the end of the month. About 27,000 U.S. troops were in Panama during the invasion. About 13,000 troops had been stationed at U.S. bases there before the invasion, and the same number are to remain after the February pullout. Garcia has been highly critical of the U.S. actions in Panama, and charged the United States intended to break the Panama Canal treaties of 1977, which call for the United States to cede control of the Panama Canal at the end of the century. Garcia also recalled his ambassador in Washington and suspended for one week joint anti-drug operations with U.S. drug agents and Peruvian police in protest.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun Launches Tank Attack on Christian Rivals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with 120 killed, nighttime shelling, Aoun commander surrenders, fire at power plant threatens city electricity supplies, details. Pickup 10th graf ``They said...''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BEI1,2
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Michel Aoun sent tanks against his rival's seaside command post Friday, the fourth day of a battle for Christian supremacy that has killed more than 120 people and wounded 500, most of them civilians. Police said a half-million people were trapped in basements and bomb shelters of Christian east Beirut without electricity, food or water after a cease-fire Thursday afternoon failed to hold. Each side accused the other of breaking it. Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir, the Maronite Catholic spiritual leader, appealed to Aoun and his adversary Samir Geagea, both Maronites: ``Stop shooting. ... Have mercy on the people. Their lives and property are not yours. You must stop this massacre now. You must stop this mass suicide.'' A statement from the International Committee of the Red Cross said it was ``alarmed by the intensity of the clashes'' and requested a ``humanitarian cease-fire quickly to permit the evacuation of casualties.'' Geagea said his Lebanese Forces militiamen ``crushed the repeated advance attempts'' by two columns of Aoun's tanks trying to converge on his command post behind howitzer fire of 20 shells a minute. Geagea's television station later said his militiamen overran the Amsheet base of Aoun's 7th brigade on the northern edge of the enclave. It broadcast a film showing 7th brigade commander Brig. Gen. Sami Rehana surrendering to the Lebanese Forces at the base. In east Beirut, shells hit high-rise apartment buildings, fuel depots, hospitals and filling stations, sparking fires that raged out of control. Police said snipers kept fire engines from battling the blazes. One salvo at 10 p.m. set the city's main power plant on fire. Mohieddin Mmehio, acting head of the state-run electricity authority, pleaded in an appeal broadcast by all Beirut radio stations for a 6-hour neutralization of the Sad el-Boushrieh industrial area to allow firefighters to put down the blaze. ``Otherwise Beirut will be without power for months to come,'' he warned. The capital has already been without power since the fighting erupted Tuesday. That was attributed to the inability of electricity authority employees to report to work at the main generating plant in the embattled Zouk suburb because of the hostilities. Tongues of orange-red flames pierced the dark sky and clouds of black smoke hung over the city as shelling duels raged into the night. Patriarch Sfeir appealed to the combatants after presiding over a meeting of senior Maronite clerics at his hilltop seat in Bkirki, north of Beirut. Four howitzer shells landed in the area while they met. Geagea's radio and television stations blamed the shelling on Aoun. Voice of the Nation, a Moslem radio, said Aoun's men fired shells that fell in west Beirut. The Moslem sector has not been involved in the war between the rebel general and Geagea, who commands Lebanon's main Christian militia. Police said seven people were killed and 40 wounded in west Beirut and President Elias Hrawi, who lives and works there, was forced to move to a secret hideout. They said at least five 120mm mortar rounds landed near Hrawi's residence in the Ramlet al-Baida district. An aide, reached by telephone, said the president ``changed his office for his own safety.'' Voice of Lebanon radio, a Christian station owned by allies of Geagea, proclaimed: ``Beirut is burning!'' Geagea's Lebanese Forces issued a statement saying Aoun ``has shown himself unscrupulous in satisfying his lust for power, even if it means apocalypse for everyone.'' Hrawi dismissed Aoun as army commander, but he has refused to step aside or turn over the presidential palace in suburban Baabda, where a bunker serves as his headquarters. He commands about 20,000 men and Geagea has about 6,000, bolstered by several thousand reservists. It was difficult to determine Friday who was getting the upper hand. Aoun appeared determined to destroy the Lebanese Forces, but repeated assaults have failed to reach Geagea's main arms and ammunition depot in the Ashrafiyeh district of east Beirut. Control in the 310-square-mile Christian enclave is about evenly split between Aoun and Geagea. In a three-minute televised address Friday, Aoun urged Christians to ``rally behind your army.'' He said the Lebanese Forces would enforce a peace agreement mediated by the Arab League last fall, which he rejects. Hrawi was elected by Parliament to carry out the peace plan in an attempt to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war, which has cost more than 150,000 lives.

DOC.HEAD: Gotti's Alleged Victim Testifies for Defense
DOC.TEXT: A union official who was allegedly shot on reputed mob boss John Gotti's orders testified for the defense Friday in Gotti's assault trial, saying he couldn't identify the people who nearly killed him. John O'Connor, former vice president of Carpenters' Union Local 608, had refused to testify for the prosecution. But under questioning by defense lawyer Gerald Shargel, he detailed the shooting of May 7, 1986. O'Connor, 56, said he noticed four or five men hanging around outside his union local's offices when he arrived there about 6:45 that morning. While waiting for the elevator, O'Connor said he heard ``a thunderous clap'' and felt something in his body, although he did not realize he had been shot. A man shouted, ``Mr. O'Connor, Mr. O'Connor,'' and the union official said he turned and saw a man pointing a gun at him. The elevator arrived, and O'Connor said he got on as the gunman fired more bullets into his buttocks. The union official said he got off the elevator at the seventh floor, saw an acquaintance and said: ``Please help me, I've been shot, several times.'' Jose Corvalan, the surgeon who treated O'Connor at the hospital, said the victim would have died without prompt medical treatment. O'Connor said that in viewing police photos he was never able to identifiy any of the men he saw outside his office the day he was shot. Gotti, 49, the reputed Gambino crime family head who's noted for his snappy attire, and Anthony Guerrieri, 60, an alleged Gambino soldier, are on trial in Manhattan's state Supreme Court on charges of assault and conspiracy in the O'Connor shooting. Prosecutors say Gotti had O'Connor shot for leading union goons to wreck Bankers and Brokers, a Gambino-affiliated restaurant. They maintain that a secretly recorded tape shows Gotti saying O'Connor needed to be ``busted up.'' Arguing the tapes are largely inaudible, the defense said that if the comment was clear enough to prosecute Gotti, it was clear enough for authorities to warn O'Connor. The defense, which rested Friday, argued that O'Connor's enemies in his union might have shot him because of internecine rivalries. O'Connor said he initially told police that union trouble had nothing to do with the incident, but conceded in testimony that within the union, ``We were having problems.'' Under cross-examination, O'Connor answered questions about the attack on him and about the 127-count indictment charging him with perjury, extortion, and labor racketeering. But he asserted his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination when asked about his alleged links to organized crime and about his ownership of certain properties. Testimony suggested that O'Connor's union was tied to the Genovese gang. O'Connor took the stand after acting Justice Edward McLaughlin denied a defense motion to dismiss the case, or to instruct the jury that in an earlier trial the prosecution had presented a different theory about the Bankers and Brokers incident. Gotti's lawyer, Bruce Cutler, said he thought it was significant that O'Connor had refused to testify against Gotti for the prosecution and that the defense had subpoenaed him. McLaughlin said the jury will hear closing arguments Monday and will get his final instructions Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Four Top Aides of Romanian Dictator Ceasescu Draw Life Terms
With AM-Romania
DOC.TEXT: A military tribunal convicted four top officials under ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu of being accomplices to genocide and sentenced then to life in prison Friday, Radio Bucharest reported. They were convicted of backing Ceasescu's orders to shoot demonstrators during the violent December revolution that toppled him after 24 years. Ceausescu and his wife Elena were executed by firing squad on Dec. 25. The five-judge tribunal, the first to try leading figures in the Ceausescu government, rejected a prosecution demand that the four men be convicted of the more serious crime of ``co-authorship to genocide.'' Both charges are punishable by a maximum sentence of life in prison, but the minimum terms are different, lawyers said. The panel ordered seizure of all property belonging to the four, including gold, jewels and large sums of money, and stripped them of their civil rights. The four, who had already pleaded guilty to the charge of ``complicity to genocide,'' stood solemnly as the tribunal president, Col. Andrei Nitoiu, announced the majority verdict after two hours of deliberation. Three of the four defendants _ Emil Bobu, 62, former secretary of the Communist Party Central Committee and No. 3 in the Ceausescu leadership; former state council Vice President Manea Manescu, 74, and former Politburo member Ion Dinca, 62 _ stared at the judges, showing no emotion as the verdict was read. Former Interior Minister Tudor Postelnicu, 59, bowed his head, as he had during much of the five-day trial. The National Salvation Front, which took power during the revolution, abolished the death penalty, making life in prison the maximum penalty. Bobu, Postelnicu and Manescu said they would appeal but Dinca told the judge he would not. Manescu, while saying he was guilty, had asked for a lesser sentence than the others, saying he had no part in repressing demonstrators. The four Politburo members admitted they backed Ceausescu's orders to shoot scores of demonstrators and did nothing to end his dictatorship. But all denied they gave direct orders to put down the protests. The military prosecutor, Col. Aurel Cosma, urged the judges to imprison all four for life ``on behalf of the thousands of victims, of orphans, children, men, women and brave military men who were killed'' in the revolution. Western diplomats have said up to 10,000 people died in the fighting between Ceausescu's Securitate forces and citizens who joined with the army. Ceausescu and his politically powerful wife fled Bucharest by helicopter on Dec. 22, but were arrested, convicted of genocide and of ruining Romania's economy in a secret summary trial, and were executed. The prosecution charged the four defendants could have prevented the genocide that killed at least 689 people and injured 1,281 by asking Ceausescu to resign. But instead they backed his order to shoot the demonstrators. The prosecutor asked for the stiffer charge of ``co-authorship to genocide'' Thursday, saying a colleague drafted the charges incorrectly. Both charges are punishable by a maximum sentence of life in prison, but the minimum terms are different, lawyers said.

DOC.HEAD: New York Neighborhood Shaken by Twin Shootings of Teens by Cops
DOC.TEXT: Flowers and bloodstains marked a sidewalk Friday where a 14-year-old robbery suspect became the second unarmed teen-ager in five days to be killed by a police officer. ``Killer cop Albergo,'' was spray-painted in black on a blue badge on a wall near the scene. Scrawled in black on the sidewalk where Jose Louis Lebron died were the words ``Killed by a man in blue.'' Lebron died Wednesday in front of the Wilson Avenue Candy Store in the Brooklyn neighborhood known as Bushwick. He was shot behind the right ear by Officer Frank Albergo, who thought he saw Lebron reaching into his jacket for a weapon. A preliminary investigation showed Albergo acted ``within police guidelines,'' police said. They said Lebron had robbed someone of $10. On Saturday, four blocks away, 17-year-old Louis Liranso was shot in the back by Officer Hyda Hernandez after he allegedly lowered his hands and turned toward the officer. Liranso was unarmed; the officer has been suspended and a grand jury is examining the case. Lebron was the seventh person killed by New York police in the first month of 1990; six of the shootings have occurred in the borough of Brooklyn. In 1989 30 people killed by police; in 1988, there were 25 and in 1987, 14. New Police Commissioner Lee Brown on Friday promised Bushwick residents ``a thorough and complete investigation'' and ``appropriate action based upon the facts of the case.'' ``I think the community will always be saddened when someone loses a life, and when young people lose their lives it is an even sadder event,'' said Brown. ``For us, it is always tragic when police officers are involved in the incident.'' Lebron's death has angered neighbors and friends, who said he had been a happy kid. But one officer on the beat said Lebron was a neighborhood tough who bullied others and was ``always on the street, hanging out and drinking.'' ``What we want is justice. We want the officer to pay for what he did,'' said Lebron's 22-year-old brother, Ruben. He said he had been eating dinner with his brother just 15 minutes before he died. ``I'll be right back,'' Ruben Lebron recalled his brother saying as he ran out the door to get a soda. Friends spray-painted Lebron's graffiti tag name, ``Rase,'' in 8-foot red letters on a building around the corner from where he was killed. Hundreds of residents marched on the local police precinct Thursday night; three were arrested after the crowd began throwing rocks and bottles at police in riot gear. ``It's just murder, plain old murder,'' one demonstrator said. ``People are tired of this,'' said one resident, Manuel Vasquez, 38. ``We're supposed to be more afraid of the criminals than the cops. It's getting not that way anymore.'' A light rain fell Friday outside the candy store, where two lines of blood stretching from the sidewalk to the street were still visible. Four floral arrangements lay where Lebron fell. ``I feel like crying,'' said 15-year-old Pearl Cantres, who added a single white rose to the pile. She had also brought Lebron's mother some flowers. ``I was thinking it could have happened to me, to my brother, any of us,'' she said. She scrawled a message on cardboard with a black crayon: ``May God take your soul and place it in a white box full of our tears of pain.'' ``He was always smiling,'' Ruben Lebron said, wiping a tear from his cheek. ``He was the clown of the block. If this tragedy happened to someone else, he'd make us laugh.'' Bushwick is also where a woman who had tried to rid her neighborhood of drugs was slain last summer. Police speculate that Maria Hernandez was killed by angry dealers. Robert Hernandez, 17, recalled how neighborhood teen-agers, inspired by her death, have since driven the dealers out of several other blocks. ``We're not no vigilantes,'' he said. ``We fight with words.'' A Hispanic police officer, who held his hat over his nameplate as he described Lebron as a neighborhood tough, said the local youths ``won't back down if they're with one another, not even to an officer.''

DOC.HEAD: Collision of Two Commuter Trains Leaves 17 Dead, 72 Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to UPDATE with 17 dead, details. Picks up 5th, `Some cars...'
DOC.TEXT: Two crowded commuter trains collided at the height of the evening rush hour outside Frankfurt on Friday, killing at least 17 people and injuring more than 70, officials said. Hesse state Interior Minister Gottfried Milde earlier said rescuers had pulled 15 bodies from the wreckage. Rescue workers were still searching through the wreckage late Friday and an updated police statement listed 17 dead and 72 injured, including 37 seriously. Walter Henss, a spokesman for the Federal Railroad network, said the accident occurred after one of the drivers of the trains apparently missed a stop signal on the heavily used run between Frankfurt and Wiesbaden. Some cars derailed and rescue workers were unsure how many passengers were trapped in the wreckage. The derailed cars also crashed into a row of parked cars. Henss said both trains were traveling at relatively slow speed when the collision occurred. The derailed cars forced authorities to close down a section of track and to reroute other trains during rush hour.

DOC.HEAD: World Leaders Praise de Klerk's Moves, But Say Apartheid Must Go
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with State Dep't, Soviet comment; picks up 5th `Prime Minister'
DOC.TEXT: South Africa won worldwide praise Friday for legalizing the African National Congress and promising to free black leader Nelson Mandela, and Britain immediately restored cultural and academic ties. Other nations tempered plaudits with reminders that apartheid remained. Anti-apartheid groups asked governments to continue economic and other sanctions, which they said had pushed the white authorities to reform. Javier Perez de Cuellar, the U.N. secretary-general, described President F.W. de Klerk's announcement as ``celestial music'' he hoped would herald the end of apartheid. President Bush called it ``quite positive'' and said he would review U.S. sanctions. A Bush aide said both de Klerk and Mandela, an ANC leader when he was sent to jail, would be invited to the White House. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said: ``We call on all South African parties, including those unbanned by President de Klerk, to take up this offer of negotiations and begin in earnest the process of a peaceful transition to a non-racial democratic South Africa.'' The Soviet Union said the measures were ``an important and long-expected step in the right direction,'' but the official news agency Tass quoted a Foreign Ministry spokesman as saying: ``It is necessary that they should be followed by practical actions,'' such as lifting ``the state of emergency.'' Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher called de Klerk's speech ``a historic landmark,'' invited de Klerk to London and lifted cultural and academic embargoes. ``We believe in carrots as well as sticks and they've had plenty of the latter, they should now have some of the former,'' said Mrs. Thatcher, who has been instrumental in thwarting harsh international measures against South Africa. The prime minister, who said she will also invite Mandela to Britain when the black nationalist leader is released, said the U.S. policy of disinvestment and tightening sanctions was ``a mistake.'' British officials said that ``in due course'' she will raise the issue of easing embargoes in the European Community and the Commonwealth, the 49-nation association of Britain and its former colonies. In a speech that reversed decades of official policy, de Klerk also said he will legalize other black dissident groups, declare a moratorium on executions, and lift more measures under a state of emergency imposed in 1986. Sir Shridath Ramphal, secretary-general of the Commonwealth, the 49-nation association of Britain and its former colonies, said South Africa had reached ``a moment of hope.'' But ``much of President de Klerk's announcement is a statement of intent,'' Ramphal said in a statement. ``Meanwhile all concerned must work ... to convert promise into performance and ensure that apartheid is ended.'' Canada's external affairs minister, Joe Clark, who leads a nine-nation Commonwealth committee monitoring sanctions, said he was ``very encouraged.'' Black African nations, South Africa's most hostile critics, joined in guarded praise. Nigeria's foreign affairs minister, Rilwanu Lukman, said de Klerk had taken ``the first concrete step in the long journey toward the total eradication of apartheid and racial discrimination.'' Mozambique, South Africa's neighbor, played an excerpt of South African music on the state radio and the announcer declared de Klerk's speech ``allows us to see, shining strongly, a light at the end of a tunnel that once seemed infinite.'' Kenya and Sierra Leone both called the moves a ``step in the right direction.'' In Zambia, where the exiled ANC has been based, President Kenneth Kaunda offered ``hearty congratulations for a job well started, not well done. I wish him (De Klerk) the best of luck.''
