Israel, long suspected of helping South Africa evade a mandatory international arms embargo and build nuclear arms, welcomed the announcement. ``Israel will continue to follow favorably the process of reform taking place in South Africa,'' said Foreign Minister Moshe Arens. Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama of Japan called the measures crucial to starting black-white negotiations in South Africa. West Germany, France and other Western European countries said South Africa had moved in the right direction. Scandinavian nations, forceful opponents of apartheid, said the time was not right to relax economic sanctions. ``The pressure of the South African regime must be kept up,'' Swedish Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson said. But Dutch Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers said he expected the European Community nations to meet soon to discuss lifting some embargoes. ``The situation has changed fundamentally,'' he said. ``A wall has come down.'' U.S. sanctions have been the harshest of any imposed by South Africa's major trading partners. The U.S. Congress has been considering bills that seek to place a total trade embargo and ban banks from rescheduling loans to South Africa. Main measures by the 12-nation European Community are a ban on iron and steel imports from South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0684 to fix byline
Talks on the Azerbaijani-Armenian Conflict Held in Riga
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for BAKU-dated item on digest.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB1
DOC.TEXT: Feuding Armenians and Azerbaijanis opened peace talks Friday and immediately found common ground: Both sides criticized the Kremlin for sending troops to their southern region. Armenian negotiators told reporters that the use of the Red Army was unnecessary and was destabilizing the entire Caucasus region, which includes Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia. The Armenians and the Azerbaijanis, meeting in the western republic of Latvia, agreed to discuss the presence of the troops, the estimated half-million refugees of both nationalities the ethnic conflict has created, and other humanitarian issues. Both sides agreed not to raise the territorial dispute that sparked the unrest. Armenians want political control over Nagorno-Karabakh, a largely Armenian district located inside Azerbaijan, but Azerbaijanis want the region to remain in their hands. Baltic mediators, leaders of the three people's fronts movements in Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania, said the talks could last two to three months. In Baku, the Azerbaijani capital, leaders of the Azerbaijani People's Front met with Soviet military commanders Thursday and took a defiant stand, raising their demand that all 17,000 soldiers be withdrawn. Lt. Gen. Vladimir S. Dubinyak, the military commandant, promised to transmit the demand to Moscow, said Tofik Gosymov, one of the 14 directors of the people's front. ``If the question of the removal of the soldiers is not solved, we won't negotiate with them and we won't cooperate,'' Gosymov said. He also said the military wanted to leave Baku for its own reasons. He did not elaborate. The one-hour talks at the Azerbaijani Interior Ministry bypassed the Azerbaijan Communist Party and the Caucasus republic's government, underscoring the increasing clout wielded by the grassroots People's Front. The party and government have been sharply criticized for failing to control violence that began Jan. 13 with attacks against Armenian residents and continued when Soviet troops stormed Baku a week later. At least 214 were killed and more than 500 injured in the unrest, according to official reports Friday. The republics have been locked in a decades-old dispute, largely centering on Nagorno-Karabakh. The Armenians are mostly Christian; the Azerbaijaini are predominantly Shiite Moslem. During the talks with the military, the People's Front also demanded release of arrested members and an explanation of what they said were military assaults on the group's headquarters. Dubinyak, accompanied by his assistant for political affairs, Maj. Gen. Anatoly I. Kirilyuk, and an official of the national Interior Ministry, said those issues could only be decided in Moscow, Gosymov reported. Gosymov said the People's Front needed at least a schedule for withdrawal to bring the situation in Baku back to normal. With such a schedule, ``We can appeal to the people to go back to work and they will, 100 percent,'' he said. Soviet officials say more than 80 percent of Baku's workforce is back on the job, but the People's Front claims the figure is much lower. On Thursday, Dubinyak told reporters that the 11 p.m.-to-5 a.m. curfew could be lifted and some soldiers withdrawn as early as mid-February.

DOC.HEAD: Coalition to Participate in Elections Under Avril
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ A coalition including two of Haiti's main parties said Friday it was satisfied with Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril's pledge to hold elections this year as promised and would participate in them. The National Alliance for Democracy and Progress said in a statement published by the independent daily Le Matin it ``expresses its satisfaction'' with the lifting this week of a nine-day state of siege. Last month, some coalition leaders said they were beaten by police during a crackdown on opponents of Avril's government In its statement, the coalition said ``all true democrats'' should urge the independently appointed Electoral Council to ``take all useful steps to ensure the regularity of the electoral process and the credibility of the results.'' Avril promised on Wednesday hold the elections scheduled for October. He acknowledged brutality by police in the crackdown and said seven exiled leaders could return. Three of those _ Louis Roy, considered the father of the constitution; conservative politician Hubert de Ronceray; and businessman Antoine Izmery _ said in Washington this week they would not do so under Avril's ``regime of terror.'' Max Bourjolly, deputy leader of the Communist Party, said in Paris he would return if permitted, but would not take part in elections. Marc Bazin, a conservative former presidential candidate, leads the National Alliance for Democracy and Progress. Several members of his party, the Movement To Establish Democracy, said they were beaten in police custody during the state of siege Jan. 20-29. Witnesses said deputy leader Serge Gilles, a socialist, and several supporters were severely beaten by plainclothes police after being arrested at his home Jan. 20. Gilles said he suffered a burst eardrum and dislocated vertebra in a second beating at the National Palace. Francois Benoit, Haiti's ambassador to the United States and a former vice president of Bazin's party, resigned to protest the crackdown. Several other opposition leaders remain in hiding and have said they would boycott any elections held under Avril. The general declared the state of seige the day after Col. Andre Neptune, his wife and a servant were shot to death by assailants as yet unidentified.

DOC.HEAD: Front Keeps its Grip on Romania Despite Power-Sharing Accord
DOC.TEXT: The ruling National Salvation Front apparently will keep control of the government until May 20 elections, despite an accord with opposition parties to share power, the Front's vice president said Friday. Cazimir Ionescu said the Front will take half the seats in a new Council of National Unity agreed at a conference with 29 opposition parties Thursday. The National Salvation Front took absolute control of Romania during the December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was later executed along with his wife, Elena. Although the opposition said it accepted Thursday's outcome as a true power-sharing agreement, the Front will still apparently have the major say in running things until May. Romanians vote then in the first free, multiparty elections here since shortly after World War II. The new 180-member Council is to be split evenly _ 90 from political parties and 90 Romanian national figures and others from all walks of life. A communique announcing formation of the Council said farmers, workers, students and all other forces that took part in the revolution would be represented. On Saturday, as its last act before dissolving itself, the ruling council of the Front will meet to decide whom to name as the 90 non-political appointees on the Council of National Unity. Ionescu told two Westeren reporters, ``If we should make the mistake of reshuffling the government ... before the elections, this would mean that in the next two or three months we would see a destabilization of the economy. ``We decided that the government would not have any political color, but only a technocratic one.'' He indicated that the current government, installed by the Front's council, would remain intact after the the Council of National Unity is established. Two members of the Front's council have resigned. One, Dimitru Mazilu, who was council vice president, quit after accusing the Front of ``Stalinist tactics.'' Asked if the new Council of National Unity would have veto power over government actions, Ionescu replied: ``This will be decided during the future meetings by the council itself.'' But he said the new council probably will decide the most important issues. He said it will decide how to operate and whether to have a president. But he considered it likely that interim President Ion Iliescu would continue in office under the new agreement, citing the threat of instability otherwise. Asked if the opposition would oppose domination of the Council of National Unity by Front appointees, Ionescu said, ``If they didn't criticize (it) until now ... I don't think there could be anyone else who could criticize this fact.'' As an apparent concession to the opposition, the new governing council will have three members from each of the nation's 29 political parties as well as three from the Front itself. The Front has agreed to transform itself into a political party and separate from its ruling council, which now runs the government and has total control of all state apparatus, including television and radio. The opposition had protested against the Front's organizing the elections, parceling out broadcast time to the different parties, and at the same time fielding candidates itself. The accord came after 10 days of violent pro- and anti-Front street demonstrations, including synchronized attacks on 28 different headquarters of the National Peasants Party, the dominant and best-organized opposition group. On Friday, a military tribunal convicted four former leaders of the Ceausescu government of being accomplices to a genocide and sentenced then to life in prison, Radio Bucharest reported. Found guilty of backing Ceausescu's orders to shoot demonstrators during the revolution were Emil Bobu, 62, former secretary of the Communist Party Central Committee; former state council Vice President Manea Manescu, 74; Ion Dinca, 62, former Politburo member, and former Interior Minister Tudor Postelnicu, 59.

DOC.HEAD: Changes Announced by de Klerk at-a-Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS further details on de Klerk's announcements. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Here are highlights of the concessions to the black majority made by President F.W. de Klerk on Friday in a speech to Parliament: _ LEGALIZATION of the African National Congress, outlawed since 1960, and more than 60 other banned and restricted organizations including the Pan-Africanist Congress, the South African Communist Party, the United Democratic Front and the Azanian People's Organization. _ RELEASE in the near future of Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners _ except those who have committed ordinary crimes. _ MORATORIUM on hangings, until the government rewrites the death sentence law to apply only to extreme cases. Death Row prisoners henceforth will have an automatic right to appeal. _ REPEAL of the Separate Amenities Act promised during the current session of Parliament, ending the right of local authorities to racially segregate public facilities. _ LIFTING of emergency regulations regarding education and the press, except the restrictions on photography and filming of political unrest. _ ENDING emergency restrictions on freedom of speech, movement, assembly and work that were imposed on 374 freed detainees, and the emergency regulations which allowed such restrictions to be repealed. _ DETENTION without trial is retained, but limited to six months, and detainees will have the right to legal representation and a doctor of their own choice.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts from President F.W. de Klerk's Speech
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS additional excerpts. Two takes, no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from President F.W. de Klerk's speech Friday in which he legalized or lifted restrictions on more than 60 organizations, including the African National Congress, and said the ANC's jailed leader Nelson Mandela will be freed soon: Mr Speaker, members of Parliament The general election on Sept. 6, 1989, placed our country irrevocably on the road of drastic change. Underlying this is the growing realization by an increasing number of South Africans that only a negotiated understanding among the representative leaders of the entire population is able to ensure lasting peace. The alternative is growing violence, tension and conflict. That is unacceptable and in nobody's interest. The well-being of all in this country is linked inextricably to the ability of the leaders to come to terms with one another on a new dispensation. No one can escape this simple truth. On its part, the government will accord the process of negotiation the highest priority. The aim is totally new and just constitutional dispensation in which every inhabitant will enjoy equal rights, treatment and opportunity in every sphere of endeavor _ constitutional, social and economic. I hope that this new Parliament will play a constructive part in both the prelude to negotiations and the negotiating process itself. I wish to ask all of you who identify yourselves with the broad aim of a new South Africa, and that is the overwhelming majority: _ Let us put petty politics aside when we discuss the future during this session. _ Help us build a broad consensus about the fundamentals of a new, realistic and democratic dispensation. _ Let us work together on a plan that will rid our country of suspicion and steer it away from domination and radicalism of any kind. _ During the term of this new Parliament, we shall have to deal, complimentary to one another, with the normal processes of legislation and day-to-day government, as well as with the process of negotiation and renewal. Within this framework I wish to deal first with several matters more closely concerned with the normal process of government before I turn specifically to negotiation and related issues.
DOC.HEAD: FOREIGN RELATIONS
DOC.TEXT: The government is aware of the important part the world at-large has to play in the realization of our country's national interests. Without contact and cooperation with the rest of the world we cannot promote the well-being and security of our citizens. The dynamic for South Africa as well. Important advances have been made, among precluded previously by ideological considerations. I hope this trend will be encouraged by the important change of climate that is taking place in South Africa. For South Africa, indeed for the whole world, the past year has been one of change and major upheaval. In Eastern Europe and even the Soviet Union itself, political and economic upheaval surged forward in an unstoppable tide. At the same time, Beijing temporarily smothered with brutal violence the yearning of the people of the Chinese mainland for greater freedom. The year of 1989 will go down in history as the year in which Stalinist Communism expired. ...
DOC.HEAD: HUMAN RIGHTS
DOC.TEXT: The whole question of protecting individual and minority rights ... is still under consideration by the Law Commission. Therefore, it would be inappropriate for the government to express a view on the details now. However, certain matters of principle have emerged fairly clearly ... The government accepts the principle of recognition and protection of the fundamental individual rights which form the constitutional basis of most Western democracies. ... It is neither the government's policy nor its intention that any group _ in whichever way it may be defined _ shall be favored above or in relation to any of the others.
DOC.HEAD: THE DEATH PENALTY
DOC.TEXT: We have now reached the position ... that the death penalty should be limited as an option of sentence to extreme cases, and specifically through broadening judicial discretion in the imposition of sentence; and That an automatic right of appeal be granted to those under sentence of death. ...
DOC.HEAD: NEGOTIATION
DOC.TEXT: I wish to urge every political and community leader, in and outside Parliament, to approach the new opportunities which are being created, constructively. There is no time left for advancing all manner of new conditions that will delay the negotiating process. The steps that have been decided are the following: _The prohibition of the African National Congress, the Pan Africanist Congress, the South African Communist Party and a number of subsidiary organizations is being rescinded. _People serving prison sentences merely because they were members of one of these organizations, or because they committed another offense which was merely an offense because of prohibition on one of the organizations was in force, will be identified and released. Prisoners who have been sentenced for other offenses such as murder, terrorism or arson are not affected by this. _The media emergency regulations as well as the education emergency regulations are being abolished in their entirety. _The security emergency regulations will be amended to still make provision for effecitive control over visual material pertaining to scenes of unrest. _The restrictions in terms of the emergency regulations on 33 organizations are being rescinded. The organizations include the following: National Education Crisis Committee, South African National Students Congress, United Democratic Front, Cosatu, Die Blanke Bevrydingsbeweging van Suid-Afrika. _The conditions imposed in terms of the security emergency regulations on 374 people on their release, are being rescinded and the regulations which provide for such conditions are being abolished. _The period of detention in terms of the security emergency regulations will be limited henceforth to six months. Detainees also acquire the right to legal representation and a medical practitioner of their own choosing. These decisions by the Cabinet are in accordance with the government's declared intention to normalize the political process in South Africa without jeapardizing the maintenance of the good order. They were preceded by thorough and unanimous advice by a group of officials which included members of the security community. Implementation will be immediate and, where necessary, notices will appear in the Government Gazette from tomorrow. ...
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Organizers of Anti-Drug TV Special Plan More Programs
DOC.TEXT: A prime-time special on the dangers of drugs, which ran simultaneously on all the city's major television stations, has flooded police lines with crime tips and may be duplicated in other cities later this year. Organizers of ``Texas CrackDown!'' hailed the project for its cooperation by competing media. The two-hour program aired simultaneously on three network affiliates, one independent TV station and three radio stations, and was coordinated with newspaper coverage and programs in schools and by anti-drug groups. Television stations and crime-stoppers programs in Houston, San Antonio, Chicago, Los Angeles, San Francisco, New Orleans and Kansas City are being contacted about producing local versions of the program, said executive producer Hugh Akin. In Dallas, response to the show overwhelmed organizers and law enforcement agencies. Arbitron ratings for Jan. 23 showed that ``Texas Crackdown!'' was watched by 72 percent of the 1.7 million households that have televisions in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, Akin said. ``We felt as though it would be effective. But we did not expect the kind of overwhelming response we got,'' said Greg MacAleese, program co-producer and executive director of the Greater Dallas Crime Commission. Since the program aired, the Dallas Police Department's Crime Stoppers Program has received up to six times its normal volume of daily calls, officers said. ``We are pleased,'' police Sgt. Barry Whitfield said Friday. ``I'm sure much good will come of it.'' One tip led to the arrest of a fugitive whose case was featured on the program and who was wanted on warrants issued by four law agencies. About 1,000 callers sought help from the Dallas Council on Alcoholism and Drug Abuse in the week after ``Texas Crackdown!'' aired, Akin said. The council normally gets 183 calls a week. The 50 phone toll-free lines set up to handle calls during the show were overloaded, Akin said, adding he'd double the number of lines for future programs. Producers are capable of doing six more shows in the next year, and Akin said they hope to negotiate deals with other major-market TV stations by the end of February or early March. In addition, broadcasters in smaller markets around the country are considering single- or multiple-station versions of the show, he said. Akin and MacAleese may consult with those stations, Akin said. The two men raised $210,000 from hospitals, foundations and corporations to fund the project. At least one school district has requested program tapes, and others have made inquiries, said MacAleese. For the first ``Texas CrackDown!'' many school districts assigned homework and classroom projects based on a program questionnaire published in local newspapers. Akin said that the morning after one north Texas couple watched the show, their two teen-age daughters admitted they had drug problems and were put in treatment programs. ``We hope there will be more examples of such openness between kids and their parents, because that is how the drug problem will get solved,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Across Northern States, Along Rockies
DOC.TEXT: Snow was scattered across the nation's northern tier of states and along the Rockies on Friday, and winter storm warnings and watches were posted across parts of the Plains, Midwest and Northeast. At midday, snow fell from eastern Washington state across the Idaho Panhandle, over southeastern Wyoming, eastern and central Colorado, northwestern New Mexico, much of Kansas, southern and eastern Nebraska, eastern South Dakota, eastern North Dakota, north-central Minnesota, south-central Iowa, central Upper Michigan, eastern Lower Michigan, much of inland New York state, southern Vermont and southern New Hampshire. Snow and poor visibility in fog caused air traffic delays and numerous accidents Friday around the Denver area, which accumulated 4 inches. Interstate 25 was closed northbound Friday afternoon from the Greenland exit to Castle Rock because of numerous accidents and blowing snow, the Colorado State Patrol said. Heaviest snowfall during the six hours up to noon included 4 inches at Buffalo, N.Y., and 3 inches at Mount Clemens, Mich.; Niagara Falls, N.Y.; rochester, N.Y.; and Syracuse, N.Y. Winter storm warnings were posted overnight across the Susquehanna and Catskill regions of New York state, and the upper Susquehanna Valley of eastern Pennsylvania. Winter storm watches were posted into Saturday over much of Iowa and northern Illinois, extreme southeastern Nebraska, much of Kansas and the northwestern third of Oklahoma. In the Southwest, snowfall overnight from Thursday into Friday morning across Arizona included 8 to 10 inches at Pinetop-Lakeside, 4 inches at Payson and Willcox, and 2 inches at Winslow. Strong chinook winds blowing at 30 to 50 mph caused travel problems across north-central Montana by whipping up blowing, drifting snow. The chinook wind also rapidly warmed the eastern slopes of the Montana Rockies. Rain fell from east-central and southern New England across southeastern New York state and Pennsylvania. Freezing rain extended from northwestern Missouri across northeastern and east-central Kansas through south-central Kansas into southwestern Oklahoma. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 3 degrees below zero at Warroad, Minn., to 87 at Fort Myers, Fla. Friday's low for the Lower 48 states was 18 below zero at International Falls, Minn.

DOC.HEAD: CAPE TOWN: from tomorrow
DOC.TEXT: The events in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe ... weaken the capability of organizations which were previously supported strongly from those quarters. The activities of the organizations from which the prohibitions are now being lifted, no longer entail the same degree of threat to internal security which initially necessitated the imposition of the prohibitions. There have been important shifts of emphasis in the statements and points of view of the most important of the organizations concerned, which indicate a new approach and a preference for peaceful solutions. The South African Police is convinced that it is able, in the present circumstances, to combat violence and other crimes perpetrated also by members of these organizations and to bring offenders to justice without the aid of prohibitions on organizations. About one matter there should be no doubt. The lifting of the prohibition of the said organizations does not signify in the least the approval ... of terrorism or crimes of violence committed under their banner or which may be perpetrated in the future. Equally, it should not be interpreted as a deviation from the government's principles, among other things, against their economic policy and aspects of their constitutional policy. This will be dealt with in debate and negotiation. At the same time I wish to emphasize that the maintenance of law and order dare not be jeopardized. The government will not forsake its duty in this connection. Violence from whichever source, will be fought with all available might. Peaceful protest may not become the springboard for lawlessness, violence and intimidation. No democratic country can tolerate that. Strong emphasis will be placed as well on even more effective law enforcement. Proper provision of manpower and means for the police and all who are involved with the enforcement of the law will be ensured. ... It is my intention to terminate the state of emergency completely as soon as circumstances justify it ... There is still conflict which is manifesting itself mainly in Natal (Province). . .. Our country and all its people have been embroiled in conflict, tension and violent struggle for decades. It is time for us to break out of the cycle of violence and break through to peace and reconciliation. With the steps the government has taken, it has proven its good faith and the table is laid for sensible leaders to begin talking about a new dispensation. ... Among other things, those aims include a new, democratic constitution; universal franchise; no domination; equality before an independent judiciary; the protection of minorities as well as of individual rights; freedom of religion; a sound economy based on proven economic principles and private enterprise; dynamic programs directed at better education, health services, housing and social conditions for all. ... I wish to put it plainly that the government has taken a firm decision to release Mr. Mandela unconditionally. ... The government will take a decision soon on the date of his release. Unfortunately, a further short passage of time is unavoidable. ... In the case of Mr. Mandela there are factors in the way of his immediate release, of which his personal circumstances and safety are not the least. He has not been an ordinary prisoner for quite some time. Because of that, his case requires particular circumspection. Today's announcements go to the heart of what black leaders _ also Mr. Mandela _ have been advancing over the years as their reason for having resorted to violence. The allegation has been that the government did not wish to talk to them and that they were deprived of their right to normal political activity. ... Without conceding that violence has ever been justified, I wish to say today to those who argued in this manner: _The government wishes to talk to all leaders who seek peace. _The unconditional lifting of the prohibition on the said organizations places everybody in a position to pursue politics freely. _The justification for violence which was always advanced, no longer exists. ... _There is no longer any reasonable excuse for the continuation of violence. The time for talking has arrived and whoever still makes excuses does not really wish to talk. Therefore, I repeat my invitation with greater conviction than ever: Walk through the open door, take your place at the negotiating table together with the government and other leaders who have important power bases inside and outside of Parliament. Henceforth, everybody's political points of view will be tested against their realism, their workability and their fairness. The time for negotiation has arrived.
DOC.HEAD: CONCLUSION
DOC.TEXT: All reasonable people in this country _ by far the majority _ anxiously await a message of hope. It is our responsibility as leaders in all spheres to provide that message realistically with courage and conviction. If we fail in that, the ensuing chaos, the demise of stability and progress, will forever be held against us. ... I call on the international community to re-evaluate its position and to adopt a positive attitude toward the dynamic evolution which is taking place in South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Queen's Pregnant Cousin Weds Photographer
LaserPhoto LON19
DOC.TEXT: Marina Ogilvy, the pregnant 23-year-old cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, on Friday married the father of her child, freelance photographer Paul Mowatt, in a small church wedding outside London. In marrying a Roman Catholic, Miss Ogilvy gave up her claim to the British throne. She was 24th in line. Miss Ogilvy was greeted with a kiss from her father, Sir Angus Ogilvy, when she arrived at St. Andrew's Church near her parents' home 10 miles southwest of London. In October, Miss Ogilvy went to the British news media and said that when she told her parents she was pregnant, they demanded she either marry quickly or have an abortion. When she refused, they cut off her family allowance, she said. The young couple had planned to marry sometime after the baby's birth. The baby is due in May, Miss Ogilvy said. Ogilvy and his wife, Princess Alexandra, responded by issuing a public statement saying they loved their daughter, had not cut her off and that she always was welcome at their home. The princess is sister of the Duke of Kent and is the queen's first cousin. The bride wore a rust-colored bolero jacket in crushed velvet with a gold tassle trim over a mid-calf-length fitted black velvet dress. She also wore a large wide-brimmed black hat with a turned-up front. Mowatt, 26, wore a sober dark blue suit. The 45-minute private service was attended by about 40 guests, who did not include the queen or any members of her immediate family. Afterward, Ogilvy said he felt ``fine'' and was ``delighted,'' while Princess Alexandra declared: ``It was a lovely wedding.''

DOC.HEAD: Armenian Patriarch of Jerusalem Dies
DOC.TEXT: Yeghishe Derderian, Armenian patriarch of Jerusalem and spiritual leader of the 8,000 Armenians in Israel, the occupied West Bank and Jordan, has dead of a heart attack, church officials said. He was 80. Church secretary George Hintlian said Derderian, one of the three custodians of Jerusalem's Christian holy places, died Thursday evening in his home at the St. James convent and monastery complex in Jerusalem's walled Old City. He had been ill with influenza for two days. Bells tolled in the Armenian quarter Friday to announce the death. Armenian women dressed in black greeted each other somberly as they entered the convent to pray. Black flags hung beside the white-and-red banner of the patriarchate. Bishop Guregh Kapikian was named acting patriarch. Another bishop, speaking on condition of anonymity, said renegade Bishop Shahe Ajemian entered the monastery at 9 a.m. with eight armed men and declared himself patriarch of Jerusalem. Derderian expelled Ajemian from the brotherhood of the monastery almost three years ago. Jerusalem police spokesman Uzi Sandouri said no information or complaints about the alleged takeover had been received from the Armenian community. According to the bishop, Ajemian ``entered the monastery with eight armed people and he has refused to leave. We don't know exactly what they plan to do.'' He did not describe the men's weapons. Derderian was born in Van, eastern Turkey, and came to Jerusalem in 1922. He studied at the St. James theological seminary, served as its dean before being named deputy patriarch in 1949, and became patriarch of Jerusalem in 1960, Hintlian said. Some Armenian priests are permitted to marry, but Derderian, a monk, remained celibate. He wrote 22 books, including biographies of religious figures and poetry, Hintlian said, adding: ``He was quite informed about the world and he was a great traveler.'' The Armenian Church follows the Eastern rite and does not accept the authority of the pope.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Brawna and Hispano cq in 3rd graf of 2nd item.
DOC.TEXT: The National Geographic Society says Alaska is where it belongs and shouldn't be moved closer to the center of the world map as a state senator requested. Alaska state Sen. Jim Duncan wrote to National Geographic magazine editors, saying too many maps show Alaska on the left. ``A constituent has written to me concerned that most world maps depict Alaska at the extreme left rather than in the center part which would be accurate,'' the Juneau Democrat said in his letter last month. ``We don't mean to intimate Alaska is at the center of the world, even though it is for Alaskans.'' John Garver, the society's chief cartographer, replied that the best way to produce a world map without cutting Europe and Asia in half results in Alaska's placement way out at the top left corner. The society in 1975 switched from producing maps with the United States in the center to ones with Europe as the midpoint, putting Alaska on the left, Garver said. ``We appreciate the dilemma with Alaska in this situation, but all things considered we feel that this is the best approach in displaying the continents and oceans of the world,'' Garver said. ``I felt they were a little bit defensive in their reply,'' Duncan said Thursday. Earlier this week, the House passed a resolution asking book publishers, magazines and newspapers to put the state in the northwest corner of the United States instead of off the California coast.

A radio station's find-the-mayor contest led about a dozen people to the office of low-profile Mayor Louis Saavedra, who posed for photographs with participants hoping to win a free dinner. The station offered a meal at a restaurant to anyone who could get their picture taken with the mayor between Feb. 1 and Feb. 15. Winners of the dinner for two can up the ante to dinner for four if they can persuade the mayor to dine with them. Brawna Martin, promotions director for KRST-FM and sister station KRZY-AM, said Thursday that listeners had complained they hadn't seen the mayor even before he created a stir when he declined to attend the Hispano Chamber of Commerce's annual banquet last week. ``There were all sorts of important political figures and celebrities attending, but our first Hispanic mayor was not there,'' Martin said. Saavedra, who took office in December, learned of the contest Thursday when camera-slinging visitors began stalking the waiting area outside his office. ``I've had some nice visitors who broke up what would have been an otherwise dull and hard-working day,'' Saavedra said. ``About a dozen people came in, took some pictures and visited a bit. They didn't get in the way.'' Peggy Clemmons, the mayor's personal secretary, said Saavedra posed for pictures between appointments and wasn't upset about the contest. ``He has a wonderful sense of humor about the situation,'' Clemmons said. ``I would hope the mayor thinks it's funny and entertaining and takes it with a grain of salt,'' Martin said. ``It's just that inquiring minds want to know. So we asked a question that's on everyone's mind: Where is Louie Saavedra? Where is our mayor? ``A few radio station listeners called to tell us it was easier to spot Elvis than Louis Saavedra. Scary, huh?''

DOC.HEAD: University of Wisconsin Board Votes to Keep ROTC on Campus
DOC.TEXT: University of Wisconsin regents refused Friday to expel the Reserve Officers' Training Corps, a move sought by a faculty group to protest the military's ban on enlisting homosexuals. The board voted 13-3 to accept the recommendation of University President Kenneth Shaw, which calls for an aggressive lobbying effort to reverse the Pentagon policy. Shaw's recommendation was adopted rather than a faculty-backed resolution that demanded ROTC be expelled in 1993 if the military continued to deny enlistment to homosexual men and women. ``I think it was the appropriate resolution to pass,'' said Regent Erroll Davis Jr. ``This resolution keeps the issue in the front line and will force us to deal with it.'' In December, the faculty at UW-Madison, the system's largest campus, approved a resolution asking the university to expel ROTC from campus in 1993 if the military continued to ban homosexuals. Several other campus groups followed with similar resolutions. Shaw responded this week by saying he didn't believe severing the university's ties to the military would effectively encourage the Pentagon to change its policy. Furthermore, eliminating military programs would hurt those students who benefit from them, he said. About 1,300 students are enrolled in Army, Navy and Air Force ROTC programs throughout the system's 13 major campuses; one-third are at UW-Madison, which has 42,000 students. The resolution approved Friday differs from one approved by the regents in 1987 because it requires UW administrators to report annually to the board on the progress of its efforts to change the military's policy. ``We intend to hold their feet to the fire,'' Regent Ruth Clusen said, referring to UW administrators. ``Writing letters isn't going to get us anywhere.'' The 1987 resolution, which said the university would lobby the military, was criticized for being too broad and ineffective. Capt. Cheryl Batterman, head of UW recruiting for the Air Force ROTC, was pleased the regents rejected the faculty's recommendation but said the resolution might make it hard to lure students to UW campuses. ``We're already feeling the pinch,'' she said. ``I had hoped they would've gotten this all resolved at once. Now, we still don't know what might happen. That's a hard plan to sell to students and parents.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Urges Delay in Use of Reagan Diary
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department on Friday urged a delay in turning over 33 excerpts from former President Reagan's diaries to Iran-Contra defendant John Poindexter and said a summary of the entries should be compiled for Poindexter's use instead. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene had set a deadline of Monday for Reagan to give the nearly three dozen excerpts to his former national security adviser, who is scheduled to go on trial Feb. 20. In urging a postponement, the Justice Department said many of the 33 entries duplicate material that came to light in last year's Iran-Contra trial of former White House aide Oliver North. ``Indeed, there may be no information in the diary entries covered by'' Greene's court order ``that is not in the public domain,'' the Justice Department said in a five-page brief. It said Iran-Contra prosecutors and Poindexter's lawyers should attempt to draft a stipulation covering the facts contained in the diary entries. Greene can then compare the proposed stipulation with the diary entries ``to ensure that all pertinent information has been covered,'' said the Justice Department. A stipulation is an agreement on facts by both sides in a lawsuit. ``We firmly believe that such an order is likely to obviate any need for the diary entries to be disclosed,'' said the Justice Department. ``The Court will thereby avoid a possible constitutional confrontation and the serious potential for delay such a confrontation would cause.'' President Reagan could raise the defense of executive privilege and argue that, under the Constitution, he does not have to turn over confidential documents used in reaching presidential decisions. Under the Justice Department's proposal, Poindexter's lawyers would not be permitted to see the diary entries during any negotiating process. Therefore, they almost certainly will oppose the plan. The Justice Department noted that information in one of the diary entries concerning Reagan's call to the president of Honduras already is summarized in stipulations from the North trial. The telephone call focused on a shipment of ammunition for the Contras that had been seized by a Honduran military commander. The Honduran president assured Reagan the commander would be ordered to deliver the ammunition to the rebels.

DOC.HEAD: Second Ford Plant Idled by Labor Strife
DOC.TEXT: A second Ford Motor Co. plant in Mexico has been hit by a strike, with workers on Friday demanding wage and benefit increases, a union spokesman said. The walkout that began Thursday idled production at the plant in the northern city of Chihuahua, one of the Detroit auto giant's three assembly lines in the country. At Ford's plant in Cuautitlan, workers maintained a three-week-old picket line despite a company back-to-work call. Ford shut the plant, 15 miles north of Mexico City, on Jan. 8 after 150 to 250 thugs shot and beat unionists, killing one and injuring nine. Workers at the plant have charged some union officials are corrupt and pro-management. Union spokesman Julian Salcedeo said the strike in Chihuahua was called to pressure Ford for wage and benefit increases in collective bargaining contract negotiations. ``It's wretched, the amount they're offering us,'' said Salcedo. Ford has offered a 12 percent raise; the workers are demanding a 15 percent raise as well as hefty increases in benefits. Pickets from the 800-member union local paralyzed the plant, which produces about 1,000 engines a day for export to U.S. and Canadian markets. A federal arbitration board in Mexico City is mediating the Chihuahua conflict. In addition to a raise, the Chihuahua workers want a 13 percent increase in interest on savings withheld by the company, a 10 percent hike in commodity coupons, higher vacation and holiday pay and bigger Christmas bonuses, Salcedo said. The labor strife at the Cuautitlan plant centers on a struggle for internal union reform. A picket has been up since Ford closed the plant on Jan. 8. ``The company is accessible; the labor federation is the biggest problem,'' said Alfredo Arista Ibarra, a member of the 21-person union negotiating committee. Despite the pickets, more than 1,000 mostly non-union workers returned to their jobs when Ford issued a back-to-work call Tuesday. Company spokesman Carlos Bandala said the plant can produce about 40 vehicles a day with the skeleton crew. The plant's 3,800 employees usually produce about 450 cars and trucks a day for the Mexican market. Arista said most workers are refusing to go back to work until the Mexican Labor Federation, which has controlled the Cuautitlan local for more than 20 years, accepts a slate of demands for union democracy. Ford's production line in the northwestern city of Hermosillo, Sonora, has not been affected by the labor conflict.

DOC.HEAD: Greece to Expel Turkish Consul in Komotini
DOC.TEXT: Greece will expel the Turkish consul in the northeastern town of Komotini, who referred to Greek Moslems as ``fellow countrymen,'' Foreign Minister Antonis Samaras said Friday night. Samaras made the announcement after Turkey refused to recall the consul, Kemal Gur. He did not mention deadline. One of many issues in centuries of enmity between Greece and Turkey is whether the 120,000 Moslems in Greece should be called Greek Moslems or ethnic Turks. Gur has been accused of fanning passions between Christians and Moslems in Thrace, which borders Turkey in northeastern Greece. The foreign minister said Turkey ``insists on describing the Moslem minority in our country as `fellow countrymen, or the equivalent term: citizens of Turkish origin.''' ``This position represents a blatant violation of the Lausanne Treaty, which recognizes only the religious identity of the minority and refers to it as Moslem for this reason,'' Samaras said. Turkey committed ``unacceptable interventions in the domestic affairs of our country,'' he said. ``Consequently, the Greek government is forced to proceed with the expulsion of the Turkish consul general in Komotini.'' The Lausanne Treaty of 1923 calls for an exchange of populations and an end to hostilities between Greece and Turkey, and specifies that Moslems in Greece be called Greek Moslems. The latest trouble began when two prominent Moslems were convicted of distributing election campaign material referring to Moslems as Turkish Moslem, which is illegal. A court in Komotini sentenced Ahmet Sadik, a former member of Parliament, and local politician Ibrahim Sherif to 18 months in prison each. Moslems protesting the sentences clashed with Christians on Tuesday in Komotini. Scores of shops belonging to Moslems were damaged. Other charges are pending against Sadik, including disseminating false information. A prosecutor in Thrace reported to the Supreme Court in Athens that holding Sadik's trial in Komotini, as planned, would cause further protests and could lead to a breakdown of law and order. Legal sources said the court was considering a change of venue.

DOC.HEAD: Man Held in Alleged Computer Extortion
DOC.TEXT: A former World Health Organization consultant accused of sending out computer diskettes that crippled computers in six countries appeared in federal court Friday in an extradition case. Joseph W. Popp, 39, is charged in warrants issued by Scotland Yard in London with blackmail and extortion for distributing the diskettes, which were said to contain information on AIDS. He was arrested Thursday and is being held on a federal fugitive warrant. Popp told U.S. Magistrate Joseph W. Bartunek he was under a psychiatrist's care and must take medication for a mental condition. Bartunek said he would schedule another court hearing after Popp is evaluated by two psychiatrists to see if he is competent to face extradition proceedings. A hearing date wasn't set, and Popp was ordered to remain in the Bedford Heights jail in suburban Cleveland. Popp, of Willowick, about 10 miles east of Cleveland, was arrested Thursday. Popp's attorney, John P. Kilroy, had asked that his client be kept in a hospital rather than jail because of his mental condition. ``He's an internationally respected researcher,'' Kilroy said. ``I don't think he'd pose any risk to flee.'' Kilroy said Popp is an anthropologist and until December had a contract with the Geneva-based World Health Organization, working sometimes in England but mainly in Geneva and Africa. Gary D. Arbeznik, assistant U.S. attorney in Cleveland, said an arrest warrant was issued in London on Jan. 18 contending Popp mailed about 20,000 diskettes from that city about Dec. 11. The U.S. attorney's office in Cleveland said the diskettes had information on acquired immune deficiency syndrome for hospitals, researchers and government agencies. Those who used the program subsequently found they were unable to retrieve data from their computers. At the time the diskettes began causing problems in early December, London authorities said it had been received by users in Britian, Norway, Sweden, Belgium, Denmark and California. Arbeznik said the diskette packages included a warning that if the diskette were inserted into a computer, a leasing fee would be charged. The program instructed the computer user to send a fee of up to $378 to a company called PC CYBORG with a Panama address, federal prosecutors said. Upon payment of the money, the recipient would receive a ``decontamination disk'' that would stop the computer virus, authorities said. ``It appears to me ... a clear warning was given on the package,'' Kilroy said in a telephone interview after Popp's court appearance. ``The facts will show his actions were not criminal in nature.''

DOC.HEAD: Hotel Owner Denies Debt Negotiation Was Gift to Jackson Campaign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 3-4: ``The Jackson,'' with Jackson campaign disputing it violated reporting rules; SUBS grafs 9-10 bgng: ``The campaign,'' for graf 7 pvs: ``Jackson aides,'' with campaign statement
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson's 1988 presidential campaign negotiated a debt settlement with a California hotel owned by a Jackson supporter but failed to report the debt or the agreement as required, according to the supporter and election records. The hotel owner, A. Bruce Rozet, on Friday confirmed a $75,000 Jackson campaign bill at the Hollywood Roosevelt was settled for $45,500 but disputed an account by two former employers who said Rozet _ a Jackson delegate at the 1988 Democratic convention _ forgave the remaining $30,000 as a gift to Jackson. The Jackson campaign said it did not believe it had violated the law. It said it did not report the initial hotel bill as a debt because it disputed the bill and that it did report to the Federal Election Committee the full amount of its ultimate payment. But FEC officials said the disputed bill should have been reported as a contested debt, citing agency regulations requiring prompt reporting of all debts and an agency advisory opinion saying a disputed claim must be reported as a debt until paid or resolved. Rozet said it was a business negotiation, based on the possibility that there had been overbilling and on the fact that the Jackson campaign was good business for the hotel. If a gift, it would be an illegal contribution either by Rozet, who as an individual donor could give no more than $1,000 to a candidate, or by any of his companies. Corporations are prohibited from making political contributions in federal elections. In any event, Federal Election Commission reports filed by the Jackson campaign show only the $45,500 payment to the hotel. Campaign finance laws require candidates to promptly report all debts in excess of $500 and all settlements for less than the initial bill amount. The FEC, which is in the process of auditing the 1988 Jackson campaign, refuses as a general practice to say whether any matter is under investigation. The hotel billing was first publicly disclosed Friday in The Washington Post. ``The campaign reaffirms that, to the best of its knowledge, it has always operated both within the spirit and letter of federal election laws,'' the campaign said in a statement read by Jackson aide Frank Watkins. ``Based on the information available to us, all legitimate campaign bills involving the Hollywood Roosevelt hotel have been paid for in full.'' Jackon himself was traveling and unavailble for comment. He told The Post he was not involved in the negotiations with the hotel but did not believe Rozet or his company had paid campaign expenses. ``Absolutely not,'' Jackson said. ``First off, we didn't need that kind of favor and, second, it would have been illegal.'' Rozet, in a telephone interview Friday, said he had no role in the debt settlement. Asked about comments in The Post account by two unnamed former hotel employers who termed the settlement a ``gift,'' Rozet said: ``That is totally untrue. If we were trying to hide it why did we bill him in the first place?'' Rozet said hotel managers contacted him when initial efforts to collect the bill were unsuccessful. Rozet said he referred the managers back to the Jackson campaign and that one hotel employee was sent to Jackson campaign headquarters to collect the bill. ``My understanding of it was that there was some question as to whether some of the Jackson people, including traveling press and security people, had been billed the top rate when they should have been billed at a group rate,'' Rozet said. ``The fact is that the hotel had its best business when Jackson was there, with higher than normal occupancy. When someone brings in that kind of business, we'll negotiate with them. That's not unusual. We do if for conventions and other major events.'' The Post quoted an unnamed former hotel employee who said he tried to get the campaign to pay the bills but a Jackson aide ``looked at me and said, `Didn't Mr. Rozet talk to you. It's all been taken care of.''' Rozet, a longtime Jackson ally and prominent Democratic fund-raiser, said he has paid for Jackson stays at the hotel in the past, but said all predated the 1988 campaign and were for non-political events, including a 1987 birthday party Rozet threw for Jackson. The general manager of the hotel, Bruno Fava, said Friday of the Jackson campaign, ``They have no billing troubles. ... I'm sorry but I have no comment otherwise.'' As for the failure to report the initial debt or the settlement to the Federal Election Commission, James Hewitt, a Cleveland attorney for the Jackson campaign, conceded the debt should have been reported. ``It should have been listed as debt,'' he told The Post, declining further comment. Hewitt did not immediately return telephone calls Friday.

DOC.HEAD: AARP Opposes Moynihan Proposal to Cut Payroll Tax
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 11-13: ``AARP said,'' to update with Moynihan comment, added detail from AARP statement; DELETES last graf, now outdated.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest senior citizen group on Friday opposed proposals to cut Social Security taxes, saying the system's mounting reserves will be needed to ensure full benefits for future generations. The American Association of Retired Persons had been courted by both fans and foes of Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut the payroll tax that finances Social Security benefits. AARP President Louise Crooks said the association was ``concerned with the potential loss of $55 billion or more in annual revenue if the Social Security payroll tax is rolled back.'' ``The association's first preference remains retaining existing Social Security policy to continue to build the reserves for future generations,'' she said. The policy was adopted by the AARP's six-member executive committee, acting on a recommendation from its 32-member legislative council. Moynihan, a New York Democrat, is concerned that Social Security's growing trust fund reserves are being used to mask the true size of the federal deficit and to pay for other government programs. His solution is to halt the buildup of the reserves and to return Social Security to a pay-as-you-go system in which taxes would be raised in the next century to finance retirement benefits for the Baby Boomers. Mrs. Crooks said that while there are legitimate concerns about how the Social Security trust funds are being used, AARP ``is not prepared to give up on the effort to bring down the federal budget's operating deficit.'' The group was careful to credit Moynihan, widely respected as an advocate for Social Security, for drawing attention to the problem. ``Americans of all ages are indebted to Senator Moynihan for sparking the debate on the federal deficit and the future of Social Security,'' Mrs. Crooks said. ``Senator Moynihan has correctly and dramatically defined the problem.'' AARP said that if the budget accounting problem cannot be resolved ``in a reasonable amount of time, then adoption of pay-as-you-go financing for Social Security will have to be seriously considered.'' Moynihan thanked the AARP for its ``careful consideration'' of his proposal and said the group is in ``complete agreement'' with him that the current budget accounting system is inadequate. ``What we absolutely agree upon is that the trust funds can no longer be used as general revenue,'' Moynihan said. AARP, with 31 million members aged 50 and over, is considered the most powerful organization among advocacy groups for the elderly. Other advocacy groups also have voiced concern about the Moynihan proposal.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Probe of Mail Bombs Continues in Alabama
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4 grafs for 5th graf, `Marshall would ...' to UPDATE with investigation of fake bomb sent to NAACP in Pittsburgh. Picks up 6th graf pvs: `O'Ferrell's attorneys ...
DOC.TEXT: FBI agents will remain in a southeastern Alabama county for the foreseeable future as they investigate the mail bombings that killed a federal judge and a civil rights attorney, a spokesman said Friday. Scores of federal agents have been in Enterprise since Jan. 22. Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, an area salvage store owner, has been questioned several times and has given the FBI hair, blood and saliva samples. He has not been charged. The FBI has collected other evidence in the area, and on Friday continued to search for a typewriter believed to have been used to write a letter from a person or group calling itself Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System, which claimed responsibility for the December bombings. ``I don't think we're at the end of it,'' said Doug Marshall, an FBI spokesman in Mobile. ``I don't see any plans to end it at this point.'' Marshall would not say if investigators are satisfied with the evidence uncovered so far. ``We're not at the point where we can say anything evaluative like that,'' he said Meanwhile, postal inspectors investigating the mailing of a fake bomb to an NAACP branch in Pennsylvania believe it was sent by someone nearby. ``We think it might have been sent locally by some less-than-rocket-scientist-type people,'' Inspector Dick Balya said. ``People who do things like this usually aren't too bright.'' Pittsburgh police on Jan. 19 blew up what appeared to be a mail bomb received by the Washington County branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. O'Ferrell's attorneys have asked the FBI to provide them with a case file of their client. Lawyer Anthony Bishop said Friday the FBI has notified him that the documents have been prepared and that he would meet with O'Ferrell when he gets them. The mail bombs killed U.S. Circuit Judge Robert S. Vance of Birmingham and civil rights attorney Robert Robinson of Savannah, Ga. Bombs were also mailed to the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta and to the NAACP headquarters in Jacksonville, Fla., but did not explode. Vance, who served on the 11th Circuit, was to be remembered Monday with a memorial service in Atlanta that is to include an address by U.S. Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Opens New Era by Legalizing ANC; Will Free Mandela
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to ADD length of speech, dropped word graf 3 `But black,' total population mix of country; picks up 11th, `Activists, white...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CPN3,4,6, PN7
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk legalized the African National Congress on Friday and promised to free Nelson Mandela, a historic concession to the epic struggle for freedom by the nation's black majority. Thousands of blacks thronged the streets of several cities to celebrate the announcements by de Klerk in a 40-minute speech that was widely hailed as courageous. But black activists and several countries said despite the move to legalize the ANC and dozens of other anti-apartheid groups, the white-run government must now follow through. De Klerk did not act to dismantle the foundation of the apartheid system that would give South Africa's 28 million blacks a direct voice in running the country. Activists, white businessmen, liberal politicians and foreign governments praised the courage of de Klerk, who scrapped many other restrictions on opposition activity in a bid to draw the ANC into negotiations on South Africa's future. ``It's incredible. What he said has certainly taken my breath away,'' said Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize for his opposition to apartheid. ``We could say that we are probably seeing history in the making in South Africa.'' President Bush called the move ``quite positive'' and said he will review U.S. sanctions on South Africa. An aide said de Klerk and Mandela will be invited to the White House when the black leader is released. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain described de Klerk's announcement as ``a historic landmark'' and lifted cultural and academic embargoes. The exiled ANC said de Klerk's announcements ``go a long way to creating the climate conducive to negotiations.'' But the Zambia-based organization, which has been fighting a guerrilla war almost 30 years, said more changes were needed before talks could begin. If the two sides begin negotiations, quick breakthroughs appear unlikely. The ANC and all leading anti-apartheid groups demand a one-person, one-vote democracy, which de Klerk opposes, saying it will result in the 28 million blacks dominating the 5 million whites. Another three million people of mixed race and 850,000 Asian and Indians make up the 37 million South Africans. De Klerk, since taking office in August, has said he envisions some type of system in which no single racial group would dominate. Mandela, 71, the country's best-known black leader, would be freed shortly, de Klerk said. But he said ``personal circumstances and safety'' were among the factors delaying the release. ``I want to put it plainly that the government has decided to release Nelson Mandela unconditionally,'' he said. ``Unfortunately, a further short passage of time is unavoidable.'' Tutu agreed with de Klerk's assessment, saying ``there may be people, a lunatic fringe, who would want to subvert the process by liquidating him. I think that we have to accept that there are certain constraints.'' De Klerk said he would lift bans on more than 30 outlawed groups and scrap restrictions on a similar number. He pledged to free most prisoners jailed for belonging to these groups, declared a moratorium on executions, and lifted most of the restrictions imposed during a 43-month-old state of emergency. These were the principal steps demanded by Mandela and the ANC as conditions for negotiations on a new constitution that would end the black majority's exclusion from national politics. ``The season of violence is over. The time for reconstruction and reconciliation has arrived,'' de Klerk said in his speech, greeted with cheers from supporters and silence from the right-wing opposition. De Klerk said his Cabinet unanimously agreed on the decision and the action on legalizing the groups requires no action from Parliament or any other branch of government. Andries Treurnicht, leader of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party, challenged de Klerk to call an immediate election for white voters to see whether they backed his decisions. ``We say he has no mandate for doing the drastic things he intends doing,'' Treurnicht said. At the perimeter of the parliamentary buildings, about 5,000 demonstrators, many chanting ``ANC! ANC!'' joined a march demanding Mandela's release. In Cape Town, Johannesburg and Durban, the three largest cities, thousands of blacks sang and danced in the streets to celebrate the ANC's legalization. Police said marchers threw stones at them in Johannesburg and ordered the crowd to disperse. They then fired tear gas. No arrests or serious injuries were reported. The groups to be legalized, in addition to the ANC, include the smaller Pan Africanist Congress guerrilla movement, the South African Communist Party and the United Democratic Front, a nationwide anti-apartheid coalition. The United Democratic Front, which is aligned with the ANC, welcomed de Klerk's changes but called for sanctions to remain in place. ``To lift sanctions now would be to run the risk of aborting the process to democracy,'' it said in a statement. De Klerk said he was lifting restrictions imposed on 374 activists following their release from detention. He said state-of-emergency detentions would be limited to a maximum of six months and emergency restrictions on the media would be scrapped except for some unspecified controls over photographic and television coverage of unrest. Mandela, 71, has been jailed since 1962 and is serving a life sentence for helping plan the start of the ANC's sabotage and bombing campaign. He has met with de Klerk, other government officials and anti-apartheid leaders over the past several months in talks aimed at clearing the way for negotiations. The ANC was outlawed in 1960 after 48 years of non-violent campaigning for black rights. In 1961, it launched its sabotage campaign. In the past year, the guerrilla campaign has subsided markedly. The ANC's exiled leadership has acknowledged that its military options were limited and that it favored negotiations if de Klerk was willing to allow unrestricted black political activity. ``The allegation has been that the government did not wish to talk to them (the ANC and the Pan Africanist Congress) and that they are deprived of their right to normal political activity,'' de Klerk said. ``The unconditional lifting of the prohibition ... places everybody in a position to pursue politics freely,'' he added. ``The justification for violence, which was always advanced, no longer exists.''

DOC.HEAD: Romania Aks Swiss Help in Finding Ceasescu Wealth
With AM-Romania-Trial
DOC.TEXT: Romania has asked for judicial help in trying to recover wealth allegedly stashed in Swiss banks by deposed and executed Communist leader Nicolae Ceausescu, Swiss authorities said Friday. Justice Ministry spokesman Joerg Kistler said the request from Bucharest cited charges against Ceausescu of genocide and misuse of office as grounds for recovering the funds. Kistler gave no indication of how much was involved. Romanian newspapers have alleged Ceausescu had $400 million in Swiss banks, much of it in gold bullion. The Swiss government slapped a precautionary freeze Dec. 22 on any assets held by Ceausescu or his associates, pending receipt of the official request for legal aid from the interim Romanian government. Kistler said the request will be passed to authorities in states where the funds are purportedly stashed.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted Bulgarian Leader Moved to Hospital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with first television pictures of Zhivkov, details; picks up 4th `The nature'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bulgaria
DOC.TEXT: Todor Zhivkov, dismissed as Communist Party chief and under arrest on corruption charges, has been transferred to a hospital for an unspecified illness, state radio and television reported Friday. Zhivkov, 78, is in investigative custody, accused of malfeasance in office, misappropriation of state property and other crimes. Television showed Zhivkov sitting in a room, his head bowed low, and walking downstairs with the aid of two men in civilian clothes. It then showed a militia car driving away, with Zhivkov apparently inside. The pictures were believed to be the first broadcast of the former leader since he was ousted Nov. 10 after 35 years in power. Friday's radio broadcast said Zhivkov's health condition was so bad he could not remain in prison and was moved to a hospital. The nature of the illness and the date of the transfer were not reported, and the hospital was not identified. Communist Party officials, commenting at the end of an emergency party congress, said Zhivkov had ``certain old age ailments'' and was under constant supervision by physicians. Andrei Lukanov, a senior Communist Party leader, also said ``it is obvious that Zhivkov will stand trial when the investigation (against him) yields categorical evidence of his guilt under the laws of this country.'' Earlier in the week, it was reported that Zhivkov had been moved from house arrest in a villa to a prison. Friday's broadcast said Bulgarian leaders are appealing to Western governments to establish whether Zhivkov or his family ever deposited money in their banks. Zhivkov was toppled on Nov. 10 after 35 years in office. Investigations are also under way against two of Zhivkov's aides, son-in-law Ivan Slavkov and Milko Balev, a Politburo member under Zhivkov.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Sell Largest Failed S&L in Texas
DOC.NOTE: EDs: A longer version is on financial circuits
DOC.HEAD: With AM-S&L Seizure
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators on Friday sold the insolvent Bright Banc Savings Association of Dallas to an Ohio bank holding company in the largest thrift sale since enactment of the S&L bailout law in August. Banc One Corp. of Columbus, Ohio, is receiving $1.1 billion in government assistance to acquire Bright Banc, founded in the early 1980s by H.R. ``Bum'' Bright, once one of the 50 wealthiest men in the country and the former owner of the Dallas Cowboys football team. Banc One is paying $45 million. Bright Banc, with $3.1 billion in assets, is the biggest failed thrift in Texas and the largest yet sold by the Resolution Trust Corp. The deal is one of the first in which the RTC has persuaded the buyer to take a substantial portion of the thrift's loans and other assets. Banc One is getting $1.7 billion of the S&L's assets, including residential mortgages, consumer loans, cash and securities. The RTC is keeping $1.4 billion in assets, mostly sour loans and repossessed real estate. After it sells the assets, it estimates the government's total loss on the institution will be $1.4 billion, including the $1.1 billion paid to the Ohio company. RTC officials had promised a major sale after undergoing a tongue-lashing earlier this week from members of the Senate Banking Committee upset with the slow pace of the administration's S&L cleanup. The agency has taken over more than 350 failed thrifts, disposing of 43 of them. But, in most of the transactions it has simply transferred the failed institutions' deposits to the new owner and retained the assets for later sale. Bank One Texas, a unit of the Ohio holding company, is assuming all $2.6 billion of Bright Banc's deposits in 250,000 accounts. The thrift's 48 offices will remain open during their usual business hours. The acquisition gives Bank One Texas a formidable retail network in Texas. It would add Bright Banc's branches to the 63 it currently operates and create a combined institution with about $14 billion in assets, among the 25 largest banking operations in the nation.

DOC.HEAD: New Bulgarian Party Leader Says Party Must Regain Confidence
With AM-Bulgaria
DOC.TEXT: Alexander Lilov, the new chief of the Bulgarian Communist Party, is a reformer who advocates open and truthful news media and who is reputed to have devised a new more liberal policy for the country's 1.5 million ethnic Turks. Lilov, 56, emerged as the new party leader on Friday after an emergency overnight session of the Communist Party, replacing Petar Mladenov, who remains in the newly separated post of state president. Lilov is a party veteran who was shunted aside under longtime party leader Todor Zhivkov, himself ousted last November. He has said he recognizes the need for the party to be revamped before it faces multiparty elections in May. ``The Bulgarian Communist Party should adopt the tactic of more businesslike work in order to regain confidence and to fulfill the hard tasks which it has to solve,'' Lilov told delegates after his election. Lilov must still convince a growing opposition, and an increasingly skeptical general public, that he is serious about reform and capable of enacting significant changes. At a news conference when he was voted into the ruling Politburo in December, Lilov charged that the legacy of Zhivkov's 35-year regime was a ``degradation of party principles and ethics.'' ``The most important question to ask is why the system breeds dictators and why it tolerates them for so long,'' he said. That news conference gave an indication of Lilov's stand on reforms and his potential as an emerging leader in the party after Zhivkov had kept him from the power center for six years. ``We have no illusions that if socialist society fails to restructure it will not be able to emerge from the crisis,'' Lilov said. He also advocated a more open information policy, including permission for ordinary people to speak up. ``We need to destroy the information monopoly (and) ensure genuine openness of mass media so it could report on developments in an objective way and give ... all Bulgarian nationals a chance to speak,'' Lilov said in December. It was Lilov's reformist views and criticism of the former Communist strongman, now in jail, that led to his dismissal from the Politburo in 1983. After Zhivkov's ouster, Lilov made a spectacular comeback. Informed sources said he was in charge of Bulgaria's new policy on its Turkish minority. Bulgaria recently reversed an assimilation campaign vigorously imposed by Zhivkov. Last month the leadership announced that those who fled to neighboring Turkey were now free to return to home and reclaim their property. About 300,000 ethnic Turks emigrated to Turkey the past two years to escape persecution and harassement in Bulgaria. About 50,000 later returned. ``We are well aware the matter is acute and part of the current crisis,'' Lilov said in December. He was one of the first Communist leaders to publicly advocate the rights of the minorities regardless of their ethnic identity or religious beliefs, based on provisions in international human rights commitments. Born in 1933 in a village in northwestern Bulgaria, Lilov holds a doctorate in Bulgarian language and literature, after philological studies in Sofia and Moscow. After work in the Communist youth union in the late 1940s, Lilov became involved in local party organizations, In 1972, he became a Central Committee member and secretary responsible for art and culture. Lilov was named a Politburo member in 1974, in charge of ideology and culture. But he was dismissed from the ruling body and as a Central Committee secretary in 1983 after he clashed with Zhivkov over the personality cult surrounding the party chief and other issues. Lilov was director of the Institute of Contemporary Social Theories in Sofia from 1985 until his December rehabilitation.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanians Doubt Early U.S. Pullout
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Julio Linares said Friday that U.S. invasion troops should leave when public order is assured, although many Panamanians don't believe that will be by the end of this month. His remarks were the first by a government official here since President Bush said in his State of the Union address Wednesday the troops would be out ``well before the end of February.'' Linares told reporters the troops ``should withdraw when we have the ability to maintain public order.'' Nearly 3,000 remaining U.S. invasion soldiers are expected to go home within the next few weeks, but at least 13,000 will remain as part of the regular soldiers stationed at U.S. Southern Command bases under terms of the 1977 Panama Canal Treaties. The United States invaded Panama on Dec. 20 to overthrow Manuel Antonio Noriega, who faces drugs charges in Miami. Maj. Gen. Marc Cisneros, commander of the the U.S. Army South, the U.S. ground forces in Panama, told a group of Latin American observers Thursday, ``There is no threat of subversion to worry about.'' Others here are not that sure. Schoolteacher Victoria Jimenez said, ``The Americans should stay longer. If they leave, there could be a coup.'' ``We want them to stay until they can train our new police force,'' said a government official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``I think this may be premature.'' Last week Vice President Ricardo Arias Calderon said publicly the U.S. soldiers would leave ``when the country is secure.'' One newspaper Friday greeted the announcement that U.S. troops moved from Delta Alert to Charlie Alert, allowing them to leave bases and visit Panama City, with the headline: ``13,000 soldiers will make their purchases here.'' Original estimates were that invasion forces would remain four to five weeks after overthrowing Noreiga. It was soon evident this was optimistic. The government abolished the old Defense Forces, the only armed authority in Panama, and asked the U.S. Army to act as policeman. The U.S. Army became in effect a police force for the Panamanian government. While U.S. forces guarded prisoners at military bases, the new police force was being trained. ``I don't want them to leave in February or ever,'' said mechanic Adrian Rubio, 42. ``What we should do is lease them some military bases. We need the dollars.'' ``Cisneros said they are going to stay as long as necessary, so I believe him more than I believe Bush,'' added Ana Perez. Another Panamanian government official, also speaking on condition of not being further identified, said even if the invasion forces leave, ``the Americans will still be here at the bases. And they can continue to train the police force.'' ``People are afraid of going out at ngiht because of the criminal elements loose,'' said Mrs. Jimenez. ``The Americans should stay here longer.'' This week two battalions of American infantry were in the Darien jungle near the Colombian border searching for remnants of Noriega's loyalists or criminals. ``We will stay here as long as the Panamanian government feels we are needed,'' Cisneros said in a recent interview. Last Sunday, when Vice Presdient Dan Quayle attended Mass with President Guillermo Endara, parishioners waved signs that read: ``Americans, do not go home.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Lawmakers Welcome South Africa Words, Wait for Action
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf before last graf to include comment from Jackson.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush welcomed as ``quite positive'' South Africa's announcement Friday that Nelson Mandela would be freed and said he would talk with Congress about the possibility of lifting U.S. economic sanctions. Yet Bush indicated any easing would depend on South Africa making good on its promise to free Mandela, the leader of a formerly outlawed guerrilla movement, and taking additional steps. Members of Congress took similar or tougher stances, with some urging Bush to keep U.S. sanctions in place. They noted that South Africa's system of racial apartheid is still intact. ``The sanctions should be maintained in full force. This is no time to relax them,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. ``Apartheid is crumbling as the Berlin Wall crumbled only a few months ago,'' Kennedy said, attributing changes in the South African government's positions to pressure brought by the economic sanctions as well as to persistence of South African blacks. The U.S. sanctions include a ban on importing South African steel, textiles, uranium, coal and agricultural produce. They also bar new U.S. investment in South Africa, forbid new bank loans and end U.S. landing rights for South African Airways. Kennedy and others also said Bush should shelve his offer to invite South African President F.W. de Klerk to the White House once Mandela is freed. ``I urge caution before that step is taken,'' said Sen.
