Paul Simon, D-Ill., chairman of a Senate subcommittee on Africa. ``State visits involving South Africa have been ruled out by past administrations as long as we continue to have fundamental differences with the South African government.'' Kennedy said simply that de Klerk ``still represents one of the most abhorrent systems'' in the world. Bush also has announced he will invite Mandela to the White House after he is freed. In a speech to the South African parliament, de Klerk legalized the African National Congress after three decades of guerrilla war against white rule. He said Mandela, the ANC leader who was imprisoned in 1962, would be freed, but not immediately. In addition, de Klerk said he would lift bans or restrictions on more than 60 other opposition groups, free most prisoners jailed for belonging to these groups, declare a moratorium on executions, and scrap most of the restrictions imposed during more than three years of a state of emergency. Bush commented on the developments on Air Force One en route to appearances in Raleigh, N.C., and Knoxville, Tenn. ``Very interesting and I would say quite positive,'' the president said. ... I view it positively and I think most people around the world will.'' Bush said that de Klerk ``recognizes the status quo is not acceptable to him or to the people in South Africa and to a lot of people in the world who want to see a more just society.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said ``a lot of conditions'' have to be met before Bush would seek the removal of sanctions. ``There's still a lot to be done before that happens.'' Stil, Bush said, ``I think when people move in the right direction, it is certainly time to review all policy.'' ``We want to see the policy initiatives go forward and the release of Mandela,'' he said. But he added, ``I am one who has not favored additional sanctions so I'm perfectly willing to review things as new developments take place,'' he added. Rep. Bill Gray, D-Pa., also welcomed the South African developments but noted that a series of conditions in connection with the sanctions remain unmet: releasing all political prisoners, lifting the state of emergency, legalizing political participation for all parties, repealing laws that regulate where non-whites can live and work, and beginning good-faith negotiations with the black majority. ``All are essential in ending apartheid and restoring justice,'' Gray said. The president can suspend or modify U.S. sanctions if Mandela and other political prisoners are released and Pretoria meets at least three of the other conditions. Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., former chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, called de Klerk's actions a ``bold stroke for freedom,'' and added: ``The trend in events is South Africa has been a strong one toward negotiation.'' Lugar said the U.S. sanctions bill gives the president flexibility to remove some sanctions if South Africa meets certain conditions. But Lugar said Bush has promised to consult with Congress before he takes any action. In Washington, the Rev. Jesse Jackson said ``we must balance hope with caution. Caution because the structure of apartheid is still in place and Nelson Mandela is still in jail.'' While de Klerk's announcement is a historic change in government policy, it makes no immediate change in the system of apartheid that establishes a racially segregated society in which the 28 million blacks have no vote in national affairs. The 5 million whites continue to control the economy and maintain separate districts, schools and health services.

DOC.HEAD: Concern in Israel over Reported Soviet Anti-Semitic Incidents
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs with further Arab League comment.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Jews and immigration activists expressed alarm Friday over possible anti-Jewish violence in the Soviet Union and urged Israel to act quickly before it's too late. ``We don't sleep, we live in fear. ... Emigration invitations from Israel are our only hope,'' Polina Mendelevitch, an attorney from Leningrad, said on Israel radio in a telephone interview Thursday night. Immigration officials say close to 1 million Soviet Jews have received such invitations, needed to start emigration procedures. Israel expects up to 100,000 immigrants to arrive in the next 12 months. Last year, 12,000 Soviet Jews came here, more than five times the 1988 number. Soviet Jews complained of anti-Semitic incidents and demonstrations. In mid-January, nationalist activists broke into a Moscow gathering of writers, shouting anti-Semitic slogans and causing a scuffle, a Soviet Television report monitored in Israel said. ``The city prosecutor appeared on the TV, saying they needed to look into the incident,'' Ms. Mendelevitch said. ``But these thugs were not punished, they found no criminal element in their actions.'' Later, a frightened Jewish author called friends in Israel, asking for an emigration invitation to be sent to him as soon as possible. On Jan. 27, Soviet TV broadcast a report that said members of the Russian nationalist group Pamyat, or Memory, at a recent rally in Moscow openly called for a Jewish pogrom on May 5. Another TV report monitored in Israel this week said city officials in Odessa, a Black Sea port with a significant Jewish population, met in emergency session to discuss rising nationalism there. Pamyat leaders in Leningrad reportedly collect Jewish addresses as a membership requirement, Soviet Jewish immigrants say. Israel radio on Friday quoted Mavrik Wolfson of Riga, a Jewish member of the Supreme Soviet, as demanding a Soviet government response to reports that Russian nationalist groups plan to carry out a Jewish pogrom, and steps to protect the Jews. Yuri Stern, a Soviet immigration activist who acts as an adviser to the Israeli Parliament's Immigration and Absorption Committee, on Friday warned that ``the situation in the Soviet Union is such that the fact we still have not witnessed large-scale pogroms is simply a miracle.'' ``We have to do the maximum to allow for the exodus of Soviet Jews, to use all the available transportation means, to speed up all the processes that largely depend on us ... Who knows how much time we have?'' Immigration activists asked the government to speed up the process of issuing invitations and explore possible routes for immigrants. They say as many as 50,000 to 100,000 Soviet Jews who have received exit visas cannot leave because of ticket shortages. Soviet immigrants now arrive through Hungary and Romania, but airplane tickets are in short supply, reports from the Soviet Union say. The Soviets are reluctant to approve their direct flights agreement with Israel. They are faced with strong Arab and Palestinian protests over the influx of immigrants to Israel and remarks by the Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel suggesting the immigrants would be settled in the occupied lands. Last week, the Kremlin registered an official protest with the Jewish state. Israel said in response it has no policy of directing immigrants to the occupied territories. At U.N. Headquarters in New York on Friday, the Soviet Union and the League of Arab States expressed concern over the likely settlement of immigrating Soviet Jews in the occupied lands, calling it a threat to Middle East peace. ``We are firmly against the use, at risk to their safety, of persons leaving the U.S.S.R. to force Palestinians off land that belongs to them,'' said Moscow's acting U.N. Ambassador Valentin V. Lozinskiy in a letter to the secretary-general. ``The Israeli leadership must realize the dangrous consequences of such action on its part.'' The 22-nation Arab League expressed concern at an urgent meeting Friday that Soviet-Jewish immigration to Israel will spill over to augment the ``illegal'' settlements in the occupied territories. In Tunis, Tunisia, Arab League Secretary General Chedli Klibi said a ``historic catastrophe'' could result if the Soviet Union allows large numbers of Jews to emigrate to Israel, League sources said without elaborating. In two hours of talks Friday with Soviet Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Gennadi Tarassov, Klibi insisted that the Soviet Union reverse its Jewish emigration policy.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect in Bank Bombing, 20 Robberies Led Double Life
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7-8, `But Mrs. Jones...Hunt said,' with 3 grafs to ADD detail of wife's description of Jones' behavior. Pick up 9th graf pvs: `About an...
DOC.TEXT: A mild-mannered ex-minister suspected of bombing a bank and carrying out 20 other bank robberies and burglaries in the past year led a double life, according to relatives and the FBI. ``He was loved by everybody in the community,'' said Sherry Jones after her husband, Edward, was arrested in the case. ``I mean, there's not a person, including myself, who would have ever dreamed he'd be capable of this.'' Jones, 50, was arrested Monday and charged with the botched attempt to blow open a safe at American Industrial Bank of Cherry Creek on Jan. 10. A homemade pipe bomb used in the attempt singed the carpet and blew a few holes in the ceiling. He also is suspected in as many as 20 more robberies and burglaries in Colorado, said Bob Pence, head of the Denver FBI office. An ordained minister who graduated from the Conservative Baptist Theological Seminary in Denver, Jones hadn't preached for several years. Jones most recently worked for a furniture manufacturer, American Seating Inc. of Wheat Ridge. Neighbors described him as an avid tennis player who frequently worked out at a health club. But Mrs. Jones said her husband began showing signs of trouble a few weeks ago. On Jan. 23, she called Lakewood police because she was concerned about her husband's emotional stability, said police spokesman John Hunt. Jones was taken to a hospital for psychiatric evaluation. On Jan. 23, the family's doctor called Lakewood police and suggested Ed Jones be given a psychiatric evaluation, said police spokesman John Hunt. At that time, Mrs. Jones told officers she was worried about her husband's emotional state, Hunt said. She said he had ``changed dramatically,'' becoming ``more secretive'' and more stressful about credit and financial pressures, for example, police records show. Jones agreed to be taken to a hospital for psychiatric evaluation, Hunt said, and an hour later his wife called police again to alert them to ``some things that might be of interest to you and also might show that he's having some problems with coping,'' Hunt said. About an hour later, his wife called police again to alert them to ``some things that might be of interest to you and also might show that he's having some problems with coping,'' Hunt said. Wigs, fake mustaches, masks, a handgun, various tools, nylons, a trench coat, assorted keys and a stolen federal government license plate were in the trunk of the couple's car. The items were turned over to the FBI, Hunt said. Two of the keys found were from the American Industrial Bank, FBI documents show. Also in the trunk was an apparent sketch of a bomb and a safe, FBI documents show, as well as an apparent checklist referring to appearance, alarms, tools and a safe. FBI agents also searched a condominium Jones used two miles west of his home and uncovered a cache of masks, fake beards, weapons and materials used to make pipe bombs, Pence said. Jones was held without bond at the Federal Detention Center in southern Jefferson County. Pence said Jones' family was unaware of his alleged criminal activities or of the condominium he maintained. Mrs. Jones, who works at a downtown Denver bank, said her husband gave every appearence of being a mellow, polite, respectful and law-abiding citizen. ``He had a double life,'' she said. ``We had no financial problems. He just was doing so many things on the side. ... He was a very sick man. What he did just doesn't make a lot of sense.'' She said her husband participated in school events for their two teen-age children. Neighbors, too, were stunned by the arrest. ``That would be the last guy in the world that I would ever think of doing something like that,'' said one neighbor who declined to be identified.

DOC.HEAD: West German Foreign Minister Gets Preview On Moscow Trip
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Baker and Genscher statements; picks up 6th graf pvs, bgng: Modrow's plan...
DOC.TEXT: West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said Friday he and Secretary of State James A. Baker agreed that unification of Germany would not mean extending NATO's military area eastward. Dramatizing the rush of developments on the issue of unifying East and West Germany, Genscher crossed the Atlantic Friday for consultations with Baker before the secretary's meetings next week with Soviet leaders in Moscow. He was returning during the night to Bonn. ``We were in full agreement that there is no intention to extend the NATO area of defensive security toward the East,'' Genscher said after their 2{-hour meeting at the State Department. ``That holds true for not only the (East) German Democratic Republic, which we have no intention of simply incorporating, but also for the other Eastern countries,'' he added to reporters in the State Department lobby as Baker stood beside him. Genscher's blitz visit, arranged earlier this week, followed close on the heels of a surprise call by East German Prime Minister Hans Modrow for a single, militarily neutral German state. Baker indirectly rejected the idea of neutrality for a future united Germany by telling reporters that ``I'm frankly encouraged'' by what Genscher has said about continued German membership in NATO. The German minister's statement about not extending the alliance eastward appeared to mean that such membership would cover only the Western part of a unified Germany. Baker also said ``we agreed we need to develop a process and a framework for (unification) ... taking into consideration the interests of all who are involved in the issue.'' The two ministers also said the 35-nation summit proposed for late 1990 by Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev should include not only formal signing of an agreement on reduction of ground forces in Europe but also add free elections to the basic human rights enumerated at the original 35-nation Helsinki summit in 1975 on security and cooperation in Europe. Baker said he and Genscher agreed ``that any such summit should involve the inclusion of the right of free elections as an additional human right in the human rights basket of CSCE.'' German unity appeared to be a major issue Baker will take up with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze during their talks in Moscow next Thursday and Friday. He also will see Gorbachev, who on Wednesday softened long-standing Soviet opposition to German reunification. Genscher, meanwhile, is consulting with British and French officials as well as Baker. Modrow's plan is for a neutral single German state that would belong neither to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization nor to the Warsaw Pact. Genscher has proposed that Germany would be a NATO member but that the portion that is now East Germany would be a neutral military zone. Genscher has joined West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl in rejecting neutrality for a future German state. ``The meeting with Baker was not scheduled because of the latest developments in East Germany,'' a U.S. official said. ``The idea was to meet with Baker before his talks in Moscow.'' And yet, the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the session was ``in context with fast-moving events.'' Genscher suggested the meeting last week. A West German embassy official said, meanwhile, that Genscher wanted ``to coordinate various positions'' with Baker before his trip to Moscow. Baker leaves Monday night, stopping first in Prague, Czechoslovakia. The embassy official, who barred use of his name, said Genscher also wanted to discuss with Baker the latest U.S. proposal to reduce U.S. and Soviet troops in Europe to 225,000 each, with a limit of 195,000 in Central Europe _ meaning West and East Germany and Czechoslovakia.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Seeks Quick Congressional Action on Science, Technology Plan
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 10th graf: ``Bush announced,'' to note no names available
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, pointing to concerns the United States is in danger of being dethroned as the ``world champion'' of science and technology, urged Congress on Friday to swiftly approve his plan to boost spending on research and development. Bush went on the road to tout his plans to spend $71 billion on science and technology in fiscal 1991, and to respond to criticism that his education budget _ a proposed 2 percent increase over 1990 _ is insufficient to improve performance in the nation's schools. The $71 billion is $4.5 billion more than the money enacted for 1990, according to White House figures. During his visit to two universities in Tennessee and North Carolina, the president toured a semiconductor lab he termed ``awesome,'' and stood in a pitch-dark room for several minutes attempting to see an experiment involving microorganisms that control chemical pollution in contaminated water and soil. ``In science and technology, the United States is today the undisputed heavyweight champion of the world,'' he told an audience at the University of Tennessee. ``Yet some wonder if America has lost its competitive edge and ask if we must now look overseas for the answer,'' Bush said. ``The United States is the defending world champion, but we have to defend our title day by day, week by week, year-in and year-out,'' the president said. Bush urged Congress to approve his budget proposals in science, including doubling spending for the National Science Foundation by 1993. ``Building America's competitive strength today also means that we need quick congressional action on our other proposals for investing in new capital _ intellectual capital,'' he said. In answer to questions from students about federal funding for education, however, Bush stressed that in terms of spending ``I still believe a lot of the emphasis has to be at the local and state level.'' Bush announced Friday he was creating a 15-member committee, headed by White House science adviser Allan Bromley and including 14 private-sector members, to advise him on ``all areas of science and technology.'' No names of members were released. The White House also announced Bush on Monday will address the opening session of a United Nations group that is working on the global warming issue. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change will meet at Georgetown University in Washington. Bush has been criticized for not taking a leadership role on global warming. The announcement Friday came after more than 700 scientists, representing more than a third of all members of the National Academy of Sciences, accused him of being complacent about the global warming threat. Before arriving in Knoxville, Bush toured a North Carolina State University lab that studies semiconductor surfaces. ``All this brainwork out here, it's a little awesome,'' the president said. Bush participated in a discussion with a handful of technology company executives about their efforts to work with educational institutions on research projects. Several stressed the need to put more emphasis on science and math education before students reach college. ``We simply can't wait for the schools to improve. Business must take an active role,'' said Richard Daugherty of International Business Machines Corp., who said IBM spends $900 million a year to educate its own employees. ``We need emphasis on math and science.'' ``The improvement of education is fundamental to competitiveness,'' Daugherty said. Bush has come under attack for proposing an increase of only 2 percent _ $500 million _ in the education budget for 1991 even as he announced national education goals of improved math and science achievement, literacy and drug-free schools. Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos, accompanying Bush on Friday, reiterated his argument that the proposed $24.6 billion budget for fiscal 1991 ``is the largest budget we've ever had.'' Bush proposes a 69 percent increase, to $230 million, in the Dwight D. Eisenhower Mathematics and Science Program. The money goes to states for improved math and science teaching programs. Bush also took Energy Secretary James Watkins on the trip Friday. He said the president's Domestic Policy Council of advisers soon will give the president ``an entirely new intitiative'' dealing with interaction between students and facilties such as the federal Oak Ridge National Laboratory near Knoxville. At the University of Tennessee, environmental technology professors showed Bush a machine to develop microorganisms that can be used in environmental cleanup. University President Lamar Alexander told Bush the school will establish a Summer School of the South for Science and Mathematics to help meet the president's goal of making U.S. students No. 1 in science by the year 2000. The state, Martin Marietta Corp. and the Department of Energy each will contribute $1 million to the Academy for Teachers of Science and Mathematics, which provide instruction for high school science and math teachers, Alexander said.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Argues Against Second Trial of Principal
DOC.TEXT: An effort to retry a high school principal in the slayings of a teacher and her two children should be rejected because misconduct by the prosecutor, the principal's lawyer argued Thursday. The principal, Jay C. Smith, was convicted in the 1979 killings _ subject of a book and TV miniseries called ``Echoes in the Darkness'' _ but the verdict was overturned in December by the state Supreme Court. Defense attorney William Costopoulos argued in court papers that a second trial would violate Smith's constitutional protection against double jeopardy, or being tried twice on the same charges. In a 105-page motion filed in Dauphin County Court, Costopoulos also argued the state was guilty of misconduct, alleging the prosecutor withheld evidence from the defense. He also accused the prosecution of using hearsay testimony that was false and using a witness who committed perjury and then improperly freed from prison for his cooperation. Robert Gentzel, a spokesman for Attorney General Ernie Preate Jr., said state lawyers believe ``the motion is without merit and we will vigorously oppose it.'' Smith was convicted in 1986 of murdering Susan Reinert and her children, Karen, 11, and Michael, 10. He was sentenced to die in the electric chair. In ordering a new trial, the state Supreme Court said Dauphin County Judge William Lipsitt erred by allowing the jury to consider hearsay testimony. Costopoulos had raised the prosecutorial misconduct allegations on appeal, but the justices didn't consider that part of the argument once it determined the hearsay evidence was improper. Much of the motion focuses on two grains of sand that were apparently found on Mrs. Reinert's feet. The material, attached to adhesive strips used to gather evidence, was found by a state policeman in an evidence drawer during the last week of the trial, but Costopoulos didn't learn of their existence until nearly two years later. Smith contended the sand would have bolstered his defense that Reinert was killed by another teacher, William Bradfield, at the New Jersey shore. The attorney general contended that the material may have been planted by the defense and wouldn't have made any difference in the jury's verdict. Mrs. Reinert's nude and bruised body was found in the hatchback of her car in the parking lot of a suburban Harrisburg hotel. The children's bodies never were found.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Distribution of Body Fat Linked to Breast Cancer Risk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with results of study on enzyme that may help predict breast cancer relapses. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `The study reported...
DOC.TEXT: Women who carry their weight around the middle are more at risk for developing breast cancer than those who bulge at the hips and thighs, according to a study published Thursday. In a separate study, researchers said they have identified an enzyme that may help them predict which breast cancer patients will likely have a relapse of the disease. The so-called ``apple'' vs. ``pear'' study concerning fat and breast cancer was conducted by David Schapira, an associate professor who heads cancer prevention at H. Lee Moffitt Cancer Center & Research Institute at the University of South Florida. ``It's not how much weight you have on your body, but where you have it,'' said Schapira, whose findings were published in The Annals of Internal Medicine. The Florida study showed women with fat over the stomach and abdominal area are at six times the risk of developing breast cancer than those with fat deposits lower on the body. Schapira called women with upper body fat patterns ``apples'' and women with traditional lower body fat ``pears.'' The team studied 216 breast cancer patients diagnosed between August 1987 and June 1988 and 432 healthy women. They ranged in age from 25 to 83. Breast cancer patients had significantly greater deposits of upper body fat in several key body sites, plus greater waist-to-hip and abdomen-to-thigh comparison ratios, researchers found. The Moffitt team thinks upper body fat leads to breast cancer because it disturbs the hormonal system. Breast cancer has been linked to obesity in previous studies, cancer experts said, but this study also looked at normal-weight woman with breast cancer. The second study, published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine, said the presence of an enzyme called cathepsin D could help doctors determine which women should receive chemotherapy or radiation treatment after breast cancer surgery. The enzyme appears to play a part in the rapid production of cancer cells, according to the study. Doctors at the University of Texas Health Science Center in San Antonio found that breast cancer patients with higher levels of the enzyme had 2.6 times the chance of a relapse and 3.9 times the possibility of dying in five years compared with those who had low levels of the enzyme. The detection of the enzyme may help doctors shape treatment for breast cancer victims who don't show signs of the disease having spread _ a condition called node-negative disease. Only about 30 percent of node-negative patients experience a recurrence. but until now doctors have been unable to figure out which patients were likely to be among those stricken a second time. By measuring levels of the enzyme, doctors may be able to target therapy to women who could benefit the most. The National Cancer Institute now recommends that all node-negative women receive chemotherapy, which is both costly and painful. The apple vs. pear health disparity was in the news in another context last week, when researchers in St. Louis reported a link between cholesterol levels and the distribution of body fat. The study reported in last week's New England Journal of Medicine showed people with fat waists have lower levels of HDL cholesterol, the ``good cholesterol,'' believed to protect against heart disease. That study could help explain why women have lower rates of heart disease than men, researchers said.

DOC.HEAD: Hunt for Escaped Guerrillas Continues, 100 Suspects Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Police raided slums around Santiago on Thursday and detained more than 100 suspects for questioning, but caught none of the 43 leftist guerrillas who escaped from a prison in the capital two days earlier. The escapees, many of them involved in a 1986 attempt to kill military President Augusto Pinochet, contacted local reporters to give details on their escape through a 300-foot-long tunnel that took more than a year to dig. They said the escapees succeeded in spreading throughout this city of 4.5 million people early Tuesday and hiding ``out of reach of security agents.'' The lame-duck military regime appointed an army general, Joaquin Valenzuela, to head Chile's prisons system. He replaces Horacio Ojeda, who resigned Wednesday following the mass escape. Most of the jailbreakers belonged to the Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front, a pro-Communist urban guerrilla gang that claimed responsibility for the Sept. 7, 1986, attempt to kill Pinochet. Pinochet, president and army commander, escaped unharmed, but six of his bodyguards were killed. The elected government of Patricio Aylwin takes over next month.

DOC.HEAD: Staffer Blasts Ombudsman's Recommendation for U.S. Military Paper
DOC.TEXT: A civilian editor at the Pacific Stars and Stripes says a recommendation to name a civilian as chief editor and make it easier to hire and fire would not end problems at the U.S. military paper. Dewey Brackett, who in congressional testimony has criticized conditions at the government-run paper, said proposals by ombudsman Philip M. Foisie could even ``weaken the newspaper's integrity and its independence.'' Foisie, a former foreign editor at the Washington Post and executive editor of the International Herald Tribune, was named ombudsman for the two Stars and Stripes newspapers last June, raising hopes of civilian staffers like Brackett who complain of censorship and other problems. The European Stars and Stripes, published in West Germany, is edited separately from the Tokyo-based Pacific paper. Last weekend, the Stars and Stripes published a report on Foisie's interim recommendations on the editorship of the papers. The ombudsman said he was issuing the proposals before his overall report on the Pacific paper because the Pentagon had announced that a U.S. Marine colonel would succeed the U.S. Air Force colonel now carrying the title editor in chief of the paper. Foisie recommends that a military officer continue to command the paper's mix of military and civilian staff members, but with the title of publisher. He said a civilian ``who has devoted his career to quality daily print journalism'' should be in charge of what appears in the newspaper. He also recommends new personnel policies, including ``the ability to dismiss editorial personnel expeditiously for what (the publisher and editor) regard as valid professional cause and to hire the best available journalists.'' Brackett said that would give less protection than civilian journalists have now. Col. Edwin J. Montgomery, who retires this spring after four years as editor in chief, said Thursday the ombudsman's proposal ``looks workable to me. I think it's important to get the right person in the job'' of editor. The Pentagon is expected to consider the ombudsman's recommendations as well as congressional views. Meanwhile, Brackett and the paper's Okinawa bureau chief, Kate Pound, said a new directive from U.S. Pacific military headquarters in Hawaii could restrict reporters' freedom. The directive makes Stars and Stripes reporters subject to decisions by base commanders to restrict off-base travel by U.S. government employees. Ms. Pound said in a telephone interview that the rule could block Stars and Stripes reporters from reporting on anti-base demonstrations or attacks on U.S. troops in the Philippines, Japan, South Korea or Micronesia. The paper's reporters have no special access on military bases, she said, ``and now they're saying that since we are government employees, they can limit us off-base, too.'' ``If they get tough, all we're going to be able to cover is the opening of the officers' wives club gift shop.'' Montgomery said U.S. commanders are responsible for the safety of U.S. government personnel. But, he added, ``If we need to have those policies relaxed for the purposes of gathering news, then we can request they be relaxed.''

DOC.HEAD: Source: Longshoremen Union Officials to Plead Guilty
DOC.TEXT: An unspecified number of local longshore officials are to plead guilty in federal court as early as Friday as part of an investigation into mob influence in the union, a source said Thursday. A highly placed member of the union who spoke only on condition of anonymity said that a number of officials from local unions of the International Longshoremen's Association were to plead guilty in a U.S. District Court Friday. Ann Driscoll, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Attorney in Brooklyn, confirmed that some union officials from the ILA were to plead in U.S. District Court Friday. She said she did not immediately have information about who they are or what the charges were. The ILA is the target of several investigations in the New York area. On Wednesday, a U.S. Justice Department source said that federal prosecutors were poised to file a lawsuit next week seeking to place several ILA locals under court trusteeship. The department was to allege that the locals had been under the influence of organized crime. The New York and Newark, N.J., locals of the ILA are considered among the most influenced by organized crime, said one government labor racketeering investigator. The lawsuit would be similar to the action settled last year against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, in which the government sought to control the Teamsters union by placing it in trusteeship.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Set Son On Fire Says He'll Honor Son's Wishes and Stay Away
DOC.TEXT: A man who was paroled after setting his son on fire seven years ago said through a spokesman Thursday he will honor the boy's wishes that he stay away. Charles Rothenberg was paroled from a 13-year prison sentence in California on Jan. 24. After his release, he said he wanted to be reunited with his son, David, who was six at the time his father set fire to his bed. However, the badly disfigured boy, now 13, said at a news conference last week he wished his father could be jailed for life, and would never forgive him. Rothenberg said he saw his son on television and plans to ``respect David's wishes,'' said Harry J. Gaynor, president of the National Burn Victim Foundation, a burn victims' advocacy group in Orange. Two days after Rothenberg's release from prison, Gaynor announced plans to publish Rothenberg's autobiography and letters. He said the writings could provide insight into the mind of abusive parents.

Attorney General Dick Thornburgh wants an independent counsel to determine if former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. and his aides broke the law by steering federal rent subsidies to politically connected developers. Thornburgh, stressing that the special prosecutor law left him no other choice, said an independent counsel is needed to determine if Pierce and other former housing officials ``may have violated federal criminal law'' in the way they chose developers to participate in the moderate rehabilitation program between 1984 and 1988. The Department of Housing and Urban Development program provides rent subsidies and lucrative tax to developers who perform a moderate amount of rehabilitation on low-income housing units. Thornburgh's formal application to a special court cited reports of a ``widespread perception among developers'' and local officials that ``funds were being disbursed in disproportionate amounts to projects backed by prominent Republicans acting as consultants or by former HUD officials.''

A man with severe Parkinson's disease showed marked improvement after receiving a transplant of brain tissue from an aborted fetus into his own brain, European researchers report. The transplanted fetal brain tissue apparently thrived and is producing dopamine, a brain chemical that is essential for normal controlled muscle movements, the researchers reported in a study published in Science magazine today. Olle Lindvall of the University Hospital in Lund, Sweden, chief author of the report, told The Washington Post that the study, involving a single patient, ``is very exciting and promising news.'' But he cautioned that the study ``does not prove that we can get this effect in other patients or sustain it in this one.'' Parkinson's disease occurs when areas of the brain degenerate and stop producing dopamine, a neurotransmitter essential for carrying signals from one part of the brain to another. By transplanting fetal brain tissue into the affected area, researchers hope to restore the production of dopamine.

Olive oil, a food already anointed with cholesterol-lowering charisma in a health-conscious age, appears to also lower blood pressure and blood sugar, say doctors who studied almost 5,000 Italians. By contrast, consumption of butter and other saturated fats was found to be associated with higher blood cholesterol, blood pressure and blood sugar, the doctors reported in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. ``The message is not new, in a sense,'' said the lead researcher, Dr. Marizio Trevisan, associate professor in medicine at the State University of New York at Buffalo. Doctors have been telling people that a diet low in saturated fats will help lower the risk of developing heart disease, he noted.

A new report says the number of Americans becoming infected annually with the virus that causes AIDS is declining, although the number of new AIDS cases will continue rising until 1995. The report's author, Peter Plumley, a consulting actuary in Chicago, also says the chances that a heterosexual not using drugs intravenously will become infected are remote and that AIDS prevention efforts focus too much on this group. Plumley writes in the January-February issue of Contingencies magazine that the number of new annual infections with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, peaked in 1986 and is going down. However, he says the total number of HIV-infected Americans will continue to rise until 1991, when 1.4 million will be infected.

DOC.HEAD: A British Perspective on Hollywood Redbaiting
DOC.TEXT: For all its tragic drama and cruel farce, Hollywood's anti-communist blacklisting has rarely been transformed into moneymaking cinema, and that makes ``Fellow Traveller'' the surprise of the British movie season. This low-budget movie about American victims of American redbaiting is British-made and set largely in Britain. ``The American film industry has always been a world film industry. American culture is my culture as well,'' explains Michael Eaton, the English screenwriter. ``Fellow Traveller,'' he says, ``organically involves both our countries.'' The film's budget of under $3 million was shared by Home Box Office and the British Broadcasting Corporation, with some assistance from the British Film Institute. It opened Jan. 5 at London's tiny Metro Cinema, where it broke the house record with an opening week gross of $20,000. It will be seen in the United States March 3 on the HBO cable channel. ``Fellow Traveller'' exemplifies the trend toward Anglo-American cross-fertilization in the movie and television industries, and ``for once the balance of forces works perfectly,'' wrote critic Adam Mars-Jones in The Independent. Mars-Jones praised ``a screenplay full of sharpness and unpredictability,'' while The Observer's Philip French called it ``one of the most politically sophisticated, visually imaginative British pictures of the past decade.'' The Hollywood blacklists resulted from the investigations of the House Committee on Un-American Activities into alleged communist infiltration of Hollywood in the years after World War II. Hollywood people blacklisted as communists or ``fellow travellers'' _ sympathizers _ were forced out of the movie business, or given no alternative but to name others with communist leanings. Many careers in acting, screenwriting and directing were destroyed. A few victims committed suicide, others worked under pseudonyms or fled to Britain. The legacy of those times still haunts the industry. In December, the Lorimar Studios changed the name of its Robert Taylor Building after tenants complained in a petition that the late actor testified before Congress against the so-called Hollywood 10, writers alleged to have associated with communist organizations during the 1930s, '40s or '50s. Taylor also was considered a supporter of the blacklist that kept those writers from working under their own names. In ``Fellow Traveller,'' Asa Kaufman, an American screenwriter, moves to London to escape the witch hunt and earns a living writing screenplays for a Robin Hood TV series. Meanwhile, back in Hollywood, redbaiting has driven actor Clifford Byrne, Kaufman's best friend, to suicide. Woven into the story is the role of Dr. Leavy, a Hollywood psychotherapist and communist sympathizer whose motivation is critical to the film's denouement. Kaufman is played by Ron Silver, Byrne by Hart Bochner and Leavy by Daniel J. Travanti. Kaufman's Robin Hood screenplays become the ironic counterpoint to his predicament, while flashbacks cleverly juxtapose the glamour and sunshine of Hollywood with rainy Britain, its postwar austerity and the early days of its commercial television. The film is loosely based on true incidents. Eaton used Victor A. Navasky's book, ``Naming Names,'' for background. Kaufman's story somewhat parallels that of Ring Lardner Jr., who wrote over 40 episodes of ``Robin Hood'' for Britain's Independent Television network between 1954 and 1960. The Byrne character is reminiscent of John Garfield, who died at 39 of a heart attack some thought may have been brought on by pressure from the blacklisters. The Hollywood witch hunts are an episode rarely tackled head-on by American moviemakers. Only in 1976 did a major movie on the subject emerge _ Martin Ritt's ``The Front,'' starring Zero Mostel and Woody Allen. In 1986 came Peter Yates's ``The House on Carroll Street,'' with Kelly McGillis. Both films were written by blacklist victim Walter Bernstein. ``Most of what you find tend to be allegories of giant ants invading Los Angeles,'' said Eaton, pulpy science fiction movies which only in retrospect came to be seen as veiled treatments of anti-communist hysteria. ``Other films dealt with the situation and problem in America from an American point of view,'' said the movie's British director, Philip Saville. ``Fellow Traveller'' is about a man who runs away from his country rather than face his predicament and drop his friends, said Saville, who studied at Columbia University in New York in 1955-56. Saville and Eaton are teaming up for a second film, set against the background of contemporary Hollywood moviemaking.

DOC.HEAD: In Touristy East Berlin, Karl Marx Gets His Beard Pulled
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: On East Berlin's austere Marx-Engels-Forum, tourists climbed the bronze statue of the founders of communism one recent weekend and snapped funky pictures for showing back home. As the camera clicked, they pulled at Karl Marx's beard, kissed his cheek, sat on his shoulder and draped themselves over his knees. Not long ago they could have landed in jail for that. But tourists have been pouring into East Berlin since the wall came tumbling down and decorum isn't being forced upon them. At the Brandenburg Gate, excited Japanese tourists hoisted one another onto the Berlin Wall, while one of their number recorded it on video tape. East Berlin has tapped a new treasure trove in tourism, courtesy of geopolitics. ``We are here to look around and to be part of history,'' said Peter Bailey of Marlow, England, as he was moved through customs at East Berlin's Friedrichstrasse train station. ``After we saw what happened on television, we decided to come and see for ourselves.'' In Western Europe, travel industry officials say, bookings for Bulgaria, Romania and Czechoslovakia have more than doubled in some cases since the revolutions there. But Berlin _ East and West _ is special. Here, Western luxury and Eastern communism are within walking distance of each other. West Berlin benefits as well. ``It is a unique situation in the world,'' said West Berlin's tourism spokesman, Michael Brodersen, and because of it, West Berlin's tourism industry is thriving. Nothing is laid-back nowadays at the Hotel California on West Berlin's fancy Kurfuerstendamm. Now travelers must book three weeks in advance to get a room when in the past at this time of year the hotel was usually more than half empty. ``For the first time, Christmas and New Year were fully booked and we have a lot more bookings until the summer than other years,'' Brodersen said of hotels in West Berlin, which had 2.1 million visitors last year. The biggest increase came from American tourists, Brodersen said, most of whom flock to the crumbling Berlin Wall. ``I just came over to get a little chunk of wall,'' said Francis Scott, a retired engineer from Orlando, Fla., who first came here with the 82nd Airborne Division in 1945 as part of the American occupation force. He was with the 24th Infantry Division in Munich when the Berlin Wall went up Aug. 13, 1961. Was chiseling away at the stubborn concrete special to Scott? ``Emotional? Absolutely! It is emotional for the whole damn world,'' he said. Tom Erlbeck of Omaha, Neb., hurt his hands getting a piece of the wall. ``All my relatives are from Germany, so it means a bit more to me,'' said the third generation American. ``I'm getting a piece of history for family and friends.'' Nearby, local people were selling pieces of the wall. ``Americans come with big bags and take what they can get,'' said one seller, identifying himself only as Carl. His pieces sell for up to $17.60 each. But for some paying for a piece of the wall is not the real thing. ``Buy? Never! It's like prostitution,'' Scott, the former GI said. ``It has no significance whatsoever.'' Other tourists in the area didn't think having a piece of concrete bore any special no significance. ``It is an absolute absurdity to chop away at a wall,'' said Anton Van Nieuwpoort, a Dutch tourist. ``I came to see and experience a society which developed differently than ours.'' At the Hotel California, an employe also took a dim view of the wall chiselers. ``They should have done that 10 years ago when it would have meant something,'' he said. ``Now, they just want to have fun.'' In East Berlin, history can get more palpable than the wall itself. Tou rists had a front-row seat at one recent pro-democracy protest near the Alexanderplatz. And, on the square itself, some got swept up in a tide of East Berliners rushing toward a stand selling bananas. Bananas are still a rarity in East Germany. That picture of East Berlin contrasts sharply with Unter den Linden, the city's fancy main thoroughfare and key tourist attraction with its bevy of 18th-and 19th-century wedding cake buildings. But tourist Eric Demuynck from Belgium found a different, more predictable East Berlin just blocks away. Walking through depressing neighborhoods still scarred by shrapnel from World War II, he said, ``This is what I expected to find.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Wed PMs Feb. 7

DOC.HEAD: In Kabul's 12th Winter of War, People Hope for a Spring of Peace
LaserPhoto Planned
DOC.TEXT: It's the 12th winter of civil war for the rugged people of Afghanistan, but in the snow and mud of this capital new hopes bud that spring will bring peace. Sounds of the bitter struggle between government forces and Moslem guerrillas still rattle Kabul. But for the first winter in a decade, Soviet troops aren't pulling the triggers and more and cheaper food is in the larder. ``Now it is just brother against brother. There is less fighting now,'' said Ahmad Amir Shah as he jerked his yellow Moskvich taxi to avoid a shower of gray slush from an oncoming army truck. However, the guerrillas' rockets still slam into the city daily, spreading panic in the mud-brick warrens that house most of Kabul's 2 million people. The U.S.-backed guerrillas known as the mujahedeen (holy warriors) are just beyond the jagged mountains ringing the city. Government soldiers, some of them too young to shave, respond with artillery fire. Late at night, Scud missiles launched from secret government bases north and south of the city roar like freight trains through the darkness, hurtling east toward the main battlefronts near the border with Pakistan. But in Kabul's teeming markets a bounty of food _ unlike last winter's scarce rations _ hints at better times. Turbaned men wrapped to their noses in thick brown shawls barter with vendors in the muddy Shor Bazaar along the Kabul River. The vendors' carts are heaped with apples, oranges, pomegranates, nuts and crispy slabs of unleavened ``naan'' bread. Chickens squawk in wicker baskets, and great hunks of beef and mutton hang in the open air. There are even pastries and sugar candy. A naan the size of a dinner plate costs 8 cents, down from 10 cents a year ago when many bakeries shut down for lack of flour, now available at $2 a 15-pound sack. A pound of mutton is about a fourth lower than a year ago at 52 to 70 cents, depending on the cut. This year's availability and prices mean that bread and meat, the staples of the Afghan diet, are within reach of more people in Afghanistan, where the average family's annual income is about $350. In the money changers' bazaar, the local currency, the afghani, is strengthening against the dollar. It took 525 afghanis to buy a dollar on Jan. 1 and by the end of the month it took just 500. ``Business is getting slightly better, but in the future, who knows? It depends on politics and the war,'' said Raja Kumar, one of the many ethnic Indian money dealers in the bazaar. Afghan government officials claim better planning, a crackdown on hoarding and the government's success in defending major cities are the main reasons for the improved supply situation. ``There were some mistakes by the government last winter of not reserving enough food,'' government spokesman Naquib Sameer said. ``Now the people are sure the government is doing the best for them.'' But this success story rests largely on two external factors: _The Soviet Union, although it ended direct combat involvement last February after nine years, still conducts a massive airlift of weapons and food to the government, weather and mujahedeen rockets permitting. _Mujahedeen leaders in neighboring Pakistan, where the most powerful guerrilla groups are based, say they've instructed their fighters to concentrate on military targets and stop attacking food convoys. The Kabul government also received help from the weather. The 1988-89 winter was the city's worst in memory, when heavy snows closed the airport and the Salang highway leading north to the Soviet Union. This year the first snow didn't arrive in Kabul until Jan. 17. The mujahedeen, who want to topple President Najib and install an Islamic government, continue to attack the capital and other cities with weapons supplied by the United States, Saudi Arabia and other Moslem countries. But they acknowledge that the level of fighting has declined since last year's humiliating failure to capture Jalalabad, barely 37 miles from Pakistan. The mujahedeen had predicted they would take Kabul within weeks or months after the Soviet withdrawal _ an optimistic view also adopted by the U.S. government. But the guerrillas, instead of uniting under a joint command, fell victim to internal rivalries that periodically burst into open fighting. Some small guerrilla bands cut separate deals with Najib's government and gave up the fight. The mujahedeen's top leaders insist they'll never negotiate with Najib and his People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan, which seized power by a military coup in 1978. ``Nobody can win this war,'' said Ahmad, the taxi driver. ``But now maybe the government and the mujahedeen learn this.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Thursday PMs Feb. 8

DOC.HEAD: Gas Lines Disappear in Poland but for the Wrong Reason
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline lines have vanished across Poland, not because gas is plentiful but because few can afford to fill the tank anymore _ or to even take the car out of the garage. Polish drivers are being forced off the roads not only by the doubling of gasoline prices but also by steep increases in car registration fees, highway taxes and insurance premiums. All are part of the dramatic steps put into effect Jan. 1 as the new non-communist government tries to create a free-market system from Poland's beleagured economy. In the southeastern city of Lublin, drivers have turned in the license plates for 13 percent of the registered cars, according to a recent report on the television news. The state-owned fuel monopoly says sales of gasoline dropped more than 20 percent during the first 20 days of 1990, compared with 1989. Taxi drivers sit in parked cabs, unable to find passengers willing to pay the 100-times-the-meter rate to cover the gas prices. An estimated 60 percent of state-run enterprises aren't using their fuel quotas because they can't pay the cost. Warsaw's streets are noticeably less congested, and gasoline trucks have been seen cruising the capital looking for service stations in need of a refill. But Poles are finding little pleasure in being able to drive in and fill up without waiting hours in line. ``It was not good and it is not good,'' said a doctor about to buy a tankful at a central Warsaw gas station. ``There is a saying: `What do you prefer, to freeze to death outside your flat due to the low temperature or inside due to faulty heating? Both situations are wrong,'' she said with a sigh. Gasoline now costs the zloty equivalent of 96 cents a gallon, up from about 50 cents before Jan. 1. That is cheap by West European standards, but it is expensive for Poles who, on the average, earn 560,000 zlotys, about $60, a month. In addition, a car owner now must pay 440,000 zlotys a year for insurance and 49,500 for highway taxes and registration. The higher gas prices are part of the government's effort to stop paying producers huge subsidies to keep consumer prices artificially low. That system left the economy with a staggering budget deficit, unbridled inflation and little motivation for efficiency. Although drivers are disgruntled, the reduced demand also may allow Poland to cut its costly fuel imports. Gasoline supplies have long been a barometer of the Polish economic crisis, with filling the tank a major project that dominated drivers' schedules and itineries. Car owners suffered through years of rationing, and even after the coupon system ended Jan. 1, 1989, supplies were frequently as short as the tempers on lines. No more. ``Never have filling stations been as uncrowded,'' said the weekly Polityka. ``Warsaw has become a truly Western capital by this standard: you drive up and there is a smiling attendant waiting to fill your car.'' At one Warsaw gas station, where it was not unusual to see a hundred drivers waiting at dawn, the manager said the eight cars at the pumps at midday constituted a rush. He said a tanker truck's gas delivery that he was able to sell in 10 hours now lasts two or three days. Attentants says customers drive in for as little as two liters, a bit more than a half-gallon. The notion of competing for customers is new in Poland, and the gas station manager, clearly not ready to give away mugs or road maps, rejected the idea of offering small extra services, such as cleaning the windshield.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Friday PMs Feb. 9

DOC.HEAD: ABC's Reverential ``Elvis'' Series Premieres
DOC.TEXT: Elvis Presley, 42, is still dead. But try to tell that to fans of the man who sang arias with such lyrics as ``You ain't nothin' but a hound dog.'' They'll just boo you and maybe whomp you upside the head. They have a very big treat coming up this week: ABC's ``Elvis,'' a half-hour series about the early, scuffling part of his career. The show is premiering Tuesday, then starts its regular run Sunday. Created by Rick Husky, and filmed in Memphis, Tenn., this Elvis is played by Michael St. Gerard. He vaguely resembles Presley. Alas, he just doesn't seem as accomplished an actor. But Elvis fans will be hard pressed to find fault with the series, which has three executive producers _ one of them the King's ex-wife, Priscilla _ and warns all that it is a ``dramatization'' of events in Presley's life. The show's tone is highly reverential, much in the manner of a documentary about Abraham Lincoln or Gandhi. Those expecting good ol' boy humor are advised to rent a great Burt Reynolds flick, ``W.W. and the Dixie Dancekings.'' Although slow and dull, ``Elvis'' is rife with indications that the polite, sometimes sullen-looking young man in the sideburns is destined for greatness and might even become a major cultural force in America. You can tell. In one nightclub scene, for example, he sings ``Money Honey'' and sets everyone to dancing. In Sunday's show, a disc jockey plays Elvis' first record, causing much of Memphis to come down with happy feet. The premiere opens with bluesy harmonica music heard as a car rolls past a Mississippi cotton field. This is because it's against the law in TV to show a car rolling past a Mississippi cotton field without bluesy harmonica music. The car contains one sheriff and Elvis' father, Vernon (Billy Green Bush, who does a fine, low-key job despite a bad script). It is gently establshed that Presley is seeing his wife and young son before being taken to prison. It's not clear why he's going to jail. But he tells Elvis, who is 3 years old here, that he's the man of the house now and to take care of his mother. The lad seems to understand. Later scenes, with Vernon now out of prison but suffering back problems that force him to quit work, include Elvis' historic visit to Sun Records in Memphis to record a song for his mother's birthday. It will be old news to Elvis fans that the company's owner, Sam Phillips (Jordan Williams), is mighty impressed with Presley's voice. No matter that here he tells the kid: ``You got a raw sound, Elvis. Real raw.'' Maybe so, but there's nothing even mildly raw in this show. The only dramatic tension consists of Elvis' desire to do other than work at a wire warehouse and his father's concern that Elvis keep that job, however grungy and low-paying. ``We all get chances, Elvis,'' he says. ``Some of them we just can't take. Life's that way. ... Sometimes it don't give you a choice.'' Ah, but TV does. And unless you want to see Elvis Presley canonized for the next eight weeks _ longer if ABC renews the show _ it'd be wise to pass on this series, find a good book to curl up with and start curling. __ Elsewhere in television... INSPECTING THE HAND THAT FEEDS IT: ABC's ``Good Morning America'' today starts a five-part series, reported by co-host Charles Gibson, on the billion-dollar world of advertising and commercials in the United States. Wednesday's chapter might prove of particular interest. It's a look at how s-e-x is used in hawking products.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday PMs, Feb. 5

DOC.HEAD: If You're Going To Chase Interest Rates, Chase Them Downhill
DOC.TEXT: In the 1970s, a decade of inflation, people chased prices, hoping to makes purchases before sales tags could be marked even higher. By compressing the demand for goods, by moving up future purchases into the present, however, such buyers did their bit to push prices even higher. To some small degree, they helped fulfill their fearful prophecy. As the 1990s begin, another chase might be developing, this one involving home mortgage rates. Those rates had been falling. Now they are rising, just as would-be homeowners prepare for the spring buying season. During the past three or four months, real estate agents in many parts of the country have observed that potential buyers were delaying purchases, hoping to find lower mortgage rates. Now that rates are rising, some of these buyers might feel compelled to act quickly to avoid even higher rates. Combined with the historical spring upturn in housing demand, this could create stiffer borrowing terms. So far, there is little evidence that the scenario is happening, but some housing people and mortgage lenders are suggesting the possibility. So, some reminders for those who might become involved: 1. The recent upward movement of home mortgage rates has indeed been sharp. HSH Associates, which tracks rates nationally, says the average of fixed-rate loans recently was 10.12 percent, up one-quarter of a percent in two weeks. Moreover, news has developed recently to douse hopes of any cuts. Perhaps most significant was the the statement by Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve board chairman, that he foresees slow expansion rather than recession. 2. There is very little evidence, however, that recent increases are part of a long-term trend. Many bankers and financial analysts still believe that rates will resume falling this year, especially as the economy weakens. 3. Still, few people can forget the devastation wrought by those 15 percent-plus prime rates in the 1970s. They fear that such a situation could develop again, putting them out of the housing market for years. The climate of the 1990s, however, is much different from those days. In the 1970s and early 1980s there were fundamental fears that the economy had gone crazy. Prices soared, and so did debt. Some small businesses actually paid 25 percent to borrow money in 1981; still, some were turned away. Viewing that scene and the trend, lenders feared that the future could only be worse. The rate, the cost to Uncle Sam, on 30-year government bonds hit double-digit levels _ 13.6 per cent in 1981 _ for the first time in memory. But, rates began backing down again in 1985. Near the end of last year that same 30-year bond was under 8 percent, indicating a return of confidence in the future. That same observation applies also to lenders on 30-year mortgages. The recent rise, which brought the 30-year bond above 8.5 percent, is only a few weeks old, and cannot be used to suggest a sustained loss of faith in the future. If it persists, yes, but it could come back down suddenly too. It adds up to this advice for those who intend someday to buy a home: Don't be panicked into believing that interest rates only go up. They come down too, sometimes when least expected. In the 1970s, some alleged authorities said we would never again see single-digit mortgage rates. We have. The lesson is this: Reconsider before chasing prices or interest rates higher, because there may be little to be gained. It might be smarter to sit back and relax, and let prices and rates come to you.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Monday, Feb. 5

DOC.HEAD: Hollywood Trappings Accompany Movie Star to Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 30th graf, Ticket Sales ... two-month run., to UPDATE with run of ``Merchant'' extended to March 10.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Lights, camera, hype. It's time for the obligatory opening night press conference, and the room is jammed with journalists and others lucky enough to get in for a glimpse of the show's stars. But wait. This isn't the movies. This is the theater, and serious theater at that. The show is ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' Tennessee Williams' Pulitzer Prize-winning drama. The ticket is movie star Kathleen Turner, making her debut as Williams' sultry Maggie, a role originated by Barbara Bel Geddes on stage and later by Elizabeth Taylor on screen. The hype is inevitable, the producers say. ``She really spells glamour,'' explained Fran Weissler, who is producing the Broadway-bound play with her husband, Barry Weissler. ``She's a real movie star, and that excites people.'' The excitement is such that 52 reporters and photographers descended on Pittsburgh's Benedum Center for the Jan. 23 press conference, some from out of state. The tall, blond actress, whose film credits include ``Body Heat,'' ``Romancing the Stone,'' ``Prizzi's Honor,'' ``The Accidental Tourist'' and ``The War of the Roses,'' seized center stage as soon as she sat down next to co-stars Charles Durning, Daniel Hugh Kelly and Polly Holliday. She was in perpetual motion, flinging her hair over her shoulders, lounging back in her chair and leaning toward Durning and Kelly, losing her shoes under the table, taking her wire-rimmed glasses off and on. Most of the questions were for Turner, who said she always had longed for the part. When the questions weren't, she would interrupt her co-stars during their responses and chat with the actors beside her while one of the others spoke. Turner was visibly pleased when a reporter asked if she agrees with the public's assessment of her as a fantasy figure. ``I'm a fantasy figure? Ahhh,'' she said, breathing heavily and twisting seductively in her chair. ``Do you agree with that Mr. Durning? Let someone else answer that. ``Nah, come on, it's acting, guys. It really truly really is. It's fun to be able to play these women with all this wonderful power and allure, and intelligence, I'd like to add. But it's acting. It's just fun. I'm really not like that at home.'' What is she like at home? ``None of your business,'' she replied. ``That's private.'' As soon as the news conference ended, many in the crowd surged forward for autographs. The actress obliged for a few moments then was whisked away for rehearsal. No private interviews, no pestering, please. Welcome to Broadway, way off-Broadway, Hollywood-style. ``It's tough. The more advance you have, the luckier you are as a producer,'' Fran Weissler said. A big name star usually facilitates financing a play, which can run into several million dollars, said Harvey Sabinson, executive director of the League of American Theaters and Producers. ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' is due to open at Broadway's Eugene O'Neill Theater on March 21 after runs in Wilmington, Del., Pittsburgh, Boston and Philadelphia. Turner is committed to the show until mid-July. The Weisslers said the actress was their No. 1 choice because _ and only because _ she's perfect for the part. ``I would say that show could run as long as she's committed,'' Sabinson said. ``There were two reasons for hiring Kathleen Turner. One, she's a fine actress, and two, she's a big name, too.'' Turner is by no means the first major motion picture star to play the Great White Way. ``(Katharine) Hepburn worked both sides. Jack Lemmon has been on Broadway. Lots of Hollywood stars have since the breakdown of the studio system years ago where actors weren't tied up for life to a studio,'' Sabinson said. ``Most of your big stars started on Broadway: Spencer Tracy, Clark Gable. They all started on Broadway. They like to work before live audiences.'' That's one reason why Turner is back on stage. The 35-year-old actress had a tiny role in one of the replacement casts for the long-running Broadway production of ``Gemini'' in 1978. ``The immediate response one garners on stage, the communal feeling as an audience comes together in this experience, is so supportive. It's so exciting,'' Turner said. ``I really feel there are moments when you start reading thoughts back and forth. It's just wonderful. ``I don't prefer either (film or stage). I want both.'' Even with the media's bright spotlight, big names on the marquee don't necessarily assure a long run. Ticket sales for ``3 Penny Opera'' with rock star Sting as Mack the Knife failed to meet expectations, for instance, and the show closed Dec. 31 after two months on Broadway. Shakespeare's ``The Merchant of Venice,'' starring Dustin Hoffman on the other hand, is scheduled to close March 10 when the ensemble disbands, after a virtually sold-out, three-month run. The best combination is a great star in a great production of a good play. ``The play is always the thing,'' Sabinson said, ``just like Shakespeare wrote.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thursday AMs, Feb. 8

DOC.HEAD: Government Test Program Sets Standards for Condoms
LaserPhoto WX20 of Feb. 2
DOC.TEXT: Garage mechanics listen for pings. Piano tuners are alert for plunks. Donald E. Marlowe's job is to wait for the next POW! to shatter the silence of his laboratory. Marlowe is the government's chief condom tester, and the explosions come from an ``air burst'' test he is perfecting to measure sample condoms' resistance to pressure. Working in a low, nondescript building that the Food and Drug Administration shares with a furniture store in this Washington suburb, Marlowe demonstrates by slipping a latex condom onto a machine equipped with gauges, dials and the squiggly needle of an instrument that looks like a seismograph. Then he inflates the condom with air. It swells to the size of a good-sized watermelon before it bursts. The instruments record that it withstood 30 liters or about 7{ gallons of air and pressure of three-tenths of a pound per square inch, well above the government's exacting standard. ``Pretty tough,'' says Marlowe, a 49-year-old mechanical engineer who runs the division of mechanics and material science for the FDA's Center for Devices and Radiological Health. In another room, Marlowe takes a circular section cut from the middle of a condom, similar to a wide rubber band, and stretches it on a machine to test its tensile strength _ how far it will stretch before it snaps. Besides condoms, Marlowe's laboratory tests a wide variety of medical devices such as cardiac pacemakers, artificial hearts and valves, false eyes, syringes, pumps and bone, joint and ligament implants. Nearly four dozen of these prosthetic body parts are attached to ``Yorick,'' the FDA's bionic skeleton, which greets visitors to the laboratory where all the devices have been tested over the years. ``The FDA is responsible for the safety and effectiveness of medical devices, and condoms are a medical device,'' Marlowe said. Marlowe is accustomed to the snickers and jokes he sometimes hears about condoms. He chuckles indulgently about the time his staff, in a playful holiday mood, inflated some condoms with helium and tied them to the office Christmas tree. ``They looked great,'' he said. But Marlowe says that with widespread public concern over the AIDS epidemic and former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop's highly publicized campaign to promote safer sex, condoms are no laughing matter. Since the early 1960s, FDA agents at a Winchester, Mass., laboratory north of Boston have been conducting random, unannounced tests of sample condoms from domestic and foreign manufacturers for possible water leakage. During the year ended in April 1988, the FDA tested 115,000 condoms for possible pinholes or tears in this way, resulting in rejection of more than 30 million imported condoms as defective and the recall of 3 million domestic condoms from store shelves. Marlowe said his laboratory's air burst and tensile strength tests for condoms form the basis for an industrywide testing standard that was first published in 1973 and was revised most recently in November. That standard is recognized voluntarily by manufacturers, the government and consumer interests, including the U.S. Agency for International Development, which supplies condoms for Third World population control projects. Compliance is determined during the FDA's regular ``quality assurance'' inspections of manufacturers. ``Someone new coming into the lab gets over the bathroom humor about condoms very quickly,'' Marlowe said. ``This is serious business.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Market's Latest Worry: Where the Japanese Put Their Money
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Japanese-German relations, once a mighty military threat vanquished by America nearly a half-century ago, have come back to haunt the U.S. financial markets. This time the weapon is plenty of money. Investors from Japan, the largest single source of foreign capital to the United States, are shifting their sights to attractive European markets, namely booming West Germany, which is emerging as the most powerful economic force reshaping Eastern Europe. The thought that the enormously wealthy Japanese may be hanging back from U.S. investments dampened the stock market's mood this past week and injected new anxiety into the market for Treasury securities. An impending $30 billion Treasury auction this week could provide a better clue about the extent to which Japanese investors are willing to keep financing America's federal deficit, economists say. Poor participation would suggest that interest rates must rise to attract buyers. This would make bonds more competitive with stocks and would raise borrowing costs of American corporations, lowering their profits. For weeks Japanese investors have been lightening up on American equities, partly to raise cash for margin calls on their own heavily leveraged stocks at home, economists say. Japanese stocks have been falling mainly in response to rising interest rates and inflation pressures. More significantly, Japanese investors have discovered potentially more lucrative markets in West Germany since the Berlin Wall came tumbling down. ``The Japanese have taken money otherwise going to buy U.S. stocks and bonds and are investing in West Germany,'' said economist Mark Killion with DRI-McGraw-Hill Inc. in Lexington, Mass. West Germany is particularly attractive to Japanese investors for two reasons: exchange rates _ the mark is stronger against both the dollar and the yen; and political changes in Eastern Europe, which are expected to enormously benefit the West German economy. Both are pushing up West German interest rates. ``The highest rates of return available today are in Germany,'' said Marc M. Goloven, an international economist with Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. In the week ending Jan. 26, the long-term West German government bond yielded 7.56 percent, Goloven said. The comparable Japanese yield was 6.19 percent. Although the U.S. Treasury's long-term bond was yielding 8.48 percent, the rising value of the mark still made the West German bonds worth more. Higher West German rates stem partly from the influx of people into West Germany from throughout Eastern Europe, which is putting pressure on prices, particularly housing, and raising the inflation rate. The West German central bank's answer to rising inflation is to raise interest rates. In addition, unification of Western Europe markets under the European Economic Community in 1992 has incited a rush of investments by the Japanese, who fear that heightened trade restrictions could keep them out. ``There's a lot of incentive for Japanese investors to get into Europe now before the barriers come crashing down,'' Killion said. ``The feeling in Japan is that investors will have a much better prospect for working successfully in European markets if they get there before 1992 occurs.'' Nonetheless, economists emphasize that Japanese investors, while investing in Europe, are not abandoning U.S. markets. ``The question is not whether Japanese investors are going to come to the United States, but at what price,'' said Lawrence A. Veit, international economist with Brown Brothers Harriman & Co. Veit says European markets are not large enough to absorb huge amounts of Japanese money. ``So whereas the Japanese can send a lot of money in a short time to Europe, it is not feasible to think that they will send a lot of money over a long period of time,'' Veit said. Economists say there are still many reasons the Japanese will come to U.S. markets, including political stability. ``We still attract significant amounts of Japanese investment capital and will continue to do so whether in the form of direct investment in such things as automobile assembly plants or portfolio investments in stocks and bonds,'' Goloven said.
