DOC.HEAD: Police Search for Phantom Stuart Killer Stings a Community
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Hattie Dudley has a list. It started taking shape Oct. 24, the day after Charles Stuart unleashed the lie that his wife, Carol, was killed by a black man outside a Mission Hill housing project. That was the day Hattie Dudley saw a young Hispanic man on the street stopped, stripped and searched by police looking for suspects in the death of the 30-year-old, and white, pregnant lawyer. She did not know who the young Hispanic man was, but the next time she took names. Ms. Dudley, who raised her seven children in the Mission Hill project she now runs, collected the names and stories of six young people subjected to police searches in the hunt for a phantom murderer. She and other residents say there were many more. ``They felt they were all accused murderers,'' she said of the young men among the 3,000 mostly black and Hispanic residents of the Mission Hill projects. Her list even includes a young woman detained in a police car for 20 minutes until a female officer arrived to don rubber gloves and inspect the woman's private parts, Ms. Dudley says. She doesn't say the search was directly related to the Stuart case, but it illustrates for her the liberties authorities took. Police do not discount such stories outright but say no one has come forward to complain of police conduct in the Mission Hill search. Martha Knight might have come forward. But her son cannot identify those who searched him. He was standing at an intersection with a girlfriend when police surrounded him on all sides. They made him pull down his trousers and then his underwear and shined a flashlight on his buttocks, she said. Then they let him go. ``It makes you angry,'' said Ms. Knight. ``It makes you feel less than human. And who do you complain to?'' Officers combed Mission Hill with the description of a black man existing only in Stuart's imagination: 28 to 34 years old, about 5-foot-10, weighing 150 to 160 pounds, with a raspy voice, a short Afro and splotchy facial hair. Police spokesman Jim Jordan said basic homicide investigation procedures were followed in the search for suspects, and authorities point to a long-standing policy of investigating civilian charges of misconduct. But Ms. Knight and others say they don't know where to turn. They are distrustful of the police to begin with, an apprehension reinforced in recent months by a citywide drug crackdown _ before the Stuart shootings _ in which suspected dealers were stopped and searched on the streets. After Stuart himself was implicated in his wife's death and jumped to his death from a bridge Jan. 4, the outrage burst forth in angry, collective protests. Many leaders of the minority community now faulted the police for their readiness to accept a stereotypical suspect. Police countered that no one doubted Stuart in the early weeks and that they would have been derelict not to have based the search on his description. Police installed a 24-hour complaint hotline, and the state attorney general is looking at both the stop-and-search tactic and the manner in which individuals were questioned in the Stuart case. But Deputy Superintendent Arthur Morgan Jr., who heads the police internal affairs office, said he still knows of no unjustified searches. ``I need someone to come up and tell me they've been stopped illegally and searched illegally and point out the policeman who did it,'' Morgan said. Hattie Dudley is keeping her list to herself. She doesn't trust government investigators, she said. ``All during the civil rights movement, there was the FBI and the Justice Department investigators,'' she said, ``and all we got from them was a dead leader _ Martin. Martin Luther King.'' In the days after the Stuart shootings, many Mission Hill residents were as eager as others throughout the city to see a suspect caught. ``The man who did it should be taken out,'' Anthony Stanley, 23, said two days after the incident. ``We got to get the death penalty back. The guy was foul. He had no heart.'' But then they watched day after day _ until several weeks later when the investigation focused on a suspect in custody for another crime _ as young men were stopped on the streets, told to lean spread-eagled against police cars and searched. ``It was just crazy times, something you see in the movies,'' said Ms. Knight, a community organizer. ``Even though there were more police, we didn't feel more protected. ... ``It makes you think that they can come in just because of where we live. I'm sure they couldn't go to Beacon Hill or some other middle-class neighborhood and do the same thing.'' Hector Mercado said he was stopped and patted down three or four times. ``It was like a war zone. A lot of cars, a lot of police going inside of hallways, checking day and night,'' said Mercado, 19, who is studying for his high school equivalency diploma. ``I feel badly because they didn't have no right.'' For one of the searches, Mercado was stopped on his way home after escorting his wife, Madelyn, to her parents' apartment. He was walking along the street minding his own business, he said, when three officers ordered him to halt. ``One of them held his hand on his gun,'' Mercado recalled. ``They said, `Stop and get behind the car.''' One officer warned him: ``I don't want to see you around here.'' Around where? Mercado now asks. Mission Hill is his home. It might not be the best place in the world, but it is home. ``We were a people full of dignity. There was a real sense of community and belonging and comfort,'' Ms. Dudley said. ``You know when you're home, that relaxed feeling.'' For now, she said, that's gone.

DOC.TEXT: New York Stock Exchange Chairman John J. Phelan Jr. plans to retire at the end of the year, capping a tumultuous tenure in which the nation's biggest securities market grew explosively, suffered a devastating crash and struggled to recover. Phelan announced his departure at a news conference Thursday in the NYSE's Wall Street headquarters after the close of the day's trading. He said he had considered retirement for about a year, but had not felt he could leave amid the continuing debate over market volatility and the uncertainty raised by an Oct. 13 mini-crash.

The U.S. economy fell sharply in January for the ninth consecutive month and at the greatest rate of decline since the last recession, the nation's purchasing managers said. The National Association of Purchasing Management said Thursday its monthly index fell in January to 45.2 percent, down from 46.7 percent in December. A reading below 50 indicates that the U.S. manufacturing economy is declining, while above 50 indicates expansion, the group said. The index has been below 50 for the past nine months.

Major U.S. retailers reported fair sales gains for January, a transition month when stores clear out leftover holiday merchandise to make room for fresh spring lines. Chains specializing in apparel reported the best growth Thursday while several mass merchandisers, including the nation's largest retailer, Sears, Roebuck and Co., tallied increases below the industry average. Sales at stores open at least a year rose around 5 percent industrywide from a year earlier, according to analysts' estimates.

Construction spending advanced last year at its slowest pace since the 1982 recession, the government said. The Commerce Department said Thursday that residential, non-residential and government construction spending totaled $414.7 billion, a 1.2 percent increase over 1988 and the worst showing since a 5.1 percent decline in 1982.

A bankruptcy judge refused to require two big department store companies to pay as much as $20 million in deposits to utilities, which feared the retailers couldn't guarantee payment of bills. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. said Thursday that if the financial condition of the Campeau Corp. retailers Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores deteriorates, he would require a one-month deposit. But he said the 596 utilities serving Federated and Allied businesses haven't shown that the retailers are deadbeats.

Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden asked Congress for more power to police Wall Street, including access to grand jury testimony in criminal probes and authority to fine securities law violators. Breeden also told a Senate panel Thursday that he supported proposed legislation that would disqualify major securities law violators from serving as officers or directors of publicly held companies.

Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. agreed to pay Massachusetts $1 million in the latest settlement arising from the Wall Street firm's guilty plea to securities fraud charges. Massachusetts became the 41st state to reach such an agreement with Drexel. The amount was the largest settlement ever paid to the state in a securities matter, Secretary of State Michael J. Connolly said Thursday.

USX Corp., strengthening its defenses against takeover strategist Carl Icahn, said it had amended its bylaws to require advance notice of proxy fights. USX Chairman Charles A. Corry said at a news conference Thursday he had informed Icahn, USX's largest shareholder, about the change in a telephone call Wednesday. Corry declined to discuss Icahn's reaction. Icahn was in meetings Thursday, his secretary said, and he did not return a telephone call seeking comment.

The Senate Judiciary Committee brushed aside complaints from consumer groups and approved plans to cut damages that can be awarded in civil fraud cases under the nation's major anti-racketeering law. ``Broad language that may be appropriate against the Mafia can be abused when used in a garden-variety fraud case,'' Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., said Thursday as the panel approved the bill 11-2 and sent it to the Senate floor.

The stock market finished mixed Thursday as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 4.28 points to finish at 2,586.26. Bond prices finished mixed, with long-term bonds posting gains while short-term issues lost ground. The dollar finished mixed. Gold, silver and sugar futures prices rose while energy, livestock and crop futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Retailers Finish 1989 With Satisfactory Sales, Another Competitive Year Seen
With PM-Retail Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Retailers could have a rough year if a loss of confidence in the economy makes consumers more cautious about spending. ``It's going to be a tough, competitive year _ that's the bottom line,'' predicted Monroe Greenstein, retail analyst at Bear Stearns & Co. Inc. Results reported Thursday by the nation's major general merchandisers, department stores, discounters and specialty apparel chains indicated the industry had satisfactory sales growth in January. Sales at stores open at least a year rose around 5 percent from a year earlier, according to analysts' estimates. Stores concentrating on apparel generally posted the highest gains while several mass merchandisers, including the nation's largest retailer, Sears, Roebuck and Co., tallied increases below the industry average. January typically is slow in the retailing trade and the month marks the end of the fiscal year for many merchants. Consumers usually take a break from shopping after Christmas and some people enter the new year with credit card debts that discourage them from shopping for a while. Widespread price cutting and other promotions this past holiday season _ particularly by debt-laden department stores desperate to raise cash _ may have left buyers more bloated than usual. Jeffrey Edelman, of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said the retailers with the leanest inventories due to good holiday business generally had the smallest January sales growth. The stores that were stuck with excess after Christmas and succeeded in pushing merchandise out to make room for fresh spring lines reported higher sales results. Edelman estimated that sales at general merchandise, apparel and furniture retailers rose 5 percent in January from the prior year. The change covered sales at stores open a year or longer, known as same- or comparable-store sales. Analysts and store executives consider same-store tallies the best indicator of a retailer's health. Jeffrey Feiner, a Merrill Lynch & Co. analyst, said recent slippage in consumer confidence, reflecting uncertainty about economic conditions and jittery financial markets, portends possibly rougher times for retailers. ``Weakness in both the housing and financial markets makes the outlook for consumer spending in retail stores ... likely to be quite sluggish, at least over the near term,'' Feiner said. The Conference Board's monthly consumer confidence index released Wednesday showed further erosion in January for the third month in a row. The business research group said the index sank to the lowest point since just after the October 1987 stock market crash. Chicago-based Sears said overall sales rose 2.2 percent in the four weeks ended Jan. 27 from a year earlier while sales at stores open at least a year rose 3.3 percent. K mart, second in size to Sears and based in Troy, Mich., reported a 13.1 percent increase in total sales but, on a same-store basis, sales were up 3.1 percent. No. 3-ranked Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the Bentonville, Ark.-based discounter that has been outperforming its competitors, saw overall sales surge 24 percent. Excluding newly opened stores, sales rose 10 percent. Among retailers concentrating on apparel, Dallas-based J.C. Penney Co. Inc. said sales increased 8.5 percent. Same-store sales rose 7.3 percent. The Limited Inc., the specialty apparel retailer based in Columbus, Ohio, posted an 11 percent total sales increase while sales grew 9 percent on a comparable-store basis. The Gap Inc., a clothing specialist headquartered in San Francisco, said January sales soared 34 percent overall and 24 percent at stores open at least a year. Dayton Hudson Corp., the Minneapolis-based owner of department stores and the large Target discount chain, said January sales rose 12.2 percent overall and same-store sales rose 5.2 percent. St. Louis-based May Department Stores Co. said its sales rose 5.2 percent, or 2.6 percent on a same-store basis. Woolworth Corp., the New York-based owner of F.W. Woolworth Co. stores plus numerous specialty retailers including the Foot Locker chain, said domestic January sales rose 8.5 percent. Domestic sales rose 4.5 percent at stores open for a year or more.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Chief Seeks Beefed Up Enforcement Powers
DOC.TEXT: Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden wants to pack more punch when his agency goes after financial fraud and securities law violators. Breeden told a Senate panel Thursday that policing Wall Street would be easier if the SEC had access to grand jury testimony in criminal probes and authority to fine securities law violators. Breeden also said he supported proposed legislation that would disqualify major securities law violators from serving as officers or directors of publicly held companies. But that authority should be in the hands of federal judges _ not the SEC _ he said. Breeden said the SEC should be able to tell repeat federal securities offenders such as fugitive financier Robert Vesco: ``Your conduct is so severe that you're not going to get another opportunity to do it again.'' The SEC chief was the first witness at a hearing before the Senate Banking Committee's securities subcommittee, which is considering many of the reforms he proposed. The proposed Securities Law Enforcement Remedies Act was introduced last year at the SEC's request by Sen. Christopher J. Dodd, D-Conn., the subcommittee chairman, and Sen. John Heinz of Pennsylvania, the ranking Republican. Other witnesses included two former heads of the SEC's key Enforcement Division _ Gary G. Lynch and Stanley Sporkin _ and a former SEC commissioner, Aulana L. Peters. Nearly all favored the proposed reforms. But the American Society of Corporate Secretaries, which supports the bill's objectives, considers the language ``much too broad,'' said Victor Futter, a board member for the nationwide group of top executives. Futter told the panel that barring violators from holding corporate office amounts to ``an economic death penalty'' and that the fine provisions did not require proof of criminal conduct or fraud. Sporkin, now a federal judge in Washington, also expressed doubt about the proposal to bar violators from future corporate offices. ``Not everybody should be barred for life,'' he said. ``Even Pete Rose has said he wants to come back'' to major league baseball. Lynch, who was enforcement director from 1985 to 1989, cautioned that the ability to fine violators ``should only be exercised in cases involving deliberate fraud or manipulation.'' Breeden asked for the power to fine securities-law violators either directly through SEC administrative proceedings or through civil court actions. Currently the SEC can seek fines only in insider-trading cases, unlike most federal financial regulators including the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which oversees the futures industry, and the Office of Thrift Supervision, the savings and loan watchdog. The SEC fines would range from a top maximum of $100,000 for an individual to $500,000 for a company or other entity. Breeden also asked Congress to give the SEC access to grand jury testimony in criminal securities investigations. He noted that SEC lawyers often work side by side with the Justice Department in criminal investigations such as the Ivan Boesky inside-trading case. But under current law, the SEC may not be given access to secret grand jury testimony _ ``even when the information was developed by our own personnel'' _ without a court ruling that it is necessary for a judicial proceeding, Breeden said. He added that the SEC can't get a look at criminal grand jury proceedings without such court approval ``even after the criminal process is completed.'' Breeden also requested ``cease and desist'' authority that would allow the SEC to halt suspected illegal activities. Currently, the SEC must go to the overworked federal court system and get a court order to halt alleged wrongdoings. That could delay the agency from halting an alleged penny stock fraud if it uncovers a boiler room operation with banks of fast-talking sales people pressuring investors with get-rich-quick schemes, said Breeden. Neither the cease and desist power nor the access to grand jury testimony was included in the original bill introduced last year.

DOC.HEAD: John Phelan To Retire as Head of New York Stock Exchange
DOC.TEXT: John J. Phelan Jr. has charted the New York Stock Exchange through a period of explosive growth and near-disaster, but he will leave the nation's largest trading forum with critical issues unresolved. Phelan announced Thursday he would retire at the end of 1990 to pursue a new but undetermined career, 42 years after he worked for his father one summer as a ``runner'' on the stock exchange floor _ and hated it. Phelan's cool leadership helped the exchange recover from the cataclysmic crash of Oct. 19, 1987, when the largest sell-off in history wiped 508 points off the Dow Jones industrial average. He also championed new technology that enabled the market to cope with record volume during the crash, implemented controversial reforms designed to limit computerized trading and sought to assure small investors they could get a fair shake in a market dominated by professionals. At a news conference Thursday, Phelan said key issues such as volatility in stock prices and the NYSE's relationship with the nation's futures and options exchanges may have to be left to his successsor. But Phelan said he felt he was stepping down at a time when the exchange was healthy and he had sufficiently addressed the crash and its aftermath. ``Markets and the exchange are the kinds of institutions where you cannot press a button and resolve them overnight,'' he said. ``Because of the enormity of the constituent groups, the problems are resolved over a period of time by constant dialogue and changes and negotiation.'' Phelan declined to specify what he might do next, though he said he might seek to combine philanthropy, education and business. A successor was expected to be named by the fall. Phelan quashed rumors he might replace Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, who worked with him analyzing the crash. Phelan said he had not been contacted about a government job and was not considering one. Wall Street reacted with some surprise to Phelan's announcement and praised his foresight in installing the technology that helped the exchange survive the 1987 crash and a mini-crash last Oct. 13. ``It's been battered and bruised and yet it's stronger than ever,'' said Securities Industry Association Chairman Robert N. Downey, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Co. ``If (Phelan) hadn't been out front pushing for the computerization, it never could have handled the volume.'' Under Phelan, the value of all stocks listed on the Big Board, as the exchange is commonly known, has grown from $1.6 trillion to more than $2.7 trillion, making it the world's second-largest exchange behind Tokyo. Volume on the exchange has grown from 18.6 million shares a day when Phelan became vice chairman in 1975 to about 170 million in 1989. More than 600 million shares changed hands on Black Monday in 1987. A onetime specialist managing trading activity on the floor, Phelan was vice chairman for five years and president for four more before being named chairman and chief executive in 1984. Phelan had said previously he didn't plan to be chairman for life, but he had been expected to remain at least until 1992, the 200th anniversary of the stock market's founding by two dozen traders gathered under a buttonwood tree on Wall Street. ``I think he's been marvelous,'' said Alan C. ``Ace'' Greenberg, chairman of the investment firm Bear, Stearns & Co. ``He came from the floor. He understands the business. It helped.'' ``We've seen everything from electronic trading pressures to the market crash to new products and innovations to congressional pressure,'' added Wall Street veteran Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Asset Management Inc. ``I think he has done a very superb job addressing most of the issues.'' The most contentious topic lately is the price zigzags that have characterized some trading days, especially last Oct. 13 when the Dow Jones lost 190 points. Some traders blame volatility on program trading, a practice in which millions of dollars worth of stocks are traded instantaneously by computers. Phelan has been reluctant to restrict program trading, although he has limited it during heavy price fluctuations. Last fall he commissioned a panel to study volatility and the role of program trading. Phelan worked for his father's securities firm while at Adelphi University on Long Island. He served with the Marines in Korea before returning to the exchange floor. Of his vacation job working for his father at age 16, he said: ``At the end of the summer, when I was finished the job he said, `Well, how did you enjoy Wall Street?' and I said, `I'll tell you one thing, I don't know what I'm going to do in life but I'm certainly not going to work on Wall Street.'''

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Shutting Down St. Louis, Jefferson Avenue
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. will shut down its car assembly plant in St. Louis and lay off 3,700 workers in a move that's likely to worsen already souring relations between the company and its union. Thursday's announcement, the latest in a series of moves by U.S. automakers to cut capacity in the face of slumping sales, makes it likely that job security will be the union's top priority when it opens contract negotiations with the nation's Big Three automakers this summer. Chrysler said its St. Louis No. 1 plant will close Sept. 21, one week after its existing contract with the United Auto Workers expires. As previously announced, Chrysler will eliminate one shift at the plant on Feb. 12. The company said it will transfer production of the Dodge Daytona to its Sterling Heights, Mich., assembly plant, and shift assembly of the Chrysler LeBaron coupe and convertible to its Newark, Del., plant. The St. Louis plant will be the third Chrysler has closed since late 1988. It was announced just one day before the company closes a Detroit plant and puts 1,700 other workers on indefinite layoff. The move angered United Auto Workers officials. ``Workers and their unions don't design the cars or develop the marketing plans,'' UAW President Owen Bieber and Vice President Stan Marshall, head of the union's Chrysler department, said in a statement. ``Senior management calls those shots, but when they miscalculate or screw up, they all stay in place while the workers are told to hit the street,'' they said. Chrysler spokesman Doug Nicoll said the timing of the St. Louis plant closing was dictated by the UAW contract, which expires Sept. 14. That pact doesn't allow the company to close a plant because of product transfers. It says plants may be shut down only if sales of its products slump badly. Chrysler used that as justification for today's closing of its Jefferson Avenue assembly plant in Detroit. That factory makes Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon subcompact cars, whose sales have fallen by more than 50 percent from their heyday of about 208,000 in 1986. The UAW has contested that closing, saying Chrysler didn't do enough to keep the design of the small cars fresh and market them properly. Some of the 1,700 workers laid off from Jefferson Avenue will be offered jobs at Jefferson North, a plant under construction next to the existing factory. That plant will begin producing a sport-utility vehicle in late 1992. Chrysler is shutting the St. Louis plant in two stages. Beginning Feb. 12, it will eliminate one shift, putting 1,900 of its 3,700 workers on indefinite layoff. In September, it will lay off the remaining 1,800 workers and close the plant. The announcement couldn't have come at a worst moment, said Harley Shaiken, a labor professor at the University of California at San Diego. ``I think this coming on top of Jefferson is going to create a lot of anxiety and hostility in the industry going into negotiations,'' he said. The UAW opens talks with General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler in July. UAW President Owen Bieber said negotiating priorities will be worked out at a special union convention in May in Kansas City, Mo., but job security was more than likely to be the top issue. Michigan State University labor professor Dale Brickner agreed. ``Job security is going to be the barn burner,'' Brickner said. ``If we had strikes this fall, one or more, it certainly would not surprise me.'' Nicoll, the Chrysler spokesman, said the Delaware and Michigan plants would be idled in November to retool for the new cars and would resume production in December. Employment at each plant will increase by a few hundred workers, with laid off St. Louis workers getting the first cracks at the new jobs. The St. Louis closing is one in a series of temporary or indefinite shutdowns or production cuts at Big Three assembly plants nationwide. About 15,400 workers will have lost their jobs at 11 GM or Chrysler assembly plants because of indefinite layoffs between January and September. ``This isn't the last,'' Shaiken said. ``I think we will see something else at GM, particularly as contract time approaches.'' The closures come as auto sales slump and capacity at Japanese-owned plants grows. Within the last year, Honda Motor Co. Ltd. has opened a second assembly plant in Ohio and Nissan Motor Corp. has announced a huge expansion of its factory in Smyrna, Tenn. Since 1986, the best year in automotive sales history, GM and Chrysler have lost market share while Ford and Japanese companies, with the help of their new U.S. plants, have increased their shares.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Workers Not Surprised By Plant Closing
With PM-Chrysler Plants, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Workers at Chrysler Corp.'s No. 1 plant in suburban Fenton have worked only two weeks since mid-October, so they weren't too surprised by the announcement that the plant will be closed permanently in September. ``In the back of my mind, I kind of thought this was going to happen,'' said Dennis Moser of Festus, who has been at Plant No. 1 for 24{ years. ``I thought they were leading up to something and I knew they would have an announcement, but I thought it would be in March.'' Ed Boyer, president of United Auto Workers Local 136, was ``disappointed and frustrated'' at Thursday's news. ``I don't know what the next step's going to be right now,'' Boyer said. ``We've got to get some answers to some very important questions that we don't have right now.'' National union leaders in Detroit said they didn't understand why the St. Louis workers have to be the ``sacrificial victims of difficulties in the market.'' In a joint statement, UAW President Owen Bieber and Vice President Stan Marshall said, ``Workers and their unions don't design the cars or develop the marketing plans.'' The nation's No. 3 automaker said it will close the St. Louis No. 1 plant Sept. 21 and transfer production of the Dodge Daytona and Chrysler LeBaron to factories in Newark, Del., and Sterling Heights, Mich. No work has been done at the plant since Dec. 18. Plant No. 1, a 2.5 million square-feet facility capable of producing 225,000 cars a year, has been in operation more than 30 years. The first car, a four-door Plymouth Belvedere, rolled off the assembly line on Oct. 20, 1959. Chrysler also operates a neighboring facility in Fenton, Plant No. 2, which makes mini-vans. None of the estimated 3,500 jobs there were affected by the announcement. To prepare for the permanent shutdown, Chrysler will cut production at Plant No. 1 to one shift Feb. 12. By September, all 3,700 employees will be laid off, although they will have first chance at several hundred new jobs to be created at the Delaware and Michigan plants. ``I'd have to go, although I'd go kicking and screaming for sure,'' said Moser, who is less than six years away from qualifying for full retirement. ``I've got a whole section of my life tied up with the Chrysler Corporation and I don't know if they've given anything back.'' Moser and other auto workers are blaming the layoff on Chrysler's strategy of shifting production to Mexico, where labor costs are much cheaper. ``Anywhere they can squeeze a penny, they'll squeeze it,'' said autoworker Rich Bolzenius of Union, a rear window molding fitter who has been with Chrysler for 13 years. ``They're always trying to make the worker look like the bad guy because he's not a team player. ``But the reality of it is, the team concept is just a company concept that the workers follow to make it better for the company.''

DOC.HEAD: Gillette Plans First Manufacturing Venture in U.S.S.R.
DOC.TEXT: Gillette Co., already an importer of razor blades into the Soviet Union, hopes to set up its first manufacturing plant there in a few years. Gillette said Thursday it had signed a memorandum of intent with the Leninets group, based in Leningrad, to establish a $50 million blade-making facility. Leninets employs some 40,000 people in the manufacture and sale of consumer products, as well as scientific, ecological and research activities. ``I think that the Leninets and Gillette joint experience will help solve the supply problem in our market with such vital products and Leningraders will be among the first to have access to these goods,'' Anatoliy Turchak, director-general of Leninets, said in a statement. Gillette is trying to find an existing facility in the Soviet Union that can be transformed into a plant that could produce 800 million blades a year, company spokesman David Fausch said. That would make the plant the fourth largest blade facility in the world for Gillette, he said. Gillette, the world leader in the razor market, would hold a majority stake in the plant. The company hopes to sign a definitive agreement for the project later this year. The project could be completed within 20 months of an agreement, Fausch said. Under the deal, blades would be made using Gillette technology, but the brand name of the products has not been decided, Fausch said. Fausch noted that Gillette has been importing blades into the Soviet Union for the past few years from a plant in India.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses Utility Deposit Request
DOC.TEXT: Utilities supplying Federated and Allied department stores say they're disappointed but not surprised by a bankruptcy judge's refusal of requests for deposits totaling up to $20 million. ``It's about what we expected,'' John Ducker, a lawyer for Puget Sound Power & Light Co., said Thursday after U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. refused to order the Campeau Corp. retailers to post guarantees. Aug said if the retailers' financial condition deteriorates, he would require a one-month utility deposit. But he said the 596 utilities serving Federated and Allied businesses nationwide haven't shown the companies won't have the cash to pay bills on time. Also Thursday, bankruptcy court Trustee Conrad J. Morgenstern announced the formation of committees of unsecured creditors for Federated and Allied. The committees include representatives from Liz Claiborne Inc. and Sony Corp. of America, among others. Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. filed Jan. 15 for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, listing $7.5 billion in debts. Cory Lipoff, a lawyer for Federated and Allied, said utilities demanded deposits equal to two months' bills. ``We are confident that we can make our payments,'' Lipoff said. ``With few exceptions, the debtors are current with all their bills.'' Aug advised utilities to ``sit tight'' until Feb. 14, when he will hold a hearing on whether to approve $700 million in bank credits to keep the store groups operating during reorganization. ``We do have companies that have cash piling up ... that don't have to tap their working capital if their creditors don't panic,'' the judge said. But Leon Mener, a lawyer for Consolidated Edison Co. of New York, said he was worried that Federated and Allied would run out of money before they emerge from bankruptcy court protection. ``We're worried about those final bills at the end of the proceeding, when we're going to get stuck like we got stuck before,'' Mener said. He said he thought the two chains could match the two-month deposit another retailer, LJ Hooker Corp., paid after filing for protection from creditors. Ducker disputed Lipoff's argument that the retailers have enough assets readily convertible to cash to qualify for normal treatment by their utilities. Under questioning by Ducker, Federated and Allied Vice President and Treasurer Mark Kennedy said he didn't know whether the company has any assets or inventory that aren't pledged as security for past debts or the $700 million in credits. ``I'm sure there would be one asset unencumbered,'' Kennedy said. ``I think my desk is free and clear.'' Aug also approved a request by Federated and Allied to renew a $300,000-a-year contract with the recruiter who is searching for a chairman and chief executive officer to replace John W. Burden III, who retired Wednesday. Aug approved resumption of severance pay and about $20,000 in monthly retirement benefits that had been suspended. Meanwhile, Federated said efforts to sell Bloomingdale's, considered by many as the group's most attractive department store chain, have been delayed and may be called off. ``It's a decision that should be made only after the creditors' committee have a chance to review an analysis of whether there would be more value for (Federated) by retaining Bloomingdale's or by selling it,'' Federated spokeswoman Carol Sanger said.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Settles with State for $1 Million
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. agreed to pay the state $1 million in a settlement, the latest agreement stemming from the Wall Street firm's guilty plea to securities fraud charges. Massachusetts became the 41st state to reach such an agreement with Drexel. The settlement announced Thursday was the largest ever paid to the state in a securities matter, according to Secretary of State Michael J. Connolly. Drexel pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court in New York last September to six felonies and paid $650 million to settle a range of fraud allegations stemming from the government's lengthy investigation of insider trading on Wall Street. Drexel also agreed to dozens of administrative changes and unprecedented federal supervision in settling civil charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Under the settlement, Drexel paid $300 million in fines to the government and set aside $350 million for investors who can prove they were harmed by the firm's actions. Those who may be entitled to restitution include people who bought stocks in about 20 allegedly fraudulent transactions cited by the SEC. The settlement with Massachusetts is one of the largest the firm reached with states that have settled so far. Drexel paid Illinois about $1.2 million. The lowest settlements were about $50,000, said a company spokesman. The settlement with Massachusetts brings the total amount Drexel has paid states to $8.3 million. ``We're pleased we were able to settle it and now we can go about our business,'' said Steven Anreder, a Drexel spokesman. The $1 million settlement will go into the state's general fund, Connolly said. Drexel originally offered Massachusetts $275,000, Connolly said, but the state held out for more. ``Their record settlement makes clear Massachusetts' firm commitment to enforce the law and combat fraud,'' Connolly said, adding lower amount was ``simply not adequate compensation.'' Settling with the states relieves the firm of possible litigation, and frees state regulators from having to investigate the firm's trading activities from 1984 to 1986, when the SEC alleged the fraud occurred. It also generally preserves the firm's ability to underwrite securities and do other business in the states. Most states can revoke a company's right to do business if the firm is convicted or admits to committing a felony. Drexel abandoned the retail brokerage business last year. In Massachusetts, the agreement includes a stipulation that Drexel must not solicit any new retail trade without first notifying the state Securities Division and demonstrating compliance procedures are in place. The firm also cannot sponsor private placements to individuals, and must work with the Securities Division to identify any state investors injured by the illegal sale of Drexel junk bonds. Victims would be entitled to place claims with the $350 million compensation fund Drexel established. In addition, Drexel must hire an independent consultant to scrutinize company policies and submit compliance reports; hire an ombudsman to receive and investigate complaints; finance annual audits by the state Securities Division and establish an oversight committee to review its internal procedures. Connolly said he did not know whether any Massachusetts residents were hurt by Drexel sales.

DOC.HEAD: Hilton Board Passes on Buyout Bids, Restructuring Plans; Stock Falls
DOC.TEXT: Hilton Hotels Corp. has hung out a do not disturb sign for the moment, deciding to pass up buyout offers for now while trying to negotiate a better deal or come up with a restructuring plan. The lodging-casino concern, which put itself up for sale last summer, said its directors met Tuesday and Wednesday to consider bids and restructuring proposals. The board adjourned ``without taking definitive action,'' Hilton said Thursday. Its stock, which had traded as high as $115.50 a share last August, tumbled $3.25 to $58.50 on the New York Stock Exchange. Hilton said its board ``instructed its financial advisers and management to further develop the acquisition proposals and the alternate strategies and to report back to the board on these matter within the next several weeks.'' Hilton has effectively been up for sale since settlement of a dispute over the estate of founder Conrad Hilton last May. The company formally invited offers in August for all or part of its lodging and casino operations. At the time, analysts estimated the 48 million shares of Hilton common stock might fetch $120 a share or more. Hilton General Counsel William C. Lebo said expressions of interest had come in from buyers worldwide, particulary in Asia. Since then, the atmosphere for deals, particularly those involving real estate, has soured. Real estate prices softened. The pilots' bid for UAL Corp. fell apart because of inadequate bank financing. Campeau Corp. made bankruptcy filings due to heavy debt. And the junk bond market, a major source of takeover financing, went into a tailspin. The offers for Hilton came in far lower than expected, with apparently no bids from Japanese buyers despite strong previous interest from the Japanese in such ``trophy'' buildings as Hilton's Waldorf Astoria. The Wall Street Journal reported in late December bids were in the $90 a share range, causing the stock price to plunge. It fell further on rumors that bids from Chicago's JMB Realty Corp. and others had been lowered or withdrawn. In addition to a sale, one option available to Hilton would be a recapitalization, in which the company would borrow in order to pay a big dividend to shareholders. Michael Mueller of Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, one of the analysts who had predicted a $120-a-share price for Hilton last summer, said Thursday he believed an outright sale of the company still would bring shareholders about $80 to $85 a share. He said Hilton's statement was a positive sign for shareholders to the extent it indicated a deal might still be made. ``It appears the acquisition offers they have received so far are below what the board would like or the terms are unacceptable, but that negotiations could still produce an acceptable deal,'' he said. The company closed its two-paragraph statement by stressing again that it could give no assurances that the directors would sell, restructure or recapitalize the company at all.

DOC.HEAD: Fans, Foes of Moynihan Plan Woo AARP
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No AARP action likely until late in day; no lead planned; also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Fans and foes of a plan to cut Social Security taxes are wooing the American Association of Retired Persons in hopes of enlisting the clout and credibility of nation's largest senior citizen group. Budget director Richard G. Darman, an ardent opponent of the tax cut, on Thursday appealed to the AARP's legislative council to ``draw upon the enormous respect that you command, that we do not command'' to fight the proposal. Darman's ally, Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn King, later told the group, ``I'm not going to press you, but I do want you to know how important it is that you not leave me out here by myself, that you not cop out of this debate.'' ``If you've got something to say on it, please say it loud and clear.'' At issue is a proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to roll back the Social Security tax increase that took effect Jan. 1 and further reduce the levy next year. A principal aim of the plan is to prevent the government from using surplus Social Security taxes to make the overall federal deficit appear smaller. Advocacy groups for the elderly generally have welcomed the attention Moynihan's proposal is focusing on the need to protect the Social Security trust funds. But they have been wary of his tax-cut plan, voicing fears about its potential effects on benefits and on the financial soundness of the system. Mrs. King's declaration that Congress should ``keep your hands off Social Security'' drew warm applause from the AARP audience. Moynihan, widely respected as a leading advocate for Social Security, visited the AARP's legislative conference earlier this week in an effort to enlist their support. He told council members, ``how you decide will have great consequence. It will make a difference.'' He tried to assure the group his plan would pose ``no risk to benefits at any time'' and was needed to keep the trust funds from being misused. Moynihan was accompanied by Robert Myers, a former chief actuary of the Social Security Administration, who told the group the senator's plan would help keep the giant retirement system on sound financial ground. The AARP's 38-member legislative council was expected to forward its Social Security policy recommendations Friday to the group's executive committee, which sets policy for the organization of 31 million members. AARP's council received the arguments from both sides of the Social Security issue politely, and members expressed personal opinions on both sides of the issue. Dennis Crites, a council member from Norman, Okla., said Moynihan's plan drew attention to the budget problems, but ``if it develops a life of its own, it may be damaging.'' Council member Lou Schwartz of Teaneck, N.J., said he liked the plan because it would ``lower the taxes on those who can least afford to pay it and open the door to have the people that can afford to pay it pay it.''

DOC.HEAD: Weyerhaeuser Earnings Fall After Restructuring Charge
DOC.TEXT: Weyerhaeuser Co. reported it lost $128.7 million in the fourth quarter after running up $461 million in restructuring costs before taxes. The wood products company said Thursday the loss for the quarter ended Dec. 31 amounted to 65 cents per share on sales of $2.6 billion. That compared with a profit of $155.3 million or 73 cents a share on sales of $2.4 billion for the same period of 1988. For the year, Weyerhaeuser earned $341.1 million or $1.56 a share on sales of $10.1 billion, compared with profits of $565.6 million or $2.68 a share on sales of $9.3 billion in 1988. Full-year results reflected $497 million in restructuring costs. During the last half of 1989, the company sold its milk carton, gypsum wallboard, most of its hardwood paneling and its nursery products businesses for a pretax gain of $47 million. The company said Thursday the restructuring charges were due principally to the closure or modification of some forest products facilities and other businesses; a scaling down of real estate operations; changes in operations of its Westwood Shipping Lines, personal care products and containerboard packaging businesses and the planned sale of Weyerhaeuser's savings and loan business. George Weyerhaeuser, chairman and chief executive officer, said the restructure charge will have no adverse effect on the company's financial strength, but rather improves the company's competitiveness. Weyerhaeuser said weakness in fine paper markets and high costs for maintenance in pulp and paper operations in the fourth quarter were partially offset by strong export markets and a runup in structural panel prices in October and November.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Rate Holds Steady at 5.3 Percent in January
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4 grafs after 6th graf pvs, Factory jobs ... to UPDATE with analyst's comment, Michigan jobless rate; picks up 7th graf pvs, However, the...
DOC.TEXT: The nation's unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent in January as the economy began the new year by producing 275,000 new jobs, the government said today. It was the eighth consecutive month with no change in the unemployment level. But the Labor Department said the strong job growth figures might be overstated because warm January weather that followed a bitter cold December made it tough to seasonally adjust job totals for construction and other industries affected by weather. Delays in the reporting of post-Christmas layoffs in retail trade also may have skewed the numbers. The manufacturing slump added to the overall slowdown in the nation's economy last year, and today's report _ the first comprehensive look at economic activity in 1990 _ indicated that the sector's lackluster performance is continuing this year. Factory jobs dropped 112,000 last month, with 90,000 of the losses suffered by the struggling auto industry. It was the 10th straight month manufacturing jobs declined. Still, analysts saw the economy's ability to absorb those declines without a hike in the jobless rate as an encouraging sign. ``The auto industry has taken a really big hit, but the rest of the economy is marching along, and has virtually swallowed up the manufacturing losses,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. ``It certainly indicates that the economy is weathering the storm. It has favorable implications for later on,'' Dederick said. Manufacturing losses were especially felt in Michigan, where the jobless rate jumped to 8.4 percent in January, up from 7.2 percent in December. That was the largest unemployment increase in the 11 large industrial states surveyed by the government. However, the government said many of the laid-off auto workers have been recalled since the survey of business establishments last month to gauge job growth. Construction employers reported a gain of 104,000 jobs during last month's mild weather after a 50,000-job loss during December. Mining industries, which includes oil drilling, added 1,000 jobs. Meanwhile, the service-producing industries, which carried the economy last year, continued to demonstrate healthy gains this year. Those industries reported 284,000 new jobs, with 48,000 of them created in health services. Other industries of the service sector posting large gains were transportation, with 27,000 new jobs; wholesale trade, 24,00 new jobs; retail trade, 127,000. The last figure, though, is likely overstated because of problems factoring in seasonal adjustments after Christmas. Average hourly earnings, sometimes an advanced warning of inflationary pressures on the economy, were up just 0.1 percent in January to $9.84. The average work week for production and non-supervisory workers edged up 0.1 hour last month to 34.6 hours, but in manufacturing, the average work week was unchanged at 40.7 hours. The government said that the civilian labor force, the number of people with jobs or actively seeking employment, declined by 149,000 last month to 124 million. The number of Americans with jobs fell by 25,000 to 117.8 million. There were few major shifts in the jobless rate among major demographic groups last month. The biggest change among Hispanics, where unemployment fell from 8.5 percent in December to 7.1 percent in January. The rates among other groups were: _Adult white men, 4.0 percent, up from 3.9 percent in December. _Adult white women, 4.0 percent, down from 4.1 percent. _White teen-agers, 12.4 percent, up from 11.9 percent. _All blacks, 11.3 percent, down from 11.8 percent. _Adult black men, 11.2 percent, up from 10.8 percent. _Adult black women, 9.2 percent, down from 10.0 percent. _Black teen-agers, 26.7 percent, down from 30.7 percent. In a separate calculation of unemployment that counts members of the armed services stationed in the UnIted States, the January jobless rate was 5.2 percent, down from 5.3 percent in December.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Inch Lower
DOC.TEXT: Most grain and soybean futures prices slipped quietly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, extending the modest declines posted in the previous session. DOC.HEAD: Roche Invests $2.1 Billion, Is Biggest Genentech Shareholder
DOC.TEXT: Roche Holding Ltd., a large Swiss health care company, on Friday announced an agreement to invest $2.1 billion in Genentech Inc., making it the largest shareholder of the biotechnology company. Under the agreement, Roche will invest $492 million in Genentech and buy half its stock for $36 a share, 65 percent higher than Thursday's closing stock price. After the transaction, Roche will own 60 percent of the 112 million shares outstanding. However, both companies emphasized that Genentech will remain a publicly traded company. Genentech's board of directors on Friday approved the agreement, which will result in Genentech shareholders receiving $36 a share in cash for half their shares. The rest of Genentech's outstanding shares will be converted into new redeemable common stock, but it will be redeemable at Roche's option. Roche will have the right to exercise its option, for all of Genentech's outstanding shares, at $38 a share before Dec. 31, 1990, and at $39 a share from Jan. 1, 1991 to March 31, 1991. After that, the price becomes $40 a share and goes up by $1.25 a share every quarter to $60 a share on April 1, 1995. The redemption right expires on June 30, 1995. Two weeks ago, Genentech, a leader in the biotechnology field, reported a complete turnaround in fourth-quarter earnings, posting a $15 million profit after losing the same amount in 1988. For 1989, Genentech posted net income of $44 million, or 51 cents a share. The company, based in South San Francisco, said sales in the fourth quarter of its heart drug Activase jumped 63 percent to $56.7 million. Genentech also markets a human growth hormone sold under the brand name of Protrofin, whose sales rose to $34.3 million in the fourth quarter. ``Roche's $2.1 billion total investment will be best served if Genentech continues to operate in the manner that led to its impressive success in such a short time,'' said Fritz Gerber, chairman and chief executive officer of Roche, in a statement. Roche, based in Basle, Switzerland, has worldwide sales of $6.5 billion, with facilities in 52 countries. Roche has done business in the United States since 1905. The transaction is structured as a merger and will be put before Genentech shareholders for approval at a planned April meeting.

DOC.HEAD: China, Chicago Board Of Trade Agree On Futures Markets Cooperation
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Board of Trade signed a memo of understanding Friday to assist China's preparations in establishing what would be the socialist world's first agricultural futures market. Under the memo signed with the Research Institute of Commmerce, a division of the Commerce Ministry, the Board of Trade would provide educational assistance on futures trading. In turn, the ministry agreed to introduce Chinese agricultural enterprises to the Board of Trade _ the world's largest futures exchange _ and the China National Cereals Trade Corporation will prepare to participate in futures trading in Chicago. ``In China approximately 65 million tons of agricultural commodities circulate in the free market each year and are therefore subject to price risk,'' said William D. Grossman, vice president and managing director of the Board of Trade's Asia-Pacific office in Tokyo. ``As a result, the conditions are ripe to learn about futures trading.'' Futures are agreements to buy or sell a product _ such as agricultural commodities like rice, wheat or frozen concentrated orange juice _ at a set price on a specific future date. Because the seller is guaranteed that price regardless of subsequent market fluctuations, producers frequently use the futures market to hedge the investment in their crop. Speculators also use futures to bet on price movements. Most of the 400 million tons of grain Chinese farmers produce annually is contracted to the state at a set price. However, after meeting their contracts farmers are allowed to sell any excess produce on the free markets. China's constant problems with shortages and gluts _ an aspect of central planning _ and poor regulation of the free markets have led to wild fluctuations in market prices, worsening supply-demand imbalances. In early 1988, when reformers still held the balance of power in Beijing, plans were announced to set up experimental futures markets in several Chinese cities. But at the end of 1988, when conservatives exerted control over the overheated economy, the government postponed plans for the futures market. Grossman said he had been assured by Commerce Minister Hu Ping that establishment of the markets had been delayed due to inadequate preparation and resources, not for ideological reasons. In the past, China branded futures markets as a form of capitalist speculation. The nation's current conservative leaders have stressed that market forces always will play a secondary role in the state-run economy. Grossman said in an interview that the first market, confined to wheat trading in the central China city of Zhengzhou, was ready for final approval last spring but was again ``put in the bottom of the in-box'' following the political turmoil that climaxed with the bloody military crackdown against the pro-democracy movement last June. He said the Zhengzhou market could be opened in time for the winter wheat harvest in May or June. Zhang Qipan, director of the Research Institute of Commerce, was less optimistic, saying the market still was in the planning stage and could open this year. ``This is an experiment. If it succeeds, then it's possible we might do the same thing in a few other places,'' Zhang said. ``Right now we still don't have the right conditions for a futures market.'' Grossman said the Zhengzhou market will not be a true futures market, where trading is done with standardized contracts of large set volumes. Instead, it will be more of an informal cash wholesaling market. Individual farmers will not participate and speculation will be prohibited, he said. Some 20 to 30 organizations will take part in daily auctions, with grain trading corporations and feed mills selling to large food processors and distributors. The Board of Trade will have only an advisory role and will play no part in operating the market. In return, the board will be introduced to potential Chinese traders for the Chicago market. ``We are the world's largest futures exchange market,'' Grossman said. ``We have a vested interest in seeing such markets develop properly around the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Jefferson Avenue Workers Say Farewell to Old Plant
DOC.TEXT: Autoworkers, some with more than a quarter-century of work at Chrysler Corp.'s Jefferson Avenue factory, drifted out of the old assembly plant Friday as it shut down after producing 8.3 million cars. Production of Chrysler's Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon ended Friday morning, when a gray Omni with a gray interior and a manual transmission rolled off the assembly line. Some of the 1,700 workers being laid off indefinitely hoped they would go back to work in late 1991 at the company's Jefferson North plant, being built next to the closed factory. Shortly after the last car rolled off the line, Ralph Winchester of Warren, Mich., who worked in the final inspection portion of the plant, walked out of the factory and into a gray, snowy morning. ``I walked around a little bit,'' he said, and thought about his 25 years at the Jefferson Avenue plant, one of the industry's oldest. Winchester said he hoped he would be recalled when training begins for Jefferson North, which is to begin producing a sport-utility vehicle in late 1992. ``I didn't get any guarantees,'' he said. Winchester, like others, will head to the unemployment line instead of the assembly line Monday. ``I'm just going to get settled and see what happens,'' he said as he crossed the six lanes of Jefferson Avenue, which splits the 83-year-old plant in two. Buildings on both sides of the street will be demolished, and Chrysler will incorporate the land on the north side of Jefferson into the new plant. The company hasn't decided what it will do with more than 100 acres on the south side of Jefferson. Another worker, Henry Anderson of Detroit, also closed out 25 years of working for Chrysler. He was laid off once before, when the company's Dodge Main assembly plant in Hamtramck, Mich., was shut down in January 1980. He said he's had enough. ``I'm going to school for robotics and TV and radio repair,'' Anderson said. The laid off workers will be eligible to draw from a variety of funds which could bring benefits while on layoff to as much as 95 percent of their straight-time pay while they were working. Officials of United Auto Workers union Local 7, which represents the Jefferson Avenue workers, doubt if the funds will be healthy enough to maintain that level by the time retraining for Jefferson North begins. They said layoffs the automaker already has announced for later this year will boost the number of eligible people _ those on indefinite layoff _ drawing against the funds. Between now and the end of March, Chrysler will lay off indefinitely nearly 6,000 workers. Jefferson Avenue is the second plant Chrysler has shut down since 1988, but it won't be the last this year. On Thursday, the company announced it would close its St. Louis car plant in mid-September. That closing will bring to seven the number of assembly plants Chrysler and General Motors Corp. will have closed in three years. Ford Motor Co., meantime, has avoided closing plants by keeping its car and truck sales healthy and eliminating large amounts of overtime it used instead of opening a new plant. While the domestic automakers slash their production, Japanese companies have been adding to their U.S. production in plants they own either wholly or partly. Since 1988, Mitsubishi Motors Corp. and Chrysler opened a plant in Normal, Ill., Toyota Motor Corp. began production at its own plant in Georgetown, Ky., Subaru of America and Isuzu Motors Ltd. opened a joint car and truck manufacturing plant in Lafayette, Ind., and Honda Motor Co. Ltd. opened its second U.S. plant in East Liberty, Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Man Arrested in Alleged Computer Extortion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to RECAST, moving up AIDS reference, and CORRECT spelling of `unleashing;' SUBS last graf to add that disk also received in California, other areas; Also moved on general newswires
DOC.TEXT: A zoologist accused of unleashing a computer virus that crippled computers in England two months ago with a fake information disk on AIDS was arrested on a fugitive warrant in Ohio. Joseph W. Popp was arrested Thursday and is being held on a federal fugitive warrant. He is charged in warrants issued by Scotland Yard in London with blackmail and extortion. During an initial court appearance here today, Popp, 39, told U.S. Magistrate Joseph W. Bartunek that he is under a psychiatrist's care and must take drugs for a mental condition. Bartunek said he would schedule another hearing after two psychiatrists evaluate Popp to see whether he is competent to face further proceedings. A date was not set. Popp, a zoologist who worked for the World Health Organization, is from Willowick, about 10 miles east of Cleveland, said defense attorney John P. Kilroy. It was not immediately clear whether Popp is still affiliated with the organization. The warrant alleges Popp distributed about 20,000 computer-crippling disks from London around Dec. 11. The disks were labeled ``AIDS Information Introductory Diskette.'' The U.S. attorney's office in Cleveland said the disks had information on acquired immune deficiency syndrome for use by hospitals, researchers and others. But authorities said the disks, when inserted into personal computers by unsuspecting recipients, halted accessibility to any other information in the computer. At the end of the program, the disk asked the computer user for a leasing fee of up to $378, then printed an invoice with a Panama address where money was to be sent, federal prosecutors said. Computer owners were told that the rogue program they had inserted in their computer would stop the machine from functioning unless the money was paid. At the time the diskette began causing problems in early December, authorities in London said it had been received by users in Norway, Sweden, Belgium, Denmark and California as well as Britain. Scotland Yard said at least 10 British computers were affected. Later in the month, a company in Bahrain, in the Midle East, also reported getting one of the disks but said it was discovered before it did any damage.

DOC.HEAD: West German Finance Chief Suggests One Currency; Soviets Soften Stand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Dresden mayor calling for convertible currency, warning of collapse; picks up 5th graf pvs bg'ng, Untold thousands ...; Also moved on general newswires
DOC.TEXT: The West German finance chief on Friday suggested circulating his country's currency in East Germany, and the Soviet Union showed its greatest tolerance yet for unifying the states. The idea of the prosperous West merging with the impoverished East continued to shape the debate over how to rescue East Germany from economic collapse and political paralysis. East Germans have brought their economy to a standstill with strikes, protests and spiraling absenteeism as the country careens toward its first free elections March 18. Dresden Mayor Wolfgang Berghofer, an influential and popular reformer, said complete collapse is imminent unless workers are given a convertible currency this year and the steady flood of people leaving the country is stopped. ``My fear is that in the next few days and weeks an exodus of hundreds of thousands will develop, and if this situation is not quickly counteracted it will lead to political and economic collapse,'' Berghofer said. Premier Hans Modrow also acknowledged this week the nation is nearing collapse. Untold thousands are working illegally in West Berlin, earning West German marks that have at least 10 times the buying power of the meager Ostmarks they earn in their jobs in the East. West German officials have previously proposed plans for eventual convertibility of the Ostmark, but Finance Minister Theo Waigel suggested Friday that a more immediate and effective measure might be wholesale introduction of the Deutschmark. He said it would give the population ``prospects for the future that are immediately convincing.'' A common currency is one of the steps toward unification of Germany proposed by both Modrow and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. A Soviet government spokesman visiting East Berlin acknowledged the situation in East Germany is extremely sensitive. Yuri Gremitskikh said strikes and demonstrations had cut deeply into industrial performance. Gremitskikh also confirmed that the Kremlin has had to accept reunification as an inevitable consequence of the democratic revolutions sweeping Eastern Europe. He repeated the Soviet view that a reunified Germany should not belong to either the NATO or Warsaw Pact alliances, but declined to say whether the Soviet Union would veto reunification if West German territory retained NATO forces. The Soviet Union, the United States, France and Britain retain control of Berlin under their status as the four victorious powers from World War II. They essentially would have to approve unification to allow Berlin to be part of a single German state. In Moscow, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze proposed Friday that Europeans, Americans and Canadians vote on reunification because they suffered so much in World War II. The Soviet envoy gave the Kremlin's strongest endorsement yet to reunification, but repeated conditions that this must not destabilize Europe. German unity should be decided in a referendum among Europeans, Canadians and Americans or ``through wide parliamentary discussions,'' Shevardnadze said in the interview carried by the official news agency Tass. Communist Party leader Gregor Gysi flew to Moscow on Friday for talks with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on East Germany. Kohl and Modrow plan their second summit on Feb. 13-14 in Bonn, but the two arranged to meet privately Saturday while in Davos, Switzerland, for an international economics conference. West German government spokesman Dieter Vogel told reporters in Bonn that the talks would focus on ways West Germany can aid East Germans until the elections. Modrow on Thursday proposed a plan for reunifying Germany and called for talks with West Germany to work out details. Kohl rejected the East German premier's condition that a united Germany be militarily neutral, but said he would be willing to enter negotiations after the vote. Uniting the Germanys has become likely since a pro-democracy revolution ousted hard-line East German leader Erich Honecker on Oct. 18, leading to the opening of the Berlin Wall and installation of a reform-oriented coalition government.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Futures Rise On News Of China Bid
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices rose moderately Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade in response to news late in the session that China was seeking to buy 300,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. Corn futures closed slightly lower while the oat and soybean markets ended mixed. The China bid was not unexpected since the Chinese had 300,000 metric tons of wheat left to buy under an allocation extended by the Agriculture Department last year. But a recent slowdown in export sales of wheat has contributed to a price drop of more than 35 cents a bushel since mid-December, so any sign of stronger demand is likely to rally the market, analysts said. Katherina Zimmer, grains analyst with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Inc., said the bid's proposed delivery dates _ in April and May _ were earlier than expected but she dismissed Friday's rally as insignificant relative to the recent decline. ``It's nothing,'' she said. At the close of trading, wheat futures were 1 cent to 4\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.79{ a bushel; corn futures were } cent to 2{ cents lower with March at $2.36} a bushel; oats were { cent lower to { cent higher with March at $1.35{ a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents lower to { cent higher with March at $5.60\ a bushel.
