DOC.HEAD: Toy Company Makes Deal With New Kids On The Block
DOC.TEXT: If a Michael Jackson doll can do well, then can dolls modeled after the five-man rock group New Kids on The Block do five times as well? Toymaker Hasbro Inc. should find out soon enough as it launches a line under an agreement with the New Kids, ranked the hottest pop group of 1989 by Billboard magazine. Wayne Charness, a Hasbro spokesman, confirmed Friday that a deal had been reached between the toy company and the group, but said details would be announced at a news conference Monday at New York's Hard Rock Cafe. The new line will include dolls and items related to their music, said Win Wilford, an executive vice president of Dick Scott Entertainment, which manages the group. It's been years since a major toy company made a doll based on a pop musician, said Paul Valentine, a toy industry analyst for Standard & Poor's Corp. Valentine said that plans for a New Kids product sound ``like a terrific idea to me.'' The Michael Jackson doll was launched by LJN Toys Ltd. of New York five years ago and did ``exceptionally well for a short period of time,'' he said. An LJN spokesman, who asked that his name not be used, said the company sold ``at least a couple of hundred thousand'' Jackson dolls. Although the doll was on the market for less than a year, ``It was considered a very successful product,'' he said. ``These things do have a lifespan, but with proper marketing within the lifespan it can be very lucrative,'' he said. Hasbro has a solid product line, including the G.I. Joe action figure, Tinkertoys, the Donald Trump board game and Cabbage Patch Kids. It even launched some dolls fashioned after the characters from the movie ``Who Framed Roger Rabbit?'' ``The rule of thumb in the industry was that toys based on motion pictures or personalities tended to be short-lived. But the rules have been broken so often that everyone is scrambling to find out what works,'' Valentine said Thursday. An animated Saturday-morning cartoon series based on the New Kids is being developed for network television, said Wilford. The New Kids, whose members range in age from 17 to 20, are popular among adolescent girls and also their parents because of their anti-drug message. ``The parents feel comfortable,'' he said, because of ``the clean image.'' The group was assembled in 1984 by Boston producer Maurice Starr and started its first major tour last summer as an opening act for former teen-queen Tiffany. By the end of the trip, Tiffany was opening for the New Kids. Some have criticized the group because none of its members play instruments _ but others have compared it to The Jackson 5 and the Monkees. ``Everything is turning out wonderful about these kids,'' said Wilford, ``the concerts are sold out, the records are selling in millions ...'' The Kids, who have sold about 11.5 million albums in three releases, including the popular Hangin` Tough album, have a new one due out in March, said Wilford. A European tour starts in April.

Stock prices, after recovering from an early slump, closed higher following a report on January employment that helped ease worries that the economy may be moving into a recession. The Labor Department reported today that the nation's unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent last month while 275,000 new non-farm payroll jobs were created. The number of new jobs was substantially higher than market expectations of about 160,000 jobs, analysts said. But the government said the strong job growth figures might be exaggerated because warm January weather that followed a bitter cold December made it tough to seasonally adjust job totals for construction and other industries affected by weather. Delays in the reporting of post-Christmas layoffs in retail trade also may have skewed the numbers, the government said. The market first reacted negatively to the jobs data in response to a slide in the bond market but quickly bounced back after digesting the data. Analysts said the data, while suggesting the economy continued to slow in January as the manufacturing sector slumped, also indicated that the economy is not headed for a recession and may be breaking out of its recent doldrums. Traders said renewed merger activity also helped revive takeover stocks. In particular, drug and biotechnology stocks got a boost from news that Roche Holdings would acquire a majority stake in Genentech Corp. ``We're having a rally from an oversold condition,'' said Charles Jensen, chief technical analyst for MKI Securities Corp. ``It's a long overdue rally.'' Late in the day, the market retraced some of its gains as investors remained cautious ahead of next week's $30 billion Treasury refunding, which could provide a better clue about the prospects for interest rates.

DOC.HEAD: Former Federated Exec Returns as Federated-Allied Chairman
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Retailing executive Allen I. Questrom on Friday was appointed chairman and chief executive officer of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. to lead them through bankruptcy court-supervised reorganizations. The appointment was announced on the day that newly formed committees of unsecured creditors for Federated and Allied conducted their first organizational meetings in Cincinnati, headquarters of the two companies owned by Toronto-based Campeau Corp. Federated and Allied filed Jan. 15 for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, listing $7.7 billion in debts. Questrom, 49, a former Federated vice chairman who once headed the company's Rich's and Bullock's department store divisions, has been serving as president and chief executive officer of the Dallas-based Nieman-Marcus department store group since September 1988. Questrom assumes his new position immediately, said G. William Miller, chairman and chief executive officer of Federated Stores Inc., the holding company for Federated and Allied. Under terms of a contract filed with the bankruptcy court, Questrom would receive $1.2 million in salary for a term of five years. The contract also would offer annual ``value-added'' bonuses beginning at $2 million in 1990. Questrom was said to be in Dallas on Friday, but did not return a telephone call. He is to arrive in Cincinnati next week, company spokeswoman Carol Sanger said. He succeeds John W. Burden III, who resigned effective Wednesday. Questrom rejoins James M. Zimmerman, president and chief operating officer of Federated and Allied. The two men worked together when Questrom was chairman and Zimmerman was president of Federated's Atlanta-based Rich's division from 1980 to 1984. Under their leadership, Rich's more than tripled its earnings to become Federated's most profitable division by 1984, said Miller, who took his job overseeing Federated and Allied on Jan. 16. ``This kind of dynamism is not an everyday occurrence,'' Miller said. ``It makes the reassembly of this outstanding management team at this point in Federated and Allied's history all the more significant and important as we look toward optimizing the performance of our department stores during this period. That is my single highest objective, and it is one I know Allen shares.''

DOC.HEAD: Bank of Boston Announces Overhaul, Retirement of Vice President
With AM-Bank of New England, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Bank of Boston Corp., the biggest bank in New England, is streamlining its structure and operations as part of a plan to expand in the region and upgrade its services worldwide, Chairman Ira Stepanian announced Friday. The announcement was timed with another one: the retirement of Clark W. Miller, hed of the bank's New England Banking Group and chief architect of the bank's reorganization. The moves Miller orchestrated include consolidating the corporation's five business groups into three. Miller had told the bank's management more than two years ago that he planned to retire on turning 60, which occurred last week. His departure after 27 years at the bank is effective March 31. The changes at Bank of Boston, the 15th-largest bank in the country with assets of $39 billion at the close of 1989, come at a time when the New England banking industry is suffering financial troubles and shaking up executive offices. Four senior officials of the Bank of New England were let go earlier this week. But Bank of Boston spokesman Wayne Taylor said Friday that a reorganization at his institution was called for ever since the bank started acquiring other New England banks in 1984. ``This is a logical strategy,'' Taylor said. ``It does not have anything to do with problems in the New England economy or real estate development. This was a long-term plan.'' The sagging economy and real estate market have been blamed in part for the banking industry's difficulties. Customers, whether commercial or retail, will see no change as a result of the restructuring other than more uniformity and availability of bank products and services, such as the opening of more branches, Taylor said. Bank of Boston's major banking subsidiaries are First National Bank of Boston, Casco Northern Bank, Bank of Boston Connecticut, Rhode Island Hospital Trust National Bank and Bank of Vermont. The bank posted a small gain in the fourth quarter after selling its credit card business to Chase Manhattan. Stepanian, in a prepared statement, described the corporate overhaul as ``a realignment of our organizational structure designed to achieve greater strategic focus, marketing synergy, operational efficiency and internal coordination. ``This organizational realignment will, in turn, maximize the earnings power and value of our enterprise to stockholders,'' said Stepanian, who also is the company's chief operating officer. The restructuring will establish three banking groups: New England Banking, National Banking and Global Banking. Within those three will be the restructured operations of the Real Estate and Treasury-Banking Services groups. Peter C. Read, most recently head of the Treasury-Banking Services Group, will succeed Miller. The bank outlined the restructuring as follows: New England Banking Group _ Under a plan to achieve regional integration begun by Miller and now to be overseen by Read, this group will reorganize its management and operations to establish them region-wide in four areas: retail banking, commercial banking, personal trust and private banking, and external affairs and marketing. National Banking Group _ This section will focus on relationship banking and on serving U.S. businesses. It will now include the commercial lending operation handled by the former Real Estate Group. This group will also now contain the bank's Leasing Division, which will be transferred from the former Treasury-Banking Services Group. T. Lincoln Morison Jr., an executive vice president, will continue to manage this group. Global Banking Group _ Kevin J. Mulvaney, an executive vice president, will continue to run this group, formerly the International Banking Group. Under the restructuring, the group will broaden the scope of its operations to provide more banking products and services to its customers worldwide. One aim is to achieve more geographically balanced earnings through customer-driven businesses. Edwin B. Morris was fired last fall as Bank of Boston's head of real estate lending after the bank announced a $125 million third-quarter loss, largely because of bad loans for real estate development.

DOC.HEAD: After Phelan, Stock Exchange Faces More Change
DOC.TEXT: John J. Phelan Jr. led the New York Stock Exchange into the computer age. His successor may have to take it into further dimensions. When Phelan retires as chairman of the nation's largest exchange at the end of the year, the NYSE will face issues experts believe threaten to remold the way the stock market operates by the year 2000. Among its greatest challenges are a relentless growth in technology, including computer-assisted trading techniques and trading floor automation. The 198-year-old exchange also must compete in interlocked global markets, an around-the-clock battle that threatens to siphon away business and may force the NYSE to change its 9:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. trading day. ``We're potentially looking at a very different industry,'' Eric K. Clemons, an associate professor at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, said Friday. ``The challenge to John's successor will be preserving all the things the exchange does well while minimizing the disruption to the various communities he serves,'' Clemons said. In his six years as Big Board chairman and chief executive, the mild-mannered Phelan has balanced the concerns of floor brokers and specialists, small investors, big institutions and companies whose stocks are traded there. Phelan foresaw dynamic growth in trading volume, to 165 million shares a day last year from 18.6 million when he became vice chairman in 1975, and the potential for disaster that came with it. And he skillfully persuaded floor professionals that installing computers wouldn't destroy their business. In fact, Phelan cites modernizing the trading system as his greatest achievement because it allowed the exchange to stay open and handle 600 million shares during the Oct. 19, 1987, market crash, when some fully automated markets closed down. ``With competition and telecommunications, the impact of technology has not yet fully had its effect on the New York Stock Exchange,'' said Hans Stoll, a finance professor at Vanderbilt University's graduate management school in Nashville, Tenn. Experts believe a calming presence and diplomatic talent like Phelan's is needed to prevent bad blood from developing over how the Big Board responds to change. ``You do have a floor and the floor has a strong opinion and a strong voice. But there are other constituencies,'' said John W. Bachmann, a managing partner with Edward D. Jones & Co., the St. Louis-based retail brokerage. ``There's going to be a need to balance the interest of each of those groups.'' As the Tokyo Stock Exchange continues to draw attention as a financial center and Europe looms as a greater power following the Common Market's planned economic integration in 1992, many experts say the NYSE could lose business overseas. Domestic markets offering after-hours trading via computer also pose a threat. Under the existing system, more than 80 percent of trades are routed to the NYSE floor electronically and the rest manually by brokers working a battery of telephones. Specialists set trading prices and execute the orders to ensure a fair and orderly market. Critics of the specialist system maintain that all trades one day will be handled automatically and the stock exchange floor will become a computer room that may eventually leave its lower Manhattan home on Wall Street. Proponents say further adaptation to computerization is inevitable, but human beings will remain essential to keeping the U.S. markets stable. ``You need all the hardware and software possible but it's still going to be a market determined by men and women,'' said Robert N. Downey, a managing partner at Goldman, Sachs & Co. and chairman of the Securities Industry Association. While Phelan also has tried to balance pro- and anti-program trading forces, his successor may be forced to regulate _ if the government doesn't do it first _ what forms of computer-driven trading are permitted. One possible reform is ``real-time'' reporting of program trading activity to give market players an idea of how much program trading, which has been accused of exaggerating volatility, is taking place. For example, such activity might be reported every five minutes. At a news conference Thursday announcing his retirement, Phelan showed his even-handed style in discussing program trading. ``You probably do more by cooperation than by fiat or somebody passing a law or regulation about it,'' he said. He also said markets need to accommodate both small investors and institutions. Securities Industry Association figures show that institutions accounted for 76 percent of NYSE volume from January-November 1989, but experts say the number of retail transactions remains larger. ``There are people on both sides who want to exclude other people from the marketplace,'' Phelan said. ``You cannot run a marketplace to the exclusion of any one element.''

DOC.HEAD: Legislators Hit Big Medigap Price Increases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress criticized the insurance industry Friday for socking the elderly with huge price increases for ``medigap'' health policies and said tougher regulation may be needed to curb price and marketing abuses. ``Millions of seniors spend billions of dollars each year on medigap policies and many are being ripped off and cheated out of their limited fixed incomes,'' Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., told a Senate Finance subcommittee. ``This medigap mess has flourished because federal regulation is a voluntary, unenforceable patchwork of legal mumbo-jumbo, more loophole than law.'' Private insurance companies sell medigap policies to the elderly to bridge gaps in their coverage from Medicare. Premiums are rising sharply this year; insurers say the increases are justified because health-care costs are rising and because benefits must be provided that previously were offered under Medicare's catastrophic-care program. But several members of the Senate subcommittee on Medicare and long-term care questioned whether this year's big rate increases are warranted, even with rising costs and the repeal of the catastrophic-care program. ``We simply cannot tolerate the sale of medigap insurance policies that are over-priced or under-valued, especially at these prices,'' said the subcommittee chairman, Sen. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va. The legislators also complained that marketing abuses continue in the medigap industry, with high-pressure salesmen selling duplicative and unnecessary policies to frightened old people. ``We continue to find people with five to 10 medigap policies that are over-priced, over-sold and seldom used,'' said Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark. Janet Shikles of the General Accounting Office told the panel that surveys found 1990 medigap rate increases averaging 20 percent among 20 commercial insurers and averaging 29 percent for individual policies sold by Blue Cross and Blue Shield. Rate increases ranged from 5 percent to 52 percent. Shikles said many insurance companies fail to meet even minimum targets, established by federal law and enforced by the states, on what percentage of premium dollars collected should be paid out in benefits. Many companies pay out benefits that equal less than 60 percent of what they collect in premiums, she said. Among Blue Cross-Blue Shield plans, however, 98 percent met or surpassed the loss-ratio standards, she said. ``We are continuing to find that policies are being marketed to the elderly that are not meeting the minimum standards, and these are not difficult standards to meet,'' Shikles said. ``Many of the rate increases seem very high.'' However, Earl R. Pomeroy, president of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners and insurance commissioner for North Dakota, said state regulators have been closely monitoring rate increases and believe most are ``supported by the costs of the benefits that the insurance companies must restore ... and prior claims experience.'' Linda Jenckes, vice president of the Health Insurance Association of America, said medigap already is the most highly regulated form of insurance and that no added restrictions are needed. She said recent price increases were justified by the rising costs of health care, the added catastrophic benefits and other factors. Jenckes said occasional abuses in the system are being adequately addressed by state regulators.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Ends Mostly Higher
Precede: BC-LONDON
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mostly higher Friday in light, uneventful trading on world currency markets. Gold prices rose, with gains more pronounced in overseas dealings. On New York's Commodity Exchange, a troy ounce of gold gained 20 cents to close at $418.20. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $418.50 a troy ounce, up 85 cents from late Thursday. The dollar rose following the release of a better-than-expected Labor Department report showing the nation's unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent in January. The government said non-farm payrolls increased by 275,000, but the manufacturing sector lost 112,000 jobs. ``It was a mixed bag,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst at Chicago-based MMS International. ``People who remain bearish on the dollar cite the manufacturing number; people who are bullish look at the payroll gains.'' Traders reason that a steady unemployment rate will keep the Federal Reserve from easing interest rates. High interest rates make U.S. securities more attractive to foreigners, who need dollars to make such investments. Most of the day's activity centered on the dollar and the West German mark, both of which moved in a wide range. When the dollar reached a high against the mark at around midday in New York, ``the market took profits in the dollar and immediately bought marks again,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. ``Every time the dollar goes up (against the mark), people jump right in and buy marks,'' he said. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 144.95 Japanese yen, up 0.45 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 145.35 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 145.50 yen, up marginally from 144.98 yen on Thursday. In London, the British pound was unchanged at $1.6820. The pound also was unchanged in New York, where it finished at $1.6840. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.6830 West German marks, up from 1.6765; 1.4920 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.7160 French francs, up from 5.6940; 1,251.00 Italian lire, up from 1,245.75, and 1.1885 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1866. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.6860 West German marks, up from 1.6805; 1.4964 Swiss francs, down from 1.4975; 5.7360 French francs, up from 5.7085; 1.9010 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8920; 1,252.00 Italian lire, up from 1,248.00, and 1.1884 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1860. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $417.25 a troy ounce from $415.25 late Thursday. In Zurich, Switzerland, the metal rose to a closing bid of $417.75 from $415.60 bid late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $2.96 to close at $415.38. Silver prices also gained. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery closed at $5.307 a troy ounce, up from $5.297 on Thursday. In London the metal traded at a late bid price of $5.29 a troy ounce, up from Thursday's $5.26.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Gasoline Demand Foreseen, Boosting Futures Prices
DOC.TEXT: Expectations of strong gasoline demand early this summer fueled a strong rally in oil futures prices Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. On other commodity markets, copper and precious metal futures rose; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Gasoline futures posted the sharpest gains, settling .83 cent to 1.9 cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at 64.22 cents a gallon; West Texas Intermediate crude oil finished .32 cent to .44 cent higher with March at 23.02 cents gallon; heating oil was .77 cent to 1.52 cents higher with March at 58.26 cents a gallon. Friday's strong rally after modest gains on Thursday suggests the petroleum markets are beginning a new upward push, analysts said. Another sign of a developing bull move was the market's ho-hum reaction to Tuesday's weekly American Petroleum Institute inventory report, which showed larger-than-expected supplies of crude oil and refined products, especially gasoline. ``Sights are getting set further out,'' said Randolph Donney, a research analyst with Elders Futures Inc. in New York. ``People are not really focusing on near-term fundamentals that much.'' Indeed, the strongest gains Friday were in contracts for April and May delivery, indicating that petroleum dealers are locking in supplies for the late spring and early summer, when the vacation season begins and gasoline consumption swells. Strong gasoline demand tends to boost U.S. crude futures prices because West Texas Intermediate crude _ the type traded in New York _ is more easily refined into high-quality gasoline than some other varieties, Donney noted. Copper futures rose sharply on New York's Commodity Exchange amid signs of tightening supplies. The Comex reported a decline of 561 tons in its warehouse stocks of copper from Thursday to Friday, bringing the level down to 6,621, the lowest this year. Warehouse stocks reported weekly by the London Metal Exchange have also been falling recently, and Monday's report is expected to show a further decline of 2,000 to 5,000 tons, analysts said. Demand for copper apparently is picking up after slackening in December. Some buying also may have stemmed from brighter economic perceptions due to the stock market's recent gains and Friday's U.S. unemployment report, which showed no change in the jobless rate. Copper is heavily used in the construction industry, making the market extremely sensitive to economic news. Copper finished 1.9 cents to 2.35 cents higher with February at $1.015 a pound. Gold futures settled 10 cents to 20 cents higher on the Comex with February at $418.20 a troy ounce; silver was 1 cent higher across the board with March at $5.338 a troy ounce. Cattle futures advanced and pork futures retreated on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange ahead of the Agriculture Department's semi-annual cattle inventory report. The report, released after the close of trading, showed a cattle herd of 99.3 million head, unchanged from a year ago. The number was slightly below expections but was not expected to have a significant impact on futures prices. Live cattle settled .15 cent to .57 cent higher with February at 79.57 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .43 cent higher with March at 83.05 cents a pound; live hogs were .35 cent lower to .12 cent higher with February at 48.42 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .32 cent to 1.2 cents lower with February at 49 cents a pound. Wheat futures prices rose moderately on the Chicago Board of Trade in response to news late in the session that China was seeking to buy 300,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. Wheat futures settled 1\ cents to 3} cents higher with March at $3.79 a bushel; corn futures were } cent to 2\ cents lower with March at $2.36} a bushel; oats were unchanged to { cent higher with March at $1.36 a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to { cent higher with March at $5.60\ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: McGraw-Hill Abruptly Closes Its Electronic Business News Service
DOC.TEXT: McGraw-Hill Inc. pulled the plug Friday on its electronic business news services, saying the market for them was developing more slowly than expected. ``In view of the current business climate and the uncertain economic outlook, McGraw-Hill is going to focus its resources on opportunities with an earlier payoff,'' the company said in a statement. The unexpected decision to close its McGraw-Hill News and Standard & Poor's News services at the close of business Friday came only a day after the company reported a fourth-quarter loss of $98.3 million, due mainly to the impact of a corporate restructuring. The company had disclosed in December that it planned to charge $152 million after taxes against its fourth-quarter earnings to reflect a realignment of operations, asset writedowns, the closing of its general book division and creation of a reserve for severance payments associated with the elimination of more than 1,000 jobs. The services were designed to provide an assortment of business, economic an financial news throughout the day in competition with similar services from Dow Jones & Co., Reuters Holdings PLC and others. The securities industry has been slumping in recent months, however, as retail investment activity failed to rebound in the wake of the October 1987 market crash. The announcement of the shutdown came after the close of the stock market. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, McGraw-Hill closed at $55.50 a share, down 87{ cents. The two McGraw-Hill news services employed about 75 people, including nine stationed at foreign offices in Tokyo, London, Frankfurt and Paris. Its domestic offices were in New York, Washgington, D.C., Detroit, Chicago and San Francisco. The company said it would ``make every effort'' to place the staff in other psoitions within McGraw-Hill, which publishes Business Week magazine, has interests in broadcasting and offers a variety of information services for a range of businesses. The company declined to say how much revenue was generated by the two services or how much it had invested in getting them in operation. ``The editors did a fine job of creating an on-line business news service but the market for the product is developing more slowly than anticipated,'' the company said. The McGraw-Hill News service was introduced in September 1987, and was made available directly to corporations and indirectly to other customers through eight database distributors. Standard & Poor's News was announced only last December and was designed for the retail stock brokerage business. The company said in December that it had signed the brokerage Edward D. Jones of St. Louis with 1,450 offices. Company spokeswoman Betsy Russo said the staff of the two news services was notified by management Friday of the plans to close the systems at the end of the business day. She said the company expected no additional writedown would be needed as a result of the shutdown because the fourth-quarter charges provided for additional streamlining that had been undetermined at that point.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Rise
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures rallied Friday, driven by technically motivated buying, with crude oil closing above $23 a barrel. Wholesale home heating oil prices regained all the ground lost in Thursday's session while unleaded gasoline also settled significantly higher. The contract for March delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, rose 32 cents to $23.02 per 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, building on Thursday's increase of 2 cents. Contracts calling for crude delivery during April, May and June posted increases of 44 cents, 44 cents and 43 cents, respectively. The March contract for No. 2 heating oil, which lost 0.82 cent on Thursday, jumped 1.52 cents to 58.26 cents a gallon. The April through June contracts also ended with gains. Among other refined petroleum products traded on the New York Merc, March unleaded gasoline surged 1.52 cents to settle at 64.22 cents a gallon after adding 0.9 cent on Thursday. Later-delivery contracts rose by even bigger amounts. Greg Dreis, a Merrill Lynch & Co. energy specialist, said the rally mainly reflected internal market dynamics, not fundamental developments affecting the supply and demand for the commodities. ``Basically, technical buying was what it was,'' he said. ``There's nothing really major about it.''

DOC.HEAD: China Being Ordered to Sell Interest in Seattle Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing thruout; Also moved on general newswires
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, citing ``credible confidential information,'' on Friday ordered a Chinese-owned corporation to sell its interests in a Seattle aircraft parts company. Bush ordered the divestiture, on national security grounds, of the Mamco Manufacturing Co. of Seattle by the China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corp. In ordering the action, Bush invoked for the first time a provision of a 1988 trade law that gives the president the power to restrict foreign investment in the United States if the nation's security is affected. The president ordered the Chinese government to sell the company because ``continued control of Mamco might threaten to impair the national security,'' a White House statement said. The statement cited ``credible confidential information'' for negating China's 1988 purchase of the Seattle company. Mamco manufactures metal parts for aircraft. Bush's action upheld the recommendation of an inter-agency review panel that the deal be voided. The panel found that the company, which reported $20 million in sales in 1988, was involved with sensitive materials that could have military applications, said officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The president's order requires China to divest itself of Mamco by May 1, uness an extension of up to three months is granted. Bush took the action even though his administration had been moving towards re-establishing contacts with the Beijing government in the aftermath of the Tiananmen Square crackdown last June. Sanctions Bush himself imposed on China in the aftermath of that crackdown bar all military sales to China. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that Bush's action ``is in response to the circumstances of this particular transaction. It does not change our policy, and it is not a precedent for the future with regard to direct investment in the United States from the People's Republic of China or any other country.'' A White House statement said, ``The president's action is based on his finding that there is credible evidence that leads him to believe that the acquistion could threaten the national security of the United States.'' The Chinese corporation is part of the Chinese Ministry of Aereospace Industry. It has business dealings with various U.S. companies ``in several sectors, including commercial aircraft,'' the statement said. Under terms of the trade act, Bush had 15 days to review the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States. The time would have expired at midnight. Bush was given the authority under the law to order the Chinese corporation to cease its U.S. operations and sell its stock in the Seattle company. His decision came a week after Bush narrowly won a congressional vote sustaining his veto of a bill to extend visas of Chinese students in the United States who do not want to return home for fear of persecution. Bush veoted that bill, calling it an infringement on his presidential prerogatives and claiming it was unnecesssary because he had issued an executive order accomplishing the same protection for Chinese students.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Of New England Head Says Turnaround Won't Be Quick
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, Bullock replaced... to CORRECT ranking, add asset total. Picks up 5th graf, Bank of... ^By ALLISON J. PUGH
DOC.TEXT: The acting chairman of Bank of New England, which is trying to rebound from the $1 billion loss projected for 1989, said Friday the bank probably wouldn't turn a profit this year but should come out ahead in the long run. ``We're in a fix-it mode. We're not going to be as big, but we're going to be better,'' said interim Chairman H. Ridgely Bullock, who was named by the board of directors last week. Bullock also told a news conference that the bank continues experiencing deposit outflows sparked by the recent disclosure of the extent of its financial problems, and would have to keep borrowing from the federal government to meet the demands of depositors. Bullock replaced Walter J. Connolly Jr., who was asked to leave in the wake of serious financial problems at the company, which with $29 billion in assets ranks as the nation's 18th largest banking concern. Bank of New England reported its projected $1 billion annual loss on Jan. 20. Fourth-quarter losses were estimated at $1.2 billion, among the biggest quarterly losses ever reported by a bank of its size. The company has attributed much of the bank's problem to bad real estate loans issued in the Northeast, which now total more than $2.5 billion. The bank's capital has plunged below $500 million, or less than 2 percent of the institution's total assets. Bullock said the bank was hit hard by the declines in the real estate market partly because lenders were not cautious enough with developers. ``I think we had drifted away from the real basics of lending,'' Bullock said. ``It's a very tough business and it has to be managed very toughly.'' One of the first tasks for the bank's new management would be to address the hundreds of depositors who have been withdrawing their funds from the bank since it publicly acknowledged the depths of its problems. Bullock declined to specify how many depositors were leaving the bank. Several municipalities, including the city of Boston and several cities and towns in Massachusetts and Connecticut have withdrawn millions of dollars from the ailing institution, officials said. Bullock also said the bank expected the outflow to continue, but assured that the bank was safe for depositors. He confirmed recent reports that the Federal Reserve had lent Bank of New England over $400 million in the week ended Wednesday, a week after it reportedly borrowed up to $475 million. Bullock said the bank expected to continue seeking loans from the Federal Reserve ``for some time'' as it sought to meet the demands of depositors withdrawing their funds from the bank. Bullock said the bank was taking several steps to regain its balance, including the sale of more than $450 million worth of leasing assets and its credit card operations for $820 million. The moves were two in a series of sales planned to net the bank $6 billion, he said. Bullock said he did not expect the bank to make money during the rest of 1990 because of the costs associated with restructuring, management shakeups and the quick pace of selling assets. Bank officials also were looking into the possibility of selling subsidiaries, including Connecticut Bank and Trust and banks in Maine and Rhode Island. No bids had been received yet, Bullock said. ``We want to make sure if we cut a deal that it is one we are pleased with when we close it six months later,'' Bullock said. ``This is not any fire sale.'' Part of what would put the bank on track would be changing its corporate culture, Bullock said. Such changes would include getting rid of personal perks that have often accompanied banking jobs in the past, he said. Major changes also have been made in upper-level management, where five top executives, including Connolly, have left since Jan. 27.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Rally After Jobs Report
DOC.NOTE: EDS: CORRECTS Dow Jones daily rise to 16.44 and closing figure to 2602.70 in 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: The stock market rallied Friday after a government report on January employment boosted investor confidence about the economy and eased fears about a possible recession. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials ended 16.44 points higher at 2,602.70. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by about 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,004 issues up, 495 down and 473 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 164.40 million shares, up from 154.58 million in the previous session. The Labor Department reported that the nation's unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent last month while 275,000 new non-farm payroll jobs were created. The number of new jobs was substantially higher than market expectations of about 160,000 jobs, analysts said. ``Stock investors took the attitude that employment is better than expected which means business is better than expected and the economy is not in a recession,'' said Jack Solomon, equities analyst for Bear Stearns & Co. ``That coming on top of a negative psychological environment it was easy for the market to spring up.'' The market had declined sharply last month, as the Dow industrials lost more than 219 points. But the government said the strong job growth figures might be exaggerated because warm January weather that followed a bitter cold December made it tough to seasonally adjust job totals for construction and other industries affected by weather. Delays in the reporting of post-Christmas layoffs in retail trade also may have skewed the numbers, the government said. The employment report also showed a continuing slump in the manufacturing sector as factory jobs fell by 112,000 last month, with 90,000 of the losses suffered by the struggling auto industry. It was the 10th straight month manufacturing jobs declined. Nonetheless, analysts said the data, while suggesting the economy continued to slow, also indicated that the economy may be breaking out of its recent doldrums. ``The unexpectedly large increase in new jobs helped today's rally in equities,'' said Charles Jensen, chief technical analyst for MKI Securities Corp. ``It eased expectations that we are moving into a recession and was encouraging for the economy.'' The market first reacted negatively to the jobs data in response to a slide in the bond market but quickly bounced back after digesting the data. Traders said renewed merger activity also helped revive takeover stocks. In particular, drug and biotechnology stocks got a boost from news that Roche Holdings would acquire a majority stake in Genentech Corp. Despite the rally, the market retraced some of its gains late in the day as investors remained cautious ahead of next week's $30 billion Treasury refunding, which could provide a better clue about the prospects for interest rates. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 195.42 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $23.358 billion, or 0.74 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.23 to 182.75. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, Genentech, the most active stock, rose 8[ to 29~ on news that Roche Holding's would acquire a majority stake in the company. Philip Morris rose \ to 38\, USX added ] to 34\ and AT&T advanced 1 to 39]. Chrysler, meanwhile, ended down [ at 16, Harcourt Brace declined [ to 2, Bristol Myers dropped { to 52~, while IBM ended up | at 98] and General Motors ended unchanged at 41~. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 2.80 to 381.13, and S&P's 500-stock composite index advanced 2.13 to 330.92. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market ended with a 4.45 gain at 422.21. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 353.56, up 2.06.

DOC.HEAD: Engelhard Restructuring Away From Its Well-Known Metals Business
DOC.TEXT: The restructuring of Engelhard Corp., the metals and chemical company once headed by the supposed model for James Bond nemesis Goldfinger, could mean higher profits and a clearer corporate identity, analysts said Friday. Engelhard, a leading metals refiner and maker of gold and silver products, says it is selling those businesses to concentrate on chemical production and its promise of higher profit margins. The Iselin-based concern also has announced a restructuring that will shed 500 salaried jobs from its 8,100-member workforce and shut a number of plants worldwide. Engelhard stock fell $1.12{ a share to $20.37{ on the New York Stock Exchange Friday. The restructuring announced Thursday prompted Engelhard to take a $160 million charge on 1989 earnings, giving it a $77.5 million loss for the year. Fourth quarter losses were $145.9 million compared with a $19.3 million profit a year earlier. Revenue for the year rose $52 million, to $2.4 billion. Engelhard spokesman Francis X. Vitale Jr. said the restructuring and sale of businesses should pare away 35 percent of its revenue. Thomas Van Leeuwen, an analyst for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York, said the restructuring was overdue and that the company's performance had stagnated in the past five years. Engelhard's performance has been hurt by a diversion of management attention to its electronics business and by competition from other major makers of catalysts, such as W.R. Grace and Union Carbide, Van Leeuwen said. Catalysts are used in petroleum refining and chemical manufacturing. Cyclical changes in refining also have hurt. With increased amounts of lighter grade crude oil coming on the market, smaller amounts of catalysts are needed to break the oil down into petroleum products such as gasoline, said analyst Jeff Cianci of Bear Stearns & Co. in New York. Shedding the metals business could help focus attention on the operations that actually constitute Engelhard's main business, possibly giving investors a better idea of the company's prospects. ``Investors have mistaken the true identity of this company in the past,'' said Van Leeuwen. Many do not realize it does not produce gold and silver but only makes products from them, and also that it has substantial chemical operations, he said. Engelhard does have the nation's largest gold and silver product manufacturing plant, located in Plainville, Mass. The company was founded in Newark in 1902 by Charles W. Engelhard Sr. after he bought the Charles Croselmire Co. and began acquiring specialty metals firms. His son, Charles W. Engelhard Jr., greatly expanded its operations. The wealthy Engelhard Jr., known as the ``platinum king,'' also was a friend of James Bond creator Ian Fleming, and supposedly served as an inspiration for the character of the villain Goldfinger. Engelhard was a portly figure who often carried an ebony cane, and would joke with friends about his identification with the spy story villain, according to a 1971 obituary. Goldfinger might not recognize Engelhard Corp. based on its remaining businesses. For sale are its gold and silver refining and fabrication businesses; metal joining operations; electronic chemicals section, which provides precious metals to electronic circuitry makers; crystals business, which supplies makers of radiation detectors; and part of its jewelry products business. Businesses it will keep include its platinum group, which makes components of catalytic convertors for cars; its profitable precious metal trading operation; its chemical and petroleum catalysts group; and its additives and pigment business.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices tumbled Friday after a new government report on employment in January suggested the economy is stronger than expected, diminishing chances for lower interest rates. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond lost } point, or $7.50 for every $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which rises when the price declines, jumped to 8.50 percent from 8.43 percent late Thursday. Analysts said bond prices fell after the Labor Department reported that the U.S. unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent in January as the economy began the new year by producing 275,000 new jobs. The job growth figure was about 100,000 more than expected, according to Sung Won Sohn, chief economist for Norwest Corp. in Minneapolis. He noted the government also reported that orders for manufactured goods gained 1.9 percent in December, and said that also was above most analysts' expectations. ``The economy is stronger than the market feels comforable with. That diminishes chances that interest rates would decline and raised some inflation concerns,'' he said. A strong economy tends to hurt bond prices because interest rates normally rise in such periods, eroding the value of bonds in circulation. Sohn said bonds finished above their lows of the day, however, because the dolar rose against the Japanese yen, making returns on dollar-denominated investments more attractive to the Japanese. The Japanese are usually relied on to buy a healthy amount of new Treasury securities, and strength in the dollar could help keep them interested next week as the government auctions $30 billion in new securities. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term government issues declined [ point to 7-32 point, intermediate maturities fell by between 5-16 point and 9-16 point and long-term issues dropped as much as 13-16 point, according to figures provided by Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 3.85 to 1,159.26. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds slipped 1-16 point to 91 6-16. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.46 percent from 7.45 percent late Thursday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 8.05 percent as the discount gained 4 basis points to 7.79 percent. Yields on six-month bills advanced to 8.15 percent as the discount gained 4 basis points at 7.74 percent. Yields on one-year bills jumped to 8.11 percent as the discount rose 3 basis points to 7.57 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8\ percent, unchanged from late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Work at Overburdened Douglas Aircraft May Be Moved to St. Louis
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Corp., facing the end of two military aircraft contracts by 1993, may shift some work on its new jumbo jet from its overburdened Long Beach plant to St. Louis, a spokesman said. The strategy, which officials said could avoid up to 12,000 layoffs in St. Louis, is under discussion but no timetable has been set, Don Hanson, a spokesman for the company's Long Beach-based Douglas Aircraft unit, said Thursday. Hanson said a shift would not lead to any layoffs at Douglas Aircraft, which is struggling with so many commercial aircraft orders that it is behind schedule on all its programs. Manufacturing components for the new MD-11 jumbo jet or other planes at McDonnell Aircraft Co. in St. Louis ``is a possibility,'' Hanson said. ``They already build the nose section for the C-17,'' the big cargo plane that Douglas assembles in Long Beach, he said. Until now, McDonnell Aircraft has manufactured planes solely for the military. William S. Ross, president of McDonnell Aircraft, said moving some of the MD-11 work to his division could help save about 12,000 jobs in St. Louis. More work on Douglas' C-17 military cargo plane also will be shifted to St. Louis, Ross said, but he declined to discuss the timing. St. Louis-based McDonnell Douglas is the nation's top defense contractor. By contrast with St. Louis, Long Beach is ``very much full to capacity,'' Hanson said. ``We have been looking for some time to find ways to put some of the work out to other sources.'' Douglas Aircraft, after increasing its payroll by about 20 percent in each of the past four years, has grown nearly as large as it can, Hanson said, although a few more employees will be added this year. Douglas now employs about 45,000 workers, including 35,000 in Long Beach and another 5,000 in nearby Torrance. McDonnell had previously announced plans to shift its T-45A Goshawk trainer program, plagued by technical problems and delays, to St. Louis from California. About 1,800 workers in St. Louis are to be reassigned to the Goshawk program. McDonnell makes the F-15E Eagle fighter for the Air Force, the AV-8B Harrier II short-takeoff-vertical landing jet for the Marines and the F-A-18 Hornet for the Navy in St. Louis. Pentagon budget proposals announced this week call for phasing out Eagle and Harrier orders after Sept. 30, 1991, although backlogs could keep the two planes in production until 1993. The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, the largest union representing McDonnell Aircraft workers, has been pushing McDonnell Douglas to shift more commercial aircraft work to St. Louis. McDonnell Aircraft has avoided a major layoff of aircraft workers since phasing out in 1979 its production of the F-4 Phantom, the Eagle fighter's predecessor.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea Records $662 Million Trade Deficit in January
DOC.TEXT: Despite a strong government drive to increase exports, South Korea recorded a trade deficit of $662 million in January, the worst since January 1985, officials said Friday. Trade and Industry Ministry officials said South Korea's economy has been sluggish this year, with its exports in January falling 10 percent from a year ago to $3.952 billion. Imports in the same month totaled $4.614 billion, up 5.2 percent from last January, they said. South Korea's total exports in 1989 amounted to $62.3 billion, up 2.6 percent from 1988, but officials said the growth rate was the lowest among other Asian competitors such as Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore and Japan. Ministry officials said the government would continue its export-drive policy this year along with anti-inflation and other measures to control steep wage and price hikes. In January, consumer prices rose by a sharp 1 percent from the previous month and wholesale prices rose by 0.5 percent, compared with a 1.1 percent increase in all of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: MGM-UA Can Continue Lawsuit Against Disney, Appeals Court Rules
DOC.TEXT: An appellate court has ruled MGM-UA Communications Co. may sue Walt Disney Co. for breach of contract because Disney built a working studio as part of a Florida theme park that uses the MGM name. The ruling by the state's 2nd District Court of Appeals earlier this week reverses a decision by the Superior Court, attorney Skip Miller, representing MGM-UA, said Thursday. ``There are triable issues of fact regarding Disney's intent to deceive,'' the appellate court stated. The action, originally filed in the lower court May 17, 1988, concerns the Disney-MGM Studios theme park near Disney World in Lake Buena Vista, Fla. In June 1985, the entertainment giants agreed that Disney would build the studio tour located on 135 acres. The park includes a 1950s sitcom set, movie-TV sound studios with backstage tours and other special effects adventures. The park opened in April 1989 and offered tourists a behind-the-scenes glimpse of Hollywood. Movie and TV production began in summer 1988 with the ``Superboy'' syndicated TV series and parts of several large-screen films, while construction continued on the tourist attraction portion. MGM-UA contends that Disney broke its license agreement by using the MGM name ``on a full-scale, operating motion picture production facility, rather than in connection with a public amusement park built around the theme of motion pictures.'' Disney argued it could not run a studio tour without a production studio. But the appellate court ruled that ``neither logic, experience or evidence compel the conclusion a studio tour must be built around an actual, working studio.'' Burbank-based Disney said in a statement it would fight the complaint. ``The prior judgment was upheld on all issues but one, which is essentially whether we have the right to use the MGM name on our working Florida studio,'' the statement read. ``While we would have preferred, of course, to have the judgment upheld on all counts, we are prepared to go to trial on the remaining issue,'' it concluded. Miller said the ruling cuts deeper. ``It terminates the license agreement and allows us to recover the MGM name so that Disney is precluded from using it in Florida or anywhere else in the world,'' Miller said. Miller added that Disney has used the name for at least two years and owes MGM-UA compensation for use of the MGM name. He said MGM-UA is seeking ``substantial'' compensatory and punitive damages, but he did not specify an amount. A trial date for the case is expected to be set within six to nine months, Miller said.

The nation's unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent for an eighth straight month in January but the economy still produced 275,000 new jobs, the government said. The Labor Department also said Friday that factory jobs dropped 112,000 last month, with 90,000 of the losses suffered by the struggling auto industry. But many laid off auto workers have been recalled since last month. Large gains were posted in construction and service industries. The jobless rate in Michigan jumped to 8.4 percent in January, up from 7.2 percent in December. That was the largest unemployment increase in the 11 large industrial states surveyed by the government.

Orders to factories for manufactured goods slowed to a 6.4 percent increase during 1989, the government said. The Commerce Department said Friday that orders for both durable and non-durable manufactured goods gained 1.9 percent to a seasonally adjusted $244.2 billion in December after rising 2.4 percent in November. Analysts said the manufacturing sector apparently hit a trough in the fourth quarter and should rebound slowly this year.

Federal regulators seized Florida's largest thrift association, CenTrust Bank, charging it with lavish spending on museum-quality art, a company yacht and high salaries. The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision on Friday declared the Miami-based S&L operating in an unsafe and unsound condition and turned it over to the Resolution Trust Corp. for sale or liquidation. With $8.2 billion in assets, CenTrust is Florida's largest and the nation's 23rd-largest savings institution.

Roche Holding Ltd. of Switzerland will become the majority shareholder of Genentech Inc., the world's leading biotechnology company, in a $2.1 billion deal. Under the agreement announced Friday, Roche will invest $492 million in Genentech, buying half its 82 million shares of outstanding stock for $36 a share _ 65 percent above Thursday's closing stock price.

The acting chairman of Bank of New England, which is trying to rebound from the $1 billion loss projected for 1989, said the bank probably wouldn't turn a profit this year but should come out ahead in the long run. Interim Chairman H. Ridgely Bullock, named by the board of directors last week, also said Friday that the bank continues experiencing deposit outflows sparked by the recent disclosure of the extent of its financial problems. He said it would have to keep borrowing from the federal government to meet the demands of depositors.

McGraw-Hill Inc. has pulled the plug on its electronic business news services, saying the market for them was developing more slowly than expected. The unexpected decision to close its McGraw-Hill News and Standard & Poor's News services at the close of business Friday came only a day after the company reported a fourth-quarter loss of $98.3 million, due mainly to the impact of a corporate restructuring.

President Bush, citing ``credible confidential information,'' has ordered a Chinese-owned corporation to sell its interests in a Seattle aircraft parts company. Bush on Friday ordered the divestiture, on national security grounds, of Mamco Manufacturing Co. of Seattle by the China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corp. In ordering the action, Bush invoked for the first time a provision of a 1988 trade law that gives the president the power to restrict foreign investment in the United States if the nation's security is affected.

General Electric Co. and two employees were convicted on several charges of bilking the government of $10 million for a battlefield computer system. A U.S. District Court jury returned the verdict Friday against GE, James Badolato and Gerald A. Leo, both former employees of Management and Technical Services Co., a GE subsidiary. GE, the nation's second-biggest defense contractor, could face a fine of $71.9 million.

Retailing executive Allen I. Questrom has been appointed chairman and chief executive officer of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. to lead them through bankruptcy court-supervised reorganizations. The appointment Friday was announced as committees of unsecured creditors for Federated and Allied met for the first time in Cincinnati, headquarters of the two companies owned by Toronto-based Campeau Corp. Federated and Allied filed Jan. 15 for protection from their creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, listing $7.7 billion in debts.

The stock market rallied Friday after a government report on January employment boosted investor confidence about the economy. The Dow Jones industrial average ended 16.44 points higher at 2,602.70. The dollar finished mostly higher. Bond prices fell sharply. Expectations of strong gasoline demand early this summer fueled a strong rally in oil futures prices; copper and precious metal futures rose; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Billionaire Again Raises Lockheed Stake
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds two grafs on NL earnings
DOC.TEXT: Texas billionaire Harold C. Simmons said Friday he may seek control of Lockheed Corp.'s board of directors after the defense contractor rebuffed his request for representation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, an investment group headed by Simmons-controlled NL Industries Inc. disclosed it had raised its stake in Lockheed to 18.9 percent. Ron Meder, a spokesman for Calabasas, Calif.-based Lockheed, said the defense contractor had not yet seen a copy of NL's filing and could not comment until it had. In the SEC filing, the investment group said Simmons met with Lockheed Chairman Daniel M. Tellep on Wednesday. ``Mr. Simmons requested that NL be allowed to obtain significant minority representation'' on Lockheed's board and that Lockheed's preferred share purchase rights takeover defense be redeemed, according to the document filed in Washington. Tellep rejected both requests, the document stated, adding, ``Mr. Simmons said he would have to consider a range of options including seeking board representation. Mr. Tellep said he had no concerns about a proxy contest.'' A proxy contest is an attempt by a person or group to take over a company or jettison its management by obtaining enough proxies _ the legal authority to exercise a shareholder's vote _ to influence a corporate election. In light of the response, the filing said Simmons and NL ``intend to consider their options including, but not limited to, securing representation on, or control of, the company's board.'' Lockheed later issued a statement quoting Tellep as confirming the meeting with Simmons and adding that the investor had offered no plans or proposals for the company beyond his requests. ``In our meeting, Mr. Simmons provided no basis whatsoever for us to determine his intentions with respect to the company or whether his interests would be consistent with those of Lockheed and its other shareholders,'' Tellep stated. According to the filing, the Simmons-led group, already Lockheed's largest stockholder, bought 629,000 shares between Jan. 16 and Jan. 23 at prices ranging from $39.38 and $39.75 per share. In recent months he steadily has increased his holdings in Lockheed, developer of the stealth jet fighter plane, from 6.25 percent to 16.9 percent in December. After Simmons' initial purchase of Lockheed stock was revealed in April, Lockheed created an employee stock ownership plan holding about 17 percent of the company's outstanding shares in an attempt to make a takeover more difficult. The meeting with Tellep is at least the second between the two executives. In a previous filing with the SEC, Simmons said he met with Tellep on May 15. In addition, he wrote the Lockheed executive saying, ``We view Lockheed as a well-managed company. We have no plans, or desire, to disrupt management. We expect to be a constructive, long-term shareholder.'' Earlier this week, Simmons, who has holdings in the chemical, timber and sugar industries, announced plans for a $1.1 billion tender offer for Georgia Gulf Corp. The Dallas billionaire was not available when phoned on Friday. In an interview last September, however, he said, ``The fundamentals of Lockheed are not good; they're deteriorating. I think defense budgets are going to be cut in real terms fairly consistently for several years.'' Simmons' latest move came as his NL Industries reported sharply lower fourth-quarter earnings, partly because of the interest on loans used to buy stock. Earnings in the three months ended Dec. 31 totaled $20.4 million, or 31 cents a share, vs. $47.1 million or 71 cents a share in the same 1988 period. Sales increased from $235.4 million to $239.4 million. For the year, NL's earnings totaled $172.9 million or $2.62 per share on sales of $1 billion, vs. $162.9 million or $2.45 a share, on $1.01 billion in sales.

DOC.HEAD: Once Ailing Big Thrift Posts Healthy Earnings
DOC.TEXT: American Savings Bank, once the nation's largest thrift before it faltered and was sold to Texas billionaire Robert Bass in a government-assisted deal, on Friday reported hefty earnings of $214.2 million for fiscal 1989. Assets, which were $15.4 billion when a group led by Bass bought American in December 1988, rose by a modest 6 percent to $16.3 billion at the close of December 1989. Return on assets was a strong 1.35 percent, meaning American earned $1.35 for every $100 in assets. American, whose problems began with bad real estate loans, said loan originations totaled $2.9 billion during 1989, mainly in residential mortgages. Of that amount, $2.6 billion were adjustable-rate loans, providing American some protection from any sharp increase in interest rates. ``Today American Savings is a stable, profitable financial institution that meets all of the new, more stringent capital requirements without benefit of regulatory forebearances,'' American Chairman Mario J. Antoci said in a statement Friday. The tougher standards for capital _ the cash cushion against risk _ were imposed as part of last year's legislation bailing out the insurance fund for the thrift industry. American was part of Financial Corp. of America when it ran into huge losses on real estate and a run on deposits in the mid-1980s under Charles W. Knapp, who was later replaced by regulators. A group led by Bass acquired the ailing thrift from regulators in December 1988 in a $1.7 billion deal that split the troubled assets off into a separate operation, which is selling them off. The Bass group owns 70 percent of what remained of the thrift, the government 30 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish-Language TV Company Works on Financial Restucturing
DOC.TEXT: Univision Holdings Inc., which operates one of the largest Spanish-language television networks in the United States, is trying to work out a financial restructuring after missing $10 million in interest payments. The privately held company said Thursday that it had missed interest payments due that day of about $3 million to its bank lenders and $7 million to holders of its subordinated debentures. It blamed an ``insufficient cash flow'' and said efforts were underway to work out a financial restructuring. Univision has about $315 million in bank debt, $135 million in senior subordinated zero coupon debt and $105 million in 13] percent subordinated debentures outstanding. Univision Holdings is 63.5-percent owned by Hallmark Cards Inc., a privately held company based in Kansas City, Mo., and 21.5-percent owned by an affiliate of First Chicago Corp. The remainder is owned by Televisa SA, a media company based in Mexico. The company was created in two steps with Hallmark's acquisition in 1987 of Spanish International Communications Corp., which owned five Spanish-language TV stations, and its 1988 buyout of Univision Inc., which operated a Spanish-language TV network. Univision Holdings currently operates the network with 18 affiliate stations and owns eight TV stations. The network and stations reach about 92 percent of the Hispanic households in the United States. ``The basic business is not in trouble,'' said spokeswoman Mary Conway, ``but it cannot satisfy the cash requirement of the present financial structure. The current business environment is much more competitive than when this financial structure was created.''

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Sell Largest Failed S&L in Texas
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators on Friday sold the insolvent Bright Banc Savings Association of Dallas to an Ohio bank holding company in the largest thrift sale since enactment of the S&L bailout law in August. Banc One Corp. of Columbus, Ohio, is receiving $1.1 billion in government assistance to acquire Bright Banc, founded in the early 1980s by H.R. ``Bum'' Bright, once one of the 50 wealthiest men in the country and the former owner of the Dallas Cowboys football team. Banc One is paying $45 million. Bright Banc, with $3.1 billion in assets, is the biggest failed thrift in Texas and the largest yet sold by the Resolution Trust Corp. The deal is one of the first in which the RTC has persuaded the buyer to take a substantial portion of the thrift's loans and other assets. Banc One is getting $1.7 billion of the S&L's assets, including residential mortgages, consumer loans, cash and securities. The RTC is keeping $1.4 billion in assets, mostly sour loans and repossessed real estate. After it sells the assets, it estimates the government's total loss on the institution will be $1.4 billion, including the $1.1 billion paid to the Ohio company. RTC officials had promised a major sale after undergoing a tongue-lashing earlier this week from members of the Senate Banking Committee upset with the slow pace of the administration's S&L cleanup. The agency has taken over more than 350 failed thrifts, disposing of 43 of them. But, in most of the transactions it has simply transferred the failed institutions' deposits to the new owner and retained the assets for later sale. Bank One Texas, a unit of the Ohio holding company, is assuming all $2.6 billion of Bright Banc's deposits in 250,000 accounts. The thrift's 48 offices will remain open during their usual business hours. The acquisition gives Bank One Texas a formidable retail network in Texas. It would add Bright Banc's branches to the 63 it currently operates and create a combined institution with about $14 billion in assets, among the 25 largest banking operations in the nation. The RTC did not name the other bidders, but said it received a total of five, including Banc One's, one other bank, two S&Ls and one non-financial institution. Banc One first ventured into Texas in June with the purchase of 20 failed banks formerly owned by Dallas-based MCorp., getting an estimated $2 billion in federal aid. The Ohio company, ranked among the top handful of most profitable banks in the nation, has a reputation as a pioneer in retail banking. It was one of the first banks to offer automated teller machines. And it has been a leader in packaging obligations owed by credit card holders into securities for sale to investors. Bright Banc was created in the consolidation of three smaller S&Ls and invested aggressively in Texas commercial real estate. It got into trouble when property values began to decline following the 1986 collapse of oil prices. The thrift was seized by the government on Feb. 8, only two days after Bush announced his bailout plan, and was put up for bid Aug. 30. William C. Ferguson, a financial institutions consultant in Irving, Texas, said most of Bright Banc's problems were caused by loans made before the consolidation. He said Bright Banc operated much like a commercial bank, had a strong operation in credit cards and other consumer services, and predicted it would mesh well with Banc One. ``I really think it will put together the first retail powerhouse that can compete on a level playing field with NCNB. I think Banc One will be suprised at how little problem they have assimilating that organization into theirs,'' he said. NCNB Corp. of Charlotte, N.C., acquired Texas' largest bank, First RepublicBank Corp. of Dallas, in July 1988 in the largest ever federal bank rescue. ``BancOne could not make it with only MCorp. It didn't give them enough of a market share,'' said Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va. ``... My sense is this will not be the last transaction in Texas involving Banc One.''
